headline: German Phone Concern in Talks to Buy British Venture
abstract: Deutsche Telekom AG reportedly is in talks to buy One2One, British mobile phone company, from Cable and Wireless and MediaOne Group (M)

headline: SPRINT TO ACQUIRE OPERATING UNITS OF WBS AMERICA
abstract: Sprint Corp will acquire WBS America LLC for $108 million less assumed debt (S)

headline: Executive at Times Gets Expanded Role
abstract: Marc Z Kramer, vice president for labor relations at New York Times, receives additional responsibility for production; Kramer is assuming production duties from David A Thurm, who was recently appointed chief operating officer of Times Company Digital, Internet unit of paper's parent company (S)

headline: DuPONT TO COMPLETE ITS DIVESTITURE OF CONOCO
abstract: Du Pont sets terms for splitting off its 70 percent stake in Conoco Inc (S)

headline: When Indexes Get It Wrong
abstract: Frank Russell Co's recent mistake in swiching five stocks to Russell 100 Value index resulted in fleeting 40 percent boost in index's technology weighting (S)

headline: Low Fat's Lowered Expectations; Procter & Gamble Overestimates America's Olestra Craving
abstract: Sales of products using Procter & Gamble Co's fat substitute olestra are waning; Procter & Gamble chief executive Durk I Jager says olestra production last year was 30 percent to 40 percent below forecasts; plans to seek broader regulatory approval to add olestra to foods like french fries and cookies have been shelved; P&G had expected $500 million in domestic revenue and $400 million in international sales of olestra by 2000; sales may hit $1 billion target, but will probably not be liquid gold that P&G management once envisioned; graph; photo (M)

headline: HYUNDAI SECURITIES CHAIRMAN
abstract: South Korean prosecutors arrest Lee Ik Chi, chairman of Hyundai Securities Co, on charges of manipulating stock prices of Hyundai Electronics Co (S)

headline: Report Outlines Problems With Donated Drugs Sent Overseas
abstract: New study by Harvard School of Public Health concludes that suspicions of many public health officials, that many drugs donated to aid groups to be sent overseas do not meet local medical needs or are likely to expire before use, are well founded; found most drugs donated by two unidentified aid agencies between 1994 and 1997--for use in Armenia, Haiti, and Tanzania--were useful and helped those in need, but that significant amount of donations were not listed by recipient country or World Health Organization as high-priority items; found about 30 percent of drugs had year or less until expiration, and six percent had less than 100 days (M)

headline: Debate on Internet Taxes Takes Political Turn
abstract: Congress has appointed elite group of high-technology and government leaders to draft sales tax policies for Internet; most of 19 members of panel, Advisory Commission on Electronic Commerce, agree that Internet sales should be subject to same taxes levied on sales in physical world; key question is how to devise more uniform tax rate or system that makes it easy for companies to collect taxes levied by more than 30,000 state and local jurisdictions; panel's chairman, Gov James Gilmore of Virginia, says he is not convinced Internet sales should be taxed; in addition to sales tax, group is expected to study international tax issues on Internet and taxes on Internet access; photo (M)

headline: Nickelodeon Animation Studio to Open
abstract: Nickelodeon, children's cable network owned by Viacom, opens major new digital animation studio at 1633 Broadway in Manhattan; Little Bill, cartoon show based on Bill Cosby's beginning-reader books, will be made at studio (S)

headline: Reservists a Crucial Factor In Effort Against Milosevic
abstract: Yugoslav Army reservists have become a crucial factor in growing campaign to force resignation of Pres Slobodan Milosevic; in previous bouts of demonstrations against Milosevic, army has either come out in favor of of Milosevic or sat on sidelines; but sudden anti-Government activism in cities like Leskovac suggests that army could prove to be muscular ally of the opposition; map (M)

headline: Connections That Are Fast, Faster, Fastest (and Even Faster)
abstract: High-speed 'broadband' Internet access that is expected to revolutionize Web commerce is becoming available; two competing technologies, cable modem and digital subscriber line, are starting to offer Web users broadband service, which uses existing cable or phone lines but has enough data-carrying capacity to feed computer without interrupting television or phone service (M)

headline: Stanley Durwood, 78, Inventor of Multiplex
abstract: Stanley H Durwood, an entertainment industry executive who is credited with inventing multiplex movie theater, dies at 78; photo (M)

headline: KAISER PROVIDES DETAILS OF DEPARTURE FROM NORTHEAST
abstract: Kaiser Permanente announces details of its planned departure from Northeastern US; Kaiser will shut down unprofitable health plans in Massachusetts and Vermont and sell its money-losing plans in New York and Connecticut; agrees to sell its New York business to Capital District Physicians' Health Plan and its Connecticut health maintenance organization to Connecticare Inc; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Charles F. Mansfield, 77, Bank Executive
abstract: Charles F Mansfield, former bank president, dies at age 77 (S)

headline: DAEWOO CREDITORS TO TAKE EQUITY
abstract: Domestic creditors of South Korea's Daewoo Group plan to swap debt for equity in Daewoo Heavy Industries Co's profitable shipbuilding unit, in first step toward halving group's 59.9 trillion won ($49.9 billion) debt (S)

headline: S.E.C. Expected to Limit Ways Earnings Reports Are Finessed
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to issue accounting rules in near future that are aimed at limiting companies' ability to finesse their earnings results; companies have been allowed to play down or ignore adjustments to liabilities, revenues and other accounts as long as amount of problem is insignificant, or in word used by accountants 'immaterial'; under new rules, commission would consider what might have prompted companies to not make necessary adjustments to their financial books (M)

headline: Russian Blast Kills 4
abstract: In the fifth blast to hit Russia recently, a truck exploded next to a nine-story apartment building early this morning in a city in the Rostov region, killing at least four people and wounding 70.  Article, page A14.

headline: Lirong Journal; Tibetans, and Vultures, Keep Ancient Burial Rite
abstract: Tibetans have three principal ways to return their dead to earth; in sky burial, body is dismembered and fed to vultures; in water burial, corpse is cut into small pieces and fed to fish; third way, cremation, is too expensive for poorest Tibetans; photo; map (M)

headline: Rebates Rise on Some Chrysler Models
abstract: Daimler-Chrysler says Chrysler unit has increased rebates to move slow-selling small cars (S)

headline: CLEANING PRODUCTS MERGER
abstract: Reckitt & Colman PLC, British detergent company, will acquire Dutch rival Benckiser NV, for about $3.2 billion (S)

headline: Caterpillar Sees Profit Growth Slowing in '99
abstract: Shares of Caterpillar Inc fall after company warns investors that profit growth will continue to decline; reports drop in second-quarter sales, to $5.1 billion, and sharp drop in quarterly profits, to $283 million (M)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: ALLEGHENY TELEDYNE INC., Pittsburgh, named Thomas Corcoran president and chief executive, succeeding Richard P. Simmons, who will remain chairman. Mr. Corcoran was the president and chief operating officer of the space and strategic missiles division of the Lockheed Martin Corp.     AMAZON.COM INC., Seattle, named Jeffrey A. Wilke vice president and general manager of operations, succeeding Jimmy Wright, who resigned. Mr. Wilke had been vice president and general manager of the pharmaceutical fine-chemicals unit of Allied Signal Inc. Ben Slivka, from the Microsoft Corp., was named to the new position of director of information technology.

headline: Saying It In Pixels, Round 2
abstract: Peter H Lewis column appraising the new Nikon Coolpix 950 dignital camera; drawing (M)

headline: TEVA PHARMACEUTICAL TO BUY COPLEY FOR $220 MILLION
abstract: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd of Israel acquires Copley Pharmaceutical Inc for about $220 million; Hoechst AG, which holds about 52 percent of Copley's shares, agrees to tender its shares to offer (S)

headline: CURRENCY RESTRICTIONS LOOSENED
abstract: Brazil's central bank, in move to shed restrictions on foreign currency holdings, will allow companies investing in petroleum and electricity industries to open domestic accounts in dollars; move, preliminary step in easing foreign currency restrictions held over from earlier exchange rate policy, should make it easier for foreign companies to make investment plans; Government hopes increased direct foreign investment will provide relief to economy after sharp decline in short-term investment from abroad (S)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: COLLINS AIKMAN CORP., Charlotte, N.C., named Rajesh Shah chief financial officer, succeeding J. Michael Stepp, who will become executive vice president for corporate planning and development. Mr. Shah had been financial chief of the automotive parts unit of the United Technologies Corp.    INCYTE PHARMACEUTICALS, Palo Alto, Calif., named Michael D. Lack to the new post of chief operating officer. Mr. Lack had been chief executive and president of Silicon Valley Networks.

headline: AIR CANADA EARNINGS
abstract: Air Canada reports second-quarter earnings fell 19.7 percent, to $73 million (Canadian) (US$48.2 million); will take $30 million (Canadian) third-quarter charge (S)

headline: NBC Completes Acquisition Of 32% Stake in Paxson
abstract: National Broadcasting Co completes its acquisition of 32 percent stake in Paxson Communications Corp, enabling NBC to achieve long-sought goal: second national television channel for entertainment programs; deal, for $415 million in new Paxson convertible stock, includes right for NBC to acquire 49 percent in Paxson in February 2002 for another $800 million should changes in Federal regulations make it possible for NBC to expand its ownership of television stations; NBC president Robert C Wright and Paxson chairman W Lowell Paxson comment; photo (M)

headline: A Meeting of Francophones, With Insults in Plain English
abstract: Leaders from 52 countries with French-speaking populations gather in Moncton, New Brunswick, traditional capital of Acadia, and Canada's English press makes much of the fact that a good number of these leaders are among the world's worst human rights violators; Prime Min Jean Chretien addresses summit, called La Francophonie, and says it should give itself the power to purge the undemocratic; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft On-Line Alliance With Ford Expected Today
abstract: Microsoft is set to announce alliance between MSN Carpoint, its on-line car-shopping service, and Ford Motor Co under which Ford's car and dealer data bases will be much more closely integrated with Carpoint site; will shortly announce other steps intended to emphasize its new, narrower focus as a supplier of software for World Wide Web and electronic commerce services; one involves placing its popular Office productivity software on Web (M)

headline: Week's Offerings Of Treasury Bills
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.

headline: TOTAL REJECTS BID AGAIN
abstract: French oil company Total Fina SA rejects $53.5 billion hostile takeover bid from French rival Elf Aquitaine SA for second time (S)

headline: Capital Buys Auto Lots
abstract: Capital Automotive REIT to buy MMR Holdings LLC, closely held company that owns 58 auto lots worth about $206 million; terms undisclosed; Capital agrees to provide $75 million in real estate financing to Sonic Automotive Inc, operator of auto dealerships (S)

headline: U.S. Officials Acknowledge Early Notice Of Bank Case
abstract: Clinton Administration officials admit it learned of Federal investigation into allegations of Russian money laundering at Bank of New York five months earlier than previously acknowledged; say State Dept and White House's National Security Council were aware of criminal inquiry in March and that Treasury Department learned of it in April; investigation has become political issue for Administration and Vice Pres Al Gore, who has long portrayed himself as taking central role in setting policy toward Russia (S)

headline: NEWELL RUBBERMAID SHARES PLUNGE ON NEGATIVE REPORT
abstract: Stock of Newell Rubbermaid Inc plunges to 52-week low after company says its third-quarter earnings will be weaker than expected (S)

headline: Tracking Down Cell-Phone Users
abstract: Federal Communications Commission has ordered cell phone industry to come up with way to track its customers so that 911 operators can know location of anyone calling on cell phone for help; scientists at Lucent Technology's Bell Labs have come up with way to reduce cost of such tracking; at issue is whether such tracking systems will be invasion of privacy (M)

headline: Yeltsin Aide Denies Report Of Secret Cash In Swiss Bank
abstract: Pavel P Borodin, top Kremlin official, denies corruption charges made in Italian newspaper against members of Pres Boris N Yeltsin's family and inner circle; newspaper, Corriere della Sera, says that $1 million in 'pocket money' for Yeltsin entourage had been funneled in 1994 through Swiss bank account; allegations follow months of public inquiry into Borodin's relationship with Mabetex, Swiss construction company that has had several large contracts to work on Government buildings in Moscow; photo (M)

headline: UNICOM TO ACQUIRE A HEATING AND COOLING CONTRACTOR
abstract: Unicom Corp acquires Midwest Mechanical (S)

headline: Ford May Receive Incentives To Build Auto Plant in Brazil
abstract: Ford Motor Co may receive incentives package from Brazilian Government of more than $700 million to build car factory in Brazil's impoverished Northeast; proposed package has created political controversy over use of public funds to aid job creation in some regions over others; Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso is expected to issue decree providing Ford with federal financing and other incentives; in return, Ford has agreed to build compact-car plant in relatively poor state of Bahia, creating 5,000 jobs (M)

headline: Windows In Your Pocket
abstract: Recent improvements in Windows CE, lightweight version of Microsoft operating system, can be seen in Compaq Aero 2100 pocket computer, a competitor of 3Com Corp's market-leading Palm Pilot; relative merits of Aero and Palm Pilot discussed; drawing (M)

headline: Virtual Experiments That Go 'Kaboom!'
abstract: Dinosaur Adventure 3-D, teaching software for children from Knowledge Adventure, evaluated; photo (M)

headline: FRENCH COURT TO HEAR OIL DISPUTE
abstract: Paris appeals court agrees to hear Elf Aquitaine SA's objections to Total Fina SA's $50 billion proposal to combine France's two largest oil companies; court says it will hear Elf's objections to bid by Aug 23 and plans to rule by end of October; decision gives Elf's chairman Philippe Jaffre time to gain shareholder support for his own plan for Elf to buy Total; photo (S)

headline: U.S. Drops Charges of Crude Oil Dumping
abstract: US Commerce Department dismisses accusations of unfair trade practices against oil-exporting countries Mexico, Venezuela, Saudi Arabia and Iraq, heading off potential economic and political crisis for Mexico and US, its biggest trading partner; charges had come from 12 independent oil producers in Kansas, Oklahoma and Texas, asserting countries had been selling crude oil in US at prices below production costs, violation of anti-dumping laws; all four countries had denied dumping charge, but Mexico, which ships 75 percent of its oil exports to US, was most outspoken; Mexico's Energy Sec Luis Tellez comments (M)

headline: U.S. Officials Say Aid for Terrorists Came Through Two Persian Gulf Nations
abstract: Clinton Administration has quietly sent senior officials to United Arab Emirates to lobby for halt to suspected financial ties between Government-controlled bank, Dubai Islamic Bank, and Osama bin Laden, embassy bombing suspect; weighs charges by some American officials that Qatar's Foreign Minister, Sheik Hamed bin Jasim al Thani, was official who warned Khaled Shaikh Mohammad in 1996 that FBI team was on way to arrest him in connection with plot by Ramzi Ahmed Yousef to blow up American airliners; both cases highlight difficulties of managing US ties with moderate Arab states where some members of elite apparently feel need to hedge bets with critics of pro-Western policies (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: OCEAN SPRAY CRANBERRIES INC.,  Lakeville, Mass., the cooperative of cranberry and grapefruit growers, said it hired Bain & Co., Wareham, Mass., to help it consider options including a merger.    CONAGRA INC.,  Omaha, whose businesses range from flour milling to frozen foods, has acquired Choice One Foods, Los Angeles, a manufacturer of beef, pork and poultry products. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: MONSANTO CO., St. Louis, named Hendrick A. Verfaillie chief operating officer. He remains president.

headline: New York Times Business Best Sellers
abstract: Latest New York Times Business Best Sellers lists (M)

headline: Schroder Lays Fiscal Blame At the Feet Of His Foes
abstract: Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany blames his Christian Democratic opponents for driving country into debt; makes impassioned attempt to shore up his political position after crushing defeats for his party in three state elections; claims there is no alternative to proposed budget cuts of $16 billion that are meant to reshape Europe's largest economy (M)

headline: Wireless Woes
abstract: Letter from Al Teich on Aug 19 article on problems with cellular telephone service

headline: On-Line Fans Of a Stock Feeling Pain
abstract: Government advisory panel votes unanimously to advise Food and Drug Administration to reject Sunrise Technologies International Inc's new laser to treat farsightedeness; company's share value plunges 75.2 percent, and more than 27 million shares change hands; graph (M)

headline: Business Travel; A company aims to make it easier for executives to work while flying around in corporate jets.
abstract: Corporate and commercial planes could be fully linked not only to on-ground data banks but to Internet in a few years, with companies like Airshow Inc acting as information providers as well as distributors; Airshow president Dennis Ferguson comments (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of advertising account changes (S)

headline: The Best Things in Life?
abstract: Sun Microsystems president Ed Zander comments on stock market's reaction to announced acquisition that would allow company distribute word processing and similar software over Internet for free (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASIA    AFGHANISTAN: TALIBAN SEIZE KEY NORTHERN TOWN -- The Taliban militia, which already controls more than 90 percent of Afghanistan, captured Charikar, the capital of northern Parwan province, prompting thousands of people to flee their homes, witnesses said. The city was the opposition's only remaining stronghold north of the national capital, Kabul.   (AP)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Digital Clock Could Disrupt Global Positioning Devices  For unwary users of the global positioning system -- the Government satellite system that guides ships and airplanes, keeps cellular networks humming and helps surveyors lay out property lines -- next weekend could be marred by a disorienting flashback.    The system's effectiveness depends in part on a calendar that boils the passage of time down to the weeks since Jan. 6, 1980, plus seconds. Sticking to such basics allows the satellites to communicate quickly, but the system will run out of digital space for such timekeeping on Saturday. Some confused receivers will stop working, and others could generate bad data or display 1980 dates. [Page C2.]

headline: Sun Microsystems to Buy Forte in $540 Million Deal
abstract: Sun Microsystems Inc agrees to buy Forte Software Inc, which produces programming tools for developing Internet applications, for $540 million in stock (M)

headline: A U.S. Office Opens, Stirring Saigon Memories
abstract: New US consulate opens in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, on site of old American Embassy in wartime Saigon, from which US Ambassador fled 24 years ago; is dedicated by Sec of State Madeleine K Albright; modest structure is in stark contrast to multi-storied concrete block that was nerve center for Vietnam War; consulate is expected to grant 25,000 immigrant visas and 150,000 visitors' visas each year, making it one of busiest posts in world; photos (M)

headline: KOMAG TO MAKE ADDITIONAL CUTS IN U.S. WORK FORCE
abstract: Komag Inc, maker of disk drive components based in San Jose, Calif, will cut 480 jobs, or almost half of its remaining US work force, and shift manufacturing to Malaysia to cut costs; will close two plants in San Jose and cut nmber of US workers to 570 from 1,050; Komag cut 400 jobs in last quarter (S)

headline: India's Election Marathon Lumbers Into Final Week
abstract: India enters its fourth and final week of marathon national elections, massive effort to make sure every citizen--no matter how remote--gets chance to vote; election officials expect more than 350 million people to vote, 60 percent of all eligible adults; political analysts expect Hindu nationalist-led alliance to still be in power, but probabaly backed this time by more powerful collection of 12 parties and probably commanding stronger majority than it did in April before it lost confidence of Parliament by single vote; Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee seems certain to head new Government, as he did old one; photo (M)

headline: Procter & Gamble Is Buying Maker of Premium Pet Food
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co acquires Iams Corp, premium pet food maker, for $2.3 billion; deal moves Procter & Gamble into market-leading position in high end of $25 billion pet food market; P&G president-chief executive Durk I Jager and Iams chairman-owner Clay Mathile comment (M)

headline: Tokyo Journal; Still Smiling, New Geishas Pour Sake and Charm
abstract: Geishas, dying breed in Japan, are being replaced by kimono-clad hostesses called furisode-san; photo (M)

headline: Can It Pay to Surf the Web?
abstract: On-line marketing companies are resorting to number of strategies in trying to get people to pay attention to advertising; some are giving away gifts, while others are offering chances to earn electronic cash or points redeemable for products; All Advantage.com is combining payments to Web surfers with multilevel marketing, which involves paying members to sign up new recruits; however, it recently cut back the amount of surfing time it would pay for by 75 percent; such plans also alarm consumer privacy advocates; photos (M)

headline: The Visor Seeks All Niches
abstract: Peter H Lewis column assesses Visor personal digital assistant to be offered by Handspring; device, fully compatible, slightly smaller and less expensive clone of Palm Computing's Palm Pilot, will let user plug in variety of matchbook-size modules that perform specialized tasks; drawing (M)

headline: Leo Burnett is reorganizing itself on two fronts.
abstract: Leo Burnett Co is reorganizing itself and realigning its senior management; Richard B Fizdale will relinquish his duties as chief executive but remain as chairman; Roger A Haupt will assume Fizdale's duties as chief executive; Haupt will assume additional duties of president from James G Oates, who will retire at end of 1999; accompanying management realignment is formal adoption of holding company structure; Leo Group will be name of ultimate parent company, owning units like Leo Burnett Co, specializing in advertising, and Starcom, specializing in media services, and managing 49 percent stake in Bartle Bogle Hegarty; photo (M)

headline: Retaliation Lawsuits: A Treacherous Slope
abstract: Number of discrimination lawsuits has stabilized but employers lose many cases when workers claim retaliation for their complaints; retaliation claims now account for 24 percent of all charges filed with Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, up 15 percent from in 1992; employment law experts say juries are far more likely to believe charges of retaliation--thus making decisions to dismiss or discipline employees who have already filed discrimiantion charges legally treacherous, no matter what facts are; chart (M)

headline: After 5 Days of Declines, Price of 30-Year Treasury Rises
abstract: Treasury bond prices rise on Treasury's plan to cut debt sales; 30-year bond rises 25/32, to 88 16/32, to yield 6.09 percent; key rates table; graph (M)

headline: CITADEL COMMUNICATIONS IN ACCORD TO BUY CARIBOU
abstract: Citadel Communications Corp agrees to buy Caribou Communications Corp, owner of five radio stations in Oklahoma City, for $60 million; Citadel will add five Caribou stations to its portfolio of 124 stations (S)

headline: Hedge-Fund Withdrawal
abstract: Rescuers of Long-Term Capital Management LP say they are taking $800 million out of hedge fund and have recovered half of their $3.6 billion bailout; 14 banks must redeem 90 percent of their money before fund's founder, John W Meriwether, and his partners can collect cash for new fund; fund has gained 14 percent since bailout (S)

headline: Whirlpool Gives Publicis More Work
abstract: Whirlpool Corp to expand its relationship with Publicis SA, awarding the agency its Whirlpool appliance account in North America; account has been handled since 1992 by Campbell-Ewald in Warren, Mich (S)

headline: COLUMBIA ENERGY EXPANDS SHARE REPURCHASE
abstract: Columbia Energy Corp will substantially increase its share buyback offer; move comes days after rejecting hostile tender offer from Nisource Inc; Columbia Energy will add $400 million to its share repurchase program, bringing total to $420 million (S)

headline: Uncovered Short Sales Rise
abstract: Open positions of short sales increased slightly on New York Stock Exchange in last month; uncovered short sales, or sales of shares that have been borrowed and sold but not yet covered by repurchase, rose to 3.81 billion in month ended Sept 10 from 3.76 billion in August period; on American Stock Exchange, open short positions increased to 181.8 million shares from 178.6 million in previous month; charts (M)

headline: Some Internet Stock Offerings Are Quiet Except for All the Shouting
abstract: Coverage by Goldman Sachs and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette of stock offering by Network Plus Corp, telecommunications company that offers high-speed data and Internet services, is somewhat unusual during the so-called quiet period--time before and after company goes public and in which it and its underwriters are prohibited by Federal law from promoting the stock; it turns out that Network Plus had already publicly traded debt and had filed papers with SEC, meaning it was not really new company and two firms were not prohibited from commenting on the stock; restrictions on quiet periods are fuzzy and while many companies and their underwriters refrain from saying anything publicly during the time immediately preceding and following their offerings, more companies are saying more than they have in the past (M)

headline: Rumblings of an Avalanche
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column assesses recent ups and downs in Nasdaq composite index, which is being influenced by option grants awarded to executives and employees; graph (M)

headline: New Ways to Sign Off
abstract: Letter from Timothy Colman comments on July 22 article on the many ways to sign off on E-mail correspondence

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Price of natural gas rises on speculation that storms during busy hurricane season will further disrupt production; in New York, natural gas for September delivery rises 12.6 cents, to $3.064 for a million BTU's; graph; chart (S)

headline: Foreign Investors Lose a Round at Russian Ship Concern
abstract: Board of Far Eastern Shipping Co, Russia's largest shipping company, elects Russia's Deputy Transportation Min Aleksandr Lugovets as company's chairman, bowing to pressure from Yevgeny I Nazdratenko, Governor of region of Primorsky, who has expressed anger over influence of foreign investors in post-communist Russia; last month Nazdratenko was suspected of having threatened to jail British member of shipping company's board, Andrew Fox, if several demands were not met, among them election of Lugovets to chairmanship; Nazdratenko has denied charges (M)

headline: Clorox Consolidates Global Account
abstract: Clorox Co consolidates its worldwide account, with total billings estimated at $250 million, at units of DDB Worldwide in New York (S)

headline: LIBRARY/JOB-HUNTING SOFTWARE; Resumes That Meet Digital Demands
abstract: Review of Ten Speed Press's resume-writing software guide, Ready-To-Go Resumes; photo (M)

headline: Intel Reduces Prices on Pentium III Chips
abstract: Intel Corp cuts prices on its flagship Pentium III chips as much as 41 percent to spur holiday-season demand and take sales from rival, Advanced Micro Devices Inc; cuts price of 550-megahertz version of Pentium III for desktop personal computers by 26 percent, to $487 from $658 million; new prices of other chips noted (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: P.& G. to Pay $2.3 Billion For Pet Food Maker Iams  Procter & Gamble is expanding its mix of top-selling brands by acquiring Iams, the maker of premium pet food, for $2.3 billion.    The deal, P.& G.'s largest acquisition in dollar terms, moves the consumer products maker into a market-leading position in the high end of the $25 billion pet food market. And it is a first step in the company's strategy to speed growth by diversifying beyond its traditional categories. Shares of P.& G. rose 50 cents, to $93.25. [Page C2.]

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Will Mp3.com soar to No. 1 with a bullet, or languish in the Wall St. cut-out bins?
abstract: THE bands cracking the Top 10 music chart this week are Red Delicious and the Streaming Geeks. No, the hit list is not the  Billboard Top 40, but one from  Mp3.com, an unconventional force in the music industry that is scheduled to make an initial public offering of stock this week.    Mp3.com, a Web site named for a technology used to compress music, offers a library of 100,000 songs from 18,000 musicians, virtually all small-time and unsigned by record labels. Visitors to the site can listen to the music in real time or download the songs free to be played later on a computer or portable digital device, which is expected to be a hot item this holiday season.

headline: RELIASTAR IS ACQUIRING PILGRIM CAPITAL FOR $258 MILLION
abstract: Reliastar Financial Corp will acquire Pilgrim Capital Corp for $258 million in stock and cash (S)

headline: PROGRESS ON BANK DEAL
abstract: Shareholders of Banca Intesa SpA approve management's move to acquire Banca Commerciale Italiana and create largest bank in Italy (S)

headline: Working for the Fun of It
abstract: Survey by Neuberger Berman investment firm finds, surprisingly, that 54 percent of respondents making less than $125,000 a year would quit their jobs if they received windfall inheritance but 28 percent of those making $250,000 or more would not do so (S)

headline: The National Football League's latest campaign stacks its legends against today's stars.
abstract: National Football League, in effort to rally fans, is bringing together its past and present as 80th professional football season gets under way; veterans and rookies are focus of league's multimillion-dollar advertising barrage for 1999-2000 season; campaign carries theme 'Feel the Power' for fourth year; NFL Properties, league's in-house marketing unit, is responsible for campaign along with NFL Films (Advertising column) (M)

headline: Kraft Foods Shifts Three Accounts
abstract: Kraft Foods, owned by Philip Morris Companies, reassigns accounts among three roster advertising agencies with total billings estimated at $23.4 million; specific account changes noted (S)

headline: ROLLS-ROYCE TO BUY COOPER CAMERON STAKE IN VENTURE
abstract: Rolls-Royce PLC agrees to buy Cooper Cameron Corp's stake in their gas-processing and transmission-equipment joint venture for $180 million in cash (S)

headline: Clinton and South Korean Leader Warn the North Against Testing Missile
abstract: Pres Clinton and Pres Kim Dae Jung of South Korea use their meeeting in Washington to show solidarity against North Korea and to warn it against testing another long-range missile in coming weeks; Kim says he hopes his country's close cooperation with US will send clear message to North Korea; senior Clinton Administration official refuses to discuss South Korea's own expanding missile program, which has become subject of increasing tension between Washington and Seoul; photo (M)

headline: CHARTER TO ACQUIRE BRESNAN FOR $3.1 BILLION
abstract: Charter Communications Inc, cable TV company owned by billionaire Paul Allen, will buy Bresnan Communications Co, partly owned by AT&T Corp, for about $3.1 billion in cash and stock (S)

headline: U.S. Seeks Details on Russia's Use of Aid
abstract: Clinton Administration officials say United States wants assurances that international financial aid to Russia has not been lost to corruption or moved surreptitiously out of nation; stop short of calling for halt in future International Monetary Fund loans; respond to reported money laundering through Bank of New York (M)

headline: What Web Retailers Really Need Is a Whole Lot of Shelf Space
abstract: E-commerce spurs changes in warehouse industry to meet growing demand for speedy delivery of small individual packages and pushes on-line companies to master back end of their businesses; huge high-tech warehouses like those scattered around Reno, Nev, area hold key to order fulfillment battles that will decide fate of Internet retailers; photo (M)

headline: Car Guys Who Really Like Cars
abstract: Ford Motor Co chief executive Jacques A Nasser drives 1939 Aston Martin at Laguna Seca race track near Monterey, Calif, during meetings among Detroit auto executives; photo (S)

headline: Beanie Baby Scams And Identity Thefts
abstract: Rise of E-commerce has seen accompanying rise in frauds; experts say shoppers must learn to recognize and avoid risks of on-line shopping; recommend consumers pay with credit cards, allowing them to dispute fraudulent charges before paying bill; cite on-line auctions as riskiest forums; table of tips to protect against fraud; drawing (M)

headline: Two Firms Plan to Offer Late Trading
abstract: Discover Brokerage, on-line unit of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co, and Dreyfus Brokerage Services, division of Mellon Bank, plan to begin allowing small investors to trade in some of most active Nasdaq and New York Stock Exchange issues on Aug 25 from 6 PM to 8 PM (M)

headline: GERMAN CABLE BIDDING
abstract: Deutsche Bank AG wants to buy cable television systems in each of Germany's nine franchise regions, with view toward assembling nationwide system that it could resell in future (S)

headline: Bonn Journal; Ex-World Capital Has Its Eye on a Virtual Future
abstract: Profile of scene in Bonn, Germany, ex-capital that was once famous as drowsiest of capitals; Deutsche Telekom, now privatized German telecommunications company, is in vanguard of unlikely plan to transform Bonn's culture from bureaucratic stodginess to Silicon-Valley sprightliness; photos; map (M)

headline: HONG KONG STOCKS SURGE
abstract: Hong Kong stocks post their biggest gains in three months on signs lower interest rates will continue to revive demand for loans and apartments; Hang Seng index rises 652.44, or 4.8 percent, to 14,184.58, highest close since Oct 9, 1997; graph (S)

headline: More Deals Seen
abstract: Top entertainment industry executives and talent agents say the merger accelerates the pressure and momentum for further deals in the industry. [Page 15.]

headline: Trader Who Broke Barings Is Back in Britain From Asian Jail
abstract: Nicholas W Leeson, arriving in Britain after four years in a Singapore jail, says he is sorry for the wild securities trading he engaged in that brought down Barings Bank; Barings liquidators allow him access to $7,900 a month of his money; Barings' creditors want to know about his financial gains from 1996 memoir (M)

headline: New Trade Chief Urges Entry of China
abstract: Mike Moore, new head of World Trade Organization, urges China be allowed to join organization, news conference, Lake Geneva (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Orange juice rises 20 percent after private forecaster says next Florida crop will be smaller than expected; in New York, orange juice for September delivery rises 17.2 cents, to $1.0275 a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Art directors are taking a greater role in defining and executing a brand's look and image.
abstract: Art directors are taking greater role in defining and executing brand's look and image, from logo design to the package to advertising; strong art and design is taking front seat as companies try to cut through growing enemy of advertising: media clutter (M)

headline: BRAZIL UTILITY FIGHT
abstract: Court in Minas Gerais, Brazilian state governed by a former President, Itamar Franco, curtails management powers of AES Corp, Southern Co and Grupo Opportunity over Companhia Energetica de Minas Gerais, state electric utility; ruling nullifies shareholders' agreement that had given American and Brazilian companies management control of utility after they paid $1 billion for one-third of its voting shares in 1997 (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Greenspan Says Stocks Influence Inflation Talks  Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said that the booming stock market now played an increasingly significant role in the Fed's discussions of inflation. But he stopped well short of calling the market overvalued.    ''We no longer have the luxury to look primarily to the flow of goods and services,'' when making decisions about interest rates, he said. The traditional view was that the economy drove the market. Now the opposite is more and more the case. [Page A1.]

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas rises as higher prices for competing fuel make natural gas a bargain; in New York, natural gas for October delivery gains 23.9 cents, to $2.851 for a million BTU's; graph (S)

headline: Paddy Devlin, 74, of Belfast, Moderate Catholic Politician
abstract: Paddy Devlin, who was active in founding of Northern Ireland's moderate Social Democratic and Labor Party, its most popular Catholic party, dies at age 74; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    FRANCE: FARMERS PROTEST -- Farmers and environmentalists demonstrated in several cities to call for the release of Jose Bove, an activist who was imprisoned after he led the ransacking of a McDonald's restaurant in the town of Millau. His group as well as farmers elsewhere in the country have picked various hamburger outlets as targets in a low-level trade war between the United States and the European Union. Washington has imposed sanctions against a range of European products, including some French food items, in response to a European Union ban on imports of American meat from hormone-fed cattle.   Marlise Simons (NYT)

headline: In Mideast, Wariness Mixed With New Hope
abstract: news an

headline: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC DENIES TALKS OVER ISRAELI COMPANY
abstract: Boston Scientific Corp denies report in Israeli newspaper Ha'aretz that it is in talks to buy Medinol Ltd of Jerusalem (S)

headline: Shifting Gear To Computers
abstract: Sun Microsystems chief executive Scott G McNealy shows up at press conference announcing General Motors new Internet unit, e-GM; photo (S)

headline: With British Court Hearings Set, Pinochet Will Soon Know Fate
abstract: Gen Augusto Pinochet, held in Britain under house arrest for nearly year, will soon learn if he must go to Spain to face charges of crimes against humanity in connection with deaths and disappearances of more than 3,000 people dating back to 1973, year he sized power in Chile; whatever the outcome, Pinochet case has secured valuable legal precedent for human rights movement: finding that former heads of state do not enjoy immunity from prosecution for systematic atrocities; case has caused strain in relations between Spain and Chile, which intensified this month when Chile recalled its Ambassador to Madrid for second time to protest over treatment of Pinochet (M)

headline: BILL TO OVERHAUL FINANCIAL SYSTEM PASSES THE HOUSE
abstract: House of Representatives approves legislation that would deregulate nation's financial system by removing last remnants of Depression-era laws that have largely kept banks, securities firms and insurance companies from entering one another's businesses; legislation, which is endorsed by Clinton Adm, is adopted by 343-86 vote; legislation will now be forwarded to conference committee, where lawmakers will try later this summer to reconcile it with different version that Senate adopted two months ago; Pres Clinton has threatened to veto Senate version because it would take away some authority of Treasury Dept to regulate banks; White House also opposes Senate measure because it dilutes current law that requires banks to lend money to minorities, inner-city neighborhoods, rural areas and others who have historically been denied access to credit; many experts say that legislation would set off new wave of financial services mergers and allow banks, insurers and brokers to expand their ranges of businesses (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Sale of Stock By Big Board Is Delayed Until 2000
abstract: New York Stock Exchange, bowing to regulatory concerns from SEC, delays until next year its plans to convert to public ownership; exchange chairman Richard Grasso says exchange will also consider making its self-policing unit a separate entity; says 'very significant public policy' questions remain about structure of regulatory unit as well as tax issues (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Clinton Is Ready to Scrap Some North Korea Sanctions
abstract: Pres Clinton, in move to reward North Korea for tentatively agreeing to stop testing its new long-range missile, prepares to lift some trade sanctions that have barred commerce between both countries for close to 50 years; gesture revives question raised by Congressional critics of Administration's negotiations with North, of whether President is rewarding hard-line Communist Government for defusing crisis it created (M)

headline: Praising the Virtual Campus
abstract: Howard Weinberg letter comments on advantages of on-line college courses (Sept 2 article)

headline: Web Sites for Class Reunions Strengthen Old School Ties
abstract: Many schools and colleges have Web sites, including alumni page or basic information on upcoming reunions; alumni of several schools even hold so-called E-reunions, at which far-flung alumni can 'make it' to the reunion, if only on line; photos (M)

headline: House to Debate Financial Overhaul Law Today
abstract: House of Representatives to debate bill that would overhaul nation's financial system; if House approves legislation, it would be first time in more than 20 years that both houses of Congress, in same term, voted to repeal Glass-Steagall Act of 1932 and nearly six decades worth of other legislation rooted in experiences of the Depression (M)

headline: Act I in an Opus of Hollywood Deals
abstract: Entertainment industry executives and talent agents see Viacom's purchase of CBS accelerating pressure and momentum for further deals; David Geffen (Dreamworks) and Howard Stringer (Sony) comment; possible television takeover targets noted; photos (M)

headline: Mexico's Ex-Drug Chief, Indicted, Is Found Dead in U.S.
abstract: Mario Ruiz Massieu, most prominent former Mexican official ever indicted on drug charges in United States, dies in New Jersey, apparently a suicide; prosecution of Ruiz Massieu had been landmark in efforts by US and Mexico to fight official corruption that has helped drug trade grow into what Mexican officials call most serious threat to their national security; law-enforcement officials say his death shuts door on case that took years to build, and one in which they hoped he might yet agree to disclose complicity of even more senior Mexican officials with traffickers; Ruiz Massieu was to appear in Federal court in Houston on drug and money laundering charges filed against him last month; he reportedly feared he would be unable to make bail and would be sent immediately to jail; photo (M)

headline: Euro RSCG Makes German Acquisition
abstract: Euro RSCG Worldwide acquires majority interest in Kremer Foerster Hintze, marketing firm in Dusseldorf, Germany (S)

headline: OCEAN ENERGY IS SELLING NATURAL GAS FIELDS
abstract: Cross Timbers Oil Co and Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc to buy natural gas fields in Arkansas and Oklahoma for $235.3 million from Ocean Energy Inc (S)

headline: Creator of Tetris Looks for New Ways to Dazzle and Beguile
abstract: Interview with Alexy Pajitnov, creator of hugely successful computer game Tetris; photos (M)

headline: Goldman Names Bond Executive
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group hires Bear Stearns Companies senior executive David M Solomon and names him co-head of its high-yield and leveraged-finance businesses (S)

headline: Bank Plans to Split Stock
abstract: Merchants New York Bancorp will split its shares two for one and increase its dividend by 25 percent (S)

headline: Appointment by Times Co.
abstract: New York Times Co announces that Lynn O Matthews, publisher of Sarasota Herald-Tribune in Florida, will become president and chief operating officer of company's regional newspaper group; Matthews will assume post upon retirement of James C Weeks, scheduled for end of year (S)

headline: $21 Million Award in Sex-Harassment Case
abstract: A jury awarded $21 million today to a woman who said she had been sexually harassed at a DaimlerChrysler factory here that builds the Jeep Grand Cherokee.    The company promised to appeal the verdict, which involved only one plaintiff, Linda Gilbert. She contended that obscene cartoons and Polaroid photos had been shown to her over the years and that someone had urinated on her chair.

headline: A Sport Called Extreme, With Reason
abstract: Article on canyoning notes that it has emerged as trendy 'extreme' sport in Europe and US, ranking somewhere between bungee jumping and whitewater rafting in its thrills and spills; it remains particularly popular in Switzerland, Austria and France as income-producing counterpart to traditional winter sports; diagram (M)

headline: POLYVISION, EDUCATIONAL CONCERN, TO EXPAND
abstract: Polyvision Corp purchases A Lawer Corp for $30 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: SEOUL TO TIGHTEN CREDIT WATCH
abstract: South Korea's Financial Supervisory Commission chairman Lee Hun-jai says conglomerates in South Korea with debt-to-equity ratios exceeding 200 percent will face credit limits from banks, with loans newly classified as substandard and deferred for just one month; adds creditor banks must set aside up to 30 percent of risky loan amount as loss reserves under new regulations and will be barred from extending new loans to unreliable borrower (S)

headline: ALLIED CARPETS TAKEOVER BATTLE
abstract: French carpet retailer Saint-Maclou touches off takeover battle with Wassall PLC for control of Allied Carpets Group PLC of Britain with bid of $122 million; graph (S)

headline: HIGHER RATING FOR MEXICO
abstract: Moody's Investor Service for first time in nine years upgrades Mexico's credit standing, bringing it to one notch below investment grade (S)

headline: Setting Her Own Precedents; Hewlett's Chief Prefers the Path Less Traveled
abstract: Profile of Carleton S Fiorina, who has been named chief executive of Hewlett-Packard Co; she comments on her corporate strategy; photo (M)

headline: Russians Say Bank Scheme May Not Be What It Seems
abstract: Some of Russia's leading businessmen, irritated by allegations of money laundering, say that West has overlooked simpler explanation for billions of dollars that have flowed through several suspicious accounts at Bank of New York; say that many of thousands of transactions under investigation can be attributed to Russian importers engaged in old games of dodging Russian tariffs and taxes (M)

headline: McDonald's Heads to Court Over a Burger King Meal
abstract: McDonald's Corp is suing archrival Burger King, saying its Big Kid's Meal food-and-toy combination is essentially a knock-off of a MacDonald's product (M)

headline: AFC CABLE SYSTEMS ACCEPTS ALL-STOCK OFFER
abstract: AFC Cable Systems Inc, which canceled agreement to be bought by Thomas & Betts Corp, says it has accepted $45-a-share all-stock offer from unidentified party; transaction is valued at $576 million (S)

headline: Survey of Japanese Business Shows Pessimism Abating
abstract: Bank of Japan survey finds perception of business conditions among executives is still negative, but improving; pessimistic executives still widely outnumber optimists; analysts say economy has stabilized after hitting bottom at end of year (M)

headline: Media Talk; Toni Morrison's New Book Puzzles Adults
abstract: Toni Morrison's first children's book, The Big Box, set for publication in Sept, explores plight of children trapped in environment where things are more important than love; focus-group research conducted by book's publisher, Hyperion, finds some young readers embrace message, while adults initially find it 'weird' and 'depressing;' photo (M)

headline: Sri Lanka Peacemaker's High-Risk Life, and Death
abstract: Article profiles Neelan Tiruchelvam, member of Sri Lanka's Parliament who like other leaders of moderate ethnic Tamil political party was assassinated by guerrillas fighting for separate homeland for Sri Lanka's Hindu Tamil minority; his decision to remain in Sri Lanka despite death threats, and despite pleas from family members and close associates, discussed; his death at hands of suicide bomber underscores effectiveness of terror tactics used by separatist rebels in silencing fellow Tamils who favor political compromise over armed struggle; photo; map (M)

headline: AUTONATION CHIEF EXECUTIVE AGREES TO STEP DOWN
abstract: Autonation Inc says Steven Berrard, who helped H Wayne Huizenga build company into world's largest auto retailer, will step down as chief executive, but will retain seat on board and continue as co-chief executive with Huizenga until new chief executive is named (S)

headline: THOMSON STAKE MAY BE SOLD
abstract: France is preparing to cut sharply its stake in Thomson-CSF, Europe's biggest military electronics maker, labor union officials said, in a bid to help its prospects for partnerships in Europe. The state will cut its stake to less than 20 percent from 44 percent, according to the union CFDT, partly through the sale of 10 percent of Thomson to Alcatel S.A., Europe's largest telecommunications equipment maker, and 10 percent to the public. The union, which holds two Thomson-CSF board seats, did not say what would happen with the other 4 percent.

headline: Rockport Leaving Kirshenbaum Bond
abstract: Rockport Co ends relationship with Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners after three years (S)

headline: That U.P.S. Mystique
abstract: United Parcel Service driver Mike McMahon comments on impact on workers if company makes initial public offering; photo (S)

headline: Microsoft's Accounting Under Scrutiny
abstract: Microsoft Corp announces that Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating company's accounting practices involving stating of financial reserves; industry experts say SEC probe could be part of its effort to restrain 'cookie jar' accounting, which can smooth over differences between strong and weak quarters; Microsoft has consistently denied any such intent and insists that it has adhered to 'conservative' accounting practices; Greg Maffei, company's senior vice president and chief financial officer, says Microsoft believes SEC began its probe in January in response to wrongful discharge suit filed by Charles Pancerzewski, former internal auditor at Microsoft (M)

headline: Argentine Stocks Fall Again, and Other Latin Markets Follow
abstract: Argentine stock market has its worst session in seven months, falling 8.7 percent on fears that Government deficit is widening and year-old recession is deepening; Brazil's market falls nearly 3 percent and Mexico's market loses 1.5 percent (M)

headline: Media Talk; New Magazine to Challenge Los Angeles
abstract: Channel Los Angeles magazine will be mailed to high-income households in Los Angeles and given away at trendy boutiques, beginning in October; it is hoped that magazine can draw paying subscribers and compete alongside Los Angeles magazine; photo (M)

headline: I.B.M. to Introduce New Server for Unix
abstract: IBM plans to introduce new server, RS/6000 S80, which it says will offer highest performance of any computer running Unix operating system; company will also introduce new so-called thin-client desktop terminal called B50, powered by Power PC chip that IBM developed with Motorola and Apple Computer (S)

headline: MONEY STORE DEAL
abstract: British finance company Cabot Square Capital acquires Money Store UK, unit of First Union Corp; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Internet Issue Up 525% in Debut
abstract: Shares of Foundry Networks Inc, three-year-old designer of devices to manage Internet traffic, rise more than sixfold in their first day of trading; shares close at $156.25, up $131.25 from offering price of $25 (S)

headline: Rome Journal; 'God's Parking Lot' Runs Into Ancient Grandeur
abstract: Work on ramp to Vatican parking garage has been halted while archeologists uncover walls of villa dating from first century AD; conservationists want ramp closed down and ruins resurrected; photo (M)

headline: Sierra Leone Measures Terror in Severed Limbs
abstract: Terror of cruel war in Sierra Leone is measured in number of amputees surviving in makeshift camp in Freetown, their limbs cut off by savage rebels; photo; map; many regard peace agreement signed by Government as surrender to rebels who use money from diamond mines to purchase seemingly endless supply of arms; accord is supported nevertheless by population weary of war (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SUBMICRON SYSTEMS CORP.,  Allentown, Pa., a maker of semiconductor production equipment, filed for bankruptcy protection and agreed to be acquired by a management-led group to be called Akrion L.L.C. for $55.5 million.    VISION 21 INC.,  Largo, Fla., a provider of laser vision correction and eye care services, sold its retail optical chains to Eye Care Centers of America Inc., a unit of Thomas H. Lee, Boston, for $37.3 million in cash.

headline: Counting Coinages In Jargon
abstract: Latest update of Univesity of South Carolina Prof W Davis Folsom's business jargon dictionary shows that he has had to add 500 terms in past two years; Folsom says jargon appears to be becoming more prevalant and more confusing (M)

headline: Russian Says He Has Proof Bribes Were Paid to Kremlin
abstract: Georgi Chuglazov, Russian investigator, says he has proof to back up published accounts of bribes to Kremlin officials by Swiss construction company Mabetek; company is at center of inquiry into kickbacks allegedly received by top Govt officials (S)

headline: Vancouver Is Astir Over Chinese Abuse of Immigration Law
abstract: Growing number of people in Vancouver, British Columbia, are growing concerned that Canada's liberal immigration policies are being abused; two ships that left 254 illegal Chinese immigrants on Vancouver beaches this summer causes furor, and exposes latent fear among Canadians taht, because of their famous generosity and courteousness, they are bcoming nation of doormats; ethnic Chinese people account for 20 percent of greater Vancouver's population, and Asians account for half of this fall's freshman class at University of British Columbia; Reform Party this fall plans to introduce legislation to tighten Canada's immigration laws; photo; map (M)

headline: Dust That May Have Eyes and Ears
abstract: Dozens of tiny machines are being made possible by technology known as MEMS, short for microelectromechanical systems; MEMS are miniature machines, some smaller than human red blood cell, that are built in same way as integrated circuits; several commercial applications of MEMS have made leap from laboratory to prototype stage and into production; many more are expected in next decade; photo (M)

headline: DEFAULT DEJA VU
abstract: Alagoas, small state in northeastern Brazil, declares moratorium on $2.9 million debt to Federal Govt (S)

headline: WEATHERFORD IS IN $64 MILLION DEAL FOR WILLIAMS TOOL
abstract: Weatherford International acquires Williams Tool Co for $64 million in stock (S)

headline: On-Line Piracy Turns From Music to Movies
abstract: Arrival of faster Internet connections could increase traffic in illegal film copies; until now, pirated copies of films have been harder to make than pirated music files; because of their large size, they are harder to download from Internet; MPEG, digital file format for compressing and playing video and audio, makes it possible to swap video files, including illegally copied versions of current films; digitized files can then be played on computer with MPEG-player software like Quicktime or Windows Media Player and 'burned' on recordable disk called VCD, which can be played on DVD player; diagrams; photo (M)

headline: 2 Found Guilty Of Hospital Fraud Charges
abstract: Federal jury in Tampa, Fla, finds Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp executives Jay Jarrell and Robert Whiteside guilty of defrauding Federal health care programs through submissions of bogus expense claims to Government in first jury verdicts stemming from investigation of potential wrongdoing at company; third executive, Michael Neeb, is acquitted, while jury is unable to reach verdict for fourth defendant, Carl Lynn Dick; four executives were charged with conspiring for more than decade to overstate expenses at Fawcett Memorial Hospital in Port Charlotte, Fla; indictment states hospital defrauded Medicare and other Federal programs of more than $1.7 million (M)

headline: For Gandhi (d.1948), a Long Due Apology
abstract: Natal Law Society of South Africa, one hundred and five years after it tried to keep Mohandas K Gandhi from practicing law because he was 'not of European descent,' unconditionally apologizes for its actions; Gandhi, who had moved to South Africa to represent Indian-based trading company, was first nonwhite to apply for credentials from society; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: I.B.M. Plans to Introduce New Data-Storage System  I.B.M. is making a bid to regain its leadership position in the high-performance end of the data-storage business with the introduction today of a new generation of big disk systems.    The new product line, code-named Shark, arrives at a time when the demand for data storage is growing at a torrid pace because of the Internet, electronic commerce and data mining -- all of which require fast access to vast amounts of information. [Page C2.]

headline: Bartle Leaving Shop He Helped to Found
abstract: John Bartle, founding partner of London-based Bartle Bogle Hegarty, says he will leave in December to focus on other business options (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro hits its weakest level against US dollar since late July on speculation that benign American inflation will lift demadn for dollar-denominated assets; euro falls in New York to $1.0364 from $1.0544; graph; chart (S)

headline: A Pen That Can Read As Well as Write
abstract: Swedish company C Technologies offers new device, C Pen, that looks like pen but can absorb information like digital scanner, carrying information like personal digital assistant and recording handwritten words as they are written; photo (S)

headline: Malaysian Ex-Minister Alleges Poisoning : Anwar Is Hospitalized After Test for Arsenic
abstract: KUALA LUMPUR—  A judge ordered Anwar Ibrahim hospitalized Friday after lawyers for the former Malaysian deputy prime minister submitted medical tests that they said showed dangerously high levels of arsenic in his urine and alleged that he had been poisoned.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: POTASH CORP.,  Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, North America's largest fertilizer maker, will shut five U.S. plants employing 328 people to cut costs by about $20 million a year.    NORFOLK SOUTHERN CORP.,  Norfolk, Va., the fourth-largest U.S. railroad, said it would pay $11 million a year for 15 years for exclusive rights to use state-owned North Carolina Railroad Co.'s 317 miles of track.

headline: 2 Reports Bolster Outlook on Rates
abstract: Government reports show retail sales accelerated in July and number of workers seeking jobless benefits last week fell to near a decade low, suggesting that more growth is likely for economy; Commerce Department reports sales rose seven-tenths of 1 percent, to $248.7 billion; reverses decline of two-tenths of 1 percent in June; Labor Department says four-week average of number of workers filing state unemployment claims declined to 288,250 last week; figure is down from 295,000 a week earlier and lowest level since week of Feb 4, 1989 (S)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for JEFFREY LEMIEUX; Clinton's Medicare Plan: A Solid Step One
abstract: fivey

headline: OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM PLANS SEPARATE CHEMICAL UNIT
abstract: Occidental Petroleum Corp forms separate unit for its specialty chemical operations, Occidental Industrial Specialty Chemicals Corp, which will have about $600 milllion in assets and 700 employees (S)

headline: When the Glitter of Stock Options Turns to Dust
abstract: Article describes risks involved when workers take advantage of initial public offerings of Internet and other young companies; options have become prime way for employers to build worker loyalty and morale; photos (M)

headline: Nebraska Students Getting a Look at the Innards of the Internet
abstract: Cables, circuits and switches that make up Internet are exposed in University of Nebraska's new engineering building, to show students how buildings are engineered in Internet age; photos (M)

headline: DROP IN CANADIAN UNEMPLOYMENT
abstract: Unemployment in Canada hits nine-year low in June, dropping half percentage point to 7.6 percent (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Graph of commodities trading over last year; table

headline: Shape of beer to come. Beverage packaging gets more emphasis.
abstract: Triarc Beverage Group, Heineken USA and Miller Brewing Co are trying some new looks for packaging of beer products; some of substances being used include aluminum, glass and clear plastic known as polyethyulene terephthalate; photo (M)

headline: Patents; New wireless systems try to do away with the tangle and restrictions of speaker cables.
abstract: Larry Schotz, William Steinike and Mark Wolski patent system for sending digital signal between parts of an audio system using air waves instead of wires (M)

headline: Fashion Magazine Industry Consolidates With a Big Deal
abstract: Walt Disney Co sells Fairchild Publications Inc to Advance Publications, parent company of Conde Nast; price undisclosed; Disney gets Advance to agree that Disney's Buena Vista Entertainment Group will retain right to publish articles and photographs from W, Women's Wear Daily and Jane on Internet; Disney and Advance agree to explore forming Internet joint venture using content of all appropriate Advance and Disney magazines; Disney retains ownership of Los Angeles magazine (M)

headline: A Time to Fight, a Time to Agree
abstract: Deborah Sontag analysis of forces that brought Israel and Palestinians to agree to revive peace effort (M)

headline: AFTER LAYOFFS, FIRST UNION WILL HIRE 2,000 TELLERS
abstract: After dismissing 5,850 employees to cut costs, the First Union Corporation will hire more than 2,000 tellers, after the sixth-largest United States bank realized its branch staff was not adequately serving customers. A First Union spokeswoman, Allison Rash, said the bank had been short by about 1,000 tellers for several months. The bank decided last week that it needed to hire another 1,000. There is a high turnover rate among tellers, she said. In March, the bank, based in Charlotte, N.C., said it was eliminating 5,850 jobs, or 7 percent of its work force, to offset higher spending on businesses including capital markets, capital management and retail delivery. Of that number, fewer than 2 percent worked in branches, Ms. Rash said.

headline: Hey There! Hi There! It's a New Michael Eisner; Disney's Leader Woos a Fretful Wall Street
abstract: Walt Disney Co chairman Michael D Eisner has suddenly begun playing Mr Nice Guy as company struggles to overcome sagging earnings; Eisner seems almost desperate to restore company's mystique--and his own image; he seems determined to assure outsiders that Disney is again poised for growth; after 13 years of growth, Disney's earnings fell last year and are expected to slip more this year; Disney's stock has slumped by about a third from its 1998 high; company's ABC network is floundering, and its huge capital-spending program has yet to pay off; Eisner continues to reign without an heir in the wings to dismay of Wall Street; Disney is attempting to revive its fortunes, investing more than $1 billion in expansion at Disneyland and building cruise ship line while selling off noncore businesses; graph; photos (M)

headline: Intel's New Processor Line To Focus on Internet Links
abstract: Intel Corp will announce new family of processors capable of powering devices that route data through corporate networks and Internet; announcement follows initial public demonstration of Intel's Merced chip, designed around new 64-bit architecture, which Intel has been developing with Hewlett-Packard Co and expects to begin shipping in volume in mid-2000 (M)

headline: People
abstract: * Gary VonKennel was named chief executive at Tracy-Locke Promotional Services Group, Dallas, part of the Diversified Agency Services unit of Omnicom Group. He succeeds Bruce Orr, who said in a statement that he was leaving to ''make a professional change.'' Mr. VonKennel had been president at Multi-Dimensional Marketing, Dallas, which is being acquired by Tracy-Locke for undisclosed terms.    * Erica Hauver was named to the new position of director at Corporate Community Investment Practice, London, a new corporate consulting division that is part of the London office of Fleishman-Hillard, owned by Omnicom Group. She had been corporate development director at Special Olympics International, Washington.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: G.M. Is Ordered to Pay $4.9 Billion in Burn Lawsuit  General Motors was ordered to pay $4.9 billion to six people severely burned when the fuel tank of their 1979 Chevrolet Malibu exploded after a rear-end collision.

headline: Tossing Religion In Your Face?
abstract: Michelle Cottle Working column answers question on whether there are laws against leaving religious literature at work site, in this case, house that was being renovated (M)

headline: GLOBAL INVESTMENT BOOM
abstract: United Nations Trade and Development agency says cross-border investments increased by almost 40 percent, to $644 billion, last year and may exceed $800 billion this year, with most of flow among industrialized countries; attributes much of investment rise to international mergers and acquisitions; says that despite Asia financial crisis, cross-border investment in Asian countries totaled $85 billion, down only 11 percent from year before (S)

headline: Why Disney Is Attached to Its Hometown Magazine
abstract: Walt Disney Co will retain Los Angeles magazine when it sells its Fairchild Publications unit to Advance Publications; executives say magazine is company's hometown glossy and is more closely aligned with Disney's core businesses than other titles; deny Disney fears new owner might run articles critical of Disney; photo (M)

headline: Yahoo Posts A 2d Quarter That Surpasses Expectations
abstract: Yahoo Inc posts results for second quarter that exceeds analysts' expectations; reports loss of $15.1 million because of $55 million in charges relating to acquisitions; lost $14.2 million in second quarter last year; revenue is $115.2 million, up 156 percent from $45 million in period last year (M)

headline: Berlitz Will Use 'Sesame Street' to Teach English
abstract: Berlitz International will join with Jim Henson Co, producers of Sesame Street, to use that program in multimedia project to teach English as second language to children around the world; 'Sesame English' will be 15-minute program produced by Children's Television Workshop and licensed exclusively by Berlitz for use in its 400 teaching centers in 50 countries, and for sale in book, audio, video and CD-ROM form; products will be marketed to schools and after-school learning centers, as well as to Berlitz customers; project will start in China, Taiwan and Japan, where demand for English instruction is high; photo (M)

headline: Vice Chairman of Chevron To Succeed Retiring Chairman
abstract: Chevron Corp says its vice chairman David J O'Reilly will become chairman and chief executive, succeeding Kenneth T Derr, who will retire; O'Reilly will take over on Jan 1; Richard H Matzke, president of Chevron Overseas Petroleum and member of board, will succeed O'Reilly as vice chairman for worldwide exploration (M)

headline: NETZERO, FREE INTERNET PROVIDER, SOARS ON FIRST DAY
abstract: Netzero Inc, which gives people free Internet access in exchange for agreeing to see on-line advertising, rises 82 percent in its first day of trading; company rises $13.125, to $29.125 (S)

headline: Runaway Banks Without Brakes: Mexico's $71 Billion Lesson
abstract: Battle over assigning blame for costly bailout of Mexico's privatized banks comes to point of closure with report commissioned by Congress in which Canadian auditor, Michael W Mackey, examines banking system performance for last two decades and record of Government rescue program since 1994; report describes system in which small business elite controls banks and many of companies seeking loans; cites lack of effective supervision of system in 1991, when Government began to sell banks; notes many purchasers lacked expertise to run banks and failed to hire competent management; produces no evidence that nay Government official broke law or was grossly negligent; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft Invests in Mortgage Data Provider
abstract: Microsoft Corp buys minority stake in Tuttle Decision Systems Inc to increase offerings on its mortgage Web site (S)

headline: Beijing Journal; If It's a Comic Book, Why Is Nobody Laughing?
abstract: Chinese Government's relentless crusade denouncing recently outlawed Falun Gong spiritual movement has expanded to include publication of comic books dripping with political venom; comics distill Govt's claims against founder Li Hongzhi as evil man in simplest form, carrying kind of political defamation mastered by Communist Party in previous campaigns in labored manner that verges on parody; some described; cartoons; photo (M)

headline: Templeton Closing Funds
abstract: funds watch: templeton clos

headline: Milosevic's Governor in Kosovo Gets NATO Protection
abstract: Zoran Andjelkovic, ally of Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic and one of organizers of suppression of Kosovo's ethnic Albanians, remains in Pristina, where he lives and works in Executive Council Building and calls self prime minister; urges other Serbs to remain, although most of his staff has left Kosovo; NATO troops guard entrance to building to stop removal of documents, but have ended up protecting him, killing two ethnic Albanian rebels in process (M)

headline: Cnet Suits Up On ABC Tonight
abstract: Next phase of $100 million marketing campaign for Cnet Inc to begin with sponsorships involving Monday Night Football on ABC (S)

headline: Wary of the Internet? Just Try to Avoid It
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column on belief by some analysts that technology stocks are overvalued; focuses on difficulty investors have in eescaping Internet issues altogether (M)

headline: Bank Admits to Lapse
abstract: The chairman of the Bank of New York told a congressional hearing that the bank failed to challenge or halt suspicious activity in nine accounts at the core of the Russian money-laundering scandal because they were opened by the husband of a well-regarded bank officer.      Article, page A8.

headline: Offerings of Equities and Debt Scheduled For Issue This Week
abstract: These equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: Possible Rift For Detroit In Labor Pact
abstract: DaimlerChrysler AG's tentative contract with United Auto Workers contains company concessions that may create problems when union demands similar concessions from General Motors Co and Ford Motor Co; DaimlerChrysler agreed to hire more employees if work force at any factory complex falls by more than 5 percent during four-year contract for any reason except downturn in auto sales; while DaimlerChrysler has relatively young work force and has been hiring more workers to keep up with demands, Ford Motor and GM have large, older work force that they have been trying to reduce through attrition; DamilerChrysler also agreed to so-called side letter that continues surprisingly categorical ban on any move to get rid of unionized businesses; side letter represents precedent for effort by some in union to stop Ford's planned spinoff of its auto parts division, which has $18 billion in annual sales (M)

headline: INDONESIAN CEMENT TROUBLE
abstract: Talks to reorganize Indonesian cement maker Semen Cibinong reportedly collapse after company discloses that up to $250 million is missing from its books (S)

headline: Trouble in the Backyard
abstract: Analysis of grass-roots dissatisfaction with Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic that is erupting across much of Serbia; analysts are particularly surprised by large, violent and unorganized protests in Leskovac, long-time Milosevic stronghold; are beginning to doubt opposition parties are capable of harnessing anger; map; photo (M)

headline: New Delhi Journal; An Octogenarian Mixes Politics, Sex and Scotch
abstract: Interview with popular Indian writer Khushwant Singh, 84, author of book The Company of Women; photo (M)

headline: Web Concession From Microsoft
abstract: Microsoft Corp, in symbolic concession that it cannot control all facets of Internet technology, agrees to license latest audio and video player from Real Networks rather than favor its own less popular competing product; Real Networks developed Real Audio and Real Video formats that Internet services use to put sound and video clips on their Web sites; Microsoft's competing technology is Windows Media Player; WebTV, which Microsoft bought for $425 million in 1997, offers service that allows people to surf Internet through their television sets; it has 800,000 subscribers (S)

headline: New Jobless Claims Increase by 4,000
abstract: Labor Department reports number of American workers filing for state unemployment benefits rose by 4,000 last week, to seasonally adjusted 279,000, while the less-volatile four-week average fell to its lowest level in four months (S)

headline: Late Selling Erases Early Advances in Equities Trading
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes down 4.12 points, to 11,135.12; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 3.10 points, to 1,388.12; Nasdaq composite index falls 4.24, to close at 2,736.78; graph; charts (M)

headline: Easy E-Mail for Travelers Without Cords, Jacks or Plugs
abstract: Two companies, Sharp and JVC, offer devices for sending and receiving e-mail from virtually any telephone, with no cords or plugs required; photo (S)

headline: Police Disrupt March to Milosevic's House
abstract: Police officers in Belgrade break up peaceful demonstration, preventing 20,000 demonstrators from marching to suburb where Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic lives; 30 people are injured; photo (M)

headline: Kosovo Damage Seems Less Than Feared
abstract: European and US officials say Kosovo appears less damaged by war than feared earlier, but refuse to predict size of final repair bill in province, or spell out how it will be divided; European nations are expected to take over biggest costs of helping Kosovo and neighboring countries (S)

headline: As Support for Intervention Grows, Indonesia Persuades U.N. to Delay Evacuation of Mission
abstract: United Nations Sec Gen Kofi Annan and Security Council back away from confrontation with Indonesia after Pres B J Habibie and Gen Wiranto beg for more time to quell East Timor violence; Annan suspends for day plan to evacuate UN mission; Security Council, meeting privately, rejects Portugal's plea for open debate; Wiranto, who replaces his commander in East Timor, reportedly has little control in area, which is controlled by officers linked to ex-Pres Suharto's son-in-law, Lt Gen Prabowo Subianto (M)

headline: Kashmir Separatists Stopped By India on Way to the U.N.
abstract: Indian immigration authorities prevent leaders of alliance of Kashmiri separatist groups from leaving New Delhi airport for New York, where they had planned to seek support for their cause at United Nations (S)

headline: Managing to Stay Afloat
abstract: Lucent Technologies chief executive Richard A McGinn raced idem, one of last twelve 100-year-old wooden boats that sail only on Upper St Regis Lake in New York's Adirondack Mountains; photo (S)

headline: AMSTED INDUSTRIES BUYING VARLEN, PARTS MAKER
abstract: Amsted Industries raises bid and will acquire Varlen Corp for $740 million in cash and assume $50 million of Varlen's debt (S)

headline: EUROPEAN LEGAL MERGER
abstract: European law firm Linklaters & Alliance will merge with Italy's Gianni Origoni & Partners in September; combined firm will be world's third biggest with 2,200 lawyers (S)

headline: Cold Facts About Child Labor
abstract: Daniel Aksk On the Contrary column explores other side of child labor controversy; holds one truth is that children in impoverished countries generally work to support their families and people devoted to rescuing them do not offer alternatives; holds poorest nations need economic development and lauds American children, who, by spending the money they earn on themselves, are transferring some wealth to children overseas who make products they buy; drawing (M)

headline: Building a Crossword: Tools and Materials
abstract: Article appraises Crossword Weaver, one of new software programs to create crossword puzzles; photo (S)

headline: XOOM.COM TO ACQUIRE LIQUIDMARKET FOR $46 MILLION
