abstract: Xoom.com Inc buys Liquidmarket Inc for about $46.8 million in stock (S)

headline: Federal Commission Predicts Increasing Threat of Terrorism
abstract: Federal advisory commission warns in report that United States faces increasing threats from terrorism in next 25 years and is likely to be compelled to intervene in other conflicts like Kosovo and East Timor even as its military shrinks; commission is headed by former Sens Gary Hart and Warren B Rudman; it makes grim predictions about crises and threats at home and abroad (M)

headline: Airbus in Lead On Plane Orders
abstract: Figures from Airbus Industrie and Boeing Co show Airbus shot ahead of rival Boeing in winning airplane orders in first half of 1999, racking up sales of 234 planes against 120 for Boeing (S)

headline: Shelling of a Serbian Village in Kosovo Kills 2
abstract: Two Serbs killed in latest mortar attack on Klokot, Kosovo, are buried; attack on predominantly Serbian village occured while it was guarded by United States Army unit; mortars landed near American command post, but no Americans were hurt; American peacekeepers say attackers fired from roadside and fled by car; it is not clear whether number of attacks on Kosovo Serbs are random criminal acts, revenege attacks or coordinated drive by ethnic Albanians to force out remaining Serbs; map (M)

headline: TIFFANY SAYS IT WILL STOP SELLING TO OTHER STORES IN U.S.
abstract: Tiffany & Co says it is ending its longtime policy of selling to domestic independent jewelers and department stores, turning its focus on developing its own network of stores and catalogues (S)

headline: SEAGRAM TO SELL CONCERTS UNIT TO RESTAURANT OPERATOR
abstract: Seagram Co to sell its Universal Concerts unit to House of Blues Entertainment Inc for $190 million in cash and assumed debt; deal will give Seagram warrants of up to 1 percent of House of Blues (S)

headline: AMERICA ONLINE IN $100 MILLION PACT WITH CARD MAKER
abstract: America Online Inc reaches $100 million pact making Americangreetings.com, American Greetings Corp unit, sole provider of greeting cards on its Web sites; 5.5-year pact extends existing accord (S)

headline: New Goal in Taiwan: To Be Left Alone
abstract: Dream of reunifying Taiwan and China is gradually evaporating among people of Taiwan, who fear reunification would result in loss of democracy; even though international opinion blames Pres Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan for exacerbating tensions with recent repudiation of one-China policy, Taiwanese say constant threat of military and diplomatic pressure from Beijing are root of tensions; photo (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: THE AMERICAS    MEXICO: EXTRADITION BY SWISS -- Authorities in Switzerland have agreed to extradite to Mexico the former chief executive of the holding company that owns Aeromexico and Mexicana Airlines, Gerardo de Prevoisin. Mr. de Prevoisin fled into exile in 1994 as the airlines he bought from the Government in 1988 careered toward bankruptcy, and he was later charged with defrauding the companies of $57.8 million. He has said he donated part of the money to President Ernesto Zedillo's 1994 election campaign.   Sam Dillon (NYT)    COLOMBIA: BISHOP FREED -- A left-wing guerrilla group that kidnapped a Roman Catholic bishop more than a month ago has released the cleric, but is demanding that the Vatican transfer him and another bishop in the region to other dioceses. ''I will not go,'' was the response of the kidnapped bishop, Msgr. Jose de Jesus Quintero, said by the People's Liberation Army to favor right-wing paramilitary groups that have recently become active in the area.   Larry Rohter (NYT)

headline: In Japan These Days, Few Speak Kindly of Central Bank
abstract: Bank of Japan is under siege; at no time since central bank was granted independence from Government control last year as part of sweeping overhaul of nation's financial system has it come under so much pressure; international experts ranging from those in US Treasury Department to prominent private economists and investors want central bank to loosen monetary policy; they say looser monetary policy will help give Japanese economy jolt needed to help lift it out of decadelong slump; bank says it can do little more to spur economy; adding to pressure is unexpected strength of yen, which hit three-year high against dollar last week, setting off concerns that it would derail start of economic recovery (M)

headline: In Search of Readers, Publishers Consider Age
abstract: Eight-year study of American reading habits finds most people under age 55 are reading less, but those over age 65 are reading more; falloff is greatest among men between ages of 18 and 34; Harry Balzer of NPD Group Inc, which conducted survey, predicts that as baby boomer generation ages, it could help book market because of its numbers and penchant among older people for reading; menawhile, challenge for book publishers is to devise strategies to nurture future generations of readers and to court older buyers; market for popular titles was confronted in last two years with 3 percent decline in number of books purchased; graph (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: R. R. DONNELLEY & SONS CO.,  Chicago, the largest United States printer of telephone directories, plans to buy back as much as $300 million of stock, in response to the drop in its share price in the last 12 months.

headline: Dogfight Over a Must-Win Contract
abstract: Article on reportedly winner-take-all contest between Boeing and Lockheed Martin for contract to develop US military's next generation of fighter jet, Joint Strike Fighter; contract is Pentagon's largest ever and will supply US Air Force, Marines, Navy and British Royal Navy; Boeing is working on X-32 and Lockheed is developing X-35 at secret government facility in Palmdale, Calif; photos; chart

headline: China Proclaims It Designed Its Own Neutron Bomb
abstract: China says it has successfully developed design technology to make neutron bombs and miniaturized nuclear weapons on its own, first time it has made such assertions publicly; announcement seems timed as pointed reminder of its military capabilities, coming just days after Taiwan shifted stance toward China; rebuts Cox Committee report issued by Congressional committee in May, which accuses China of systematically stealing American nuclear technology--such as information on designs for neutron bomb and for W-88, most advanced miniaturized warhead; China says report is misleading, full of lies and racist (M)

headline: 51% Lang Stake Is Sold to Prada
abstract: Helmut Lang, Austrian fashion designer who moved his business to New York two years ago, sells 51 percent of company to Prada of Milan (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    CROATIA: PEACEKEEPING ROLE -- Croatia, which has begun cooperating with the war crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, said that it would also begin contributing troops to United Nations peacekeeping operations for the first time since the country became independent in 1991. The Croats are offering to send soldiers to a military observer mission in Sierra Leone, where a peace treaty was signed between the Government and rebels in July.   Barbara Crossette (NYT)    TURKEY: A WAY OUT FOR CONSCRIPTS -- Desperate to raise money for earthquake relief,  the Government announced legislation that would let Turkish men pay their way out of compulsory 18-month military service. Turkey's generals backed the move, a major turnaround for NATO's second-largest army. The Chief of General Staff, Gen. Huseyin Kivrikoglu, calculated that up to 200,000 men would take up the offer, bringing in an estimated $1.6 million.   (AP)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: George Plans to Continue But With Two Fewer Issues  George magazine, the political magazine whose founder and editor was John F. Kennedy Jr., will continue publishing next year, but will reduce the number of issues to 10 annually from 12.

headline: For Berliners, Real-Time Traffic Intelligence
abstract: Berlin government-funded consortium that includes DaimlerChrysler, Siemens, BMW and Volkswagen is developing traffic management center in city; project will use data collected from variety of sources throughout Berlin to make real-time information about traffic conditions available to public over Internet, cell phones and palm-size devices; photo (M)

headline: Long Distance By Bell Atlantic Expected Soon
abstract: Bell Atlantic Corp plans to ask Federal regulators for permission to sell long-distance communications services in New York State; approval would make it first Baby Bell to enter $80 billion long-distance market; Federal Communications Commision has rejected five previous long-distance applications from other Baby Bell companies, saying they had not opened their local networks to competition, as required by Telecommunications Act of 1996; communications experts expect Bell Atlantic's application to be approved; say it could set regulatory tone for rest of nation (M)

headline: Amazon Moves To Ease Worry About Privacy Of Customers
abstract: Amazon.com will adjust new 'personal circles' marketing tactic in response to critics who raised privacy concerns; says it will let customers request that their buying habits not be included in on-line lists of books and music popular with various groups of people (M)

headline: AUTO PARTS MAKER PURCHASED
abstract: Federal-Mogul Corp buys rival Sabo Industria e Comercio Ltda of Brazil (S)

headline: BRAZIL'S INFLATION RISES
abstract: Brazil's inflation rate rose 1.09 percent in July, fastest rate since March (S)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Economic Scene -- Strong Currency, Weak Economy; As the Yen Soars, Japan Has More at Stake Than Does U.S.
abstract: Michael M Weinstein (Economic Scene) column discusses weak American dollar vis-a-vis strong Japanese yen in terms of the impact on the economies of both countries and related issue of trade; says that despite dollar's woes and country's huge trade deficit, impact on economy of dollars' slide against yen is minimal because dollar has not dropped against most other currencies; notes same condition does not hold for Japan; says despite having Government that is running huge fiscal deficit of nearly 10 percent of its gross domestic product and has poured nearly $200 billion into country's banking system, Japanese economy grew at paltry 1 percent annual rate between April and June; notes real problem is that Japan suffers from insufficient domestic spending, causing deflation (M)

headline: Newspaper Prize Awarded to Goodby
abstract: Goodby, Silverstein & Partners takes top honors, winning $100,000 grand prize, in Athena Awards competition sponsored by Newspaper Association of America for creative advertising in newspapers (S)

headline: TALKS ABOUT SALE OF PUBS
abstract: The battle for the 3,500 British pubs of Allied Domecq P.L.C. has taken another confusing turn. Punch Taverns Group Ltd., the main contender for the pubs after Whitbread P.L.C. withdrew from the bidding, said that it, too, was pulling out, but then it changed tack to say that talks had resumed. Punch lowered its earlier offer of 2.9 billion [pounds] to around 2.7 billion [pounds] after Whitbread's withdrawal. Allied Domecq confirmed that talks with Punch were continuing but said it had been in touch with unidentified new suitors. Punch is 70 percent owned by the United States private equity firm Texas Pacific.   Alan Cowell

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Bertelsmann Sells America Online Shares
abstract: Bertelsmann AG sells 7.2 million shares of America Online Inc, valued at $714.2 million, in order to raise money to finance expansion of its own multimedia businesses (S)

headline: Faces Reflected in Crystal?
abstract: Volunteers for Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center will be photographed for new Lalique jewelry ad campaign in return for which Lalique will make substantial but unspecified contribution to center (S)

headline: Big Selloff Eases, but Investors Remain Concerned
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 39.26 points, or fourth-tenths of 1 percent, to 10,279.33; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closes down 3.05 points, or two-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,277.36; Nasdaq composite index falls 9.42 points, or three-tenths of 1 percent, to 2,740.41; price of 30-year Treasury bond rises 9/32, to 102 7/32; yield drops to 5.96 percent from 5.98 percent; graph on Dow Jones industrial average; charts on stocks with large percentage gains and losses and US key interest rates (M)

headline: Lowe Wins Part Of iPlanet Account
abstract: San Francisco office of Lowe & Partners/SMS is awarded off-line advertising account of iPlanet, new venture that offers software for Internet commerce; it is part of alliance of Sun Microsystems and Netscape Communications Corp unit of America Online; billings estimated at $20 million (S)

headline: Consumption And Incomes Up Yet Again
abstract: Commerce Department reports 0.2 percent hike in personal incomes in July, smallest increase since end of 1998; reports 0.4 percent increase in spending; if growth continues through January, expansion will be longest in US history; graph (M)

headline: That Annoying Beep
abstract: Letter from Arthur B Siegel on Aug 19 article on computer beeping

headline: Changes Reported At Tenneco and Ikon
abstract: J Walter Thompson resigns worldwide account of Tenneco Automotive USA after 25 years, citing 'philosophical differences'; Ikon Office Solutions awards its account to Bozell Worldwide; billings estimated at $30 million (M)

headline: PILOT HOUSE TO INVEST $5 MILLION IN RESORT SPORTS
abstract: Pilot House Associates plans to announce that it has agreed to invest $5 million in Resort Sports Network Inc; Pilot House is to receive 20 percent stake in Resort Sports (S)

headline: Raul Mangalpus, 80, Dies; Power in Post-Marcos Era
abstract: Raul S Manglapus, former Philippine Foreign Secretary who had lived in political exile in US, dies at age 80; photo (S)

headline: SHONEY'S TO CLOSE OR SELL 81 RESTAURANTS AND CUT JOBS
abstract: Shoney's Inc, which operates restaurant chains, will close 72 sites and sell 9 more, cutting 2,351 jobs, to increase profits; Shoney's expects to close company-owned restaurants by end of October; will also sell five Charlotte, NC, restaurants to franchisee Graham Foods and four to Bud Foods for undisclosed price (S)

headline: Bell Atlantic And Vodafone, Once Enemies, Are Now Allies
abstract: Vodafone Airtouch PLC and Bell Atlantic Corp are reportedly planning to consolidate their United States cellular telephone operations into separate company with 23.5 million subscribers and value of between $70 billion and $80 billion; for Bell Atlantic, joint venture with Vodafone Airtouch would give it national cellular footprint it has craved; Vodafone Airtouch would get expanded American presence to rival national wireless networks of AT&T and Sprint; Bell Atlantic and Vodafone Airtouch were hostile adversaries in January, when Vodafone Group snatched Airtouch Communications from Bell Atlantic in two-week bidding war; combined companies became known as Vodafone Airtouch; photos (M)

headline: Next Israeli Leader Steps Out of His Silence
abstract: Prime Min-elect Ehud Barak of Israel, who will be sworn in on July 7, is emerging from behind scenes to take his place as country's leader; Barak telephones Yasir Arafat, Palestinian leader, for their first official conversation; two make date to meet 'soon' and to restart stagnant peace effort; Barak also reproaches Pres Clinton for his seemingly offhand remark about wanting Palestinian refugees to live wherever they want to live; ultimate disposition of Palestian refugees has been left for final status talks, which have not yet begun (M)

headline: A Word About Writepro
abstract: Writepro Corp executive Sol Stein letter on Aug 19 review of company's software for film writers looked at Mac version, not vastly more popular Windows version

headline: Tell-All Book Creates Furor at Vatican
abstract: Interview with Rev Luigi Marinelli, whose book, Gone With the Wind in the Vatican, has become runaway best seller since Roman Catholic Church officials ordered retired Vatican official to cease publication of his insider account of intrigue, homosexuality and corruption within Vatican bureaucracy; he says he cannot recant or withdraw book; book's more shocking anecdotes date back decades and no dissolute figures are identified by name; photo (M)

headline: U.A.W. Deal Doesn't Pack The Wallop It Once Did
abstract: Analysis of UAW-DaimlerChrysler Corp labor contract that includes annual wage increases of 3 percent on top of cost-of-living adjustments that nearly match inflation; holds hardly any economists, auto executives or industry experts are warning of disaster on inflation front or to industry's competitiveness; says agreement has not set off any inflation alarms because it no longer sets lockstep nationwide pattern for other unionized industries as it did in 1960's (M)

headline: Why Do Kazakhs Keep Trying to Ship MIG's to North Korea?
abstract: Sale of about 40 MIG fighter jets to North Korea has set off diplomatic furor in Kazakhstan, including possible US threat to cut off aid; Kazakhstan officials say rogue group that included senior Government officials delivered undisclosed number of jets to North Korea before deal was discovered last month and shipments halted; affair has brought down Nurtai Abukayev, head of State Security Committee, who has been considered one of most powerful men in country after Pres Nursultan Nazarbayev; map (M)

headline: E-Mail Offers New Insights To Microsoft Trial Strategy
abstract: Microsoft Corp and Government file new declarations in court, revising voluminous findings of fact each side filed in September in Federal antitrust suit against company; Government brief seeks to capitalize on concessions that Microsoft witnesses made on stand; Microsoft's new filing ranges from dismissive to contemptuous of Government's position (M)

headline: A Program That Lets You Talk Your Way Around
abstract: Conversa Web allows users to run Microsoft's Internet Explorer Web browser with their voices rather than their hands; simple spoken phrases operate browser's navigation commands; photo (M)

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch extends a print campaign to TV.
abstract: Abercrombie & Fitch, clothing retailer, to use one of its most successful current print campaigns for upcoming cable television and in-store spot presentations; print campaign has been notorious among some for its youthful sensuality, which is aimed at college-age consumers; was developed by Shahid & Co in collaboration with fashion photographer Bruce Weber; ad photo (Advertising column) (M)

headline: I.B.M. Earns $2.4 Billion, Up 65 Percent, in Quarter
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had earned $2.4 billion in the second quarter, up 65 percent, largely because of a gain from the sale of its Global Network Internet unit to AT&T.    I.B.M. used much of the $2.1 billion after-tax gain to cover $1.2 billion in special charges related to reducing costs of memory and hard disk manufacturing and a $241 million charge from an accounting change.

headline: MATTEL TO PRODUCE ENCYCLOPEDIA IN DISK FORMAT
abstract: Mattel Inc enters $30 million agreement to make and distribute Encyclopaedia Britannica on compact disk and digital video disk through 2001; two companies will develop three versions of reference material to go on sale this fall (S)

headline: Not Shy, or Cheap
abstract: Investment banker Frank Quattrone is credited with helping to move Credit Suisse First Boston to third place from sixth for 12 months ended August 1 (S)

headline: Domino's Pizza To Begin a Review
abstract: Domino's Pizza announces unexpectedly that it has begun closed review for national creative development portion of its advertising account, with billings estimated at $120 million; those duties have been handled since March 1997 by Campbell Mithun Esty (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    BELGIUM: A PORK SCARE -- Belgium plunged into another food-safety crisis after its new Government banned the sale of pork from more than 200 farms after discovering toxic levels of cancer-causing dioxin chemicals in pork fat. The new ban comes after a scandal over contamination of eggs, poultry, beef and dairy products. Public uproar led to the election June 13 of a new Government under Prime Minister Guy Verhofstadt, who plans to start a food safety agency.   Craig R. Whitney (NYT)    GERMANY: MORE MONEY FOR MEMORIALS -- The budget for the preservation of memorials at former Nazi concentration camps is to be increased from $16 million next year to $27 million by 2003, Germany's top cultural official said. Michael Naumann, who said last year that the camps provided the most effective evocation of the Holocaust, made the announcment after construction of a vast Berlin memorial close to the Brandenburg Gate was approved by Parliament. The money will go to former camps at Sachsenhausen, Bergen-Belsen and Dachau, among others.   Roger Cohen (NYT)

headline: NOVARTIS INCOME DOWN
abstract: Novartis AG says first-half operating income, excluding one-time gains and charges, fell 4 percent; says pretax operating income fell to 3.881 billion Swiss francs ($2.529 billion) from 4.053 billion francs a year earlier (S)

headline: DUPONT AND MONSANTO DISCUSSED MERGER, FILING REVEALS
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission filing shows E I du Pont de Nemours & Co held merger discussions with Monsanto Co early this year as part of its plan to build up its life sciences business; talks took place as DuPont was also negotiating buyout of Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc; Pioneer agreed to sell, though DuPont left open possibility of deal with Monsanto after DuPont completes acquisition of 80 percent of Pioneer it does not already own (S)

headline: Compaq Plans To Cut Staff By Up to 12%
abstract: Compaq Computer Corp to cut up to 8,000 jobs, 12 percent of its work force, and take third-quarter charge of $700 million to $900 million as result of cost-cutting reorganization; posts second-quarter loss of $184 million, compared with operating profit of $32 million and net loss of $3.63 billion in 1998 period (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: EL PASO ENERGY CORP., Houston, the gas and energy holding company, agreed to acquire Bonneville Pacific Corp., Denver, for $63 million.    LUXOTTICA GROUP.p.A., Agordo, Italy, said it would eliminate 110 jobs over the next two months at its Ray-Ban Sun Optics Inc. unit in Rochester, which it bought from Bausch & Lomb in June, as part of a restructuring.

headline: GENERAL ELECTRIC IS CUTTING 1,400 JOBS AT INDIANA PLANT
abstract: General Electric Co to cut 1,400 jobs at refrigerator plant in Bloomington, Ind, or 44 percent of the plant's employees, and move some of the work to Mexico (S)

headline: MIDEAST STANDOFF REMAINS UNSOLVED AS ALBRIGHT VISITS
abstract: Israelis and Palestinians fail to deliver agreement for signing ceremony in Egypt that Secretary of State Madeleine K Albright had hoped to preside over; Albright meets with Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat in Egypt, then arrives in Israel to meet with Prime Min Ehud Barak, but talks break up without a deal; at issue is Israel's refusal to release 50 Palestinian prisoners now held in Israel; negotiating atmosphere between Israelis and Palestinians was supposed to have substantially improved with new Israeli leader, Barak; it is not clear whether dispute over prisoners constitutes real crisis or matter of brinkmanship, with each side seeking to show its constituency that it is reaching for best possible bargain on emotional issue; photo (M)

headline: No Winners, Only Losers as Paris Resolves Bank Battle
abstract: PARIS—  A bruising takeover battle at the summit of the French banking industry ended this weekend with a ruling by French regulators that Banque Nationale de Paris had failed in its hostile bid to take over Societe Generale SA, the third-largest French bank, and create Europe's largest financial institution.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: That Annoying Beep
abstract: Letter from Dr Evan K Krakovitz on Aug 19 article on computer beeping

headline: China to Allow Debt-for-Stock Swaps in State Companies
abstract: China, faced with over $200 billion in bad debt at moribund state-owned companies, sets broad program of debt-for-equity swaps that could include some foreign ownership; decides larger percentage of Government-owned shares can be sold on nation's stock markets; Zheng Silin, official of agency overhauling publicly owned enterprises, says plans are proceeding to handle debt through new asset management companies, news conference; insists China still plans to eliminate debt of large and medium-sized state companies by end of 2000 (M)

headline: Small Internet Providers Survive Among the Giants
abstract: Rapid growth of America Online, which added 5.1 million members in last year, masks possible decline in its share of Internet-access market; market for Internet service providers, rather than consolidating around AOL, Microsoft and phone companies like AT&T as expected, remains diverse industry with wide open possibilities for competitors, including small operations; AOL's monthly subscription plan is now just one of many business models for Internet access, with new models emerging weekly; graph of growing number of service providers (M)

headline: RIO TINTO SHARES SURGE
abstract: Rio Tinto PLC, mining conglomerate, reports better-than-expected net of $509 million for first half of 1999, compared with $551 year earlier; beats analysts' forecasts of $470 million (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Nasdaq's Busy Year; The Market Steers Several Ways at Once
abstract: Market Place column on response by National Association of Securities Dealers and it chairman, Frank G Zarb, to challenges facing Nasdaq stock market; he has been busy with mergers and alliances along with planning for 24-hour trading and taking the market public to meet increased competition from well-capitalized private communications networks; is slowed by NASD's hefty infrastructure; Zarb argues NASD is setting pace, not being overtaken by events; graphs comparing New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq; photo (M)

headline: FEDERAL REALTY IN TALKS TO SELL STRIP SHOPPING CENTERS
abstract: Federal Realty Investment Trust is in talks to sell its strip shopping center properties, one of largest such holdings in nation; plans to spin off unit that focuses on redeveloping downtown shopping districts (S)

headline: It Looks Like What?
abstract: Letter from Ben Shin ridicules July 22 article comparing shape of Apple's new iBook to toilet seat

headline: 'What Is China?' Taiwan's New Answer Is Puzzling
abstract: News analysis of Taiwan Pres Lee Teng-hui's surprise statement that his Government no longer stands by premise that Taiwan and mainland are parts of same country; photo; even hint that Taiwan is moving toward formal declaration of independence rings loud alarm bells in Beijing, and shift inevitably complicates US-China relations, as well as election politics in Taiwan; Lee is expected to step down next spring after 12 years in office and apparently wants to cement his legacy as father of modern Taiwan separate from mainland (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: LABOR'S SLIM VICTORIES -- The Labor Party won two parliamentary by-elections, but with considerably less support than it drew in May 1997, when it swept to power in Britain. Victor Bill Tynan narrowly held off the challenge of the Scottish Nationalists in a suburban Glasgow seat vacated by George Robertson, who is becoming NATO's Secretary General. Neil Turner won a seat in Wigan in northern England left vacant by the death of Roger Stott.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: Companies learn that selling merchandise on line can be surprisingly messy, especially those pesky returns.
abstract: E-commerce companies are finding on-line sales can be hard to manage; merchandise returns are proving troublesome, particularly for companies with no previous experience in catalogue or traditional retailing; analysts and executives say customers are often subjected to poor customer service when trying to make returns, resulting in delayed exchanges or mishandled refunds that discourage repeat business; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: UNLIMITED SOLUTIONS INC.,  Columbus, Ohio, agreed to be acquired by NSB Retail Systems P.L.C., Basingstoke, England, the top provider of software and support services to British apparel retailers, for $59 million.    IRON MOUNTAIN INC.,  Boston, the world's largest records-management company, said it planned to sell Arcus Staffing Resources, a temporary staffing unit, to focus on its information-services business.

headline: As Goethe's City Is Honored, Buchenwald Lurks Nearby
abstract: Juxtaposition of high German thought and German barbarism complicates celebration of culture by Weimar, small eastern German town that is commemorating 250th anniversary of birth of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe and its selection by European ministers as continent's cultural capital for 1999; Weimar was home to Schiller and Nietzsche and birthplace of Bauhaus, but lies adjacent to Nazis' Buchenwald concentration camp, where more than 50,000 people were killed between 1937 and 1945 Buchenwald concentration camp; photos; map (M)

headline: For the People, by the Computer
abstract: Concept called electronic government is spreading to cities across United States, giving people access to wide range of municipal information and services through the Internet; by using such sites, people will be able to get all of their services without having to go to government offices; by relying more on computers and less on workers, cities hope to save money as well; some city Web sites are already offering number of services, such as Indianapolis site, Indygov (www.indygov.org) which provides such information as polling places, parks and zoning issues; some other sites noted; photo of Allan H Dorbin, New York City commissioner involved with on-line city services (M)

headline: A Celebrity Web Site For Gauging Fund Costs
abstract: Personal-finance author Andrew Tobias opens new Web site offering projected calculation of returns on investments in specific stock funds; photo (M)

headline: Putnam and Buyout Firm Form Joint Venture
abstract: Putnam Investments, mutual fund manager, and Thomas H Lee Co, buyout firm, form partnership to offer investments in hedge funds and private companies to wealthy individuals and institutions; venture will be known as TH Lee; venture will be 25 percent owned by Putnam and 75 percent owned by Thomas H Lee (M)

headline: DANA WILL SELL FORGING PLANT IT ACQUIRED FROM EATON
abstract: Dana Corp plans to sell forging factory in Marion, Ohio, acquired as part of Eaton Corp purchase (S)

headline: Jean Drapeau, 83, Mayor Who Reshaped Montreal
abstract: Jean Drapeau, who in nearly three decades as autocratic Mayor of Montreal brought both grandeur and grandiosity to his city, dies at age 83; photo (M)

headline: MORE FREE NET SERVICE IN ITALY
abstract: Wind SpA, Italian mobile phone company that began operations in March, signs accord with Yahoo Italia to provide free access to Internet, matching offers made by its larger rivals, Telecom Italia and Tiscali (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Long-Distance Rate War Heats Up After AT&T Cuts  AT&T has introduced lower long-distance rates, reluctantly joining a price war with large and small phone carriers that has brought bargains for consumers but threatens to add to already intense pressure on profits.   The new plan, which has a $5.95 monthly fee, offers calls at 7 cents a minute any time. That represents a 30 percent cut in the per-minute rate from AT&T's previous main offering, 10 cents a minute with a $4.95 monthly fee. Customers must request the new plan, otherwise they will remain with their older, more expensive ones. Shares of AT&T declined $1.50 a share, or 3 percent, to $46, on the news. [Page A1.]

headline: Beach Lounging? Spaniards Seem to Prefer Summer School
abstract: University summer courses are increasingly popular in Spain, where they have spread from two main campuses to forty universities; vie for famous speakers, attracting politicians, intellectuals and scientists (M)

headline: Kosovo Cathedral Bombing Is Latest Raid on Serbs' Churches
abstract: Bombing of Serbian Orthodox Cathedral in Pristina rouses condemnation from church leaders and UN and NATO representatives; follows several others bombings in churches in Kosovo, mostly those built in 1981 after Communist restrictions were lifted and Serbian religious nationalism revived; photo; map (M)

headline: It's a Bird! It's a Plane! (And It Wobbles?)
abstract: Game Theory column appraises new Nintendo 64 cartridge, Superman; photos (M)

headline: BIOVAIL TO BUY FUISZ TECHNOLOGIES FOR $154 MILLION
abstract: Biovail Corp International to acquire Fuisz Technologies Ltd for $154 million in cash and stock and assume debt of $91 million (S)

headline: Cooper Industries Job Cuts
abstract: Cooper Industries of Houston, Tex, announces plan to layoff undisclosed number of workers as it consolidates power tools and hand tools divisions and moves unit to Lexington, SC (S)

headline: New Owners of Saks Acknowledge Rough Spots
abstract: New owners of Saks Inc say it is not integrating disparate parts of its swiftly acquired retail empire as smoothly as it had forecast at beginning of year; executives acknowledge significant difficulty in several crucial parts of business, including flagship Saks Fifth Avenue stores, where analysts say snooty merchandise mix has been generating disappointing returns; say problem appears to be that stores have cut out high-margin crowd pleasers in favor of costly do-not-touch items; chairman-chief executive Brad Martin comments; Proffitt's Inc acquired Saks last September and quickly adopted its stylish name (M)

headline: In Effort to Revitalize, Levi Strauss Hires Outsider as Top Executive
abstract: Levi Strauss & Co goes outside controlling family to name Philip A Marineau, Pepsi-Cola North America president and chief executive, as its president and chief executive; Robert Haas, family member, will continue as chairman; photo (M)

headline: Ford Workers in Brazil Strike Over Shift of Plant
abstract: Workers at Ford Motor Co truck plant in Brazil go on strike, fearing that their jobs are threatened from proposed plan to build $1.3 billion Ford Motor auto factory in Brazil's poor northeast, far from industrial south where most of country's auto industry is concentrated; Ford denies it is planning such a move; strike by 1,500 workers is latest negative development to tarnish Ford's image in Brazil since company clashed with Socialist officials in dispute over tax breaks in southern state earlier this year (M)

headline: Citing Credit Card Unit Woes, Bank One Will Trail Forecasts
abstract: Bank One Corp says its 1999 earnings a share could be as much as 8 percent below forecasts because of lower-than-expected revenue from its First USA credit card unit; bank is still in process of integrating First USA with its own credit card business (M)

headline: Loosening the Yoke of the Benchmark
abstract: Mark Hulbert Strategies column describes benefits that might be gained by calling truce in war between those who believe stock market can be beaten and those who do not; graph (M)

headline: In This Race, 3 of the 5 Runners Left a Benchmark in the Dust
abstract: Performance of five money managers who assembled hypothetical mutual fund retirement portfolios for New York Times reviewed; market's turn from big growth stocks to smaller issues and value stocks in second quarter aided investors with such diversified portfolios, with three of five managers beating 7.06 percent rise in Standard & Poor's 500-stock index; tables; photos (Mutual Funds Report) (M)

headline: A Keeper Of the Charts Sees a Line Going Down
abstract: Kenneth N Gilpin Market Insight column interviews Salomon Smith Barney director Alan R Shaw, who comments on latest stock market trends and why Dow Jones industrial average may rise to 20,000 in next few years; photo (M)

headline: Rating Fidelity Managers
abstract: Jim Lowell rates Fidelity Investments' Kenichi Mizushita, manager of Japan Small Companies fund, top Fidelity manager in his latest report on company; his other ratings noted (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Resurging Oil Prices Lead Rally in Commodities
abstract: Resurging oil prices are leading rally in commodities; oil has been flirting with $20 a barrel, and financial analysts expect it to pass that benchmark easily; some see $25 a barrel by end of year, further increase of 25 percent; price has jumped 73 percent from its low point of year, $11.37, reached in February; Kathryn Kobe, senior economist at Joel Popkin & Co, says Consumer Price Index will rise to 2.4 percent from December to December, compared with 1.6 percent increase last year; that would put inflation back at its pace in 1997 and is not considered inflationary breakout; copper has risen 15 perent this year, while aluminum has gained 12.8 percent, nickel 44.1 percent, and zinc 20.4 percent; some factors that have pushed up commodity prices and will continue to put pressure on market in coming months discussed; graph (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Shares That Track Assets Add Value At a Cost
abstract: Kenneth N Gilpin Market Insight column offers excerpts from interview with Lehman Brothers managing director and analyst Robert Willens, who comments on latest interest in tracking stocks (M)

headline: Uncovered Short Positions Rose a Bit in Latest Month
abstract: Open positions of short sales on New York Stock Exchange rose slightly in most recent monthly period; uncovered short sales rose to 3.76 billion shares in month ended Aug 13 from 3.73 billion shares in July; short interest increased 4 percent on American Stock Exchange, to 178.78 million shares; charts (M)

headline: Bank's Head Admits 'Lapse' In Money Laundering Case
abstract: Bank of New York chmn Thomas A Renyi tells House Banking Committee that suspicious activity in nine accounts at core of Russian money laundering investigation was not stopped because accounts were opened by Peter Berlin, husband of highly regarded bank officer, Lucy Edwards (M)

headline: PARKER DRILLING WILL SELL 13 ONSHORE RIGS
abstract: Parker Drilling Co agrees to sell 13 of its American land-drilling rigs to Unit Corp for $40 million in cash and $8.4 million in Unit shares (S)

headline: I.B.M. to End Chip Deal With Toshiba
abstract: IBM will sell its half of computer-chip plant in Manassas, Va, to joint owner, Toshiba Corp, as IBM, number 1 computer maker, scales back its low-profit memory business; financial terms not disclosed (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.25   8.25   8.50        Discount rate   4.75   4.75   5.00        Federal funds   5.06   5.20   5.38        3-month T-bills   4.64   4.66   4.67        6-month T-bills   4.84   4.89   4.67        10-yr. T-infl.   4.07   4.06   3.65        10-yr. T-note   5.92   5.90   4.71        30-yr. T-bond   6.09   6.07   5.15        Telephone bd.   7.85   7.85   7.05        Municipal bds.   5.89   5.86   5.09          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer

headline: Would Tax Cuts Prove Too Stimulating?
abstract: Many economists are concerned that Federal tax cut being debated in Congress may make already strong economy too strong, finally stoking inflation after long period of relatively stable prices; advocates of tax cuts say any reductions will probably be small, at least in initial years; few analysts expect any final tax cut to come close to $864 billion over next decade that has been proposed by House Republicans; Sen Connie Mack, author of proposal to cut taxes by $137 billion over 10 years, says most of cut would come at end of period; adds immediate economic stimulus would be small; Federal Reserve governor Edward M Gramlich says cut would put more pressure on monetary policy (M)

headline: Cable Giant Is Planning An Offering
abstract: Charter Communications Inc, cable television company founded by Paul G Allen, files for initial public offering to raise about $3.4 billion; Allen plans to keep voting control of parent company; will personally invest $750 million in Charter subsidiary, Charter Holdings Inc (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

headline: Earnings at Dell Rise 47% Amid Robust Industry Sales
abstract: Dell Computer Corp reports 47 percent gain second fiscal quarter ended July 31, exceeding analysts' estimates, as company continues to gain market share and surpasses rival Compaq Computer Corp as No.1 supplier of personal computers; reports earnings of $507 million, up from $346 million in year-earlier period; sales rose 42 percent, to $6.143 billion from $4.33 billion (M)

headline: As Colombia Declares an Alert, Rebel Offensive Rages On
abstract: Leftist guerrillas in Colombia renew attacks on more than score of towns after Government decree sets dusk-to-dawn partial curfew in nearly one-third of country and orders armed forces into state of alert; clashes between army and units of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia reportedly leaves 180 guerrillas, soldiers, police officers and civilians dead in several parts of southeast; armed forces chief, Gen Fernando Tapias, predicts escalation will continue; says situation is under control; photo; map (M)

headline: INFLATION WARNING TO BRAZIL
abstract: International Monetary Fund cautions Brazilian authorities to stand ready to raise interest rates if inflation shows signs of accelerating; central bank, which foresees inflation of not more than 8 percent this year, has cut rates to 19.5 percent from 45 percent in March (S)

headline: Surfing the Human Genome; Data Bases of Genetic Code Are Moving to the Web
abstract: Pangea Systems, whose 'bioinformatic' software provides access to genetic data spawned by Human Genome Project, is about to launch Doubletwist.com, a new Web site intended to make on-line genetic and biological research fast, easy and available to any amateur or professional biologist; test phase will be limited to student body and faculty of Stanford University; eventually casual users will be able to access information at no charge, while heavy users will pay for it on a sliding scale, but far less than the $500,000 or more Pangea now charges big pharmaceutical companies; other bioinformatics companies may soon follow suit; some industry executives foresee the day when an educated consumer might take a CD-ROM containing a laboratory's rendering of his genetic profile, and combine it with a Web surf through gene libraries to determine his predisposition toward adverse drug reactions, for example, or for Alzheimer's disease, colon cancer or other afflictions that might eventually be treatable through gene therapy; photos (M)

headline: PHILIPPINE PHONE PROFITS FALL
abstract: Philippine Long Distance Telephone Co reports 64 percent decline in first-half earnings; graph (S)

headline: Hallmark Cards Expands Roster
abstract: Hallmark Cards Inc expands its advertising agency roster by awarding major branding assignment with undisclosed billings to Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer/Euro RSCG (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASIA    PAKISTAN: COUP RUMORS DISMISSED  Responding to rumors of an army coup, Information Minister Mushahid Hussain said no such thing would happen because there was ''complete harmony'' between the civilian and military wings of the Government. Opposition groups have united against Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, left, since he called for a withdrawal of Pakistan-supported forces from a conflict with India in Kashmir this summer.     Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

headline: Microsoft's New Dictionary Is Well-Thumbed by Rivals
abstract: Publication of Microsoft Corp's Encarta World English Dictionary ignites tart war of words in elite universe of dictionary publishing; rival lexicographers, warily facing threat of company's unmatched financial resources as well as marketing muscle and global reach, are retaliating by making gleeful sport of word spotting; are discovering errors and trading jokes about them; some established dictionary publishing houses have even compiled findings into house lists; Microsoft dismisses criticisms as kind of response to be expected from aggressive competitors; plans publication of electronic version as extension of popular electronic Encarta Encyclopedia brand; photo (M)

headline: Another Entry for King of the Sky
abstract: Simon Romero column The Business World on Brazilian developer Mario Garnero, who plans to build world's largest skyscraper, modeled on India's Vedic temples, in downtown Sao Paulo; photos; drawings (M)

headline: Downshifting in Argentina; Recession and Rivalries With Brazil Stall the Economy
abstract: Brazil's sharp Jan currency devaluation has worsened Argentina's recession, costing Argentina competitiveness in world trade and limiting its capacity to export its way out of slump; Argentina's commitment to pegging its peso to dollar has ended its traditional hyperinflation, helped lure over $100 billion in foreign investments and stemmed capital flight and bank failures; sudden currency disparity has cut Argentina's exports to Brazil, which buys nearly one-third of its exports, by 30 percent; auto sector, most dependent on foreign sales, has been worst hit; graph of steep drop in auto exports; photos of car plant (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Japanese Yen Rises 2.2% In a Rally Against the Dollar  The Japanese yen resumed its more than two-month rally against the dollar, jumping 2.2 percent to a three-year high. Analysts said the rally should continue. In New York, the yen settled at 106.44 to the dollar, up from 108.81.    The surge came after the Bank of Japan intervened in the foreign exchange market on Friday and staved off the rally for a day. But the selling of yen for dollars worked for only one day because Japanese officials made clear that they were not trying to change the direction of the yen, only slow its rise. [Page C11.]

headline: Prada Will Buy Control of Jil Sander
abstract: Italian fashion house Prada plans to buy 75 percent of Jil Sander AG's common shares and 15 percent of German company's publicly traded preferred stock; Prada plans to buy stake from Sander's controlling shareholder, Jil Sander, who will remain head of company; Patrizio Bertelli, chief executive of Prada, will become head of Jil Sander's supervisory board; financial terms undisclosed; photo (S)

headline: Patents; Architects debate concepts behind housing design.
abstract: Architects Mark I Kaufman and Donald J Meeks, going beyond traditional copyright protection for their designs, patent what they contend are novel space-saving configurations for apartment buildings and single-family dwellings; patents protect building concepts, not specific plans; have raised concerns among builders and architects; Charles R Chubb patents type of window that lets in tiny amount of ultraviolet rays, which are blocked by normal glass and needed by body to make vitamin D; Paul Godwin patents battery-operated smoke detector system which will trigger all alarms in house when one detects fire (M)

headline: European Stocks Gain as Rate Fears Ease
abstract: Most European stock markets rise, as concern fades that interest rates would soon rise; in Tokyo, Japanese stocks rise for first time in three days; stock indexes in Hong Kong and South Korea gain; financial markets in United States to reopen Sept 7 after being closed Sept 6 in observance of Labor Day (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar rises against Japanese yen amid concern that Japan may step in to sell its currency, which remains at 44-month high; in New York, dollar settles at 105.00 yen, up from 104.23; graph; chart (S)

headline: RACING CHAMPIONS GETS AN OFFER OF $11 A SHARE
abstract: Racing Champions Corp gets buyout offer from Enna Corp (S)

headline: GERMAN PRICES RISE
abstract: Inflation rises slightly in July in four German states, prompting concerns that European Central Bank will increase interest rates (S)

headline: OIL COMPANY TO SELL COAL UNIT
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group plans to sell its coal subsidiary, completing its exit from mining; analysts value subsidiary, with seven mines in Australia and one in Venezuela, between $600 million and $1 billion (S)

headline: Limits Urged For Managers Of Pensions
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission proposes rule to curb political contributions by managers seeking to influence politicians who control decisions about lucrative public pension management contracts; would limit contributions by managers to state and local officials to $250 and bar managers from seeking asset-management contracts for two years after making contribution; Government Finance Officers Association opposes rule (M)

headline: SYNAPTIC'S SHARES FALL AFTER DRUG PROGRAM IS SET BACK
abstract: Shares of Synaptic Pharmaceutical Corp fall 34 percent after its development partner, Merck & Co, ends efforts to develop experimental Synaptic drug intended to treat common enlarged prostate condition (S)

headline: A Helpful Hint To the Government
abstract: Mohamed al-Fayed, Egyptian-born owner of Harrods department store, who has been waiting in vain to be admitted to British citizenship and issued passport, tweaks British authorities by sending one of Harrod's distinctive vans laden with coffee, tea and soda to be handed out to British citizens waiting on line at Government offices for passports; his photo (S)

headline: Tracking Just What The Doctor Ordered; Medicare Changes Would Bolster Prescription Management Services
abstract: Medicare changes proposed by Pres Clinton would bolster prescription management services; shift would illuminate some practices of management drug companies that have largely escaped public notice, including power of pharmacy benefit managers to affect doctors' decisions and their dealings with drug companies; arrangements, which include rebates from drug companies to managers for giving preference to certain drugs, would become much more visible; pharmacy benefit managers try to influence doctors' prescribing habits and encourage use of lower-cost drugs, including generic substitutes for brand-name medicines; in some ways, pharmacy benefit managers are like health maintenance organizations: they try to control cost of care; Barrett Toan, president of Express Scripts Inc, which supervises filling of 295 million prescriptions a year for 47 million people with private health insurance, comments on Clinton's program; list of top five prescription management companies; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The American Stock Exchange may soon face competition for some of its best-selling products.
abstract: American Stock Exchange is facing some fierce competition for its most popular securities, exchange-traded funds; Barclays Global Investors, which is leader in these funds, plans to introduce dozens of new ones next year, in what has been regarded as boon for Amex; Barclays has also been talking with Chicago Board Options Exchange about new listings, potentially creating rival for Amex in crucial market where none existed before (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Grey Wins Oracle Worldwide Account
abstract: Oracle Corp names Grey Advertising to handle its worldwide advertising account, which was handled by DDB Worldwide Communications Group; billings estimated at $75 million to $90 million (S)

headline: From Russia, With Bankruptcy; A High Cost for BP Amoco's Investment in an Oil Concern
abstract: BP Amoco PLC is embroiled in bankruptcy proceeding and takeover fight that threatens to destroy Russian oil company Sidanko and BP Amoco's investment in it; eighteen months ago BP paid $484 million for 10 percent of Sidanko shares and planned to invest $3 billion more over next decade, mainly to develop huge Siberian gas field; Vladimir Potanin, president of Uneximbank, Sidanko's owner, had political influence to shepherd project through Russia's hostile business environment; BP Amoco has been outmaneuvered by aggressive, well-connected Russian rival, the Tyumen Oil Co; BP Amoco accuses Tyumen of tampering with Russian courts to wrest Sidanko's main production unit away through bankruptcy process; Tyumen denies this; BP Amoco has already written off $200 million of its investment; it will have to write off rest of its investment if Tyumen succeeds in taking over Sidanko; BP Amoco's involvement with Sidanko unravels as tale of carelessness and naivete, one in which it tried to follow rules of Western business only to discover too late that those rules do not apply in Russia; drawing; graphs; photo (M)

headline: TEREX TO BUY RAYTHEON UNIT FOR $170 MILLION
abstract: Terex Corp acquires Cedarapids Inc, subsidiary of Raytheon Co, for $170 million in cash (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Chevron and Phillips Discuss Joint Venture  Chevron and Phillips Petroleum have discussed forming a joint venture in the petrochemical business, people close to both companies said, but they added that a merger of the companies was not imminent, despite a report in The Sunday Times of London that sent Phillips shares up $2.8125, to $56.5625.    Analysts said that the recent recovery in crude oil prices meant oil companies were under less pressure to merge. [Page C2.]

headline: Taking More Chances in Trusts
abstract: New Internal Revenue Service data reportedly shows that Americans who create charitable remainder trusts, which give donors lifetime income and pass their assets to charity at death, are moving toward more risky unitrusts, which usually invest in stocks or mutual funds (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro sets another record low against US dollar after European Central Bank says it will not try to halt currency's decline; in New York, euro settles at $1.0214, down from $1.0226; graph; chart (S)

headline: London Journal; Plinth Seeks Occupant. Nelson Will Be Neighbor.
abstract: Statue of Jesus now occupies unused plinth in London's Trafalgar Square, first of several works of art by British sculptors that will be changed ever six months; they will take their place there as part of effort by Royal Society of Arts to spur public debate on what permanent use to make of choice spot; map; photo (M)

headline: Treasuries Set for Auction During Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and two-year notes being auctioned on Wednesday.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 4.68 percent and the rate on the six-month issue at 4.87 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.59 percent.

headline: GSD&M to Promote Wenner Magazines
abstract: Wenner Media Inc names GSD&M to handle company advertising; billings estimated at $2 million (S)

headline: STEAMSHIP COMPANY CHANGES COURSE
abstract: Peninsular & Oriental Steam Navigation Co will sell its entire stake in Bovis Group when shares of construction company are sold on London Stock Exchange in October; analysts estimate sale could raise up to $481 million (US) (S)

headline: JAKARTA CONCEDES A LOSS OF CONTROL OVER TIMOR FORCES
abstract: Gen Wiranto, chief of Indonesia's armed forces, tells high-level United Nations delegation in Dili that he has lost control of elements of his military in East Timor; says that he is becoming more open to help from international peacekeeping force, but that time is not right; is trying to persuade his men to crack down on East Timorese militias, to which they feel emotional allegiance; map; photo (M)

headline: GENERAL ELECTRIC MAY CLOSE TWO REFRIGERATOR PLANTS
abstract: General Electric Co is considering closing obsolete refrigerator plants in Louisville, Ky, and Bloomington, Ind, and adding production of new refrigerator line in Mexico; closings may result in cut of at least 1,500 jobs in US (S)

headline: EXCITE@HOME TO ACQUIRE IMALL FOR $425 MILLION IN STOCK
abstract: ExciteatHome agrees to acquire iMall Inc for stock valued at $425 million (S)

headline: Welcome To the Club, Finally
abstract: Anecdotes illustrate how women's status in work force and executive suites has changed for the better; drawing (M)

headline: On Many Travel Web Sites, a Limited View of the Beaten Path
abstract: Paul Grimes article on Internet travel sites; notes many are more promotional than informational; cites other shortcomings; sampling of helpful sites; table of tips on using travel planning sites; drawing (M)

headline: LTV AGREES TO PAY $650 MILLION FOR 2 IMETAL BUSINESSES
abstract: LTV Corp to buy two units of France's Imetal SA for $650 million in cash (S)

headline: At Last, the Euro Looks Ready to Climb
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer Portfolios column on recent rebound of eurocurrency, which must not be discounted by investors; graph (M)

headline: PAXSON SEEKING MERGER OR EQUITY STAKE SALE
abstract: Paxson Communications hires Salomon Smith Barney to explore potential alliances, including merger or sale of equity stake in company; Paxson says its board settled on this course of action because of changes in Federal Communications Commission ownership regulations that clear way for broadcasting companies to expand their ownership of television and radio stations (S)

headline: High-End Digital Cameras Begin Moving Up a Notch
abstract: Manufacturers are preparing to offer new, more highly evolved digital cameras; Sony Electronics' Cyber-shot DSC-F505 is priced below $1,000; Canon USA says its version of new professional-class digital camera, called Powershot S10, will be smallest and lightest of its kind; photos (S)

headline: A Parent's View of the World Wide Web as It Reaches Adolescence
abstract: Tim Berners-Lee comments on evolution of World Wide Web, the story of his new book, Weaving the Web: The Original Design and Ultimate Destiny of the World Wide Web by its Creator; also discusses his work as founder and director of World Wide Web Consortium, whose mission is to see that fundamental software for identifying and sharing information on the Web is a public standard; believes next stage of Web technical standards will enable computers to talks to each other, doing the routine and repetitive work involved in everything from homework to shopping and allowing people the time and energy for more creative tasks; voices irritation at being asked--especially by incredulous Americans--about why he did use his creation to enrich himself; photo (M)

headline: Waste Management May Lower Its Earnings for First Quarter
abstract: Waste Management Inc warns it may restate first-quarter earnings, lowering them by $55.4 million, because of errors; reports second-quarter adjusted net income rose 53 percent, to $371.8 million, up from $243.2 million in year-earlier period (M)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; BUFETE MISSES PAYMENT
abstract: Bufete Industrial SA, one of Mexico's leading construction companies, will default on payment on $100 million Eurobond (S)

headline: With Its Layoffs, Michelin Skids Into a Hornet's Nest
abstract: PARIS—  Even for Michelin SCA, a French company known for its aloof management, it was a stunning act of disdain for social context when the chief executive announced last week that a 20 percent profit rise would be accompanied by a downsizing program to eliminate 10 percent of the 75,000-person work force in Europe.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: THE AMERICAS    ARGENTINA: PARAGUAYAN TO BE RELOCATED -- Reversing an earlier decision, President Carlos Saul Menem has agreed to move Paraguay's exiled former army chief, Gen. Lino Oviedo, from Buenos Aires Province to the south, where he will be less likely to meddle in his country's affairs. Tensions are growing between the two countries over Paraguay's request to extradite the general, accused of planning the slaying of Vice President Luis Maria Argana.   Clifford Krauss (NYT)    BRAZIL: LEGISLATOR'S IMMUNITY STRIPPED -- After hearing testimony from associates who said they had killed more than 50 people on his orders, the lower house of Congress has voted 394-41 to expel a first-term member, Hildebrando Pascoal, for ''lack of parliamentary decorum.'' An investigating panel accused Mr. Pascoal, who lead the military police in the Amazon state of Acre before entering Congress, of torture and narcotics trafficking. He denies the charges, saying he is the victim of a political vendetta, and had asked for asylum abroad. But the expulsion stripped him of congressional immunity, and he surrendered to the police.   Larry Rohter (NYT)

headline: Ford in Pact With Canada's Auto Workers
abstract: Ford Motor Co reaches tentative, three-year contract with Canadian Auto Workers union, three hours before threatened strike at midnight; agreement is similar to generous deal that DaimlerChrysler AG negotiated with United Automobile Workers union, although that contract is for four years; both deals call for workers to receive annual wage increases of 3 percent plus annual cost of living adjustments nearly equal to inflation rate; union says total annual wage increases will be roughly 4.5 percent with Canadian inflation running close to 2 percent; both deals also provide large increases in pension benefits, to encourage older workers to retire, partly to make way for younger workers and partly to allow auto workers to reduce their work forces slowly so as to become more competitive; union president Basil Hargrove lauds agreement (M)

headline: Vote Near on U.N. Job
abstract: The Senate will probably vote next week on the long-delayed nomination of Richard C. Holbrooke as chief  delegate to the United Nations, a top Democrat said. Republicans have blocked the vote until the Administration addresses demands that have little to do with Mr. Holbrooke.  Article, page A5.

headline: Hard Line at Harvard
abstract: Prof Robert D Putnam letter on June 20 article hold forced resignation of Harvard Divinity School Dean Ronald F Thiemann for reportedly having pornographic images on school-owned computer in his Harvard-owned home raises issue of privacy rights at workplace

headline: SAAB EARNINGS RISE
abstract: Saab AB reports almost fourfold rise in second-quarter profit, to equivalent of $40.9 million (S)

headline: Air Canada Prepares for Strike Threatened by Flight Attendants
abstract: Air Canada prepares for strike by its unionized flight attendants; cancels all ticket sales and freight shipment orders for next seven days, promising to resume if strike is called off (M)

headline: Scottish & Newcastle in $1.8 Billion Pub Deal
abstract: Scottish & Newcastle PLC, Britain's dominant brewer, acquires 868 pubs, restaurants and budget hotels from Greenalls Group PLC for $1.8 billion (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Post-Communist Media Deal Is Torn by Personal Dispute
abstract: Uncertainty over whether Central European Media Enterprises Ltd or station's dismissed general director, Vladimir Zelezny, controls license of TV Nova, greatly popular Czech Republic television station, has driven down Central European's share price, endangering its planned acquisition by SBS Broadcasting SA; Central European holds Zelezny stole from company in variety of ways; Zelezny, who seized license and runs station, comments, interview; photo (M)

headline: Patents; For the do-it-yourself builder, interlocking bricks that can be snapped together to make a structure.
abstract: Dominic Cerrato is granted patent for his interlocking blocks, which allow builder to construct real structures without being expert mason; 10 new inventors will be inducted into National Inventors Hall of Fame (M)

headline: A Year After Bombing, Grief Lingers in Ulster Town
abstract: Grief and trauma linger in Omagh, Northern Ireland, year after bomb planted by splinter group of Irish Republican Army exploded in downtown shopping area killing 29 people and wounding 400 others; approximately 25,000 stage march on first anniversary of bombing, deadliest in 29 years of sectarian violence, with Catholic and Protestant prayers and hymns in front of local courthouse; map; photos (M)

headline: 1-800-WELLDARNIT!
abstract: James F McCann comments on less-than-expected revenue from initial public offering for his company, 1-800-Flowers (S)

headline: Syrian President Due in Russia Today as Mideast Diplomacy Starts to Revive
abstract: Surprise trip to Russia by Pres Hafez al-Assad of Syria is seen as first step in an expected flurry of Middle East diplomacy as Arab and Israeli leaders jockey for position in peace effort that is suddenly showing signs of life for the first time in three years (M)

headline: Computer Shock
abstract: Letter from James Ferguson claims Macintosh computer would have been easier for Dr Edwin Rothman to use

headline: Brokerage Firm Is Indicted In Fraud Case
abstract: Manhattan District Attorney Robert M Morgenthau indicts A S Goldmen & Co, small New Jersey brokerage firm, and 26 employees on charges that firm orchestrated securities fraud that cost thousands of investors $100 million in losses; among those named in 240-count indictment are Goldmen's president and owner, Anthony Marchiano, and his twin brother, Salvatore, Goldmen's head trader; chief financial officer Stuart E Winkler is also named; prosecutors say Winkler, who worked as field examiner at National Association of Securities Dealers from 1979 through 1986, devised firm's fraudulent schemes; Morgenthau brings civil action seeking $100 million in repayment for what he calls criminal process of corrupt activities; State Supreme Court Justice Helen E Freedman signs temporary restraining order prohibiting defendants from disposing of any assets without court approval; photo (M)

headline: BENCHMARK TO BUY AVEX ELECTRONICS FOR $289 MILLION
abstract: Benchmark Electrú

headline: As Layoffs Loom, Loyalties Are Divided
abstract: Jeffrey L Seglin The Right Thing column on risks managers face when revealing to their workers financial changes that may result in layoffs (M)

headline: Rolls-Royce to Buy Vickers for $933 Million
abstract: Rolls-Royce PLC agrees to acquire Vickers PLC for $933 million, saying deal will create giant in growing market for engines and other propulsion systems to push ever-bigger ships at ever-higher speeds; Rolls-Royce chairman Ralph Robins comments (M)

headline: In Clinton's Words: East Timor, Waco, Clemency Offer, and Other Issues
abstract: Excerpts from Pres Clinton's statement on East Timor; photo (M)

headline: WYNDHAM RECEIVES $1 BILLION FROM INVESTOR GROUP
abstract: Wyndham International Inc receives $1 billion investment from investors that include affiliates of Thomas H Lee Equity Fund IV LP and Apollo Investment Fund IV LP (S)

headline: American Airlines Lawsuit Is Dismissed
abstract: American Airlines wins dismissal of lawsuit brought by passenger Matthew Zifrony that accused air carrier of illegally driving smaller competitors--Vanguard Airlines and Pan American Airlines--out of business, costing consumers more for tickets (S)

headline: People
abstract: Jeff Purcell is named to new position of vice president for marketing at E&F/MARC Advertising (S)

headline: When an Expense Is Not an Expense
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column explores possible reasons for decline in companies' reported tax receipts as profits continue to surge (M)

headline: MONSANTO SAYS IT PLANS TO SELL TWO BUSINESSES
abstract: Monsanto Co will sell its artificial sweeteners business to pay debt and focus more on its drug and agricultural products; sweeteners unit sells its products under brands like Nutrasweet and Equal; company says it plans to sell unit that makes biogums, food ingredients used to thicken products like sauces and gravies (S)

headline: U.S. to Seek To Alter Plan For Pursuing War Crimes
abstract: United States is expected to continue its drive against politically inspired war-crimes prosecutions at conference on proposed International Criminal Court set for United Nations; meeting of representatives of about 120 nations that have approved court's formation will discuss outstanding technical issues; US, concerned its citizens might suffer frivolous or politically inspired prosecution, voted against treaty setting up new tribunal (M)

headline: Iran Students Halt Protests But Still Press For Changes
abstract: Iranian student leaders announce temporary ban on pro-reform demonstrations, but press Islamic Government on long list of demands, including resignation of country's chief of police, Hedayat Lotfian; decision by student leaders to call off their protests, at least for time being, buys time for country's clerical leadership in face of worst unrest since early days of Iran's revolution two decades ago (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Broadcom Plans to Acquire Hothaus for $280 Million  Broadcom, a leading maker of high-speed communications semiconductors, has agreed to buy Hothaus Technologies for $280 million in stock. Broadcom will issue two million of its Class B shares for Hothaus, a closely held developer of software that enables communications over broadband networks.     The acquisition will enhance Broadcom's position in the emerging market for phone calls using Internet technology. [Page C2.]

headline: Housing Data, New Offerings Cool Demand For Treasuries
abstract: Treasury bond prices fall; 30-year bond drops 3/32, to 89 10/32, to yield 6.03 percent; key rates table (M)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Snyder Communications will rename its Snyder Health Care Services unit as Ventiv Health after spinoff in September; Poux Co is opened by Paul D Poux (S)

headline: Russians Feel Helpless Against Terror
abstract: Moscow is on full alert, with residents battling feelings of helplessness following bombing of third apartment building in two weeks in seemingly random wave of violence and terror; photo (M)

headline: NISSAN-SAMSUNG RUMORS DENIED
abstract: Nissan Motor Co denies rumors that it weighs bid for South Korea's insolvent Samsung Motor Corp (S)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: BANC ONE CORP., Columbus, Ohio, named Richard J. Lehmann to head commercial banking and asset management operations, succeeding David Vitale, who will retire Nov. 1. Mr. Lehmann is now head of Banc One's credit card, retail and auto finance arms.     BDO SEIDMAN L.L.P., Chicago, named Alan Sellitti managing director of its New York office, succeeding Richard Roedel, who was named chairman-elect in April. Mr. Sellitti had most recently been director of accounting and auditing for the New York region.

headline: CVF TECHNOLOGIES CLEARS WAY FOR ITS TAKEOVER
abstract: CVF Technologies Corp grants USA Global Link Inc option to acquire CVF for $76.7 million (S)

headline: Butcher, Baker, Skyscraper Maker: What America Earns
abstract: Set of charts based on Bureau of Labor Statistics figures for 1997 shows salaries for highest- and lowest-paying occupations in US's largest cities and salaries in most common jobs; drawings (L)

headline: Mario Vespa, 93, a Cruise Industry Official
abstract: Mario Vespa, cruise industry executive, dies at age 93 (S)

headline: U.N. Says It's NATO That Lags in Kosovo
abstract: United Nations Asst Sec Gen John Ruggie, stung by charges by United States military leaders that United Nations is moving too slowly in creating police force and civil administration in Kosovo, notes NATO members have not yet deployed all soldiers pledged; holds UN is moving according to plan, deploying people and resources at 'unprecedented' pace; says full UN police force will be in place throughout Kosovo by Nov or Dec (M)

headline: New Ways to Sign Off
abstract: Letter from Donald J Kahn comments on July 22 article on signing off on E-mail correspondence

headline: Phelps Dodge Offers to Acquire Two Merging Copper Companies
abstract: Copper producer Phelps Dodge Corp, continuing commodity industries consolidations, offers all-stock bids of $2.4 billion then $2.66 billion to Cyprus Amax Minerals Co and Asarco Inc, which had just agreed to merge; analysts say combination would make it number one producer; Cyprus and Asarco boards reject Phelps offer (M)

headline: Indictments Unveil the Dark Side of a Mexican TV Comedian
abstract: Murder indictments are handed down in Mexico City against individuals alleged to have been involved in June 7 slaying of popular television comedian Francisco Stanley Albaitero; indictments show that Stanley was also a customer and business partner of one of Mexico's most notorious drug traffickers; Stanley was heavily in debt to drug lord, Luis Ignacio Amezcua Contreras, and when Stanley fell behind in his payments, Amezcua hired someone to kill him; also indicted is Stanley's longtime television straight man, Mario Rodriguez Bezares, who was often humiliated by Stanley (M)

headline: Click Here for a Few Well-Chosen Words
abstract: Niamh Crowe is E-commerce pioneer in Ireland, with Web site that offers pre-packaged and customized speeches for any special occasion around world; photo; drawing (M)

headline: San Francisco Agency Offers Gun Control Ad
abstract: San Francisco-based Red Ball Tiger advertising agency has created television commercial advocating gun control; agency executives are offering spot free to any person or company that agrees to spend at least $5 million to run it (S)

headline: A Palace Fit for a Fugitive And Ukraine's Ex-Premier
abstract: Ukrainian ex-Prime Min Pavlo Lazarenko, detained by United States for possible extradition to Ukraine or Switzerland on charges of embezzling state funds and money laundering, bought lavish $6.75 million Marin County, Calif, estate for cash last Sept; US authorities say he made money buying and selling natural gas contracts when he was energy minister; his attorney holds charges are politically motivated; photos (M)

headline: Primedia to Sell Publishing Group
abstract: Primedia Inc, publisher controlled by buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co, which owns 83 percent of shares, agrees to sell its supplemental educational publishing group to Ripplewood Holdings PLC for $415 million to reduce its debt (S)

headline: NBC Is Seen Close to Deal With Paxson
abstract: Unnamed executive says NBC is 'on track' to complete a deal to acquire a 32 percent interest in the money-losing Paxson Communications Corp as early as next week; Paxson Communications, which is owned by W Lowell Paxson, owns group of 73 television stations that reach more than 75 percent of the homes in the country; NBC's interest in Paxson is reportedly based on its longtime desire to create second national distribution outlet which NBC could use for entertainment programming that it owns rights to (S)

headline: Turk Minister Criticizes Government's Response to Quake
abstract: Turkish Tourism Min Erkan Mumcu sharply criticizes Govt's slow response to recent devastating earthquake as 'declaration of bankruptcy' for Turkish political and economic system; criticism is echoed by Ibrahim Yasar, member of Parliament from district near earthquake zone; seemingly chastened Pres Suleyman Demirel meets with seismologists in Istanbul; makes rare apology; pledges Govt will monitor earthquakes more closely, will review building codes and will construct buildings better able to withstand earthquakes; number of deaths put at 12,148 and officials fear toll could rise much higher; Turkish and Israeli teams rescue small boy from wreckage of home in hard-hit town of Cinarcik; Govt's faltering response to disaster has infuriated many Turks, many of may have lost respect for ruling elite; photos (M)

headline: BOC, British Supplier of Gases, to Be Bought
abstract: BOC Group PLC of Britain, world's second-largest supplier of industrial gases, will be taken over and divided up by Air Liquide SA of France and Air Products and Chemicals Inc of US under $11.2 billion cash deal (M)

headline: A New Place on the Internet To Explore Space's Wonders
abstract: New Web site devoted to space is launched on 30th anniversary of moon landing; site is brainchild of Lou Dobbs, former news executive with lifelong fascination with space(S)

headline: U.N. Oratory: Pleas for Help, Pride in Democracy
abstract: Excerpts from addresses given at General Assembly by Brazilian Foreign Min Luiz Felipe Lampreia, British Foreign Sec Robin Cook, Pres Thabo Mbeki of South Africa, Prime Min Hun Sen of Cambodia and Pres Jorge Sampaio of Portugal; photos (M)

headline: PROFIT WARNING BY KROLL-O'GARA, SECURITY FIRM
abstract: Shares of Kroll-O'Gara Co fall 45 percent after it says it is considering selling itself and warns that third-quarter earnings will miss estimates (S)¼

headline: Major Nations Report Progress on Pact to Ease Sanctions on Iraq
abstract: Five permanent members of United Nations Security Council report progress toward deal to ease sanctions on Iraq in exchange for Baghdad's submission to new system of weapons inspections; is agreement is struck, and accepted by Iraq, it could lead to redeployment of United Nations personnel to monitor Iraqi weapons programs; British officials caution that there is no guarantee that this latest effort to revive arms inspections would succeed (M)

headline: Taiwan's Strict Codes Reflect California's Rules
abstract: American experts say Turkey and Taiwan have effectively adopted California building requirements for earthquakes, which are intended to enable occupants to get out alive in major earthquake even if structure is rendered unusable; say in Turkey there are no inspections and probably more corruption; say Taiwan's greatest vulnerability is that many of its buildings are built on soft soil (M)

headline: Affordable Scanning
abstract: Letter from David Moore on July 29 article on scanners to turn slides into digital images

headline: Swiss Turn an Unblinded Eye on Russian Funds in Their Banks
abstract: Switzerland and its banks, concerned that flood of Russian deposits may be linked to organize crime, are taking steps unusual by Swiss standards to ferret out any illegality; have begun enforcing laws against money laundering, created police unit for Russian gangs and cooperated with Russian investigators (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of July 18 article on collaboration between environmentalists and Dow Chemical Co to cut toxic emissions at Midland, Mich, plant; consultant's name is Bill Bilkovich, not Bilkovitch (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Expectation that Japan will persuade other leading industrialized nations to intervene to weaken yen deflates it versus dollar and euro; in New York, dollar rises to 106.86 yen, from 105.19; graph; chart (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    RUSSIA: ARMS RACE WARNING -- Russia and the United States ended a new round of arms control talks with Moscow saying American plans for a missile defense system could start a new arms race in outer space.
