After three days of talks, the two sides appeared to have made little progress, with the main bone of contention American hopes to modify the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile treaty to permit a limited missile defense.   (Reuters)    GERMANY: TRANSPLANT FOR MRS. GORBACHEV -- Raisa Gorbachev, 67, the wife of the former Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev, will have a bone-marrow transplant in the next few weeks, with her sister serving as donor, doctors at the University Hospital of Munster said. Mrs. Gorbachev, who has leukemia, has responded well to chemotherapy, the doctors said.   Victor Homola (NYT)

headline: Rebel Push in Colombia Adds Urgency to Washington Talks
abstract: Colombian Defense Min Luis Fernando Ramirez and armed forces chief Gen Fernando Tapias will consult with US officials in Washington as sporadic clashes continue between government troops and left-wing guerrillas; about third of Colombia is now under partial curfew; map (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Cambridge Soundworks gives its advertising account to Pagano, Schenck & Kay (S)

headline: The Free Index Fund: Latest in Internet Lures
abstract: Stockjungle.com, financial Web site, plans to offer Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fund that does not charge investors management or distribution fee or any other expenses (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro touches another low against dollar amid more signs of weakness in European economy; in New York, euro settles at $1.0226, down from $1.0240; graph; chart (S)

headline: Report Says Labor Market Tight
abstract: Labor Department reports number of workers filing for state unemployment benefits rose last week, while less-volatile four-week average declined to its lowest level in more than a quarter-century, suggesting pool of available employees remains relatively small; says first-time jobless claims increased 4,000, to seasonally adjusted 287,000 for week ended Aug 14; four-week average of claims dropped to 281,250 from 288,250 the previous week; that is smallest number of claims since week ended Dec 22, 1973, when four-week average was 280,000 (S)

headline: 3 Drug Makers Agree to Settle U.S. Charges
abstract: Justice Department says three Japanese pharmaceutical companies, Takeda Chemical Industries, Eisai Co and Daiichi Pharmaceutical Co, have agreed to plead guilty to United States antitrust violations and to pay more than $137 million to settle charges that they took part in a worldwide conspiracy to fix prices in vitamin market; case does not involve sale of any vitamin tablets, but the ingredients that go into eveything from vitamins to orange juice; in breaking the cartel, the United States Government has now recovered more than $850 million and exposed loose confederacy of vitamin makers that met secretly for years to plot how to divide up world markets (M)

headline: As Plain as the 'Nose' on Your Chip
abstract: Scientists and engineers are building electronic noses with long-elusive sense of smell; Dr Steven Sunshine of Cyrano Sciences says his electronic nose cannot match human nose in some areas, like detecting sulfur compounds inserted into natural gas to warn people if there is leak; drawing (M)

headline: Cox Is in Deal With Gannett For Cable-TV Subscribers
abstract: Cox Communications will acquire 522,000 cable subscribers from Gannett Co in continuing expansion of cable television holdings; will pay $2.7 billion in cash for systems in Kansas, Oklahoma and North Carolina (M)

headline: School Spirit Inc.; Millions of Cheerleaders Create a Growth Industry
abstract: Profile of what some call the spirit industry, which caters to more than 400,000 cheerleaders as well as school dance teams, pompom squads and dancers nationwide who attend camps, regional and national competitions; it is estimated that it costs $5,000 a year for each cheerleader for such things as summer camps, clothes and uniforms; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Argentina Rattles a Bit, and Latin Investors Shake
abstract: Latin American stock markets decline on concern about Argentina, which is facing tough recession, growing budget deficit and presidential election; all adds up to uncertainty about country's economic restructuring--something not helped by Gov Eduardo Duhalde of Buenos Aires, presidential candidate, who wants to ask Pope John Paul II to support debt moratorium for Argentina and other struggling countries; some analysts expect continued pressure on Argentina's markets; such concerns could spill over in rest of region, especially if Federal Reserve decides to raise interest rates further next month; higher US rates would make it harder for Latin nations to attract foreign capital; graph on widening spread between interest rates on Latin American bonds and comparable US Treasury bonds (Market Place column) (M)

headline: TXU INCREASES PLANNED STOCK BUYBACK TO $800 MILLION
abstract: TXU Corp, previously known as Texas Utilities Co, has increased amount of stock it plans to buy back from investors to $800 million from $600 million (S)

headline: Computer Shock
abstract: Letter from Sean Brennan on July 1 article on Dr Edward Rothman's frustrating attempts to set up his new computer

headline: Alcohol and Tobacco Sales Are Being Blocked by Ebay
abstract: On-line auction site Ebay confirms it plans to prohibit sale of alcohol and tobacco products on its service, asserting that sales could subject some users to prosecution under growing number of state regulations governing sale of such products across state lines (M)

headline: Angst in the Great American Middle
abstract: Susan Berger letter on Louis Uchitelle's August 1 article holds most middle Americans simply do not understand philosophy of frugality and thrift (S)

headline: Voice Xpress Lets You Work While on the Go
abstract: Lernhout & Hauspie introduces portable voice recognition system that holds 70 minutes of dictation, which can later be downloaded to computer; photo (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US Treasury bonds are little changed; benchmark 30-year Treasury is at 100 18/32, up 6/32; yield is down to 6.08 percent, from 6.10 percent; graph on 3-month Treasury bills; chart on US key interest rates (S)

headline: Obsessively Independent, Yahoo Is the Web's Switzerland; Cutthroat Battles Are Ahead, Threatening a Stoic Resolve
abstract: Profile of Yahoo, rapidly growing Internet search engine and portal; cites chief executive Timothy A Koogle's stress on speed and his insistence that Yahoo stay independent; he comments, interview; table of most popular Web sites; photo (M)

headline: Old Thinking at the Fed
abstract: Economist Leon Korobow letter, responding to June 20 article on lack of indications of inflation in US economy questions why Federal Reserve Board felt compelled to raise rates in June (S)

headline: Timor Death Toll Disputed
abstract: Indonesia's top military commander, Gen Wiranto, disputes reports of thousands of deaths in East Timor; claims fewer than 100 people have been killed there (S)

headline: Full-Time U.S. Force in Haiti To Leave an Unstable Nation
abstract: Defense Department and Clinton Administration officials say Pres Clinton plans to withdraw last American troops from Haiti, under pressure from Pentagon and Congressional Republicans, by end of year even though peace there remains tenuous; say Pentagon, in future, will send small contingents of reservists and National Guard members on short temporary assignments; only 480 regular troops remain in Haiti, down from force of 20,000 that occupied nation in 1994, but are seen as psychologically important; smaller United Nations force of about 400 peacekeepers acting as advisers to police will not be affected (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of August 22 article on leadership succession at S C Johnson & Co, which misstated name of Louis family, which has nearly 40 percent interest in business but no role in running it (S)

headline: Brokerage Chief Hired at E*Trade
abstract: E*Trade Group Inc hires Frank J Petrilli, TD Waterhouse Group Inc president and chief operating officer, as president of E*Trade Securities; he succeeds Kathy Levinson, who remains president and chief operating officer of parent company; TD Waterhouse says Keith Gray will assume Petrilli's role as chief operating officer (S)

headline: Malula Journal; Passing On History by Word of Mouth
abstract: Aramaic, the language of Jesus, survives as language of daily life of Malula, Syrian town of 5,000, and two nearby villages; successive conquerors never bothered to force their languages on this remote community in Qalamum Mountains; scholars visit Malula to study language; photos; map (M)

headline: More Trouble With Rebates
abstract: Letter from David L Ottenstein on keeping track of rebates from computer companies

headline: Clues to Sentencing Mystery In the Archer Daniels Case
abstract: Analysis of Federal Judge Blanche M Manning's decision to sentence Archer Daniels Midland Co informant Mark E Whitacre to stiffer sentence in price-fixing scheme than Michael D Andreas, former vice chairman, and Terrance S Wilson, former head of corn processing; says outcome stems from intricate workings of Federal sentencing guidelines, which use complex formula for determining ranges for prison terms for each defendant; holds in this case, formula did not work to best interest of Whitacre; says outcome is also partly result of finding by Manning that Whitacre was manager of conspiracy--and thus liable for heavier penalties--even though he was outranked by at least one of his co-defendants, whom Manning found to have no managerial role; Andreas and Wilson were sentenced to two years in prison and $350,000 fine; Whitacre was sentenced to two and a half years in prison, with no fines since he has no money to pay them (M)

headline: Factory Production Rose More in August
abstract: Federal Reserve reports factory production rose three-tenths of 1 percent in August, exceeding expectations; automotive production rose 8.1 percent, biggest increase in a year; Labor Department reports first-time claims for unemployment benefits unexpectedly fell 4,000, to 288,000, last week; graphs on industrial production and capacity utilization (M)

headline: Toyota Is Seeking to Stop Use of Seniority to Set Pay
abstract: Toyota Motor Corp is negotiating with its union to eliminate seniority as major factor in determining salaries of white-collar workers; if company is successful, it may influence pay practices of companies across Japan, particularly because Hiroshi Okuda, Toyota's chairman, is also chairman of Japan Federation of Employers' Associations; Japan has been grappling for ways to mobilize its labor force to help country out of its recession; union spokesman says union is not likely to oppose Toyota's plan (S)

headline: Back to the Moon: Apollo 11 Revisited
abstract: Several Internet sites highlighting 30th anniversary of Apollo 11 moon mission noted; photo of footprint from Neil Armstrong's first step on moon (S)

headline: ACCORD IN ULSTER HITS A ROADBLOCK OVER DISARMAMENT
abstract: Ulster Unionists, main Protestant party in Northern Ireland, refuses to join Irish Republican Army political wing as ally in new government until guerrillas disarm, halting all progress in carrying out Northern Ireland peace agreement; leader David Trimble spurns last-minute appeals and concessions from British Prime Min Tony Blair, blocking critical transfer of power over local affairs from British Parliament to new Northern Ireland Assembly in Belfast; accord to end 30 years of sectarian violence that has taken more than 3,200 lives, was signed to wide acclaim in 1998; while it contains general commitment to disarmament, it does not spell out timing or methods; Sinn Fein, IRA's political wing, argues that guerrillas cease-fire, now more than two years old, proves their commitment to non-violence (M)

headline: Bacardi-Martini Selects DeWitt
abstract: Bacardi-Martini USA assigns media work to DeWitt Media in New York (S)

headline: Taipei Journal; Color Taiwan Red, White and Blue? (He's Serious)
abstract: David Chou, Taiwan toy industry executive, proposes that Taiwan become 51st state of US; map; photo (M)

headline: Singapore Investor Settles Trading Charge
abstract: Lum Chang Holdings Ltd chairman Raymond Lum Kwan Sung agrees to pay $2.25 million to settle insider trading charges filed by Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with his acquisition of APL Ltd securities (S)

headline: 9 Big Creditor Banks Agree to a Delay in Russian Debt Talks
abstract: Russia's nine big bank creditors on committee led by Deutsche Bank AG, after meeting with Russian delegation led by Min Mikhail Kasyanov, agree to meet in Sept to weigh Russia's bid to reschedule some of country's more than $30 billion in Soviet-era debt (M)

headline: Agencies Offering Quake Aid in Turkey
abstract: Partial list of aid agencies that are accepting contributions to help the victims of earthquake in Turkey (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MIAMI COMPUTER SUPPLY CORP. , Dayton, Ohio, which sells computer and office-automation supplies, agreed to buy the closely held Technical Industries, Atlanta, to increase its market share in the Southeastern U.S. market for audiovisual products. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICO BEEF DISPUTE
abstract: Tariffs as high as 200 percent have been imposed on some United States beef exports to Mexico, second-largest export market for US producers; Mexican producers charge US rivals sell below cost (S)

headline: FRANCE URGED TO CUT STAKE
abstract: German Government is pressing France to reduce its stake in aerospace company Aerospatiale Matra SA, to clear way for merger with DaimlerChrysler AG's aerospace unit; German Government wants French Government to reduce its stake by 48 percent; DaimlerChrysler Aerospace want no state involvement in Aerospatiale (S)

headline: Internet's Governing Body Debates Domain Names
abstract: Major meeting of Internet Corp for Assigned Names and Numbers, Internet's new governing body, opens with fireworks and controversy that have become its trademark, including protests over closed session of one of its advisory groups and dispute over what should be voted on later this week, Santiago, Chile; at heart of much of discussion is how to guarantee that individual Internet users and noncommercial interests have a voice before it starts making key policy decisions; officials want to crack down on cybersquatters who hoard Web names (M)

headline: Clinton and Arafat Confer Again on Peace Negotiations
abstract: Pres Clinton and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, in what are becoming almost regular sessions, meet at White House to discuss how to proceed on negotiations that are to define a final peace settlement between Israel and Palestinians; Administration officials depict meeting as opportunity for Clinton to bolster Arafat's confidence so that he will proceed briskly with negotiations with Israelis; photo (M)

headline: U S West Reduces Internet Access Price
abstract: US West Inc, which provides local telephone service in 14 western US states, is dropping price of high-speed Internet access by a third to attract customers who now use slower connections; new service, Megabit Select, costs $19.95 (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.25   8.25   8.50        Discount rate   4.75   4.75   5.00        Federal funds   5.38   5.26   5.50        3-month T-bills   4.60   4.67   4.60        6-month T-bills   4.86   4.90   4.68        10-yr. T-infl.   4.04   4.04   3.67        10-yr. T-note   5.92   5.95   4.86        30-yr. T-bond   6.10   6.12   5.22        Telephone bd.   7.89   7.90   7.09        Municipal bds.   5.86   5.86   5.13          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer

headline: DEUTSCHE BANK INVESTIGATED
abstract: Deutsche Bank AG says regulators are investigating its Japanese units in latest examination of foreign bank; inspectors from Financial Supervisory Agency are examining all seven of Deutsche Bank's Tokyo businesses, including units it obtained in its $9 billion acquisition of Bankers Trust early this year; bank officials say inspection is routine; watchdog agency is preparing criminal charges against Credit Suisse Group of its Japanese derivatives arm (S)

headline: Rwandan in Genocide Case Makes Last Appeal to Stay in U.S.
abstract: Rwandan under indictment for genocide by international war crimes tribunal in Africa, Elizaphan Ntakirutimana, makes final plea to Supreme Court to avoid deportation from United States; he is Seventh-day Adventist pastor and Hutu accused of inciting massacre of hundreds of frightened Tutsi hiding in his church compound in 1994; State Dept has been fighting for his deportation since 1996 (M)

headline: INDUSTRIAL GAS OFFER
abstract: Shares in BOC Group PLC soar after company says it is considering new joint bid by Air Products & Chemicals Inc and Air Liquide; BOC rejected earlier bid of $11 billion from same suitors two weeks ago; graph (S)

headline: BRITISH AEROSPACE SEEKS AID
abstract: British Aeropsace applies for $794.5 million (US) from British Government to help pay for building of largest aircraft in the world; double-decker planes will carry 600 passengers on long flights; project is expected to create 22,000 jobs in Britain (S)

headline: Democrats Now Expect Senate to Vote on Holbrooke Next Week
abstract: Sen Thomas A Daschle says majority leader Trent Lott has assured him that Senate will vote on long-delayed nomination of Richard C Holbrooke as chief US delegate to United Nations before lawmakers leave for their summer recess (M)

headline: The Times and Granada in Documentary Deal
abstract: Granada Media and New York Times agree to create television documentaries exploring topics in science, travel and current affairs; two Granada producers will be posted in newsroom to generate ideas for documentaries that could be expanded into series of programs (M)

headline: BOSTON CHICKEN AND LENDERS END TALKS ABOUT SALE
abstract: Boston Chicken Inc and its lenders end talks about proposed sale to Texas entrepreneur Jack Baum and group of unidentified institutional investors (S)

headline: Rebels Attack Caucasus Area; Bomb Kills 30
abstract: Islamic militants mount ferocious assault in Russian republic of Dagestan, and a powerful bomb demolishes an apartment building housing Russian officers and their families in Buinaksk, republic's second-largest city; at least 30 people are killed and about 110 wounded in explosion; renewed fighting is unwelcome political test for Vladimir V Putin, Russia's new Prime Minister; photo; map (M)

headline: Rebuffing an Early Selloff, Dow Still Falls 63.96 Points Traders Leave Early to Beat Hurricane
abstract: Rebuy

headline: For Stock Investors, A New Star System
abstract: Morningstar Inc, best known for its star system of mutual fund rankings, begins rating individual stocks on weekly basis (S)

headline: Gates Hits $100 Billion Mark, More or Less
abstract: Worth of Microsoft co-founder and chairman Bill Gates, as result of remarkable performance of company's stock, rises to record $100 billion on July 16; company shares climb 5.4 percent to record high of $99.4375 on expectation that it will establish separate tracking stock for its Internet properties; photo (M)

headline: Ecuador Seeks To Ease Fears It May Default
abstract: Ecuador plans to renegotiate its foreign debt when payment falls due next week but does not intend to default; Finance Min Ana Lucia Armijos says Government of Pres Jamil Mahuad will propose coordinated restructuring, using market mechanisms in repaying $6 billion worth of so-called Brady bonds for which country has contracted; amount due at end of month is $94 million, but fears of Ecuadorean default have contributed to market instability throughout Latin America in last week, affecting much larger and more diversified economies like Brazil, Mexico and Argentina; no country has ever defaulted on Brady bonds, which are financial instruments devised by US with specific purpose of preventing default; Brady bonds were created in response to Latin American debt crisis of 1980's (M)

headline: Compuware to Buy a Software Vendor
abstract: Compuware Corp will acquire Viasoft Inc for $164 million (S)

headline: With No Surprises, the Markets Show Restraint
abstract: Financial markets get what many investors interpret as all-clear signal from Federal Reserve, as central bank indicates that its latest quarter-point rate increase will be enough to slow economic growth and keep inflation in check; reaction is subdued in stock and bond markets because many had anticipated Fed's announcement; Dow Jones industrial average drops 16.46 points, or two-tenths of 1 percent, to 11,283.30; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closes up 3.28, or two-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,363; Nasdaq composite index closes up 32.80 points, or 1.2 percent, at 2,752.37; price of 30-year bond rises 23/32, to 102 24/32, as yield drops to 5.93 percent from 5.98 percent; price of two-year note, which is more sensitive to Fed interest rate moves, rises 3/32, and yield drops to 5.58 percent, from 5.64 percent; graphs on fluctuations in Dow Jones industrial average and yields of selected Treasury securities; charts on stocks with large price percentage gains and losses and US key interest rates (M)

headline: A Faster Way Of Shuffling The Data Cards
abstract: E-commerce companies use algorithms, repetitive procedures for solving problems, to analyze massive amounts of data they collect about customers (M)

headline: The Best of Jurisprudence: Reliving Days in the High Court
abstract: Northwestern University Press produces Supreme Court's Greatest Hits, digital recordings of oral arguments and opinions from 50 of what legal scholars consider some of most important Supreme Court cases in last 44 years, including Roe v Wade, New York Times v Sullivan and Miranda v Arizona; photo (S)

headline: Nairobi Embassy Blast Survivors Still Struggling
abstract: Kenyans are still coming to terms with devastation year after terrorist bombing of American Embassy in Nairobi; many Kenyans, split by ethnic, religious and class differences, say blast gave them greater sense of unity; people remain divided over how to commemorate bombing's anniversary; aid handed out by Government to victims has backfired in some cases, with compensation squandered or stolen; many Kenyans want United States to provide more aid; photo (M)

headline: Postponing Trial Of Khmer Rouge
abstract: Cambodia moves to postpone trial for Khmer Rouge commander, Ta Mok, endorsing law that would extend his pretrial detention period to three years from six months (S)

headline: A Movable Epidemic; Makers of AIDS Drugs Struggle to Keep Up With Market
abstract: Drug companies scramble to introduce AIDS drugs to new types of patients, as profile of those who have AIDS broadens to include women, Hispanic people and blacks; demographic change comes at precarious time for makers of AIDS drugs; worldwide market for such drugs ballooned 123 percent, to $3.47 billion, from 1996 to 1997, but has begun to slow sharply; analysts cite several factors: that demand for drugs was so great that it hit its sales peaks quickly, that market for HIV drugs has become crowded, and that many women or low-income members of minorities do not have health insurance or thorough knowledge of illness and are not always easy to reach; photos; charts (M)

headline: I.B.M. AGREES TO ACQUIRE INTERNET SECURITY COMPANY
abstract: IBM acquires Internet-security company Dascom Inc for undisclosed price to strengthen its on-line commerce business (S)

headline: Asian Luxury Hotel Is Near a Rare Sale
abstract: Surya Semesta Internusa, company controlled by Suriadjaya family of Indonesia, reportedly plans to sell Melia Bali Hotel, Bali, to Trenwith Holdings Ltd, joint venture 70 percent owned by Rockefeller family's Rockvest Development; deal has broad implications because Asian owners view luxury hotels as symbols of business success and rarely sell them when facing other financial problems; could signal sales of other big Asian hotels; map (M)

headline: Three Points on MP3
abstract: Will Affleck-Asch letter comments on June 17 article on Rio PMP300 Personal Edition CD player that allows downloading of music from Internet (S)

headline: Editor Who Thrives on Celebrity Is Pleased With Latest Sensation
abstract: Tina Brown's latest project, Talk magazine, is most talked-about new monthly magazine in many years, even before its first issue is unveiled; Ronald A Galotti, Talk's publisher, says there is intense interest in Brown, fact Brown herself acknowledges; she has chosen risky road by introducing general-interest magazine at time when most magazine publishers are focusing on niche-oriented titles for narrowly selected audiences; first issue of Talk will hit newsstands on Aug 3, with cover price of $2.95; photos (M)

headline: Deal to Create Moving Concern
abstract: Clayton Dubilier & Rice, New York-based private equity firm that owns North American Van Lines, acquires NFC PLC's moving company, Allied Pickfords, and will combine it with North American to create world's largest mover; Clayton Dubilier will pay $450 million for Allied Pickfords (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.00   8.00   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.94   4.97   5.51        3-month T-bills   4.47   4.52   4.92        6-month T-bills   4.46   4.49   5.03        10-yr. T-infl.   4.02   4.01   3.76        10-yr. T-note   5.62   5.65   5.43        30-yr. T-bond   5.88   5.89   5.66        Telephone bd.   7.63   7.65   7.10        Municipal bds.   5.49   5.48   5.25          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Auto Workers Try to Wring DaimlerChrysler Concessions
abstract: United Automobileú

headline: DRUGSTORE CHAIN IS PLANNING TO CUT ABOUT 830 WORKERS
abstract: Rite Aid Corp, drugstore chain troubled

headline: P.& G. and Yahoo To Expand Links
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co and Yahoo Inc say they will significantly expand their relationship as Procter & Gamble seeks to intensify its advertising and marketing efforts on Internet (S)

headline: In Eye of China-Taiwan Storm, an Island Is Calm
abstract: If military conflict breaks out between China and Taiwan any time soon, military experts say, it is as likely to begin on this little island as anywhere.     A mere three miles off the coast of southeast China, Matsu still belongs to Taiwan, which is more than 100 miles away. By its location alone, Matsu is highly vulnerable to attack from the Chinese Army, and is guarded by a slim force of 6,000 Taiwan soldiers. Roughly the same number of civilians live here.

headline: U.P.S. Shifting Cargo to Trucks
abstract: United Parcel Service, citing growing delays on Conrail rail lines, increases amount of freight sent by trucks (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: FORD MOTOR CO.,  Dearborn, Mich., is shutting down an assembly plant in Wixom, Mich., for one week because of a shortage of parts for its new Lincoln LS sedan.

headline: NBC Names Ex-ABC Executive to Head TV Production Unit
abstract: NBC names Ted Harbert, former top entertainment executive at ABC, to be new president of its in-house television production unit, NBC Studios; move underscores increasing emphasis that networks are placing on producing their own programming to take advantage of potential profits from hit entertainment shows (M)

headline: NORTON, SAINT-GOBAIN SUBSIDIARY, BUYING FURON
abstract: Norton Co unit of French industrial giant Compagnie de Saint-Gobain acquires Furon Co for $25.50 a share, or about $472 million; deal also includes assumption of $116 million in debt and purchase of $29 million in outstanding options (S)

headline: Pope Repeats an Apology
abstract: Pope John Paul II asked forgiveness again today for past errors of the Catholic Church.     Speaking at his weekly general audience, the Pope said that when mistakes ''are verified by a serious historical investigation, the church feels the duty to recognize the sin of its members and to ask forgiveness from God and other Christians.''

headline: Sharp Cuts At Daewoo Car Unit
abstract: Daewoo Motor Co, South Korea's second-largest auto maker, says it plans to reduce its staff by 30 percent and reduce number of its suppliers to 300, from current 500, to lower its costs (M)

headline: Donor Implicates Mexican Party in Scandal
abstract: Carlos Cabal Peniche, financier who recently disclosed that he was donor of large sums to Pres Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon's Presidential campaign before breaking with ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party and fleeing Mexico, says that Zedillo aides pressured him during 1994 campaign to direct troubled banks to pay for $4 million worth of Zedillo-for-President posters and other expenses and that campaign sent him invoices and his banks paid bills; opposition politicians express outrage over allegations, but Zedillo spokesman and chairman of Institutional Revolutionary Party deny them; Cabal is in Australian prison battling Mexican request that Australia extradite him to face fraud charges; photo (M)

headline: Hackers Break Into Computers Of Internet's Governing Group
abstract: Hackers break into network computers run by Internet's governing body in apparent attempt to fan flames of continuing struggle for control of lucrative business of assigning Internet addresses known as domains; officials with Network Solutions, company that has monopoly in business of registering Internet addresses, says FBI is looking into attack, which company's chief technology officer, David Holtzman, says has been traced to Internet service provider in Marina del Rey, Calif; says that company, Softaware, is in same building as global network's new oversight organization, Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, or Icann (M)

headline: How Schroder's 'Dip' Is Deepening
abstract: Analysis of German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's deepening political crisis; central issue is that Germany is running out of money, and proposed deep spending cuts that will affect most Germans are very unpopular; Schroder is trying to change conservative country deeply attached to its habits; his proposed budget, designed to open way for sharp cuts in corporate and personal tax rates, is intended to jolt Germans into rethinking their lives; Schroder is charting course of less state, more personal responsibility, less enveloping social protection, more entrepreneurship; recent election results show public reaction to his plan has been violent; photo (M)

headline: For DaimlerChrysler's latest Dodge campaign, 'new' is old and 'different' is new.
abstract: DaimlerChrysler Corp says it will send tag line 'The New Dodge' to junkyard and replace it with 'Dodge Different' in what company says will be largest and most comprehensive print and television campaign in division's 85-year history; Dodge refuses to says how much it plans to spend on new marketing effort developed by Omnicom Group's BBDO Detroit (Advertising column) (M)

headline: That Annoying Beep
abstract: Letter from Thomas C Zebovitz comments on annoying electronic beep

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: PATAGON.COM INTERNATIONAL Ltd., Miami, named Daniel J. Canel president and chief operating officer. He is a former senior managing director and head of Latin American and Eastern European emerging markets at Union Bank of Switzerland, New York. Gabriel Politzer was named chief strategy officer. He had been managing director and deputy head of emerging markets for the America region at ING Baring. Patagon.com offers on-line trading in Argentina.

headline: South African to Court U.S. Investors
abstract: Pres Thabo Mbeki is set to visit New York, where he is scheduled to meet with Vice Pres Al Gore and prominent business leaders in effort to spur investment in South Africa's struggling economy (M)

headline: Fighting to Save Children From Battle
abstract: Efforts of Olara A Otunnu, United Nations official from Uganda charged with saving children from scourge of war, have led UN to begin to establish critical legal and moral framework for giving childen special status and their protection new priority; photos (M)

headline: France Says Algeria Is Emerging From the Ordeal That Began in '92
abstract: French officials say Foreign Min Hubert Vedrine's recent meetings with Pres Abdelaziz Bouteflika of Algeria have lain groundwork for renewing relations between the two countries; Vedrine says Algeria is emerging from its civil war (M)

headline: F.C.C. WILL PERMIT OWNING 2 STATIONS IN BIG TV MARKETS
abstract: Federal Communications Commission votes to allow single company or network to own two television stations in nation's largest cities, relaxing rules that have limited television-station ownership for most of century; William E Kennard, chairman of FCC, says new rule is common-sense response to dramatic changes in media marketplace in last 30 years; immediate result of new rule may be rush by big TV companies like broadcast networks to sweep up available television stations in cities where they already own station; networks seek to increase their presence in areas that are becoming increasingly crowded with other viewing options, like cable and satellite channels; for viewers in biggest markets like New York, change could lead to more local news and sports programming (M)

headline: Apple Says Shortage of Chips Will Weaken Results for Quarter
abstract: Apple Computer Inc, in first setback since return of company's co-founder Steven P Jobs two years ago, says shipments, revenue and earnings for current quarter will fall short of expectations because of smaller-than-expected deliveries of microprocessors from Motorola Inc; Jobs says Apple is going to receive only about 40 to 45 percent of microprocessors it had expected for quarter; Motorola vice president Brian Wilke says there has not been problem with with chip production, but Apple's demand has grown faster than expected (M)

headline: A Domestic Sort With Global Worries
abstract: Article profiles Samuel R Berger, Pres Clinton's national security adviser; photos; 53-year-old Cornell and Harvard educated lawyer from Millerton, New York, is Clinton's closest foreign-policy aide, but is, at bottom, a political figure with a lawyer's inherent caution; Berger wrote Clinton's much-criticized statement that he did not intend to put US troops into Kosovo, which may have caused Slobodan Milosevic to hold out longer against NATO air attacks and certainly gained Serbs time to save ethnic Albanians; Berger later said he should have put all options on table at start, but that Americans would not have supported ground war without European participation, and 19 NATO allies would not have signed on if ground war were planned; Berger also works for boss with only sporadic attention to foreign policy, at time when there is no clear policy framework; Berger has known Clinton since George McGovern's Presidential campaign of 1972 and helped Clinton in small but important ways at low points in his career; he is liked throughout Washington as trustworthy, good-natured, organized and unpretentious, with ego of normal dimensions, reading glasses bought at drug store and house he has lived in with wife, Susan, for 26 years; Berger grew up as Jew in WASP heartland, Brooklyn Dodger in Yankee town; he himself credits small-town sense of community and social responsiblity for his perspectives (L)

headline: Making Hay With 'Custom' Magazines
abstract: Custom published magazines have grown into big business for publishers, generating $650 million annually for industry; created from scratch, they allow greater control over mix of feature articles and elaborate product placement; photos (M)

headline: China Steps Up Its Drive to Halt Dissident Sect
abstract: China steps up its offensive against Buddhist Law movement, announcing ban on organization and unleashing barrage of charges against its founder that reveal how seriously Government takes sect as a challenge to its control; Government's ban on group, known in Chinese as Falun Gong, has been rumored since police rounded up more than 100 leaders of sect in several Chinese cities this week; but ferocity of Beijing's campaign--aimed at a group of mainly middle-aged people who practice form of Chinese breathing exercises and meditation--suggests that it regards Falun Gong as more than a movement of physical and moral uplift; at a time when China's economy is slowing and social unrest is rising, officials view amorphous but fast-growing sect as a dangerous political force; photo of several Falun Gong members exercising (M)

headline: More Trouble With Rebates
abstract: Letter from Albert Best says rebate victims and computer owners in general need to educate themselves about Small Claims Courts when businesses deal with them unfairly (Sept 16 article)

headline: KOREAN CEMENT DEAL
abstract: Lafarge SA of France will buy cement business of South Korea's insolvent Halla Group for at least $345 million; Lafarge reaches agreement with RH Cement, formerly known as Halla Cement Manufacturing Corp, and could buy unit by end of September; graph (S)

headline: Banking Scandal Threatens Efforts to Change Indonesia
abstract: Indonesian banking scandal widens and threatens economic overhaul as ruling party lawmakers join opposition in calling for resignation of Finance Minister Bambang Subianto and Glenn M S Yusuf, chairman of Bank Restructuring Agency (M)

headline: Economic Scene; The ins and outs of putting a price tag on product safety.
abstract: Economic Scene column on jury verdict that ordered General Motors Corp to pay $4.9 billion to six people severely burned when fuel tank of their 1979 Chevrolet Malibu exploded after drunken driver ran into them; says verdict leaves unanswered what exactly General Motors did that was reprehensible; holds jury may have choked on notion that car manufacturers trade off benefits and costs when designing safety features, but so do Government regulators operating on behalf of consumers (M)

headline: Datek Sets Volume Mark
abstract: Internet broker Datek Online says it has achieved Wall Street first, executing 1,000 trades in 90 minutes before markets opened at 9:30 AM (S)

headline: Agent for the Women of the Hour
abstract: Profile of Sue Rodin, who has become one of few sports agents specializing in representing women; three of her nine clients are Women's World Cup champion soccer players; photo (M)

headline: Purchase for Macromedia
abstract: Macromedia Inc acquires Elemental Software for about $24 million in stock (S)

headline: Madison Avenue sees another spate of deals, including some acquisitions overseas.
abstract: Grey Advertising Inc acquires Beyond Interactive; JDA Advertising buys Hurst Group; Earle Palmer Brown Cos acquires KSK Communications Ltd; Jack Morton Co acquires Instructional Design Group; Porter Novelli and Millsport team up to form joint venture, Porter Novelli Millsport Sports, formally establishing existing collaborative efforts for clients; Bob Druckenmiller, Jim Millman and Juslie Winskie will add duties of jointly leading venture as senior counsels; Draft Worldwide acquires Strategic Solutions; Publicis SA aquires AMA in Manila and majority stake in Publi-Graphics in Beirut, Lebanon; WPP Group PLC acquires 49 percent stake it does not already own in Grill & Gull Thompson GmbH, Vienna, on behalf of its J Walter Thompson agency; NPD Group and Gfk AG acquire from third partner, Audits and Surveys Worldwide Inc, its stake in Intelect ASW, which is renamed NPD Intelect (M)

headline: Blowing the Whistle
abstract: Letter by Joan Z Bernstein, director of Bureau of Consumer Protection of Federal Trade Commission, notes FTC Website for consumer complaints (July 8 article)

headline: GEORGIA GULF GETTING U.S. VINYL BUSINESS OF RWE
abstract: Georgia Gulf Corp to acquire US vinyl business of RWE AG of Germany for $270 million (S)

headline: Kaufman & Broad Earnings Climb 36%
abstract: Kaufman & Broad Home Corp says earnings for its fiscal third quarter ended Aug 31 rose 36 percent, beating expectations; net income rose to $38.2 million from $28.1 million a year earlier; revenue increased 60 percent, to $1.06 billion (S)

headline: SECURITIES UNIT INVESTIGATED
abstract: Republic New York Corp, which owns Bank of New York, says its securities unit is being investigated by Japanese regulators because of transactions with unidentified client; regulators in Japan are investigating Tokyo branch of company affiliated with client of Republic New York Securities Corp's Philadelphia office; Republic says it is also investigating and replaced management of unit's futures division; it also suspended securities unit's chief executive (S)

headline: Rules Issued on Year 2000 Compliance
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission votes to shut down any broker-dealer or nonbank transfer agent whose computer systems are not Year 2000 compliant, beginning December 1 (S)

headline: Ingram Micro Loses Its Chief, And Its Shares Plummet 31%
abstract: Jerre L Stead says he will step down as chief executive of Ingram Micro Inc, world's largest wholesale distributor of computer equipment, after three years in that post; analysts suspect Stead is being pushed out by board after Ingram disappoints Wall Street in three of last four quarters; in latest report, Ingram says it will earn 10 cents to 14 cents a share in third quarter, sharply below 41 cents that analysts had estimated; analysts suspect it will be difficult for Ingram to find suitable replacement for Stead, because industry is oversupplied; photo (M)

headline: Kosovo Now Losing War Against Winter
abstract: Residents of Pec, Kosovo, are coping as best they can with infrastructure that was destroyed in war; relief aid is arriving slowly, and many residents have given up on their expectations for reconstruction help from Western powers that drove Serbs out of Kosovo; Kosovo's long and miserable winter is just two months away; United Nations official Dennis McNamara estimates that 300,000 to 400,000 people in Kosovo do not have habitable homes for winter; map; photos (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.00   8.00   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.94   4.90   5.70        3-month T-bills   4.57   4.56   4.99        6-month T-bills   4.49   4.51   5.00        10-yr. T-infl.   4.02   4.00   3.77        10-yr. T-note   5.72   5.70   5.49        30-yr. T-bond   5.91   5.90   5.70        Telephone bd.   7.66   7.65   7.14        Municipal bds.   5.51   5.51   5.25          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate;  The Bond Buyer

headline: Deal Suggested For Trade Group Post
abstract: Bangladesh and Australia introduce compromise proposal to end deadlock over next head of World Trade Organization; proposal would allow two contenders to split one term; divisive process of choosing between Mike Moore, former New Zealand Prime Minister, and Supachai Panitchpakdi, Thailand's Deputy Prime Minister, has undermined trust among member nations of group (S)

headline: Ex-Broker Faces Broader Federal Charges
abstract: Randolph Pace, person prosecutors say was the mastermind behind big securities fraud in early to mid-1990's, is charged with directing wider conspiracy that involved three brokerage firms, manipulation of 11 companies' stocks and $200 million in illegal profits; Pace has been under indictment since November on charges of manipulating shares of six companies through Sterling Foster, defunct NY securities firm that prosecutors say he secretly controlled; prosecutors also say Pace and Alan Novich enlisted aid of eight individuals, including employees and top management at VTR Capital and Investors Associates, two defunct brokerage firms, to help manipulate stock and reap illegal profits; list of companies whose shares were underwritten by VTR and Investors Associates (M)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: EUROPE; NEW DOUBTS ABOUT TV MERGER
abstract: Central European Media Enterprises Ltd has come one step closer to losing its prize asset, TV Nova, successful Czech commercial station; Vladimir Zelezny, who was dismissed as the station's director but who seized control of TV Nova's broadcasting license pending court decision, says he will no longer use services of Central European Media's Czech subsidiary; move is seen as increasing risk that Central European Media's planned merger with SBS Broadcasting SA may have to be renegotiated or abandoned (S)

headline: PC 101: Some Tips For Fall
abstract: State of the Art column notes it has become increasingly difficult to succeed in college without computer; offers tips to college students and their parents about buying personal computer; notes some large universities offer students free access to computers on campus (M)

headline: Airlines Offer Discounts Through Web Sites
abstract: United States airlines are offering discounts of up to 10 percent to lure people to book tickets on airline Web sites, cost-cutting effort that is hurting travel agents (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro slips against dollar on news that July's increase in US producer prices was less than expected; in New York, euro settles at $.0564, down from $1.0669; charts (S)

headline: Graying, in Black and White
abstract: Fred Brock Seniority column on rise in advertising directed toward baby boomers as oldest ones move closer to retirement; offers sampling of books on senior matters, including Linda and Bob Kalian's The Best Free Things for Seniors, John F Walsik's The Late-Start Investor and Ken Dychtwald's Age Power: How the 21st Century Will be Ruled by the New Old; drawing (M)

headline: Hints of a Possible Bidding War for Reynolds Metals
abstract: Prospects of bidding war for Reynolds Metals Co arises when executives in planned merger of Canada's Alcan Aluminium, Pechiney SA of France and Alusuisse Lonza Group of Switzerland suggest they might try to outbid Alcoa Inc's $5.8 billion hostile takeover; hints dropped by Jacques Bougie, chief executive of Alcan, and Jean-Pierre Rodier, chairman of Pechiney add to tumult in global aluminum industry, where depressed prices and plentiful supplies are forcing competitors to cut costs and scramble for partners (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SUNTRUST BANKS INC.,  Atlanta, the ninth-biggest United States bank, said it would buy back up to 15 million shares, or 4.7 percent of its 321.6 million shares outstanding, over an unspecified period. The buyback is worth about $950 million.    CONOCO GLOBAL POWER,  Houston, a unit of Conoco Inc., the fifth-largest United States oil company, said it would build a $250 million, 420-megawatt power plant to provide steam and electricity to the DuPont Sabine River Works nylon feedstock plant near Orange, Tex.

headline: Treasuries Fall on Consumer Price Concerns
abstract: Bond prices fall on declining dollar, rise in crude-oil prices and unexpected economic growth in Japan; 30-year bond falls 9/32, to 100 17/32, to yield 6.09 percent, up from 6.07 percent; graphs (M)

headline: Fearful of Militias, East Timor to Vote on Its Future
abstract: East Timor, after 24 years of bloodshed and fear, reaches its moment of truth, referendum on Aug 30 that could lead it into new era of freedom and reconciliation or one of even fiercer civil war; referendum offers choice between independence or an autonomous relationship with Indonesia, which invaded former Portuguese colony in 1975 and has fought against separatist rebels ever since; but as vote has drawn near, what should been an election campaign in tiny, remote territory has been instead a campaign of terror by brutal, ragtag militias that oppose independence; militias, backed and organized by Indonesian military, have largely ignored appeals for calm from United Nations, which deployed in East Timor in May to organize referendum; Sec Gen Kofi Annan says he is 'appalled' by continuing attacks and demands that Indonesian security forcess fulfill their obligation to maintain order; map (L)

headline: DROP IN UNEMPLOYMENT
abstract: France's jobless rate unexpectedly declined to 11.2 percent in July, lowest since February 1993, from 11.2 percent in June; Government report shows production rose more than expected in June; graph on unemployment (S)

headline: Israel's Premier Is First State Visitor to 'Berlin Republic'
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak, accompanied by survivors of Nazi concentration camp, arrives in Berlin on first state visit to German capital since Government moved from Bonn in Aug; photo of Barak with German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder (M)

headline: Banker Is Cleared in Orange County Case
abstract: US District Judge Gary L Taylor dismisses Securities and Exchange Commission case against former Dain Rauscher investment banker Kenneth D Ough who was charged with failing to tell investors risks of buying $800 million in bonds by local governments in Orange County, Calif (S)

headline: Morris D. Crawford Jr., 83; Headed Bowery Savings Bank
abstract: Morris D Crawford Jr, who headed Bowery Savings Bank from 1965 until 1980, dies at age 83; photo (M)

headline: The Game as Elegant Fashion Statement
abstract: J C Herz reviews Wipeout 3, latest version of futuristic racing computer game from Psygnosis; photos (M)

headline: Praising the Virtual Campus
abstract: Paulette Mark letter notes value of on-line courses for thousands of people who cannot attend school on a college campus (Sept 2 article)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: ASIA    INDIA: KASHMIR POLITICIAN SLAIN -- A leader of the ruling National Conference party in the state of Kashmir was killed and 26 people injured in attacks by suspected separatist militants a day before a parliamentary election. Earlier this month a parliamentary candidate with the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party was killed in a land-mine blast for which militants battling Indian rule have been held responsible.   Celia W. Dugger (NYT)    MALAYSIA: ANWAR WIFE'S PLEA -- The wife of the jailed former Deputy Prime Minister, Anwar Ibrahim, appealed to authorities to let her visit her husband in the hospital where he is being treated for suspected arsenic poisoning. Wan Azizah Wan Ismail said she had been denied permission to visit since Wednesday.   (Agence France-Presse)

headline: Barak on Europe's Role
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak, in London, tells British Prime Min Tony Blair that NATO effort in Kosovo shows Britain and European Union can play significant roles in Mideast peacemaking; Blair pledges full British backing for peace effort; lauds Barak (M)

headline: Brazil Steelmaker to Add U.S. Link to Pan-American Chain
abstract: Brazilian steelmaker Gerdau SA to buy 75 percent stake in Ameristeel Corp from Kyoei Steel Ltd; deal throws into question assumption that Gerdau would buy Companhia Siderurgica Nacional, Brazil's largest steelmaker (M)

headline: DELANCEY PLANS DEAL
abstract: British property company controlled by financier George Soros, Delancey Estates PLC, agrees to acquire rival, Milner Estates PLC, for $278.4 million (S)

headline: Auto Sales Rose Sharply In August
abstract: Many auto makers says sales soared in August, with biggest growth occurring for some of most expensive models with highest profits; DaimlerChrysler AG says its Chrysler, Dodge, Plymouth, Jeep and Mercedes-Benz brands had their best August ever, together climbing 9.6 percent from August 1998 sales; Honda Motor reports its sales climbed 10.5 percent from year earlier, to highest level ever for any month, while Toyota Motor reports its best August ever in US with 2.8 percent increase; General Motors says its sales jumped 63.4 percent; sales in August 1998 were severely depressed because 54-day strike had just ended and dealerships had not yet been restocked; Nissan Motor reports 7.7 percent drop in sales, Subaru a 9.1 percent increase, Mitsubishi Motors a 42.8 percent jump and Volkswagen AG a 33.8 percent increase (M)

headline: Under Fire, Yeltsin Is Defended By His Wife
abstract: Pres Boris N Yeltsin's wife, Naina, delivers emotional defense of her family, giving rare television interview in hope of dispelling mounting allegations of corruption; this marks first time that member of Yeltsin family has addressed nation in charges that Pres Yeltsin and his youngest daughter, Tatyana Dyachenko, received kickbacks from construction firm; neither Mrs Yeltsin nor interviewer deal with accusations in any detail; Yeltsin portrays her family as people of modest means, the victims of sensationalist and politically biased press and jealous rivals; Mrs Yeltsin is most popular member of generally unpopular family; she may be family's best hope to influence public opinion; photo (M)

headline: Stock-Options Listing Battle Heats Up
abstract: Chicago Board Options Exchange, in most aggressive move yet in battle for supremacy over stock-options trading, plans to list options on additional 29 stocks, including some listed on Pacific Exchange (S)

headline: U.N. Chief Wants Faster Action To Avoid Slaughter in Civil Wars
abstract: United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan addresses world leaders at opening day of debate in General Assembly; urges Security Council to act faster and more effectively to meet challenge of world engulfed in civil wars that quickly descend into slaughter of helpless civilians; says countries that have resisted international intervention will no longer be able to hide behind protestations of national sovereignty when they flagrantly violate rights of citizens; Annan's unusually strong criticism of Council's initial failure to deal with genocide in Rwanda in 1994 and its inability to agree on responding to Serbian atrocities in Kosovo are oblique references to American policy decisions; Pres Clinton will address assembly on second day; photo (M)

headline: Japanese Premier Is Off to Mend Fences (He Hopes) With China
abstract: Japanese Prime Min Keizo Obuchi leaves on major visit to China that aims to soothe relations and improve outlook for China's admission to World Trade Organization by end of year (M)

headline: Brainstorming at 7. Kayaking at 11. Now That's Teamwork.
abstract: Article, citing continuing US economic boom, on rise in number of corporate meetings, conferences, retreats, training sessions and incentive trips; some unusual corporate retreat sites described; photos (L)

headline: Charles Roman, the Brains Behind the Brawn, Dies at 92
abstract: Charles P. Roman, the not particularly husky ad man and executive who created classic advertisements for the bodybuilder Charles Atlas, including the one about a 97-pound weakling, died on Friday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 92 and lived in the Chelsea section of Manhattan.    Mr. Roman did much to gain fame for the once-skinny Mr. Atlas, born Angelo Siciliano in Brooklyn, for whom the Charles Atlas bodybuilding course is named. Mr. Atlas has been called the Horatio Alger of the human body. After Mr. Atlas died in Florida in 1972, still a fine figure of a man at 78, Mr. Roman labored for years in his Manhattan office to keep the Charles Atlas legend going.

headline: MASCO MAKES FIVE ACQUISITIONS FOR $3.8 BILLION
abstract: Masco Corp, largest US maker of kitchen cabinets and bathroom fixtures, acquires five home-improvement products companies for about $3.8 billion in cash, stock and assumed debt; companies are Behr Process, Mill's Pride, Arrow Fastener, Inrecon and Superia Radiatoren (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Albright to Ask China to Set Taiwan Talks
abstract: Sec of State Madeleine K Albright says she will appeal for peaceful resolution of Taiwan-China dispute at meeting with China's Foreign Min, Tang Jiaxuan; Pres Clinton tells Pres Jiang Zemin of China that he would take very seriously any abridgement of peaceful dialogue; Albright also says United States is concerned by reports that Chinese companies provided North Korea with missile components (S)

headline: Russia Frees Journalist Who Exposed Nuclear Dumping
abstract: Russian military court drops treason charge against Grigory Pasko, who disclosed Navy's dumping at sea of nuclear wastes; rules he overstepped authority as military journalist; grants him amnesty; Pasko, who spent 20 months in jail, says he will fight for complete vindication; photo (M)

headline: Shaping a Spinoff
abstract: Kansas City Southern Industries executives, pondering question of what to do with its most valuable asset, Janus Capital Corp, favor spinning it off by itself, which would give it higher valuation (S)

headline: What Business Was That You Said You Were In?
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission halts trading in thinly-traded public company Uniprime Capital Acceptance of Las Vegas following claim that Spanish doctor working in Portugal for obscure Uniprime subsidiary had developed herbs-and-vitamins cure for AIDS (S)

headline: Tests Trace Turin Shroud to Jerusalem Before A.D. 700
abstract: Scientists attending International Botanical Congress in St Louis report that analysis of pollen grains and plant images taken from Shroud of Turin, believed by many Christians to be burial shroud of Jesus, places cloth's origin in or near Jerusalem before eighth century; finding seems to contradict radiocarbon dating tests, which in 1988 led experts to put origin of cloth at between AD 1260 and 1390 and to conclude that it was most likely medieval forgery (M)

headline: Chief of Smart Car Division At Daimler to Step Down
abstract: Lars Brorsen, chief executive of DaimlerChrysler AG's struggling smart car business, will resign at end of September; surprise resignation comes just as sales of quirky two-seater in class of tiny vehicles known as city cars finally appear to be picking up; no successor is named; news of resignation overshadows introduction of two new Smart models at Frankfurt International Auto Show (M)

headline: ITALIAN MERGER REPORT
abstract: Italian newspaper La Repubblica says Italy's largest bank by assets, San Paolo INI, and Istituto Nazionale Assicurazioni, one of Italy's biggest insurers, have decided to study possiblity of merging companies in September; proposed merger would also include Banco di Napoli; INA already owns 51 percent of Banco di Napoli's holding company (S)

headline: Day Care for the Dog, Peace for the Owner
abstract: American Board and Kennel Association estimates that 500 of more than 8,500 kennels nationwide specialize in day care for dogs; photo (M)

headline: MEDIACONSULT.COM AGREES TO BUY PHYSICIANS' ONLINE
abstract: Mediconsult.com Inc to buy Physicians' Online Inc for $166.5 million in stock and assumption of $13.5 million in debt (S)

headline: Orangemen Scale Down Ulster March, Avoiding Conflict
abstract: Ulster's Orangemen stage just a token procession in Portadown and say they hope their step back from confrontation will gain them an end to the ban on parading along their traditional route; British troops go to great lenghts to prevent a Protestant-Catholic confrontation; photos; map (M)

headline: People
abstract: Janet M Thompson is named president and chief executive at Designory Inc; Ron Bernstein is named to new position of vice president for advertising sales at Compuserve; Jack Rotherham, acting associate publisher at Rolling Stone, is named associate publisher; Beth Press is named advertising director at Teen magazine, succeeding Laurianne Murphy, who was promoted to publisher (S)

headline: Bank Inquiry Intensifies; Reno Taking 'Personal Interest'
abstract: Atty Gen Janet Reno and British authorities step up interest in money-laundering investigation at Bank of New York and House Banking Committee sets hearings on international financial corruption; Repr Jim Leach says issue is whether foreign theft is facilitated by self-serving practices of Western banks; probe involves huge money transfers involving Benex Worldwide Ltd, whose owner, Peter Berlin, is married to Lucy Edwards, Russian-born bank executive in London; she reported to Natasha Gurfinkel Kagalovsky; both have been suspended; chronology of suspicious money dealings (M)

headline: Goliath.com Still Winning, but David Has an On-Line Sling
abstract: Janice Maloney article on inexpensive or free Web development services from giants like IBM and boutiques like Turnstyle.com and Bigstep.com that offer small retailers chance to compete with big companies that now dominate Internet commerce; mom and pop shops are coming onto Internet in droves, bringing their personality and ingenuity and passion for what they do; photos (M)

headline: Italy's Biggest Insurer Makes Hostile Bid for a Competitor
abstract: Assicurazioni Generali SpA, Italy's largest insurer, announces hostile $12.8 billion bid for domestic rival, Istituto Nazionale delle Assicurazioni SpA; if deal succeeds, it will undo plans for friendly merger between Istituto Nazionale and San Paolo-IMI SpA (M)

headline: News Corp.'s Earnings Fell In 4th Quarter
abstract: News Corp's earnings before extraordinary item fell 20 percent in its fourth fiscal quarter; reports after-tax earnings of $214 million for three months ended June 30, down from $266 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue for quarter edged up to $3.27 billion from $3.24 billion in 1998; Fox Entertainment Group, which is 83 percent owned by News Corp, says net income in quarter ended June 30 jumped to $35 million from $3 million a year earlier; revenue increased more than 12 percent, to $1.97 billion from $1.75 billion (M)

headline: Despite Upturn in Rates, Dow Still Gains 95.62 Points
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 95.62 points, to close at 11,066.42; Nasdaq composite index rises 20.06 points, to close at 2,706.18, and Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 8.25 points, to close at 1,380.96; US Treasury yields finish slightly higher; benchmark 30-year Treasury bond falls 18/32, to 89 20/32; yield rises to 6 percent, up from 5.96 percent; graph on Dow Jones industrial average; charts on stocks with large price percentage gains and losses and US key interest rates (M)

headline: Business Travel
abstract: Most major airline carriers report record or near-record passenger loads in last few months; anyone who joins British Airways frequent-flier program and then takes trans-Atlantic flight on full-fare business-class round-trip ticket, or two one-way tickets, will receive two free coach tickets to almost anywhere in world; specifics of deal noted; analysts are not convinced that Carnival Corp will succeed in buying Princess Cruises, but neither do they think it is pipe dream, especially since Carnival has confirmed that it has held talks with Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Co, Princess's British owner (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: Book Industry Study Shows Sales Increased 4% Last Year
abstract: Book Industry Study Group reports sales of adult hard-cover and trade paperback books rose over 4 percent in 1998 to 497 million copies; forecasts sales growth of over 2 percent annually through 2003, indication that on-line sales are not expected to increase market for popular books; sales of children's books rose 6 percent, emerging from 1997 slump; graphs (M)

headline: Of Bombs and Israeli Arabs, and Years of Loyalty
abstract: Deaths of three Israeli Arabs in two car bomb explosions in Hafia and Tiberias on September 5 send shock waves through Israeli Arab communities; perhaps first suicide car-bombing attempt by Israeli Arabs has horrified many Arabs in small community of Mashad, who fear they may all be tarred with same brush as Palestinian militants from West Bank and Gaza; photos; map (M)

headline: G.M. Internet Sales Hit Snag in Texas
abstract: General Motors Corp is denied license by Texas motor vehicles division to sell used cars directly to Houston customers through Internet because Texas does not let manufacturers own or control dealerships (S)

headline: A Survivor Helps Track French Debt Of Wartime
abstract: Adolphe Steg, veteran of French Resistance during World War II who later became famous surgeon, is deputy chairman of blue-ribbon panel set up by French government in 1997 to establish facts about looting of bank accounts, insurance policies, art works and other property from Jews in France during war; committee plans to publish findings this year and make recommendations on restoring what still remains in wrong hands to rightful owners or their survivors; Steg and Claire Andrieu, French historian who is member of panel, will appear before House Banking and Financial Services Committee in Washington on Sept 14 (M)

headline: Gap and Kmart Both Post Rises In Their Second-Quarter Profits
abstract: Gap Inc and Kmart Corp say second-quarter profit rose; net income at Gap rose 43 percent, to $195.8 million, compared with $136.9 million a year ago; revenue for quarter ended July 31 jumped 29 percent, to $2.45 billion; Kmart's profit rose 44 percent, to $134 million, compared with $93 million in quarter a year earlier; sales rose 7.9 percent, to $8.76 billion (M)

headline: Washington, Sensing a Chance for Fresh Momentum on Mideast Peace, Awaits Barak
abstract: Pres Clinton and advisers, buoyed almost to point of ebullience by prospect of fresh momentum in Middle East peace effort with new Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak, hope Barak's upcoming visit will be opening chapter of comprehensive peace settlement that will culminate near end of Clinton's term; confluence of number of factors, including Barak's quest for peace with both Syrians and Palestinians and seeming willingness of Arab leaders to negotiate, has convinced Administration it can capitalize on rare moment; photo (M)

headline: Co-Chairmen Split Duties at Citigroup
abstract: Citigroup co-chairmen, Sanford Weill and John Reed, will split responsibility for managing company; Weill will oversee operating businesses and financial functions; Reed will maintain responsibility for Internet, technology, human resources and legal issues (S)

headline: SARA LEE TO ACQUIRE 2 BRANDS FROM DAWSON
abstract: Sara Lee Corp to buy Duofold and J E Morgan apparel brands from Dawson International PLC for $95.7 million in cash (S)

headline: CHEMDEX SHARES SOAR ON NEWS OF PROMEDIX PURCHASE
abstract: Shares of Chemdex Corp rise 16 percent after it says it will buy Promedix.com for about $388.7 million in stock to begin selling medical products to hospitals (S)

headline: How to Invest By a Different Book
abstract: Crosswalk.com, publicly traded Internet portal described as leading host and advocate for online Christian community, has investing site that, for fee, evaluates holdings according to values-based criteria (S)

headline: Lucent to Buy Consultant For $3.7 Billion in Stock
abstract: Lucent Technologies Inc agrees to buy International Network Services Inc, fast-growing consulting company, for $3.7 billion in stock; International Network is essentially temporary-employment agency for network engineers (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH: Erin Sullivan; Fidelity Aggressive Growth Fund
abstract: Profile of Fidelity Investments manager Erin Sullivan, who comments on her accomplishments as manager of Fidelity Aggressive Growth fund since April 1997; photo; chart; graph (M)

headline: Oil Scorecard: Texaco Drops, ARCO Soars
abstract: Texaco Inc reports second-quarter net income fell to $273 million, from $342 million in 1998 period; reports operating earnings fell to $286 million, from $335 million; ARCO reports net income of $313 million, up from $154 million in 1998 period; reports operating earnings rose to $302 million, from $220 million (M)

headline: Yield Slides To 6.04% On Treasuries
abstract: Treasury securities rise for the second consecutive session as pricing of huge debt issue by Wal-Mart Stores Inc fails to hurt sale of United States Government paper; 30-year bond gains 23/32 to 89 7/32, to yield 6.04 percent, down from 6.09 percent; graph (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Hog prices rise as meatpackers increase purchases to make up for dearth of market-ready animals last month; in Chicago, hogs for October delivery rise 1.125 cents, to 46.775 cents a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Lucent in Deal to Develop Digital Radios
abstract: Lucent Technologies Inc says its radio division will join Harman International Industries and Recoton Corp in developing radio receivers that can read digital signals; Lucent Digital Radio says it is also in talks with Pioneer Corp of Japan for similar agreement to make digital receivers (S)

headline: Newspaper Web Sites That Look Like Print
abstract: Newzprint, new service from Infopager Technologies, downloads news from more than 30 newspapers, then reformats it into something that resembles newspaper on computer monitor, with columns, bold headlines and even illustrated thumbs holding paper aloft; photo (S)

headline: CLINTON AND JIANG HEAL RIFT AND SET NEW TRADE COURSE
abstract: Pres Clinton and China Pres Jiang Zemin, in Auckland, New Zealand, for Asian economic summit conference, declare end to months of frozen relations following bombing of Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, and their trade ministers begin meeting in hopes of closing deal that will get China into World Trade Organization this year; Chinese officials are pleased that Clinton has been critical of Taiwan Pres Lee Teng Hui for his statements describing island as separate state (M)

headline: Ford Reports Surprisingly Strong Sales For August
abstract: Ford Motor Co says August sales rose 8.1 percent, compared with year earlier, making last month the best August ever for auto sales in the United States and best month in 1990's after adjusting for seasonal variations in demand; chart on US vehicle sales in August as reported by major auto makers (M)

headline: Olivetti Rejiggering Telecom Italia to Pay Debt
abstract: Olivetti SpA, Italian company that gained control of Telecom Italia in May, says it is reshuffling telecommunications giant, in move that would help it repay debt it took on to acquire its larger domestic rival; Olivetti chairman Roberto Colaninno says Telecom Italia will shift its 60 percent stake in Telecom Italia Mobile to Tecnost, Olivetti gambling machine subsidiary that was used as vehicle in acquiring Telecom Italia; Olivetti parked $15.6 billion of debt it took on to acquire Telecom Italia in Tecnost (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: JOHN WOOD GROUP P.L.C.,  Abderdeen, Scotland, an energy-services company, agreed to buy Kreisler Manufacturing Corp., St. Petersburg, Fla., a maker of metal parts for aircraft engines, for $25.5 million.

headline: VIGILANTES ACTIVE
abstract: Street battles rage through huge swaths of Teheran as police fire tear gas and weapons at demonstrators and passers-by, in scenes eerily reminiscent of Islamic revolution two decades ago; photos; map; violence closes businesses and even capital's vast bazaar; tens of thousands of police, soldiers, Revolutionary Guards, armed mobs and street thugs fan out from Teheran University; reformist Pres Mohammad Khatami abruptly shifts tone after meeting with Islamic leaders, and condemns nationwide demonstrations that have left at least two people dead and countless others injured or behind bars; officials make clear that no further protests will be tolerated; vast pro-Government demonstration planned; protests and crackdown recall year that led up to 1979 revolution that overthrew shah and installed ayatollahs; students began with protest against law curbing press; they seek faster progress toward democracy and cultural freedom, but are not calling for change in Islamic system of government; chaos on streets on both sides described (M)

headline: In Home Ownership Data, A Hidden Generation Gap
abstract: Louis Uchitelle Economic View column assesses somber reality of perceived rise in American home ownership during current economic boom; statistics show that households headed by older Americans, since 1980's, continue to be majority of home owners; ownership in every age group under 55 remains below early 1980's figures (M)

headline: Italian Banks in Merger, but French Banks Fail to End Fight
abstract: Boards of Banca Intesa and Banca Commerciale Italiana in Milan approve $15 billion stock swap, creating what will be Italy's largest banking group; in Paris, governor of Bank of France is unable to negotiate end to five-month-old confrontation over $38 billion hostile bid by Banque Nationale de Paris for rivals Societe Generale and Paribas, leaving it up to investors to decide outcome (M)

headline: LOSS AT LOEWEN
abstract: Loewen Group, operating under bankruptcy protection in US and Canada, reports second-quarter loss of $105.3 million, compared with year-earlier earnings of $10.2 million (S)

headline: An Eye on Your E-Mail
abstract: High Probability Selling president Jacques Werth letter on July 18 article about companies that monitor workers' e-mail; holds employees and companies should share responsibility for offensive e-mail (S)

headline: P.& G. to Tie Agency Compensation to Sales
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co, world's largest advertiser, plans major changes in how it pays agencies that create campaigns for its 300 household brands around the world; effective July 1, 2000, P&G, will no longer pay agencies commissions based on what is spent to advertise products; from that date, company will base compensation on sales objectives, with agencies being paid more if brand's sales increase and less if sales decline; many marketers have already replaced traditional commission system with performance-based compensation: calculating agency payments on predetermined, measurable goods like growth in sales, increased awareness of a brand or gaining broad distribution for new product; decision by P&G to join their ranks is likely to accelerate shift to performance-based compensation (Advertising column) (M)

headline: Humbled By the Company He Kept
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson profiles change in fortune for Richard Harriton, whose tough competitive stance successfully guided Bear Stearns Securities Corp, clearing house unit of Bear Stearns Companies; Harriton's problems stem from his failure to recognize Securities and Exchange Commission's seriousness in its scrutiny of small, dubious brokerage firms among Harriton's clients; Bear Stearns agreed in principle to settle SEC fraud charges that agency is preparing to bring against Harriton's unit; case, which concerns Bear Stears dealings with A R Baron, brokerage firm that Manhattan prosecutors called criminal enterprise, recalled; biggest question in case is how could smart person like Harriton have made series of bad judgments that have put his firm and career at peril to point where Bear Stearns executives are toning down their all-out defense of his conduct; photos; chart on brokerage firm trades (L)

headline: Algerian Work for G.E.
abstract: General Electric Co says its Italian unit has agreed to build power plant for Algeria's state-owned oil company Sonatrach for $107 million; new plant will serve Ghadames oilfield in southeastern Algeria (S)

headline: G.M. and Ford Report Gains In June Car and Truck Sales
abstract: General Motors Corp and Ford Motor Co report that car and truck sales edged higher in June as entire auto industry recorded its best June in history and second-best month ever; Ward's Communications says industry sales of cars and light trucks totaled 1.6 million vehicles in June, a 2 percent increase over sales of year ago; GM sold 493,475 cars and trucks in June, up 1 percent; Ford says sales rose 5 percent from year earlier, to 422,979 cars and light trucks (M)

headline: Anti-Milosevic Rallies to Begin Tonight in Belgrade
abstract: Opposition parties in Belgrade plan series of rallies and demonstrations in effort to bring down Pres Slobodan Milosevic; Zoran Djindjic, one leader, says outcome is up to Serbian people; Milosevic's Government is exploiting public's deep and aviding inseurity and fear of chaos and civil war; Djindjic says point of demonstrations is to turn thoses concerns into collective action (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Copper posts its biggest one-day gain ever after Phelps Dodge becomes second mining company in a week to cut output; in New York, copper for July delivery rises 5.15 cents, to 75.95 cents a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Lowe Group Creates The Octagon Brand
abstract: Lowe Group is rebranding its sports marketing and entertainment operations under name Octagon; Frank Lowe, chief executive at Lowe, remains chairman and chief executive; Frank Craighill continues as president (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Playboy Loses Round Over Search Engine Ads
abstract: Federal Judge Alicemarie H Stotler of California seemingly gives green light to common but controversial Internet advertising practice of placing ads with search results for trademarked words; at issue is request by Playboy Enterprises to stop Web search services Excite.com and Netscape.com from placing ads for pornography sites with search results for words 'playboy' or 'playmate'; photo (M)

headline: As America Online's No. 2 Brand These Days, Compuserve Is Being Rejuvenated
abstract: American Online reports that Compuserve, a former rival which it now owns, added 300,000 subscribers so far in its fiscal first quarter; Compuserve has been offering cash rebates to new subscribers who buy certain brands of computers and agree to sign up for three years of Internet access at $21.95 a month; AOL executives consider surge in Compuserve subscriptions a sign of healthy growth in a cutthroat industry; see it also as vindication of their view that Internet access market will fragment into different consumer tiers, including 'premium' tiers like AOL and 'value' tiers like Compuserve; photo (M)

headline: Silicon Valley's Own Work Threatens Its Domination
abstract: A T Kearney survey for Joint Venture: Silicon Valley Network shows that booming Internet economy is decentralizing technology industries and threatening Silicon Valley's domination of all things digital; shows that Internet companies--and economic growth they reap--are expanding rapidly in seven regions outside of Valley: Seattle, Los Angeles, Austin, Tex, Boston, New York City, District of Columbia, and San Francisco's 'Multimedia Gulch' (M)

headline: Jobs and Pay Grow, Stoking Inflation Fear
abstract: Labor Department reports employers added some 310,000 nonfarm jobs in July, unemployment rate remained steady at 4.3 percent and average hourly earnings rose 0.5 percent, to $13.29, continuing gradual acceleration of wage growth in recent months; growth in jobs and wages underscores mounting pressures in labor market and increases likelihood Federal Reserve will raise interest rates to curb inflation; news spurs sharp drop in Treasury bond prices; graph (M)

headline: Streetwise Styles Show Off the Body : Young Japan Breaks Free
abstract: PARIS—  Ask a fashion aficionado to describe Japanese style, and adjectives such as poetic, purist, complex and intellectual inevitably come up.
