The thought-provoking shapes, ground-breaking fabrics and personal vision that have put Rei Kawakubo, Yohji Yamamoto and Issey Miyake in the forefront of design have also become synonymous with Japanese fashion as a whole.

headline: OUTLOOK SPORTS TO BUY MADISON & WALL
abstract: Outlook Sports Technology Inc plans to buy Madison & Wall Financial Services Inc for about $103 million in stock (S)

headline: Investors Buy $1.6 Billion Of Municipal Debt Issues
abstract: Municipal bond investors buy up $1.6 billion of tax-exempt bonds backed by toll revenue from Southern California highway; Treasury securities are little changed; yield on benchmark 30-year bond is unchanged at 5.91 percent, while price falls 1/32, to 90 25/32; graph on tax-exempt yields; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Barak's Quest Starts With Boost by Egypt
abstract: Prime Min Ehud Barak promises that Israel with 'turn every stone' in quest for a broader Middle East peace, but cautions that it will be a few weeks before he will be ready to make his first moves; meets with Pres Hosni Mubarak of Egypt in Alexandria, who praises Barak as a friend and man of his word; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASIA    VIETNAM: NEW U.S. PRESENCE  The United States opened a new consulate in Ho Chi Minh City, the former Saigon, nearly a quarter century after a dramatic airlift from the old American Embassy marked the end of the Vietnam War in 1975. Diplomatic relations were normalized in 1995.    (Reuters)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Stock index funds have finally started to lose their allure for investors seeking peak performances.
abstract: Investors have begun cutting back their purchases of mutual stock funds that track stock market indexes; AMG Data Services says in first quarter of year, about $3 of every $4 that flowed into stock mutual funds went to index fund; adds in second quarter, only about $1 of every $4 went into such funds; index funds took in $12.3 billion in second quarter compared with $17.8 billion in first quarter; recent slowdown has come as actively managed stock funds have begun beating indexes for first time in years (Market Place column) (M)

headline: SONIC AUTOMOTIVE TO BUY 11 DEALERSHIPS FOR $54 MILLION
abstract: Sonic Automotive Inc, third-largest publicly traded auto retailer, agrees to buy 11 dealerships for $54 million in cash and stock as it builds its network in Las Vegas, Nev, and southern US (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GENESYS S.A.,  Montpellier, France, a provider of teleconferencing services, agreed to buy Denver-based Williams Companies' conferencing unit for $39 million.    MIDDLE BAY OIL CO.,  Houston, an oil and natural gas exploration company, is selling a 36 percent stake to the closely held 3TEC Energy Corp., Dallas, another energy exploration company, for $21.4 million in cash.

headline: Good Fortune by the Cupful; Brazil Coffee Producers Turn to the High-End Market
abstract: Brazil's coffee producers are turning to high-end market, lured by market for high-end coffees that has spread from Europe to US and is now growing in other countries; Brazilian producers are focusing for first time on quality instead of quantity; Brazil produces roughly a third of world's estimated coffee output of 106.8 million bags; scene at Ipanema Agricola, one of Brazil's largest coffee producers, discussed; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Ernesto Melo Antunes, 66; Led 1974 Portuguese Coup
abstract: Lieut Col Ernesto Melo Antunes, Portuguese Army officer who was an architect and ideologist of almost bloodless coup that overthrew his country's longtime conservative dictatorship in 1974 and led to return of democracy, dies at age 66; photo (M)

headline: Keep Your Ears on the Road
abstract: Letter from Sharon Foster disagreees with Katie Hafner's July 29 article regarding safety of driving while using cellular phone

headline: AT&T Consolidates Interactive Account
abstract: AT&T Corp consolidates its interactive advertising account with Strategic Interactive Group, unit of Bronnercom, which had shared assignment with Modem Media.Poppe Tyson; billings not disclosed (S)

headline: Study Says Overweight Adults Push Up Cost of Health Care
abstract: Lewin Group, in study commissioned by American Obesity Association, says spending on health care for growing number of adults who are seriously overweight accounts for almost one-third of national cost of treating 15 important diseases; study urges Government and private employers to give more attention to problems of people who are overweight; finds cost of all treatments for obese adults will be $238 billion in 1999 (S)

headline: MacManus Acquires Interactive Agency
abstract: MacManus Group, New York, acquires a majority stake in Novo Interactive, San Francisco, for undisclosed terms (S)

headline: TEXACO PLANS TO INCREASE NUMBER OF JOB CUTS TO 2,500
abstract: Texaco Inc increases number of jobs it will cut to 2,500, or 10 percent of its work force, from 1,400 it estimated last year; most of jobs will be cut by end of September (S)

headline: Angst in the Great American Middle
abstract: Republican National Committee chairman Jim Nicholson letter, responding to Louis Uchitelle's August 1 article on American middle class's financial squeeze, notes article omitted taxes as major component (S)

headline: Clues in Search For Financier Lead to Europe
abstract: Federal investigators hunting for Martin R Frankel, Connecticut money manger wanted in huge insurance fraud, say they believe that they have traced him to Europe and are actively pursuing leads there; details of hunt for Frankel are among several revelations, as Connecticut criminal lawyer Hugh F Keefe discloses that he has been authorized to represent Frankel, and Mississippi regulators say they have filed orders to liquidate three insurance companies in Frankel's crumbling corporate empire; Keefe agrees tentatively to represent Frankel; says he has not met with Frankel in person, and does not know how Frankel obtained his name; Mississippi regulators liquidate Franklin Protective Life Insurance Co and Family Guaranty Life Insurance Co, both units of Franklin American Corp, and First National Life Insurance Co of America, subsidiary of International Financial Corp; total liabilities of three companies put at $21.8 million (M)

headline: Chechens Flee Russian Bombs By Thousands
abstract: Thousands of desperate Chechen refugees flee after days of intensive air bombardment in Russia's war against Islamic militants; more than 100,000 of them have crossed border into neighboring Russian republic of Ingushetia, prompting Ingush authorities to appeal to Moscow for emergency assistance, including food and tents; Akhmed Malsagov, acting Prime Minister of Ingushetia, closes border, saying his republic is on brink of humanitarian disaster; situation remains chaotic as 10-mile-long stretch of major highway is clogged with lines of cars and pedestrians trying to make their way across border; Russia's Defense Minister Marshal Igor Sergeyev hints about sending ground troops into Chechnya to go after rebel sanctuaries; photo; map (M)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; REFINANCING BY MEXICO
abstract: Mexico sells $400 million in bonds that mature in 2016 and uses proceeds to repurchase $510 million in outstanding debt at discount (S)

headline: U.S. Warns Indonesia Over Political Violence
abstract: Pres Clinton warns Indonesian Pres B J Habibie that relations with US will be seriously harmed if there is mass violence during referendum on self-rule in East Timor; photo of relatives mourning victim of violence there (S)

headline: Bishop Saw to Survival Of East Timor's 2d City
abstract: Bishop Basilio do Nascimento says with Dili charred ruin, Baucau, city of 27,000, could become temporary capital of emerging new nation of East Timor (M)

headline: Robert Polhill, 65, Lebanon Hostage for 3 Years
abstract: Robert B Polhill, American business professor who was held hostage for 39 months in Lebanon, dies at age 65; Polhill, former heavy smoker, learned he had throat cancer four days after he was freed in April 1990 (S)

headline: Australians in Show of Force in East Timor
abstract: As departing Indonesian soldiers marched with their duffel bags toward this city's port today, the foreign troops who are replacing them staged an aggressive show of force, sealing off and searching the city center for hours as helicopters circled and clattered above them.    Refugees crawled from cardboard shelters to watch Australian soldiers sweep through their burned-out neighborhoods, fingers on their triggers, as if on the front lines of a war.

headline: Report Addresses Standards In Marketing of Alcohol
abstract: Federal Trade Commission, in a report to Congress that was prompted by public concern over advertising's role in under-age drinking, recommends tightening the standards aimed at preventing beer, wine and liquor companies from marketing to people under age 21; while the study uncovered many instances in which companies ignored the standards, it stops short of recommending stricter regulation of the industry, which governs itself when it comes to advertising (M)

headline: Venezuelan Leader Names an Ally as Head of Oil Monopoly
abstract: Venezuelan Pres Hugo Chavez moves to solidify his control over state-run oil monopoly, naming ally, Hector Ciavaldini, head of Petroleos de Venezuela; pledges to strengthen Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries; Roberto Mandini, who resigned post, says he was not in disagreeement with Government over strategy or aims (M)

headline: Clinton Is Sending 200 Troops for East Timor
abstract: Pres Clinton says United States will contribute 200 troops to East Timor; says troops will be responsible for intelligence, logistics, communication and transport, but not for combat (M)

headline: Hearings on Russian Money Moves Are Likely to Be Partisan
abstract: Congress opens hearings into allegations of Russian corruption and money laundering; lawmakers expect extremely partisan fight over Pres Clinton's policies, as well as examination of effects on American and international financial systems; panels plan to explore how billions of dollars in Russian money flowed through Bank of New York and how it was used (M)

headline: Energy to Count On; Fuel Cells Tapped as Power Source for Computer Systems
abstract: Companies that need power source that is close to 100 percent reliable are considering fuel cell systems to replace electricity supplied by utilities; fuel cell technology has failed to catch on because of high cost, but in era of increasing dependence on voltage-sensitive computer equipment, people will pay a lot for power that will not quit; fuel cells may now have found niche after seven years of failing to attract widespread commercial use; advantages and disadvantage of fuel cell systems discussed; diagrams (M)

headline: Road to Capitalism Taking Toll On Men in the Former Soviet Bloc
abstract: UN Development Program report finds that ratio of men to women is falling across many of post-Communist countries of former Soviet bloc, because men in these countries are leading shorter and less healthy lives; rising suicide rates, declining life expectancy, poor health care and increase in self-destructive behavior cited (S)

headline: Israeli's Talk With Clinton: Syria Accord Back in View
abstract: News analysis of first round of meetings in Washington between Pres Clinton and new Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak; officials familiar with their conversations note that how to reach an agreement with Syria, one of last Arab countries still at war with Israel, dominated their discussions; Clinton Adm officials believe that a deal with Syrian Pres Hafez al-Assad is doable but that it will require involvement of highest-level American officials (M)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: BANK OF MONTREAL, Toronto, named Tony Comper, its chief executive, to the additional post of chairman, succeeding Matthew Barrett, who was named chief executive of Barclays P.L.C.    BETHLEHEM STEEL CORP., Bethlehem, Pa., named Duane Dunham president and chief operating officer. Mr. Dunham had been executive vice president for commercial and business development.

headline: Russia Routs Caucasus Rebels but They Vow to Carry On
abstract: Russian troops in Dagestan retake mountain villages around Botlikh seized three weeks ago by Islamic militants who crossed from Chechnya; Defense Min Igor D Sergeyev warns militants, driven out largely by air strikes, remain threat; rebel leader, Shamil Basayev, says militants prepare for clandestine phase of fight to end Russian rule; map; photo (M)

headline: Domain Concern To Release Data
abstract: Commerce Department reports Network Solutions Inc agrees to open its data base to public while talks on Network's monopoly on registering Internet addresses continues; extends for third time, until Sept 10, its target date for introducing full-scale competition into domain registration business (S)

headline: GENERAL ELECTRIC TO BUY KVAERNER UNIT
abstract: Kvaerner SA to sell part of its natural gas power plant business to General Electric Co; is selling businesses that build natural gas turbines and design and maintain power plants (S)

headline: White House Used Auditors Against a Bill
abstract: Senate Banking Committee report says White House enlisted help of regulators from the Office of Comptroller of Currency who were auditing banks to find bank executives who would join Clinton Administration in opposition to Republican financial legislation; measure, which White House says Pres Clinton, would veto, would take regulatory authority away from Comptroller of Currency, unit of Treasury Department, and vest it with Federal Reserve; would also relax key elements of Community Reinvestment Act, which encourages lending to minorities and others historically denied access to credit; one of the more than dozen banks contacted by examiners complained to Senate committee, calling the solicitations for positive comments inappropriate, especially coming in middle of routine bank examinations; spokesman at Comtroller's office says agency made a mistake (M)

headline: Deal to Create Biggest U.S. Wireless Network
abstract: Bell Atlantic Corp, nation's largest local phone company, and Britain's largest wireless concern, Vodafone Airtouch PLC strike deal to combine their US wireless operations and create nation's largest coast-to-coast network; $70 billion combination will give both companies scale to compete against AT&T Corp and Sprint Corp, both of which have dominated US cellular phone market; Vodafone and Bell Atlantic--along with GTE once it completes its merger with Bell Atlantic next year--will have more than 20 million customers, compared with AT&T's 11 million; Bell Atlantic will own 55 percent of entity, while Vodafone will own rest; Bell Atlantic chief executive Ivan Seidenberg and Vodafone chief executive Chris Gent comment; photo (M)

headline: Greens Say They'll Quit French Government if It Plans New A-Plants
abstract: France's Green Party, emboldened by good showing in recent elections for European Parliament, threatens to pull out of Govt if Prime Min Lionel Jospin approves new generation of nuclear power stations to replace old ones; Greens, who joined Jospin's Govt in 1997, have always insisted that nuclear energy is at center of their policy concerns; even though party leader Dominique Voynet serves as Environment Minister, party says it is being ignored on vital questions inside governing coalition; country's 57 nuclear reactors provide 78 percent of country's energy (M)

headline: Ulster Is Given An Ultimatum To End Impasse
abstract: British and Irish Governments deliver ultimatum to feuding politicians of Ulster: resolve impasse that threatens Northern Ireland peace settlement or see their hard-won new legislature shut down; threat follows five grueling days of talks with Prime Mins Tony Blair and Bertie Ahern and two sides, Ulster Unionionists and Sinn Fein; dispute centers on which of two pivotal steps in peace settlement formula would occur first: creation of Roman Catholic-Protestant Cabinet to run new Northern Ireland Government, favored by Sinn Fein, or beginning of disarming of paramilitary groups, demanded by Ulster Unionists; photos (M)

headline: In England, Everything Is Cricket — and Everything Is Simply Dreadful
abstract: LONDON—  Conjuring up his idealized image of England, former Prime Minister John Major once wrote of a land of warm beer, dog-lovers and "long shadows on county cricket grounds."

headline: Unum Provident Shares Plunge 30%
abstract: Unum Provident Corp shares fall 30 percent after Unum reports second-quarter operating earnings fell 7.3 percent, to $156.4 million, from $168.7 million a year ago; Unum posts net loss of $191.2 million, compared with year-earlier net income of $173.5 million (S)

headline: Chernomyrdin Back Home At Old Company, Gazprom
abstract: Former Russian Prime Min Viktor S Chernomyrdin is installed as chairman of Gazprom, Russia's biggest company, cementing ties between government and big business; move gives Pres Boris N Yelstin and his allies greater influence over lucrative enterprise and potential source of campaign money (M)

headline: Accord Expected on Plan For Big Board's Offering
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission officials say they expect to work out agreement with New York Stock Exchange on thorniest issue involved in its going public--what happens to exchange's self-policing unit; once exchange converts to public ownership, exchange's self-regulatory unit will face possibility of investigating and disciplining its own shareholders; that has raised concerns about conflicts of interest and whether exchange's self-policing unit will have enough independence (M)

headline: MAJORITY OWNER OF SIMMONS TO ADD A BEDDING RETAILER
abstract: Fenway Partners Inc, investment firm with majority stake in Simmons Co, bedding maker, acquires retailer Mattress Giant Corp for undisclosed price (S)

headline: Banking Scandals Rattle Asians and Worry Lending Agencies
abstract: Banking scandals have rippled across Indonesia and Thailand, and bankers and securities analysts predict that they are likely to worsen, intensifying pressure on two countries' Governments and providing growing source of consternation to lenders at World Bank and International Monetary Fund; Thai central bank, after providing 185 billion baht ($4.83 billion) to country's second-largest financial institution, Krung Thai Bank, dismissed all but one of Krung Thai's board members amid disagreement over how to proceed with its rescue; there have been accusations of mismangement in scandal that has involved country's Finance Min Tarrin Nimmanahaeminda; in Indonesia, officials prepare to expand investigation of questionable payments by Bank Bali to include country's central bank, after IMF request that they do so; Bank Bali scandal has involved Indonesia's Pres B J Habibie and his brother and provoked calls for resignation of nation's top financial officials; IMF and World Bank officials have sounded stern warnings that Indonesia needs to clear up Bank Bali mess expeditiously; what makes latest scandals so troubling to IMF and World Bank is that they have touched some of people and institutions they have been using as agents of reform--in Jakarta, Indonesian Bank Restructuring Agency, and in Bangkok, Finance Min Nimmanahaeminda (M)

headline: BRITISH PHONE RATES CUT
abstract: British Telecommunications PLC announces new initiative to cut residential phone rates for British customers (S)4

headline: It's the Dog Days for Treasuries as Yields Won't Budge
abstract: Yields on Treasury securities hover at their lowest levels in a month; price of 30-year bond rises 1/32, to 102 1/32, leaving yield unchanged at 5.98 percent; graph on 3-month Treasury bills; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Europeans Trail Americans In Time on Line, Survey Says
abstract: Survey by PricewaterhouseCoopers finds that more than 40 percent of Americans, 24 percent of British, 18 percent of Germans and 10 percent of French have access to the Internet at home; also finds Americans are spending 5.3 hours on line per week, while Europeans devote half as much time to Internet (M)

headline: A 1970's act to preserve faltering newspapers seems only to delay the inevitable end.
abstract: Proposed sale of San Francisco Chronicle to Hearst Corp, owner of rival San Francisco Examiner, calls into question rationale for 1970 law that lets competing newspapers share certain costs and split certain revenues to maintain multiple editorial voices in single market; end of joint operating accord in San Francisco is widely expected to leave city with one daily; photo (M)

headline: GERMAN JOB CUTS PLANNED
abstract: German energy company Bayernwerk AG says it is cutting 2,000 jobs as part of its streamlining efforts (S)

headline: Motorola Unit to Add 1,400 Positions
abstract: Network Solutions Sector unit of Motorola Inc plans to create 1,400 positions in engineering and in research and development; Network Solutions makes and sells Motorola's cellular infrastructure and wireless communications systems (S)

headline: Port of Choice: Easy U.S.B.'s
abstract: Q.  I have a new Pentium III PC and a printer that can work with U.S.B. or parallel connections. Which should I use to hook up the printer?    A.  The choice between the U.S.B. and parallel ports for your printer's connection might depend on how comfortable you are with installing hardware. The U.S.B., or Universal Serial Bus, route is considered by many to be easier than configuring the parallel port. Windows 98 will automatically recognize that you have attached a new U.S.B. device and lead you through the installation process.

headline: Computer Shock
abstract: Letter from Marhsall Makstein comments on July 1 diary kept by Dr Edwin Rothman on his frustrating attempts to set up new computer; says he should have bought iMac

headline: BLOCKBUSTER RAISES $465 MILLION IN AN INITIAL OFFERING
abstract: Blockbuster Inc raises $465 million in initial public offering; sells 31 million shares to public at $15 each; offering represents 18 percent stake and values Blockbuster at $2.63 billion; Viacom Inc, which retains about 82 percent of Blockbuster shares, plans to spin off remainder of shares to its own shareholders (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar gains as rebound in US stocks puts to rest concerns that foreign investors will reduce their holdings; in New York, euro settles at $1.0657, down from $1.0702; graph; chart (S)

headline: NEW ZEALAND PACT FOR E.D.S.
abstract: Electronic Data Systems Corp of US wins 10-year contract worth $1.5 billion (New Zealand) to manage Telecom Corp of New Zealand's information systems (S)

headline: FINANCIER IMPRISONED
abstract: Swiss financier Werner K Rey is sentenced to four years in prison for his part in collapse of his business empire, Omni Holding, which left $2.6 billion in debts; Rey, who avoided trial for seven years by fleeing to Bahamas, is found guilty of fraud and falsifying documents by court in Bern (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: VIDEO SERVICES CORP., Northvale, N.J., a video services provider, hired Lazard Freres & Company L.L.C. to explore a sale of the company, as well as a possible merger or joint venture.    AMERICAN RE CORP., Princeton, N.J., a unit of Munich Re A. G., the world's largest reinsurer, said it would buy closely held United National Group, Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., to expand its presence in the U.S. commercial insurance market. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Taiwan's New Doctrine Unintelligible in Chinese
abstract: Taiwan's new formula defining itself as separate state, but not independent country from China, is so hard to articulate in Chinese that Taiwanese officials routinely resort to English; Chinese uses same word to mean 'nation,' 'country' and 'state'; Pres Lee Teng-hui emerges in public to reiterate stance; photo (M)

headline: Liability Fears Sink Republic New York's Share Price
abstract: Fears about Republic New York Corp's liability in what prosecutors are calling huge fraud drags down company's stock for third consecutive trading session; shares of Republic New York fall 1.6 percent, to close at $59, for total decline of nearly 15 percent this month; investors are apparently concerned that fraud could derail or alter HSBC Holdings' planned acquisition of Republic for $72 a share; officials at HSBC decline to comment on status of deal and refer reporter to bank's statement on Sept 1 announcing internal investigation into trading losses generated by customer, Martin A Armstrong, chairman of Princeton Economics International Inc, which in turn controlled Cresvale International, brokerage firm based in Hong Kong; at that time, HSBC said its offer to acquire Republic was proceeding but would be postponed until investigation was concluded (M)

headline: CHINA TELECOM EARNINGS RISE
abstract: China Telecom (Hong Kong) Ltd says earnings jumped 14 percent in first half year; company, which dominates China's mobile phone business, reports net income of 3.95 billion yuan, or $477.2 million (S)

headline: Taiwan's President Declines To Soften His New Doctrine
abstract: Taiwan Pres Lee Teng-hui, defying pressure to soften his stance, reaffirms that Taiwan will only talk to China as a separate state, and he predicts that China will eventually accept Taiwan's new position; Lee calls his new diplomatic tack 'friendly and positive,' and not provocative, as Beijing terms it (M)

headline: Mitchell Says It's Up to Ulster Political Leaders to Settle Their Feud
abstract: Former US Sen George J Mitchell, who helped broker 1998 Ulster accords, returns to Belfast, Northern Ireland, in effort to break stalemated peace talks between Protestant leaders and Irish Republican Army; says ending impasse is up to feuding political leaders, but that stalemate can be broken; urges political leaders to seize 'best' political opportunity in many years to set province on path to enduring peace and political stability; says he will not renegotiate original settlement, but will focus tightly on disarmament methods and timing and on creating executive Cabinet with members from rival parties to run new Northern Ireland Assembly, power-sharing institution at heart of agreement; impasse centers on disarming Irish Republican Army before assembly begins functioning (M)

headline: This Broker Really Takes A Long View
abstract: I CAN'T see what all the fuss is about,'' said Frank W. Fletcher, a 95-year-old stockbroker. ''My father was pushing a hand mower well into his 90's.''     And the way things are going in the workplace, there may soon be no fuss whatsoever about people toiling into their 90's -- or even their 100's. Not only are Americans living and working longer, but in some fields, older workers are even being sought out.

headline: ILLINOIS TOOL IN $3.4 BILLION DEAL FOR PREMARK
abstract: Illinois Tool Works Inc to buy Premark International Inc for $3.4 billion in stock (S)

headline: One Last Explosion At Kazakh Test Site To Aid Arms Treaty
abstract: Next-to-last tunnel at nuclear test range in Kazakhstan will be sealed on Sept 25 with conventional explosion having force of 100 tons of TNT; measurements from explosion will also enable seismic stations through the world to 'calibrate' their equipment and help scientists distinguish between a natural event, like an earthquake, and an underground test by a nation developing nuclear weapons; photo; map (M)

headline: Colombian Leader Says U.S. Won't Be Drawn Into War
abstract: Pres Andres Pastrana of Colombia insists that despite his Government's request for huge new infusion of aid from abroad, United States would not be drawn more deeply into Colombia's 40-year fight against leftist rebels; Pastrana is in New York to address United Nations on opening day of General Assembly; he seeks to reassure Americans about Clinton Administration's deepening commitment to Colombia; says military aid and training would be channeled mainly to special units like army battalions; Pastrana Administration seeks at least $3.5 billion in international aid over next three years to carry out wide-ranging strategy to deal with leftist and rightist insurgents, surging drug trade and faltering economy; photo (M)

headline: HELP FOR BOND MARKET
abstract: South Korean banks and insurance companies respond to weekend announcement by Government of measures to prop up sagging bond market; with contributions from local banks and insurance companies, Financial Supervisory Commission says it will form an $8.3 billion fund to stabilize bond market; agency says contributions to fund are voluntary (S)

headline: Sanctions for Indonesia Could Spark a Nationalist Backlash, Analysts Say
abstract: AUCKLAND, New Zealand—  With foreign demands against Indonesia increasing, political analysts said Tuesday that outside pressure could spark a nationalist backlash or even a military takeover in the world's fourth most-populous nation.

headline: June Orders For Durables Rise Slowly
abstract: Commerce Department reports durable goods orders rose smaller-than-expected 0.3 percent, June; graph (M)

headline: Citing Gains, NATO Plans To Cut Back Bosnia Force
abstract: NATO is planning to cut its military forces in Bosnia by half, an indication of improvements in the security situation there and of the strain on the alliance of undertaking a second Balkan mission, in Kosovo, at the same time.    Kenneth H. Bacon, the Pentagon spokesman, made the announcement today during a visit by Defense Secretary William S. Cohen to the American base in Tuzla, Bosnia. He cautioned that the decision to reduce forces in Bosnia was preliminary, pending full NATO approval, and was based on a recent six-month review showing positive changes there.

headline: In Jakarta, News of Timor Is Barely a Blip
abstract: Most Indonesians appear more concerned about major official corruption scandal than about plight of East Timorese; preparations by international peacekeeping force to enter East Timor have stirred nationalist anger over what many Indonesians see as foreign meddling in their sovereign affairs; most have little understanding of history or of current events in East Timor, which was invaded by Indonesia in 1975 and been swept by violence since voting for independence two weeks ago (M)

headline: DELL TO ACQUIRE DATA STORAGE COMPANY
abstract: Dell Computer Corp says it agreed to buy Convergenet Technologies Inc for about $340 million in stock (S)

headline: Forever NumLock
abstract: Letter from Mark Ozdoba says he finds NumLock key invaluable in dealing with upkeep of PC's

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.25   8.25   8.50        Discount rate   4.75   4.75   5.00        Federal funds   5.25   5.33   5.49        3-month T-bills   4.67   4.72   4.73        6-month T-bills   4.93   4.95   4.71        10-yr. T-infl.   4.04   4.05   3.75        10-yr. T-note   5.92   5.94   4.92        30-yr. T-bond   6.07   6.07   5.26        Telephone bd.   7.84   7.87   7.10        Municipal bds.   5.80   5.80   5.15          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer

headline: U.N. Says Troops May Expel Kosovo City's Provocateurs
abstract: United Nations representatives Bernard Kouchner signs new regulation giving troops and police extra authority to detain or expel troublemakers from town of Mitrovica or from Kosovo province altogether; new attempt to control tensions follows confrontations that French troops have had with demonstrators in city during last week; map (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent advertising account changes noted (S)

headline: OFFER FOR INSURER
abstract: World Business Brief

headline: Prison Sentence For Baron Broker
abstract: Justice Edward J McLaughlin sentences Roman Okin, formerly star salesman at A R Baron & Co, to three to nine years in jail for his role in defrauding investors of millions of dollars; firm collapsed three years ago (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Job Creation Surged in July; Jobless Rate Unchanged  Employers added an estimated 310,000 nonfarm jobs in July, 50 percent more than analysts had anticipated, suggesting that economic growth rebounded early in the summer after tailing off in the spring. Meanwhile, the unemployment rate in July remained steady at 4.3 percent, the Labor Department said.

headline: As Iraqis Starve, U.S. Asserts, Their Leaders Live in Luxury
abstract: US, which is seeking to force new weapons inspection program on Iraq, reports new evidence that Pres Saddam Hussein has spent money to build 'sprawling amusement park' to entertain his political followers instead of feeding hungry populace; State Dept releases declassified aerial photographs showing complex near Baghdad; photogrqaphs also substantiate reports that Hussein recently bulldozed villages where anti-Govt protests took place (S)

headline: China and U.S. Meet on Trade and Chilled Relations Thaw a Bit
abstract: American and Chinese representatives hold trade talks in Beijing and agree to higher-level discussions later in year; remain stuck on most important issue of China's proposed entry into World Trade Organization; Deputy Commerce Sec David L Aaron, who met with Foreign Trade Min Shi Guangsheng and other senior Chinese officials, says Chinese discussed trade organization membership only indirectly and showed no willingnes to establish timetable for new negotiations (M)

headline: Slowly but Surely, Internet Alters U.K. Agriculture : Farmers Plow in Cyberspace
abstract: LONDON—  Farming has come a long way since the word "web" meant a home for Charlotte. British farmers, though still not to the extent of their American cousins, are getting connected.

headline: Reports of Coercion in a Mexican Election
abstract: Electoral monitors and people of State of Mexico report that governing Institutional Revolutionary Party has buying or coercing the votes of poor Mexicans who are to cast ballots in elections for governor on July 4, Mexico's most important election before presidential balloting in 2000; some of tactics may constitute crimes, although most appear to be abusive but not illegal; poto (M)

headline: Beijing Seems to Lose Battle Over Who Is the Real Lama
abstract: Chinese authorities escort 9-year-old Gyaincain Norbu, their official choice to be Panchen Lama, to Shigatse, Tibet, traditional seat of power of Panchen Lama, second-most important religious figure after Dalai Lama; Tibetans, however, overwhelming revere another boy as reincarnation of Panchen Lama, but that boy disappeared in custody of Chinese authorities in 1995, prompting accusations from exiled Tibetan activists that he had become youngest political prisoner in world (M)

headline: Arms Sales Are Down Worldwide but U.S. Still Leads in Exports
abstract: Congressional Research Service reports United States was world's biggest arms exporter in sluggish market last year, as weak economies in Asia and among oil producers in Middle East dragged global sales to developing countries to lowest level since 1991; report shows US negotiated new agreements to sell $7.1 billion worth of weapons in 1998, nearly 31 percent of $23 billion in sales worldwide; Congressional Research Service is arm of Library of Congress (M)

headline: A 50-50 Split Means Fewer Worries for Growers
abstract: Growing trend in wine industry is 50-50 partnerm

headline: Montblanc's Clean, Well-Lighted Place
abstract: Montblanc, German pen maker, sets up sound-proof 'de-acceleration studio' at new Manhattan store, sans computers and cell phones, where customers can listen to music, sip coffee, peruse first-edition books and try out and order custom-made pens (S)

headline: Airline Drug Sting Likely to Generate Action by Congress
abstract: WASHINGTON—  U.S. authorities have indicted 58 people — mostly employees of American Airlines or a major German-owned airline catering company — after investigators uncovered an extended network of drug and weapons smuggling on regular commercial flights from South America to Miami and other U.S. cities.

headline: Holbrooke Is (Finally) New Man at U.N.
abstract: United States Amb Richard C Holbrooke, confirmed by Senate after long delay, makes low-key first appearance at United Nations; says top priority is UN reform; photo (M)

headline: U.P.S. Going Public And Its Employees Hope for Windfall
abstract: Employee-owned United Parcel Service of America Inc plans initial public offering of 10 percent stake in company; offering is likely to raise $3 billion to $5 billion, creating windfall for employees; chairman and chief executive James P Kelly says employees and managers will retain 99 percent of voting rights; table of financial data (M)

headline: A Second Giant Moves Toward an Index Pension
abstract: Philip Morris Cos moves to pure index investing for its nearly $8 billion of assets in its defined-benefit pension plans (S)

headline: JUDY McGRATH, President, MTV
abstract: Judy McGrath, MTV president, cites her own favorite shopping sites on Internet; photo; drawing (S)

headline: Hewlett-Packard Picks Rising Star at Lucent as Its Chief Executive
abstract: Abandoning a long tradition of picking its leaders from within its own ranks, the Hewlett-Packard Company announced today that it had chosen as its next chief executive a woman who earned her power and reputation in the telecommunications industry.    Carleton S. Fiorina, the 44-year-old president of the global service provider business of Lucent Technologies will become president and chief executive of the company, the world's second-largest computer maker, at the end of this year after the retirement of Lewis E. Platt, who is now chief executive with the title of chairman.

headline: Karl H. Menges, 91, and Expert On Central Asian Languages
abstract: Karl H Menges, authority on strateg

headline: Memo From Lahore; Editor Held 25 Days Finds Nightmare Never Ends
abstract: Ordeal of Najam Sethi, outspoken Pakistani journalist critical of Govt, continues; he was released from prison after 25 days in detention after charges of sedition were dropped, but currently faces income tax probe and possible revocation of standing of Muslim and loss of voting rights; his passport has been confiscated; treatment has left many Pakistani journalists wary of criticizing Govt; map; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Once Again, Coca-Cola Predicts Lower Earnings  Shares of Coca-Cola fell $2.125, to $57.375, after the soft-drink company confirmed Wall Street's fears that near-term profits will suffer, as improving unit volume remains a challenge for the rest of this year. Citing the lingering impact of halted sales in parts of Europe this summer, as well as sluggishness in other markets, Coke said unit case volume in the third quarter would increase only at a low single-digit rate. Analysts figure the increase to be about 2 percent, which is down slightly from the 3 percent to 4 percent they had originally estimated.    As a result, the company lowered earnings expectations by 3 cents to 5 cents a share. Including the product recall in Europe, which will account for 2 cents to 3 cents against earnings, third-quarter profits may be as low as 31 cents a share, in contrast to the 36 cents analysts had been expecting. [Page C14.]

headline: U.S. Firm Has Control of Korea First Bank
abstract: South Korean Government signs binding agreement to sell controlling stake in Korea First Bank to Newbridge Capital Ltd, a US-based investment firm; sale marks first time that foreigners have attained control of South Korean bank; Newbridge, backed by investors Richard C Blum and David Bonderman, agrees to pay 500 won, or about $417 million, for 51 percent stake and total management control of Korea First (M)

headline: PORTUGAL THWARTS DEAL
abstract: Portugal is standing by its veto of alliance between Champalimaud Group, Portuguese company that controls the insurer Mundial Confianca and three banks, and Banco Santander Central Hispano of Spain despite threat of legal action by European Union; Government contends there are irregularities in proposed alliance; has been accused of trying to shield Portugal's second-largest financial company from foreign takeover (S)

headline: The Diaper Rush of 1999: Cloth Makes a Comeback on the Net
abstract: Article on latest revival in popularity of cloth diapers, made by stay-at-home moms, as result of Internet access; some microbrands have gone into factory production but many entrepreneurs say they are too busy keeping up with demand to make bigger plans; photos (M)

headline: Main Foe of Milosevic Pulls Out of Big Rally Plan
abstract: Vuk Draskovic, leader of Serbia's largest opposition party, withdraws from major rally against Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic set for Belgrade; cites actions and behavior of rally sponsor, which is effectively led by his rival, Zoran Djindjic; Momcilo Perisic, ousted in Nov as army chief of staff, also withdraws; says he does not back transitional government of experts, one of rally's aims; calls for early elections; Government, despite continually dividing opposition, remains anxious about sentiment in Belgrade (M)

headline: He Skirts Boundaries Of the System
abstract: Biographical sketch of Liu Junning, 38-year-old scholar who is one of China's most influential liberal intellectuals; photo (M)

headline: BRERA CAPITAL PARTNERS TO ACQUIRE INSURANCE UNIT
abstract: Brera Capital Partners agrees to pay $165 million to acquire 91 percent of GAB Robins insurance-services unit from SGS Holding AG (S)

headline: North Korea Said to Agree to End Missile Tests
abstract: American officials say North Korea has tentatively agreed to end its testing of long-range ballistic missiles in exchange for commitment from US and Japan to move forward with economic assistance (S)

headline: So Many Analysts, So Little Analysis
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column questions rise in fame and wealth of Wall Street analysts when so many are unoriginal, unenlightening and unquestioning (M)

headline: Companies' Shares Soar and Sink on Ruling in Gene Research
abstract: Shares in Incyte Pharmaceuticals Inc plummet and shares in Affymetrix Inc soar after US Patent and Trademark Office Judge Richard Torczon ruled last week in favor of Affymetrix in patent dispute between two companies over gene chip technology; Incyte, which says it will appeal decision, had sought to block two Affymetrix patents on production of DNA microarrays, glass chips that are coated with genes for use in genetic analysis and drug research; Affymetrix agrees to acquire Genetic Microsystems Inc in stock swap valued at about $121 million (M)

headline: Germans Lag In Reaching Slave Labor Settlement
abstract: German Government and leading German companies abandon Sept 1 target date for multibillion-dollar settlement with slave laborers and others forced to work by Nazis; date was symbolic as 60th anniversary of Hitler's invasion of Poland and start of World War II, but negotiators are still unable to reach agrement on size of payment; companies say 500,000 to 800,000 people were involved, while lawyers for victims put figure at up to 2.3 million (M)

headline: For a World Apart, a Lesson in Social Work
abstract: Israel's ultra-Orthodox, or haredim, are starting to negotiate new relationship between their own society and larger Israel; this includes training in three-year social work program at Bar Ilan University; laboriously negotiated permission of rabbis for 18 men to take course reflects ultra-Orthodox leaders' increasing willingness to acknowledge that their community has social problems that require professional help; haredi men have largely stayed away from higher education, army and secular workforce; originally, this was intended to keep alive dying tradition; now, as ulta-Orthodox community is burgeoning, many within it question economic practicality of having most working-age men remain outside workforce; social work program is first university degree program tailored to haredi men; program grew out of extraordinary negotiations between Bar-Ilan and rabbis, involving compromises on both sides; photos (M)

headline: Indonesia Says No to Timor Peacekeepers
abstract: Indonesian officials, meeting with high-level United Nations delegation pressing for action to end widespread violence in East Timor, refuse to let foreign peacekeepers restore order; UN mission in East Timor says it will close operations and evacuate staff; later reverses itself and says it will delay decision and skeleton staff will likely remain; campaign of killing, burning and forced evacuation orchestrated by elements of Indonesian military continues unabated in wake of independence vote; foreign pressure on Indonesia is constrained by fragility of nation's political structure and Pres B J Habibie's limited power to enforce his offer of independence to East Timor; map; photo (M)

headline: Serbs' Fears Put Segregation Back on the Table in Kosovo
abstract: United Nations administration in Kosovo weighs de facto segregation of Serbian enclaves and even temporary resettlement of Serbs to protect them, but continues to reject Serbian pleas for formal partition of province; UN Special Rep Bernard Kouchner says UN and NATO peacekeepers will still try to protect Serbs where they live; some Serbs have already moved to safer places within Kosovo on their own and UN refugee agency has moved some 400 others; map (M)

headline: $21.3 Billion Deficit For May Is a Record; Markets Feel the Heat : U.S. Reports Unexpected Widening of Trade Gap
abstract: NEW YORK—  The U.S. trade deficit ballooned to a record $21.34 billion in May, the government reported Tuesday, a bigger-than-expected gap that called into question America's ability to finance its appetite for imports.

headline: Shulamit Katznelson, 80; Teacher of Arabs and Jews
abstract: Shulamit Katznelson, honored by Israel for teaching Arabs Hebrew and Jews Arabic, dies at age 80 (M)

headline: STAAR SURGICAL SPURNS OFFER FROM UNDISCLOSED BIDDER
abstract: Staar Surgical Co rejects offer from undisclosed bidder to buy at least 51 percent of its common shares outstanding at $15 each, saying bid is inadequate (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    FRANCE: LIBYA PAYS FOR BOMBING PLANE -- Libya has transferred $31 million to France to compensate families of the 171 people killed when a French airliner was blown up over the African desert in 1989, officials said. A French court that convicted six high-ranking Libyan officials in absentia this year ordered Libya to pay compensation for the bombing, which occurred at a time of tension between the two countries over Chad. The French Foreign Ministry said the payment was acknowledgment by Libya that its officials were responsible for the deaths.   Craig R. Whitney (NYT)

headline: VOWING TO PURSUE PEACE WITH ARABS, BARAK TAKES OVER
abstract: Ehud Barak is sworn in as Prime Minister of Israel, and he pledges in his inaugural speech that pursuit of true, lasting peace will be his foremost concern; reaches out to all his domestic constituencies; speaks of pain and death on both sides of Israeli-Palestinian conflict and suggests that both sides stop focusing on settling of historical wrongs; says he will move forward on both peace tracks at once in effort to allay fears of Palestinians that negotiations with Syria will take precedence; repeats campaign promise to withdraw Israeli troops from southern Lebanon within a year; his words are received by Palestinians in Gaza as welcome break from perceived hostility of his predecessor, Benjamin Netanyahu, and Palestinian leaders express cautious optimism; photos (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.00   8.00   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   5.06   5.05   5.60        3-month T-bills   4.63   4.76   4.91        6-month T-bills   4.85   4.88   4.95        10-yr. T-infl.   4.05   4.04   3.80        10-yr. T-note   6.06   6.08   5.64        30-yr. headline: Employee's Lawsuit Accuses Morgan Stanley of Racial Bias
abstract: Alan Damon Harvey, employee on extended disability leave from Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, has sued firm, accusing it of racial discrimination; Harvey, black financial analyst, contends his superiors in Morgan Stanley's real estate finance division assigned him more 'grunt work' than they assigned white people with similar jobs; also contends that superiors used term 'boy' when referring to black employees; Harvey contends that race-oriented abuse caused him to have nervous breakdown (M)

headline: To Help Israel, Albright Delays Visit To Mideast
abstract: State Sec Madeleine K Albright postpones Mideast trip at Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak's request to at least end of Aug while Israel presses Palestinians to accept changes in latest land-for-security accord; State Department says she consulted with Barak, Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat and Syrian Min Farouk al-Sharaa before deciding to delay trip (M)

headline: Lockheed's Ticket to the Future
abstract: Article explores possiblity that X-35 joint strike fighter could prove to be ticket to future of Lockheed Martin; photo (M)

headline: The Wizard Turns Out to Be an Artist
abstract: Article on trend in computer game industry toward using traditional artists, illustrators and animators in designing new games; work of architect David T Glenn described; photos (M)

headline: Where the Classics Live
abstract: Letter from Bob Millard on July 22 article on using older computers

headline: Patents; Researchers marshal more effective weapons in the battle to contain a tuberculosis resurgence.
abstract: Dr Robert Ledley patents new test to determine within minutes which antibiotic to use to treat tuberculosis patient; Robert L Wolfe patents practice of inserting interactive advertising into streaming audio music being listened to by Internet user; Pamela Esposito patents hair pouch designed to help long hair dry while keeping it from dripping (M)

headline: Helping Airdrops Hit the Spot
abstract: Several companies are trying to bring air drop into digital age, combining advances in parachute technology with satellite-based navigation units; companies say new systems will allow military or aid groups to drop cargo where it is intended to go; photo of computer-guided parachute carrying 1,000-pound payload (M)

headline: Plenty Of Seats Available
abstract: Four leading publicly held movie theater companies are losing money and share price, caught in industry transition from multiplexes to megaplexes; audiences are flocking to spacious new megaplexes, but staying away from many of so-called multiplexes of shoe-box size theaters that have been mainstay of shopping malls and staple of movie industry for decades; big exhibitors that erected megaplexes are also largest owners of fading multiplexes, so they are bearing brunt of forces they themselves unleashed; analysts predict that strongest exhibitors will survive industry's transition from shoe boxes to showcases, but few expect recovery to be swift or smooth; four largest companies are AMC Entertainment, Carmike Theaters, GC Cos and Loews Cineplex Entertainment; photos; diagrams; chart (L)

headline: Economic Scene; Why all the fuss over pint-sized Ecuador? Brady bonds.
abstract: Economic Scene column on Ecuador as first country to skip interest payments on Brady bonds; says US Treasury Department and International Monetary Fund remain fixated on Ecuador's economic problems because Ecuador's potential default could contaminate financial markets in Latin America; drawing (M)

headline: Kisii Journal; Malaria, a Swamp Dweller, Finds a Hillier Home
abstract: Kisii, Kenya, is center of serious malaria outbreak; experts are particularly concerned because city's altitude, nearly 6,000 feet, was considered too high for mosquitoes that spread malaria parasite; problem in Kisii underscores how disease is changing and spreading in Africa to new areas; resistance to various drugs is also rising steeply; maps; photo (M)

headline: Fearing Deflation, Chinese Set Limits On New Factories
abstract: Chinese officials, in move aimed at reversing steady fall in prices, say they will ban new construction of factories that make broad range of ordinary consumer items; ban also covers construction of luxury hotels, apartment and office buildings and department stores; officials, by withholding approval for new production lines while allowing existing output to continue, hope they can shackle China's deflation, which has become serious new economic threat; prices of consumer goods in China have fallen for 22 months in row (M)

headline: Rubin Is Kidnapped, but, Hey, Who Cares?
abstract: In last 24 hours as Treasury Sec, Robert E Rubin scolds Congress for legislation that would make life easier for money laundering, cleans out his office and then watches in mock horror as Pres Clinton's closest advisers play out their fantasy: That Rubin had been captured by Japan's Ministry of Finance and held for bizarre ransom; kidnapping was plot of video entitled: Free Bob: A Documentary, which had its premiere in State Dining Rooming during farewell party given by Pres Clinton; Clinton Administration works hard to make sure first showing is also the last, but it will be hard to keep bootleg copies from leaking out; photo (M)

headline: Milosevic's Vision of Glory Unleashed Decade of Ruin
abstract: Roger Cohen, who covered war in Balkans in 1994-95, reports on his visit to Kosovo for 10th anniversary of Slobodan Milosevic's speech envisioning a Greater Serbia; describes widespread destruction in Kosovo, where weary Serbians see change in Balkan equation; finds that decade after Milosevic envisioned it in speech that whipped up Serbian nationalism and helped cement his power, Greater Serbia is dead; finds that in its place, a new group of largely ethnically homogenous states has emerged, with help of Milosevic's consistent brutality from Vukovar in Croatia through Bosnian capital, Sarajevo, to Kosovo towns like Djakovica and Pec; finds that Milosevic has been 'midwife' of his enemies' ascendancy; his tactics of mass killing and eviction of civilians have helped forge a separate Croatia, a new Bosnian Muslim identity and now an embryonic Albanian nation state in Kosovo; Serbia, meanwhile, one of first Balkan states to emerge in 19th century, is still casting around for stable borders, unable to resolve its dilemma of how to unite Serbs in one country now that old Yugoslavia is dead; photos; map (L)

headline: Clinton Sees U.S. Playing Support Role In East Timor
abstract: Pres Clinton says American troops will have limited but important function in peacekeeping force Indonesia is reluctantly permitting into East Timor, although Asian officials insist US will inevitably be drawn into central role if troops are to be sent quickly to stop killings; US officials say American participation can be held to about 600 troops, though Australian and Asian diplomats say they expect figure to be much higher; photo (M)

headline: GAS TARIFF SCRAPPED
abstract: Mexico eliminates its tariff on natural gas imports from US and Canada, making it possible for American and Canadian companies to compete with Government petroleum company, Pemex, on equal basis; in late June, in retaliation against dumping complaint by independent American oil companies, Mexico reversed earlier promise to lift tariff; when complaint was dismissed by US Commerce Department, Mexico said tariff would soon be eliminated (S)

headline: Chief of Circulation Named by The Times
abstract: Scott H Heekin-Canedy, vice president for strategic planning at New York Times, is appointed newspaper's senior vice president for circulation; he succeeds Richard H Gilman, who is named by parent Times Co to be publisher of Boston Globe; photo (S)

headline: Law Firms Approve U.S.-British Merger
abstract: Lawyers at Rogers & Wells in New York and Clifford Chance in London approved a merger of their firms, the first combination between major British and American law firms.

headline: Foe Suggests Giving Milosevic Immunity To Get Him to Quit
abstract: Vuk Draskovic, leading Serbian opposition politician, says best way to get Pres Slobodan Milosevic out of power is to seduce him to resign by promising immunity from arrest or extradition for war crimes; says he will soon name shadow Yugoslav government of experts led by prime minister selected by Milo Djukanovic, democratic leader of Montenegro; will press Milosevic through public rallies to accept government and to call new elections in three to six months while opposition works to attract disaffected Milosevic supporters; others in opposition feel time is right to confront and oust Milosevic, not to encourage him; senior opposition figures remain intensely competitive, and their lack of unity makes it more likely that if Milosevic falls it will be through chaotic outpouring of discontent; map; photo (M)

headline: Serb Suspect In Atrocities Is Arrested By French
abstract: serb suspect in stocities is arrested by french**French police arrest Dragan Marjanovic, Serbian paramilitary leader and war crimes suspect, raiding his apartment in Mitrovica, Kosovo, and confiscating weapons and ammunition; Serbian police and military personnel were supposed to have left Kosovo two weeks ago; arrest is one of series indicating lingering presence of Serbs viewed by NATO as provocateurs; Marjanovic, with others, had been blocking main bridge in Mitrovica in attempt to divide city and create Serbs-only quarter (M)

headline: Cash Is Tool In Gauging I.P.O. Health
abstract: Research by O'Sullivan Graev & Karabell law firm in New York indicates that investors who troll markets for bargain stocks should pay close attention to a company's cash flow; graph (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; As Britain Sells Some Gold, South Africa Howls
abstract: Bank of England sells first 25 tons of gold in planed sale of 415 tons, latest in series of central banks to unload some of their bullion; sudden influx of gold on market pushes prices to another 20-year low, $255.75 an ounce in Europe, and leads to widespread criticism of Britain in South Africa, world's leading gold producer; National Union of Mineworkers in Johannesburg says it will picket British embassy in Pretoria; depressed price of gold also claims its first South African gold mine; trading is suspended in shares of East Rand Proprietary Mines, which files for bankruptcy protection and lays off 5,000 workers, possibly with no severance pay; South Africa's new Pres Tahbo Mbeki reverses himself and comes out firmly against International Monetary Fund's plan to sell gold to help forgive debt of poor countries; falling price of gold is severely undermining efforts of black majority in South Africa to claw its way out of poverty; unemployment is at 40 percent and 68 percent of black South Africa lives below 'the bread line' defined by University of South Africa--$170 a month for family of four; graph; photo (Market Place) (M)

headline: SHARES OF GENERAL GROWTH FALL AFTER STOCK SALE
abstract: Shares of General Growth Properties fall after company sells 10 million new shares to Lehman Brothers Inc at below-market price (S)

headline: That Never-Ending Spending
abstract: Deborah Stead reviews new book, Consuming Desires: Consumption, Culture and the Pursuit of Happiness, edited by Roger Rosenblatt; photo (M)

headline: China and U.S. Are Reported To Trade Threats on Taiwan
abstract: China and United States reportedly trade threats over what Beijing sees as Taiwan's moves toward independence; Clinton Administration officials are not certain what course Beijing has decided on, since warnings about possible use of force have come from lower-ranking Chinese officials, not from top Chinese leaders; Administration officials note that military aircraft from China and Taiwan have been flying close to each other over Taiwan Strait, making situation in 100-mile-wide waterway 'very delicate'; say United States is preparing for 'contingencies' in strait, but decline to elaborate (M)

headline: In Russia, a Power Play Acted Out on Television
abstract: Russian television channel controlled by Boris A Berezovsky, ally of Pres Boris N Yeltsin, plans weekly news program whose host, Sergei Dorenko, is known for attacks on political opponents; program will be aired at same time as long-running weekly program hosted by Yevgeny Kiselyov on channel controlled by Vladimir Gusinsky, who has recently broken with Yeltsin's dwindling team; head-to-head competition is latest skirmish in media war linked to political power struggle; Dorenko recalls both channels scheduled their news programs to avoid competition when both backed Yeltsin, interview; photo (M)

headline: TRUCKERS THREATEN STRIKE
abstract: Brazilian truckers threaten one-week nationwide strike to protest alleged unfair treatment by government authorities (S)

headline: Media Talk; News Executive Leaving It Behind For a Baseball Life
abstract: Media Talk column: publisher Michael Gartner will sell The Tribune--10,000-circulation newspaper in Ames, Iowa--to become part owner of Iowa Cubs, AAA minor-league franchise of Chicago Cubs; photo (S)

headline: Bank's Awareness Called Long Delayed
abstract: Large sums moved through accounts at the Bank of New York for at least six months before the bank was aware of it, according to individuals who have direct knowledge of an  investigation into Russian money laundering. They said accounts being examined became active much earlier than was previously believed.      Article, page A12.

headline: Compressed Data; G.E. Applies Its Talents To Internet Housekeeping
abstract: General Electric Co revamps three-year-old Web page and plans total makeover in fall; first changes are mainly cosmetic (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Copper rises almost 3 percent amid speculation about more production cuts in North America; in New York, copper for September delivery rises 2.2 cents, to 79.9 cents a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Subaru isn't tampering with success; it's just going to do what it has been doing -- only bigger.
abstract: Subaru is rolling out largest advertising campaign in its history, but is not changing its existing theme; Paul Hogan continues as Subaru's spokesman in integrated campaign from Subaru's agency Temerlin McClain, and campaign continues to emphasize safety and performance features; Subaru is doubling amount of broadcast and print placements and backing ads with $70 million and $80 million to push its revamped Legacy line and its 2000 Forester model; photo (Advertising column) (M)

headline: Expedia Expected To Pick Deutsch
abstract: Expedia, Webtravel site, is expected to name Deutsch LA as its first ad agency of record (S)

headline: With Plenty of Shine and Spin, CD's Weave Tapestries of Data
abstract: There are now almost 240 million CD-ROM drives installed in world's computers; in last five yaers, number of uses and types of optical disks have exploded; description of how optical disks work; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Actively Managed Funds Outpace the S.& P. Index Again
abstract: Average US diversified equity fund appears poised to top Standard & Poor's 500-stock index for second consecutive quarter; with Standard & Poor's index down 7.3 percent since June 30 and with return up only 4.2 percent for year, investors' impatience is showing; Investment Company Institute says investors put $9.2 billion into stock funds in August, down 25.7 percent from July sales of $12.4 billion; Trimtabs.com estimates total September stock fund sales of $11 billion; Lipper Inc says large-cap growth funds lost average of 4.2 percent this quarter through Sept 23, compared with 8.3 percent drop for large-cap value funds; mid-cap growth funds broke even, but mid-cap value funds fell 9.3 percent; performance of some of biggest funds noted (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Morgan Stanley Is Ordered To Produce Bias-Suit Files
abstract: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co loses round in its legal battle with employee Allison K Schieffelin who complained to Federal Government that company discriminated against her and other women; US District Judge Denise Cote rules that Morgan Stanley must turn over to Equal Employment Opportunity Commission all formal complaints of sexual harassment or discrimination that have been filed since Jan 1, 1995, by firm's employees in US (M)

headline: Art Museum Names 2 Agencies
abstract: Metropolitan Museum of Art names Abelson Co to handle creative part of its advertising account and DeWitt Media to handle media duties; account had been handled by LaPlaca Cohen Advertising (S)

abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.00   8.00   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.94   5.03   5.44        3-month T-bills   4.51   4.59   4.94        6-month T-bills   4.52   4.59   5.02        10-yr. headline: Drugstores Scramble to Find Choice Corners in Cyberspace
abstract: Lisa Prevost article on aggressive competition among Internet-based drugstore chains; on-line pharmacies can make it easier than ever to refill prescription or shop around for best deal in over-the-counter remedies; are finding it hard to win needed contracts with companies that manage prescription benefits for health insurance plans because of turf battles over mail-order prescriptions; some pharmacy benefit managers are moving ahead with own on-line pharmacies; photos (M)

headline: Political Reforms Reach Nigeria's Gasoline Pumps
abstract: Pres Olusegun Obasanjo, who heads Nigeria's first civilian Government in 16 years, has quickly pushed reforms that have visibly affected daily life; has ended military rulers' manipulation of oil supplies that had kept prices high and led to long, tense lines at gas stations in oil-producing nation; even critics say there is greater individual freedom; map; photo (M)

headline: Suspect in Atom Secrets Case Publicly Denies Aiding China
abstract: Wen Ho Lee, scientist dismissed from job after security breaches at Los Alamos National Laboratory, speaks in own defense on CBS news program 60 Minutes; proclaims innocence and denies divulging nuclear secrets to China or to any unauthorized person; admits transferring data from classified to unclassified computer system, but says operation was common practice that he performed to protect information; says he has become convenient scapegoat for American investigators, in part because he is only Asian-American working in weapons design group; Energy Sec Bill Richardson says Lee massively violated security procedures by having improper contact with Chinese officials, by deceiving American officials at Los Alamos and by transferring nuclear weapons information to unclassified computer systems; department officials acknowledge that other employees have sometimes violated computer security procedures, but say those infractions were on much smaller scale than Lee's (M)

headline: Violence as East Timor Awaits Vote Count
abstract: Gangs of street toughs battle outside United Nations compound, Dili, East Timor, killing at least one person and trapping UN officials and journalists inside for several hours; Indonesian police are slow to arrive and mostly stand aside during fighting, failing to protect Indonesians or foreigners beaten by thugs; battle is part of surge of tension as UN officials begin counting ballots after referendum on independence from Indonesia; photo (M)

headline: TECHNOLOGY: Digital Commerce; It's beginning to look as if users would rather pay directly for services on the Internet than wade through advertising.
abstract: View that all Internet businesses must offer free, advertiser-supported content is under attack as consumers increasingly use Internet for transactions; number of people who click on banner ads has fallen sharply, software is emerging to block ads entirely and consumers seem willing to pay for subscriptions; investors remain reluctant to fund pay services; drawing (M)

headline: Electronic Tolls for Thee
abstract: Joe McMahon letter on Sept 9 article cites electronic toll system used in Italy that does not require vehicles to slow down

headline: Big Internet Sites Joining Auction Network
abstract: Nearly 100 Internet sites, including Microsoft Corp's MSN, Excite at Home and Lycos, agree to share their auction listings so that an item put up for sale on one site will be available for bidding on all other sites; move is effort to catch up with huge popularity of Ebay, dominant on-line auction site; new auction network is owned by Fairmarket, small company in Woburn, Mass (M)

headline: $3.8 BILLION MORE FOR SEOULBANK
abstract: South Korea will spend another $3.8 billion (US) b

headline: A Feeding Frenzy Made for Consumers
abstract: E-commerce companies, flush with funds from initial public offerings or venture capitalists and desperate for fast growth, are offering shoppers variety of goods at or below cost, or with free shipping or all sorts of other giveaways and promotions; Web sites have been started for nearly every category of merchandise and most are planning to lose money for years; on-line buyers still face problems finding and navigating sites and with shipments that are often wrong, not intact or not on time; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PERRIGO CO., Allegan, Mich., the No. 1 U.S. maker of store-brand drugs, plans to sell its personal-care business, which has sales of $190 million, to Cumberland Swan Holdings, a concern owned primarily by Nashville investors, to focus on its over-the-counter pharmaceuticals and nutritional products. Terms were not disclosed.    ELCOM INTERNATIONAL INC., Norwood, Mass., a developer of business software, hired Wit Capital Corp., New York, as it considers selling shares of its electronic commerce unit to the public.

headline: In Real Life's Shadows, Virtual Life Can Pale
abstract: Commentary on whether virtual communities approximate the real thing, and how personal loss showed one user that sometimes nothing substitutes for a real community; photo (M)

headline: Deutsche Bank Predicts Growth And the Euro At $1.15 in 2000
abstract: FRANKFURT—  Confidence in Europe's economic upswing and its common currency gained new adherents Monday when Europe's biggest commercial bank gave an upbeat outlook for the first year of the next millennium.

headline: Compressed Data; Large Phone Contract From South Africa
abstract: Telcordia Technologies, formerly known as Bellcore, will announce big contract to help modernize Telkom South Africa's antiquated telephone systems and bring phone service to millions of South Africans for first time; contract is thought to be worth hundreds of millions of dollars to Telcordia over three years; Telkom, South Africa's telephone monopoly, is 30 percent owned by consortium of American giant SBC Communications Inc and Telekom Malaysia (M)

headline: Death Match on the Green (but Take Turns)
abstract: J C Herz column on Links Extreme CD-ROM, which combines precision of golf with wanton violence of video game; photo (M)

headline: Marketing services are gobbled up, and other tales of agency consolidation.
abstract: MORE agencies and agency companies are agreeing to deals to sell full or partial control to larger firms, as the acquisition boom remaking Madison Avenue continues.    In several instances, the deals involve shops that specialize in marketing services apart from traditional advertising tasks like creating television commercials and print advertisements. Spending for those services, which include direct marketing, sales promotion and interactive marketing, has been growing faster than their more familiar counterparts.

headline: Elizabeth Arden campaign strives for the unconventional.
abstract: Elizabeth Arden Co will redefine its image in unconventional $50 million advertising campaign, telling women that beauty comes from within, not from a jar; themed 'Embrace yourself,' campaign created by J Walter Thompson offers single image for cosmetics brand used for all Arden products around the world; Arden has been struggling in slow market dominated by Estee Lauder Companies; photo (M)

headline: For Iridium, A Quick Trip Back to Earth
abstract: Iridium LLC of Chicago, satellite phone service, files for Chapter 11 bankrputcy protection (M)

headline: AT&T Cost Cuts Could Trim Long-Distance Jobs
abstract: Thousands of employees in AT&T Corp's core long-distance telephone operation could lose their jobs before end of next year; many of those employees could find jobs in other, fast-growing AT&T divisions that will continue to adds jobs; lastest round of job cuts would come on top of 14 percent reduction in work force announced last year (M)

headline: KLM to Start Budget Flight Service in 2000
abstract: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines NV will start low-cost airline called Buzz early next year to challenge EasyJet Airlines Co and Go subsidiary of British Airways PLC; airline is investing $12.2 million (US) in Buzz (S)

headline: But Command Still Defends the Air War : NATO Lowers Its Tally Of Tanks Hit in Kosovo
abstract: PARIS—  NATO destroyed significantly fewer Serbian tanks in Kosovo than the alliance had claimed at the end of the air war, General Wesley Clark said Thursday, acknowledging that only 26 actual wreckages had been found by allied troops who have been combing the province since June.

headline: BARAK AND ARAFAT SIGN PEACE ACCORD WITH A NEW HOPE
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat sign broad peace accord, Sharm el Sheik, Egypt, as trust between them apparently grows; State Sec Madeleine K Albright, Egyptian Pres Hosni Mubarak and Jordanian King Abdullah II attend rite; Albright earlier met in Syria with Pres Hafez al-Assad, but won no immediate signal that Israeli-Syrian talks can open soon; then visited Beirut, previously unannounced stop, for talks with Lebanese leaders; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    CROATIA: WAR CRIMES SUSPECT EXTRADITED -- Croatia extradited a Bosnian Croat suspected of war crimes for trial before the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague. Vinko Martinovic, 36, was indicted in December on charges of crimes against humanity, grave breaches of the Geneva Convention and violations of laws and customs of war. He and Mladen Naletilic, 52, were accused of driving tens of thousands of Muslims from Mostar, in Bosnia.   (AP)    MACEDONIA: PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION SET -- An election will be held on Oct. 31 to choose a successor to the 84-year-old President, Kiro Gligorov, who said he would not seek a second five-year term. Voters in Macedonia, which seceded from Yugoslavia in 1991, are sharply divided along ethnic lines. Ethnic Albanians, who comprise about one-third of the electorate, have already announced their own nominee.   (AP)

headline: G.M. Finance Unit in Deal
abstract: General Motors Acceptance Corp announces plan to take over operations of Nippon Asset Management Inc (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.00   8.00   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.94   4.92   5.48        3-month T-bills   4.43   4.47   4.92        6-month T-bills   4.45   4.46   5.02        10-yr.
