headline: China Urged to Free American Hurt Fleeing Police
abstract: Clinton Adm presses China for immediate release of American reported suffering serious spinal injuries during jump or fall from window of building in confrontation with Chinese police; China says 29-year-old Daja Meston, Tibetan linguist from Newton, Mass, was injured while trying to escape police in remote area of Qinghai province where Govt is carrying out population resettlement program opposed by human rights groups and environmentalists (S)

headline: Circuit City Stores Picks Omnicom Unit
abstract: Circuit City Stores names TBWA/Chiat/Day to handle its advertising account; billings estimated at $60 million to $75 million (S)

headline: Facing 2000, Companies Stock Up On Money
abstract: Kenneth Gilpin Market Insight column offers excerpts of interview with Merrill Lynch & Co managing director Thomas M Likovich, who comments on reasons why increasing number of companies are raising funds through initial public offerings and common stock offerings as year 2000 comes closer; photo (M)

headline: He Criticizes Malaysia for Jailing of Canadian : Clinton Backs Journalist
abstract: KUALA LUMPUR—  President Bill Clinton said Monday that he was "deeply concerned" about the jailing of a Canadian journalist in Malaysia.

headline: Indian Official Denies Talks With Pakistan Over Kashmir Fighting
abstract: India External Affairs Min Jaswant Singh asserts that India is not involved in 'any negotiations' and 'not even consultations' with Pakistan, sloughing off speculation in both nations that back-channel diplomacy is under way to end violent crisis in mountains of Kashmir (M)

headline: Amex Trader Is Given Fine in Settlement
abstract: American Stock Exchange member Michael H Schwartz, options trader, agrees to pay $160,000 fine to settle case stemming from accusations that he authorized New York Stock Exchange floor broker Steven Blandi to trade for gain of both on floor of New York Stock Exchange; fine is one of largest imposed by Amex against individual member; Schwartz was accused of agreeing to share profits from improper trades with Blandi, who bought and sold stock for Schwartz's account (S)

headline: A Renaissance In Computer Science; Chip Designers Search for Life After Silicon
abstract: Groundbreaking research suddenly seems to be flourishing at both corporate and academic computer laboratories around United States; researchers seem to be at or near breakthroughs that could vastly raise power and ubiquity of computers; Hewlett-Packard-University of California at Los Angeles joint work on tiny electronic switches thickness of single molecule cited; diagrams; photo (M)

headline: Software to Help Violinists Bring Tears to Listeners' Eyes
abstract: Prof Frank Boutsen and Christy Bager develop software aimed at helping aspiring violinists improve efficiency of arm movements in order to make cleanest sound; software also enables violinists to view results of their vibrato attempts (vibation of player's fingers as they press strings on neck of stringed instrument) as depictions of waves on computer screen; photo of sofware image (M)

headline: Michelin to Invest $400 Million in U.S.
abstract: Michelin North America Inc will invest at least $400 million in South Carolina over next five years as it expands to overcome slower growth in Europe; says investment could reach $900 million over 10 years and include 1,400 new jobs (S)

headline: 401(k) Advice on Line
abstract: Number of services have sprung up on Internet to offer investors advice about their 401(k) retirement plans (Mutual Funds Report) (S)0

headline: MONTGOMERY WARD EMERGES FROM BANKRUPTCY
abstract: Montgomery Ward Holding Corp emergences from bankruptcy after being acquired by GE Capital Inc for over $650 million (S)

headline: As 2000 Nears, a Wary Optimism for Ukraine's Nuclear Plants
abstract: Project financed by Western governments is under way to try to immunize Ukraine's 14 aging, trouble-prone nuclear reactors against year 2000 computer problem (M)

headline: JAPAN GIVES HINT THAT IT WILL ACT TO HALT YEN'S RISE
abstract: Bank of Japan's governor hints he may reverse course and act to halt three-month-long rise in value of Japanese yen before it chokes off country's fragile economic recovery and provokes further clashes with United States; vaguely worded announcement from Masaru Hayami, plus communique issued by finance ministers of Group of 7 largest industrialized nations, is enough to strengthen dollar slightly and weaken yen; just last week Hayami and central bank defied Japanese politicians and Washington by refusing to stop rise in yen's value; Hayami's comments are important in part because Wall Street reacted badly to moves last week by Bank of Japan; future of American stock markets seem increasingly dependent on decisions of Japan's central bank, institution that operates by its own rules and market rationale (M)

headline: Where the Help Desk Goes for Good Advice
abstract: Win 98 Central, Web site offering technical advice and information on Microsoft Windows 98, evaluated (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: MIDDLE EAST    ISRAEL: SABBATH CRISIS AVERTED -- A political crisis was defused over the transport of a huge electrical turbine on the Jewish Sabbath. Ultra-Orthodox parties, which had threatened to quit Prime Minister Ehud Barak's coalition, were temporarily assuaged by a compromise agreement: The electrical company's turbine, which was to be transported on the Sabbath because it will move only at three miles per hour, was loaded before sundown, will be unloaded after sundown and will be driven by a non-Jewish truck driver.     Deborah Sontag (NYT)    EUROPE    SPAIN: BASQUE REBELS HALT TALKS -- The Basque separatist group E.T.A. suspended peace talks with the Government, accusing it of seeking political gain from the only negotiations last May. But the rebels stopped short of halting their unilateral cease-fire observed since Sept. 16. Their latest statement to the Basque news media, on Thursday, came a day after Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar blamed the rebels for stalling and charged that they are ''afraid of peace.''   Al Goodman (NYT)

headline: Fraud Conviction Reversed In Air Crash Insurance Case
abstract: Federal appeals court throws out fraud convictions of United States Aviation Underwriters Inc, a leading airline insurer, and its former chief executive, Jophn Brennan, who had been accused of trying to avoid financial responsibility in 1987 commuter plane crash in California; says case should have been tried in Southern District of New York, not Eastern District; decision nullifies fine of $20.5 million against insurer and prison term of 4 years and 9 months for Brennan; case against insurer grew out of midair shooting aboard Pacific Southwestern Airlines flight from Los Angeles to San Francisco; plane crashed, killing 43 people, after disgruntled employee of airline shot his former supervisor, the pilot and co-pilot (M)

headline: Israeli Cabinet Appointments Seem Aimed at Consolidating Barak's Control
abstract: Israel's Prime Minister-elect Ehud Barak consolidates hold on power as he completes Govt by appointing loyal old-timers to two key posts in Cabinet and keeping third for himself; Israeli political experts say he is acting much like military commander, flanking himself with Foreign Minister and Finance Minister not expected to challenge or overshadow him; he appoints Avraham Shochat Finance Minister for second time and David Levy Foreign Minister for third time; other appointments noted; political makeup of Cabinet discussed (M)

headline: Banco do Brasil Rescue Plan Raises Investors' Anxiety
abstract: Senate approves measure that erases $3.4 billion in questionable securities from books of Banco do Brasil, move that may have averted insolvency at 191-year-old bank, Latin America's largest; measure, which transfers responsibility for securities from bank to federal treasury, has raised considerable concern among investors about how such large amounts of risky securities could be so easily shuffled around in Brazil by high-ranking officials with little accountability; measure reverses earlier decision that had made Banco do Brasil responsible for questionable bonds; bonds, originally issued by City of Sao Paulo years ago during period of rampant fiscal mismanagement, have face value of $3.4 billion; transfer of bonds to federal Government could lead to closer examination of how Braxil manages its financial institutions (M)

headline: Pakistani's Pullout Vow: A Very Hard Sell at Home
abstract: News analysis: Pakistan's Prime Min Nawaz Sharif is likely to find it difficult to deliver on pledge to US following White House meeting with Pres Clinton to withdraw Pakistani-backed forces from Indian side of cease-fire line in disputed territory of Kashmir; few Pakistanis see Sharif's sudden decision to visit Clinton, and pledge to take concrete steps to restore cease-fire line, as breakthrough that could end limited, undeclared war with India; most see it either as sell-out of Kashmir cause or another ill-fated move in diplomatic game of chess; photo (M)

headline: North Korea Agrees to Talks With U.S. Aide On Missile Test
abstract: State Department reports United States and North Korea will meet in Berlin in Sept to discuss North Korea's suspected preparations to test new long-range ballistic missile; says Charles Kartman and Deputy Min Kim Gye Gwan will lead delegations (M)

headline: Leadership Shift At Campbell Mithun
abstract: Jim White, executive officer of Campbell Mithun Esty, is leaving agency; John Hurst is named executive vice president and chief creative officer, assuming White's duties; Rick Gibson and George Halvorson are promoted to associate creative officers (S)

headline: Indonesia Invites a U.N. Force to Timor
abstract: Pres B J Habibie concedes that Indonesian Government forces are unable to control continuing violence in East Timor and capitulates to international pressure by inviting UN to send peacekeeping force to troubled territory; says international force must work hand in hand with Indonesian troops, who appear divided over whether to undermine or enforce policy of allowing East Timor to choose independence; Prime Min John Howard of Australia, which is spearheading potential force, praises decision; Defense Min John Moore says deployment may take three to five days after Indonesia and UN work out details; Pres Clinton says US contribution will be limited but important, such as providing intelligence reports and communications help; maps (M)

headline: LOAN FOR LOEWEN
abstract: Bankruptcy court has approved request by Loewen Group Inc of Canada, one of largest funeral home operators in North America, to draw on $200 million survival loan arranged by First Union National Bank (S)

headline: A New Player Can Decipher MP3 Music Files on CD's
abstract: Pine Technology, in uncommon merger of competing technologies, says it has found way to combine best of MP3 music and CD players; device, which can also be used as regular CD player, can read and decode compressed music stored on compact disks in MP3 format; users will need to add CD writer to their personal computers to get MP3 music onto CD's (S)

headline: Taiwan Quake to Be Costly to World Technology Makers
abstract: Industrial disruption from Taiwan's devastating earthquake could delay or reduce production of high-technology items--affecting far more than just computer semiconductors that Taiwan manufactures in large quantities; Taiwan is world's fourth-largest maker of semiconductors and third largest of personal computers; most of its products go into big-name brands all over world, including IBM, Motorola and Toshiba; immediate and obvious impact on international business from earthquake is on semiconductor makers, which supply chips that are brains of personal computers; Taiwan Semiconductor, with world's biggest chip foundry, says its installation withstood quake and that it will lose no more than 10 percent of its production this month; analysts say big problem facing producers in Taiwan is not structural damage, but absence of electricity; effect of earthquake could be to further inflate prices of memory chips, which have been rising because demand is outstripping supply; graph on surge in price of semiconductors in recent weeks (M)

headline: DATABANK: JULY 18-July 23; If It Weren't for Those Darn Profits...
abstract: Roundup of stock and bond market for week ending July 24, when robust profit reports abounded and major stock market indexes sagged; graphs; charts (L)

headline: An Internet Stable Is Ahead of the Pack
abstract: Article on success of recent stock offering by Internet Capital Group, holding company in Wayne, Pa, that owns stakes in 36 mostly private Internet-related companies; graph (M)

headline: A Toy, Yes, But a PC At Heart
abstract: Peter H Lewis State of the Art column evaluates Sega's new Dreamcast video game console, first of new generation of home game machines to go on sale in United States; unlike earlier machines, which were closer to toys than to computers, powerful $199 Dreamcast blurs distinction between PC and game console; unit comes with 56K modem and Internet software for e-mail, Web browsing and chatting, but games must be purchased separately; Dreamcast, along with consoles to be released soon by Sony and Nintendo, could become an alternative to PC's for people who want to connect to the Net through TV screeens; drawing; photo (M)

headline: Paris Journal; An Old Prediction Speeds France's Annual Exodus
abstract: Dire predictions of Nostradamus that apocalypse will descend across swath of northern Europe on August 11 speeds exodus of French residents on annual five-week vacations; many are heeding advice of well-known designer Paco Rabanne in best-selling book, 1999: Fire From the Heavens, to stay at least 60 kilometers from Paris; photo (M)

headline: IN MY... BAG: Maria Elena Lagomasino
abstract: Chase Manhattan Global Private Bank executive Maria Elena Lagomasino describes what she carries in her purse; photos (M)

headline: Oil Price Up As OPEC's Cuts Seem to Hold
abstract: Crude oil rises to 19-month high of $19.78, up 9 cents, on signs that OPEC will adhere to its promised production cuts in months ahead; graph; chart (M)

headline: 'A Breather' From the Tycoons
abstract: 'A Breather' From the Tycoon

headline: SJW, CALIFORNIA WATER UTILITY COMPANY, CONSIDERS SALE
abstract: SJW Corp, which owns water utility with 971,000 customers in California, hires Morgan Stanley Dean Witter to help it consider strategic alternatives, including sale of the company (S)

headline: PROTECTION ONE AND LIFELINE END MERGER TALKS
abstract: Protection One and

headline: Deutsche Telekom to Expand Into British Market
abstract: Deutsche Telekom AG to buy British cellular phone company One 2 One Ltd for equivalent of $11.1 million in cash and $2.5 billion in assumed debt from Cable and Wireless PLC and Mediaone Group Inc; merger signals its broader move to become pan-European telecommunications brand (M)

headline: Profit Up 6% at Times Mirror; 2% Rise at Los Angeles Times
abstract: Times Mirror Co, parent of Los Angeles Times, says second-quarter profit rose 6 percent; company earned $74.7 million compared with $70.5 million a year ago; revenue rose 6 percent, to $801.3 million from $755.8 million; operating profit at Los Angeles Times increrased by at least 2 percent; newspaper's advertising volume increased by 33.5 percent (M)

headline: Russia's Role Still Debated
abstract: Despite an earlier accord, Russia and NATO are still arguing about exactly where Russian peacekeepers should go in Kosovo and whose orders they should follow. Page A10.

headline: Finalists Named For Internet Work
abstract: Newspage.com, Real Media Inc and Gay Financial Network Inc narrow reviews on advertising accounts (S)

headline: French Prosecutor Says Pursuers of Diana Did Not Cause Crash
abstract: Paris prosecutor's office recommends dropping all charges against nine photographers and photo-agency motorcyclist under investigation for their role in Aug 1997 car crash that killed Diana, Princess of Wales, Emad Mohammed al-Fayed and driver, Henri Paul; says exhaustive probe found no grounds for bringing criminal charges (M)

headline: Laidlaw Selling 2 Businesses to Focus on Bus Operations
abstract: Laidlaw Inc, Canadian-based operator of North America's largest bus fleet, including Greyhound lines, to sell 44 percent stake in its Safety-Kleen Corp and its health care division and will use some of $2 billion in anticipated proceeds to buy more buses; health care division includes American Medical Response and Emcare (M)

headline: A Big Birthday Finds the Chinese Prospering
abstract: First article in series A Half-Century in China, examining scene in China as it prepares to celebrate 50th anniversary of People's Republic; finds that most people have a sense of progress and pride, despite an uncertain economy and grumbling about politics; reports on legacy of revolutionary experiment that Mao Zedong initiated 50 years ago on Oct 1, an experiment that in some way upended and uprooted virtually every family in China, leaving millions dead or broken, but ultimately easing the survivors into relative prosperity of today; contrasting experiences of two families over last 50 years discussed; chronology of China's revolution; photos (L)

headline: Chief of Tenneco to Resign After Spinoff
abstract: Tenneco Inc chief executive Dana G Mead reportedly will retire after company spins off packaging business to shareholders later in year (S)

headline: 3 in the Running For Lending Tree
abstract: Lending Tree Inc narrows review for its first account to three finalists; billings estimated at $50 million (S)

headline: A Way to Let Your Fingers Recharge Your Batteries
abstract: Compaq Computer Corp files patent for keyboard that uses typing motion itself to recharge laptop batteries (S)

headline: Niagara-on-the-Lake Journal; Low Pay and Hard Work, Blessed by Immigration
abstract: Article on farm program run by Canadian Govt that allows thousands of migrant workers, mostly Mexican, into country each year for up to eight months; workers are paid $4.75 per hour, are provided with free housing and medical care and pension that will be sent to them when they retire; use of workers on farms in Niagara-on-the-Lake discussed; map; photo (M)

headline: Take These Jokes . . . Please
abstract: Joke-telling is one of most popular uses of the Internet and e-mail; online humor is developing as an art unto itself, with its own customs, critics and avant-garde; even as new joke forms develop, a debate has broken out among some sophisticated jesters over whether Internet mode of distribution is changing the essence of humor; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Fed Raises Interest Rates But Is Neutral on the Future  The Federal Reserve, led by Alan Greenspan, nudged its benchmark interest rate up by a quarter-point but said there was no clear case for another rate increase to keep inflation at bay, catching many economists and investors off guard.    The shift to a neutral stance from a stance toward higher rates was taken as a green light by investors on Wall Street, who rapidly bid up stock and bond prices. The Dow Jones industrial average surged 210 points in the 13 minutes after the central bank's announcement and finished up 155.45 points, while the Nasdaq composite index and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index reached new highs. [Page A1.]

headline: Israel to Release Eichmann Memoir
abstract: Israeli Justice Ministry says last memoirs of Nazi war criminal Adolf Eichmann, kept under lock and key in Israeli state archives for nearly 40 years, will be released to German researchers for scholarly publication; photo (M)

headline: Fed Actions Aid Recovery Of Treasuries
abstract: Bond prices rebound as traders cover short positions after Federal Reserve takes measures to insure there would be enough money in banking system to counter any Year 2000 computer problems; price of 30-year bond rises 3/32, to 100 26/32, with yield unchanged at 6.07 percent; graphs (M)

headline: ICG COMMUNICATIONS SELLS FIBER OPTIC HOLDING
abstract: ICG Communica

headline: To Get Cult To Leave, Japan Cities Buy It Out
abstract: Growing number of Japanese cities are driving out followers of Aum Shinrikyo religious sect by using public money to buy up property owned by doomsday cult (M)

headline: China's Bright Young Stars
abstract: They were only in their teens when Mao died in 1976; they came of age in the more outward-looking China of Deng Xiaoping. They do not know the fear and caution that their parents and grandparents imbibed with revolution and repression; they are not strangers to the world; they are not afraid of reform. And when the men who have led the Communist state through the half-century since its founding on Oct. 1, 1949, are gone, they may well be among its leaders. Who are they?     Zeng Qiang is the founder of an Internet company that, he is confident, will soon be earning billions of dollars a year. Zhao Shujing is the producer of China's most influential women's show. Dong Yunhu is an active Communist who has helped formulate China's human rights policy. Lu Zhi is an environmentalist, one of the world's top authorities on pandas. Liu Junning is one of China's most influential liberal political thinkers. Sun Jianjun returned from studies in California to stage popular TV shows and galas.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro drops to its weakest level ever on expectations that European economic growth will lag behind that of US; in New York, euro settles at $1.0229, down from $1.0338; graph; chart (S)

headline: INTERNET SPEED
abstract: Computer scientists at Duke University announce development of system for standard Internet communications over local area network, or LAN, that moves at rate of more than one gigabit per second, which is twice speed of current fastest LAN (S)

headline: Merger of Veba and Viag Expected Today
abstract: Veba AG's supervisory board approves $14.7 billion merger with Viag AG, creating Europe's third-largest electricity company and third-largest chemicals company (S)

headline: Peru's Drug Successes Erode as Traffickers Adapt
abstract: Price of coca leaves in Peru has rebounded over last year--two-thirds of way to its 1995 highs; officials say drug traffickers have found ways to reopen some air routes and to replace others, making coca profitable once again; change underscores cyclical nature of drug war in Peru that is unavoidably tied to appetite for cocaine in US and Europe and to impossibility of choking off all trafficking routes through South America; graph; map; photo (M)

headline: Locking the Door
abstract: Aaron Sherber letter comments on dial-up Internet access addresses (July 8 article)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.

headline: Germans Await U.S. Extradition Request
abstract: Martin Frankel, money manager said to have embezzled hundreds of millions of dollars, is in prison in Hamburg, Germany, as prosecutors there wait for American law enforcement officials to ask formally for his extradition to United States; Frankel's lawyer, Thomas Piplak, visits him in jail and says his client is depressed and fearful of returning to United States; says he may try to block extradition if he finds that Frankel is in danger from strong, powerful groups that are after him because of what he knows; photo (M)

headline: AMERICAN TOWER GETS RIGHTS TO 2,100 AIRTOUCH SITES
abstract: Vodafone Airtouch PLC says its Airtouch Communications Inc unit has agreed to grant rights to 2,100 communications towers to American Tower Corp for $800 million; agreement bolsters American Tower's position as number 1 wireless tower owner in US (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Copper falls as soaring stockpiles signal that demand is still too weak to absorb higher output from Latin America; in New York, copper for September delivery falls 1.7 cents, to 76.20 cents a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: HYUNDAI UNIT SELLS ASSETS
abstract: Hyundai Petrochemicals sells its waste-water treatment operations for $200 million to Vivendi SA and sells its power generation operations for $100 million to Sithe Energies, US affiliate of Vivendi (S)

headline: East Timorese Flee Homes, And Encounter More Danger
abstract: East Timorese fleeing campaign of terror by Army-backed militias encounter fresh danger in makeshift camps in neighboring West Timor; gangs roam camps, harassing aid workers and journalists in search for those they believe voted for independence; fear is pervasive as army and police seem unwilling or unable to control gangs, which effectively run camps; Indonesian Government is supplying food and water to refugees, but international relief agencies are reluctant to send staff members; photo (M)

headline: A Car, With a Catch, When Credit Is Bad
abstract: Mel Farr, the former Detroit Lions football player who is now a car dealer in Detroit, is willing to lease autos to people with no credit or bad credit. A payment of at least $50 is due every Friday night, and customers must pay up each week to get a code they need to punch into a device attached to the dashboard. Otherwise, the car won't start. It isn't cheap. Mr. Farr's interest rates run as high as 25 percent.     Article, page A15.

headline: Planet Earth Calling Iridium; Can the Satellite Phone Service Achieve a Soft Landing?
abstract: Iridium LLC, global satellite telephone venture, is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy, but its executives dismiss any talk of liquidation and Motorola, which designed and built satellites, continues to support venture; company has just 20,000 subscribers after spending more than $5 billion in last decade to create network of 66 low-orbit satellites capable of serving most remote places on planet; broad array of experts suggest even most enlightened restructuring plan may not stave off liquidation; say there is not enough of potential market for such satellite-based global communications system; photos; graphs; chart (M)

headline: Deluxe Dilemma: To Sell Globally or Sell Haughtily?
abstract: Luxury vendors, while opening informational Web sites, are reluctant to sell goods on line; seek ways to tap Internet market without harming exclusive image or angering traditional retailers; weigh separate merchandise lines for sale only on Internet; some luxury sites are loosely knit fronts for dozen or more upscale retailers; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Bear Stearns Agrees to Pay Fines of $38.5 Million  Bear Stearns has agreed to pay $38.5 million in fines and restitution relating to its role as the processor of securities trades for A. R. Baron, a small New York brokerage firm that collapsed in 1996.

headline: CEL-SCI RECEIVES UNSOLICITED $124 MILLION BID
abstract: Cel-Sci Corp says it has received unsolicited cash offer of $124 million from unidentified persion in Argentina; Cel-Sci says it has been unsuccessful in trying to reach person who made offer and that it is unable to determine whether offer is legitimate (S)

headline: Jumping Off the Bandwidth Wagon
abstract: Alex Mashinsky's Arbinet Communications, Manhattan exchange that deal in long-distance telephone minutes from New York, has boomed as capacity for such calls has become a commodity, a result of deregulation and advances in technology; Mashinsky comments; graph; photos (M)

headline: NEW PUBLISHING CHIEF
abstract: Reed Elsevier PLC names Crispin Davis to be its new chief executive, beginning in September; Davis is chief executive of media services company Aegis Group PLC; Davis replaces co-chief executives Nigel Stapleton and Herman Bruggink (S)

headline: Even Guerrillas Vote Peaceably
abstract: East Timor guerrillas fighting for independence from Indonesia vote on referendum--some traveling from secret base with armed escort (S)

headline: Two Victims Are Identified In Accident In Swiss Gorge
abstract: Rescue workers continue searching rapids near Interlaken, Switzerland, for two missing tourists; police say they have identified two of 19 victims of July 27 flash flood, Swiss woman and New Zealand man who were guides on disastrous canyoning excursion (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Executive Power Struggle Hobbles Kroll-O'Gara  A power struggle among executives of Kroll-O'Gara, America's leading corporate investigations company, has contributed to a 50 percent fall in its share price despite its having posted record profits just two months ago.    Jules B. Kroll, Kroll-O'Gara's chairman and chief executive, has lined up several potential investors he expects will help him remove Thomas M. O'Gara, the vice chairman, from the company, according to people close to the company. [Page C10.]

headline: Russian Promises Help From Police
abstract: Foreign Min Igor S Ivanov of Russia says team of Russian law enforcement officials is going to Washington in effort to prove Moscow's eagerness to cooperate with American inquiries into money laundering; aide to Secretary of State Madeline K Albright says Russian corruption and its effect on international financial system was high on agenda during her recent meeting with Ivanov (S)

headline: Tennis Elbow?
abstract: Readers are asked to respond to question sbout whether they ever fibbed to get out of work or caught anyone else playing hooky; drawing (S)

headline: Honors
abstract: Carla Loffredo is elected president of Advertising Club of New York, succeeding Steven Farella, who continues as chairman; Robert Mate is elected first vice president (S)

headline: Kansas Utility Deal Advances
abstract: Western Resources Inc, largest electric utility in Kansas, reaches agreement with Federal regulators on steps that it must take to win approval of $3 billion buyout of Kansas City Power and Light Co (S)

headline: NEWS WATCH
abstract: New Web site called Book Adventure offers prizes to children who earn points for successfully answering on-line questions about books they have read (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: MIDDLE EAST    IRAN: PRESIDENT AFFIRMS STANCE -- President Mohammad Khatami, his reformist policies under attack by hard-liners after some of the worst unrest since the 1979 Islamic revolution, pledged to stand by his election promise to protect civil liberties. Mr. Khatami's speech, his first public appearance since pro-democracy student protests from July 8 to July 13, kicked off a three-day tour of the western province of Hamadan.   (Reuters)    IRAQ: NERVE GAS SET FOR DESTRUCTION -- The United Nations Security Council permitted an international arms team to proceed with the destruction of tiny specimens of the deadly nerve gas VX in Baghdad despite weeklong attempts by Russia to have the samples preserved. At issue was an attempt by Russia to have the chemical agents analyzed, a move suggesting suspicions by Moscow that the Special Commission, in charge of Iraqi disarmament, might have daubed VX on Iraqi missile warheads to fabricate evidence against Baghdad.   (Reuters)

headline: AMERICAN TOWER IN $260 MILLION DEAL WITH UNIT OF AT&T
abstract: American Tower Corp has agreed to acquire 1,942 microwave towers from AT&T Corp and build 1,000 new wireless communications sites for AT&T's Wireless Services unit; transaction has cash value of $260 million (S)

headline: For a Perky Do-It-Yourself Web Site, the Price Was Right
abstract: Marty Katz article on helping friend, coffee store owner, set up own electronic commerce Web site at very little cost and without owning working computer; notes friend uses site to research suppliers, lure customers with special promotions and sell coffee-related items; photo (M)

headline: Traders Bet Fed Is Done With Rate Increases
abstract: US Treasury securities rally on prospect that increase in short-term interest rates announced by Federal Reserve could be last of the year; 30-year Treasury bond is up 1 5/32, to 103 29/32; yield falls to 5.85 percent from 5.93 percent; graphs on 2-year Treasury notes and yields on Feeral Home Loan Mortgage Corp participation certificates; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Push for Wholesale Banks Stalls in Overhaul of Law
abstract: Push for wholesale financial entities knowns as 'woofies' stalls in overhaul of law to deregulate financial services industry; House version of measure provides for woofies, but Senate version does not, and it is unclear whether woofies will be restored or jettisoned as Congressional conferees reconcile differences in two versions later this month; woofie is basically commercial bank that does not engage in retail activities and does not take retail deposits; woofies would not get Federal deposit insurance but would be part of Federal Reserve system and have access to Federal Reserve's discount window, should it need to borrow money for liquidity needs; Edward Yingling, chief lobbyist for American Bankers Association, says he is not sure anyone is interested in woofies anymore (M)

headline: Banners Carry Blunt Message: 'Change' and 'Resign'
abstract: Most of demonstrators in Belgrade are educated urban elite: students, young professionals and their parents, who look as if they are walking in park after work; but they are also ordinary workers and activists who drive in from various parts of country, bringing flags and banners, even fireworks (M)

headline: PARTIAL EXONERATIONS IN SOUTH KOREA
abstract: South Korean court acquits former Finance and Economy Minister Kang Kyong and former chief presidential economic secretary Kyong Shik of charges that they neglected duties during economic crisis (S)

headline: Hard Line at Harvard
abstract: Don Rothschild letter on June 20 article defends forced resignation of Harvard Divinity School Dean Ronald F Thiemann for reportedly having pornographic images on school-owned computer in his Harvard-owned home

headline: BRITISH AIRWAYS TO CUT JOBS
abstract: British Airways PLC will eliminate 1,000 jobs as it tries to cut costs by $361 million (US) in move to increase profits after its worst quarter in seven years (S)

headline: A Second Look at Second-Quarter Forecasts
abstract: Expectations are high as second-quarter earnings season gets into full swing this week; Wall Street analysts who make forecasts for the 500 companies in Standard & Poor's stock index are predicting first double-digit growth in quarterly corporate earnings since end of 1997; graph shows yearly change in operating earnings for S&P 500 companies )M)

headline: ALLIED SIGNAL SELLS ONE BUSINESS AND BUYS ANOTHER
abstract: Allied Signal Inc sells its Laminate Systems business to Rutgers AG for about $425 million; buys Johnson Matthey PLC's electronics unit for $655 million (S)

headline: Even Beyond the Big Guys, A Wealth of Auction Choices
abstract: Smaller Internet auction sites offer far fewer items for sale at one time than Ebay or other giants, but often at lower prices; list of alternative auction sites; drawing (M)

headline: Role Reversal In Merger Deal
abstract: Westinghouse Air Brake Co and Motivepower Industries reverse roles in revised $475.3 million stock swap merger that would create North America's largest rail-parts maker and build on rail-industry consolidation; Westinghoue Air will exchange 0.66 share of its stock for each share of Motivepower and will assume about $130 million in debt; combined company will be called Westinghouse Air Brake; Motivepower's chairman John C Pope and chief executive Michael Wolf will leave combined company when transaction is completed (S)

headline: First Out of the Starting Gate
abstract: Register.com has positioned itself as first and most aggressive competitor to Network Solutions Inc in Internet address registrations; it and other competitors await Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers meeting at which it is expected to resolve key policy issues; founder Richard Forman comments; photo (M)

headline: East Timor Chaos Is Seen as Imperiling Indonesia Recovery
abstract: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: East Timor Chaos Is Seen as Imperiling Indonesia Recovery**Indonesian Government officials and independent analysts warn failure to quell chaos in East Timor could strangle Indonesia's fragile economic recovery; fear apparently military-backed terror campaign will spur International Monetary Fund, World Bank and other foreign lenders to shun Indonesia and cause local business to lose confidence in Government's authority; Indonesian currency continues to y weaken (M)

headline: Low Fares and Empty Seats Hurt British Airways' Results
abstract: British Airways PLC says first-quarter pretax profit fell 84 percent; profit fell to 23 million pounds, or $37 million, compared with 145 million pounds, or $233.4 million in year-earlier period; net income rose 43.5 percent, to 188 million pounds, or $302.5 million, compared with 131 million pounds, or $210.8 million a year ago (M)

headline: Prices in Broad Decline, With Dow Falling 52.55
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes at 10,655.15, down 52.55 points, or 0.5 percent; Nasdaq composite index is down 28.87 points, or 1.2 percent, to 2.490.11; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closes at 1,281.43, down 16.37 points, or 1.3 percent; graph; chart (M)

headline: Hewlett Says Earnings Top Expectations
abstract: Hewlett Packard Co reports third fiscal quarter earnings that exceed Wall Street analysts' estimates; predicts company will see 11 to 13 percent revenue growth in next quarter; reports earnings in quarter ended July 31 of $853 million, up 37 percent, compared with $621 million in year-earlier period; revenues rose 11 percent, to $12.23 billion, compared with $10.98 billion in third quarter of fiscal 1998; company says it has filed registration statement with Securities and Exchange Commission for initial public offering of its subsidiary, Agilent Technologies Inc (M)

headline: Timberland Splits Stock
abstract: Timberland Co sets two-for-one stock split (S)

headline: AMAR GOEL, Chief Executive, Chipshot.com, a golfing-gear site
abstract: Amar Goel, Chipshot.com official, cites his favorite Internet shopping locations; drawing; photo (S)

headline: CBS Extends Deal With Head of TV Operations
abstract: CBS extends its deal with Leslie Moonves to serve as CBS Television president; elects him to board (M)

headline: PACIFICORP TO SELL ITS CALIFORNIA OPERATIONS
abstract: Pacificorp agrees to sell its California electric service operations to Nor-Cal Electric Authority for $178 million (S)

headline: Sprint Assignment For D.M.B.& B.
abstract: Sprint Corp expands agency roster by naming D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications as first advertising agency to handle consumer Sprint Ion account, residential communications system combining Internet with phone and other services (S)

headline: Leader Tries to Brighten Algeria's Image
abstract: Algerian Pres Abdelaziz Bouteflika is in New York City, talking to business groups, courting investors and promoting free enterprise; is trying to brighten Algeria's image; he was elected President in April after country had endured seven years of fighting between Islamic militants and army-backed Government in which tens of thousands of people were killed; week ago, Algerian voters overwhelmingly endorsed amnesty plan devised by Bouteflika that is intended to persuade militants to surrender so that country could begin to rebuild; photo (M)

headline: I.B.M. Does An About-Face On Pensions
abstract: IBM, in major victory of controversial type of new pension, says it will allow 35,000 additional employees to retain their old pension benefits, backing down from earlier move forcing them to accept what for many would be far lower benefits from new cash-balance pension; company has been under pressure since it announced earlier this year that it was switching to cash-balance plan, prompting lawmakers to demand age-discrimination investigations and IBM workers to seek to organize union (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Thank a team of number-crunchers in Geneva for the recent bumpy ride in Asian stock markets.
abstract: Decision by Geneva-based Morgan Stanley Capital International to change its Asian stock indexes is linked to volatility in Asian stock markets; on Aug 12, Morgan Stanley announced it would reinstate Malaysia in two of those indexes; also said it would adjust its portfolios to double weighting of Taiwan; to restore Malaysia and bolster Taiwan, Morgan Stanley will reduce relative weighing of other Asian countries in indexes; that could be crucial to how much foreign investment flows to these countries; news had drastic effect on Asian markets (Market Place column) (M)

headline: American Topics : Short Takes
abstract: The American Civil Liberties Union plans to sue a Mississippi school district that banned a Jewish student from displaying a Star of David necklace because administrators feared it could be mistaken for a gang symbol.

headline: North Korea in Pact
abstract: North Korea has tentatively agreed to end its testing of long-range ballistic missiles in exchange for a commitment from the United States and Japan to move forward with economic assistance for the Government there, American officials said.    Article, page A7.

headline: Turk to Visit U.S.; Focus on Aid and Rights
abstract: Turkish Prime Min Bulent Ecevit will visit US on Sept 28 for talks with Pres Clinton that could lead to more US aid for earthquake relief; Clinton is expected to encourage Ecevit to push ahead with tentative steps to improve human rights and to build positive relationship with Greece; will press Ecevit to seek compromise with Greece over divided island of Cyprus; photo (M)

headline: P.C. Exports Eased
abstract: Technological advances that have made personal computers as powerful as supercomputers were just a few years ago prompted President Clinton to greatly ease restrictions on exports of high-speed machines to countries like Russia and China.      Article, page A4.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: Iran's Supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamanei, blames 'hidden hands' of United States for pro-democracy protests this month, contending that Washington had tried to repeat 1953 coup that restored monarchy (S)

headline: Focal in Initial Offering
abstract: Focal Communications Corp raises $129.6 million in initial public stock offering, selling 9.95 million shares for $13 each (S)

headline: A Hispanic Pencil At Leo Burnett
abstract: Leo Burnett Co renames Hispanic marketing unit of Leo Burnett USA; new name is Lapiz, Spanish word for pencil (S)

headline: Recruiting A Reference
abstract: Michelle Cottle Working column answers question on what to do when past employer refuses to give any information to potential new one (M)

headline: An Internet Beginner Learns as She Goes
abstract: Two interviews with novice Internet retailer Suzanne Richie, before and after her Web site went on line, on her plans to sell antiques via Internet; photo (M)

headline: Reluctant Typists
abstract: Letter from Edward S Winskill on problem of people over age 50 being dragged into cyberage who never learned to type

headline: To Aid Euro, Bank May Favor Rise in Rates
abstract: European Central Bank president Wim Duisenberg says bank might toughen monetary policy soon in move to help push up sagging value of the euro against US dollar; his remarks help nudge euro up about half-cent against dollar, reaching $1.024 in European trading; photo (M)

headline: John Doe Need Not Apply
abstract: People with common names are forming clubs on Internet; John Carter, who started home page for people with same name five years ago, comments; photo (M)

headline: Export Rules Are Said to Be a Threat to Satellite Industry
abstract: Tightened restrictions on satellite exports raise concerns in aerospace industry and in Congress; industry executives say new rules hinder them from supplying even American allies, could jeopardize billion-dollar projects and may threaten US competitiveness (M)

headline: Hewlett-Packard to Shut Down Production of a Cult Favorite
abstract: Hewlett-Packard announces it will no longer manufacture Palmtop line, tiny notebook that was last popular PC to be made to run on MS-DOS; Palmtop aficionadoes are heartbroken; photo (S)

headline: As Economies Revive Abroad, Dollar Falls vs. Key Currencies
abstract: US dollar begins to slide against Japanese yen and European single currency, as investors turn their attention to reviving economies in Asia and Europe; dollar falls below 110 yen; dollar is falling against euro after 15 percent rise that ended in July; Asian economies, many of which fell into recession after currency turmoil in 1997, show signs of life, and these countries stock markets have soared in 1999; optimism is being heard about economic prospects of European countries; euro rises to value of $1.0578, from $1.0471; graph; chart (M)

headline: Carpe Diem, Even to The Grave
abstract: Lawrence Van Gelder On the Job column offers anecdotes showing that job interviews can take place at odd locations; drawings (M)

headline: Day Trading's Advantage
abstract: Christopher Luis letter disputes August 1 Market Watch column on risks of day trading (S)

headline: Local Centers Try to Span 'Digital Divide'
ALCATEL PLANS TO BUY GENESYS FOR $1.5 BILLION
abstract: Alcatel SA acquires Genesys Telecommunications Laboratories Inc for about $1.5 billion in stock (S)

headline: ANATOMY SITES
abstract: Listing of anatomy sites on Internet (S)

headline: STARWOOD HOTELS TO SELL UP TO $500 MILLION OF ASSETS
abstract: Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide Inc plans to sell $200 million worth of assets by second quarter of 2000, raising money to buy back stock (S)

headline: Newspage.com Work Goes to Grey
abstract: Newspage.com, unit of Newsedge Corp that delivers personalized news and information to business customers on the Web, awards its first off-line branding account to Grey Advertising; billings estimated at $10 million to $15 million (S)

headline: THE MARKETS -- Big Board at Brink of Unknown; Questions Abound as Exchange Ponders Going Public
abstract: New York Stock Exchange and its chief executive, Richard A Grasso, search for survival stategy in face of competition from electronic communications networks, other challenges; photo (M)

headline: K.G.B. Told Tall Tales About Dallas, Book Says
abstract: The Sword and the Shield, new book by Christopher Andrew and former Soviet KGB officer Vasily Mitrokhin, says KGB fabricated evidence linking Central Intelligence Agency to assassination of Pres John F Kennedy and passed material to unwitting conspiracy theorists in US; Mitrokhin defected to Britain in 1992; photos (M)

headline: A BANK'S INDONESIA FOOTHOLD
abstract: Standard Chartered PLC to pay $123 million for 20 percent stake in Bank Bali, becoming first foreign bank to win control of local bank under Indonesia's financial-system bailout (S)

headline: Burmese Pain In Spotlight As 2 Britons Sent to Prison
abstract: Rachel Goldwyn is sentenced to seven years at hard labor in Myanmar for staging one-person protest against military Government; is second young Briton in two weeks to be harshly sentenced, drawing concern of family members and diplomats and further attention to political repression in former Burma; map (M)

headline: Two Agencies Fill Top Posts
abstract: Fitzgerald & Co, division of Interpublic Group of Companies, names Lisa Galanti executive vice president and managing director, Jim Paddock executive vice president and Nik Mainthia executive vice president and chief media officer; Bozell Worldwide, division of True North Communications, names Rich Levy and David Nobay group creative directors; J Richard Hsu is named to new post of creative director and design head (S)

headline: The Feel of Cinema, but a Game at Heart
abstract: Game Theory column appraises Drakan, fantasy adventure game developed by Surreal Software; photo (M)

headline: 3 Advertisers Decide on Accounts
abstract: Juno Online Services expands its relationship with Omnicom Group by awarding new direct response account to Rapp Collins Worldwide; billings estimated at $10 million; DirectAG.com awards new account to Colle & McVoy Marketing Communications Corp; billings estimated at $1.2 million; Celebritystores.com is seeking ad agency; billings estimated at $1 million to $4 million (S)

headline: Crowding Transistors Onto a Chip
abstract: Integrated circuits of 2005 will likely have about 200 million transistors packed into each minuscule microprocesor; new tools are being developed to help silicon circuits reach faster speeds; photo (M)

headline: Making the Best of a Mess
abstract: The Boss column by Hewlett-Packard Co's new chief executive Carly Fiorina recalls problems she encountered as manager of AT&T Corp's Access Management division in 1984; suggests seven principles for personal, and business, growth and success; photo (M)

headline: Lowe Group Forms Equity Partnership
abstract: Lowe Group forms equity partnership with Miller/Huber Relationship Marketing; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: SFX to Buy EMA Telstar
abstract: SFX Entertainment Inc acquires EMA Telstar Group; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Mexican Contender Acknowledges an Out-of-Wedlock Child
abstract: Francisco Labastida Ochoa, a leading contender for Institutional Revolutionary Party's nomination for Mexican pres, acknowledges that he has daughter out of wedlock and that her mother works in Mexican consulate in El Paso, Tex; admits he is father of Paloma Labastida, 21-year-old student at University of Texas at El Paso (M)

headline: Pfizer Reports Gain in Profit And Deal in Price-Fixing Case
abstract: Pfizer Inc., the nation's second-largest drug maker, said yesterday that its second-quarter profit had risen 13 percent on increased sales of medicines including the high-blood-pressure pill Norvasc, the antidepressant Zoloft and the antibiotic Zithromax.    In a separate announcement, the company said that it would pay $20 million in criminal fines and plead guilty to charges that its former Food Science Group unit had taken part in two international price-fixing conspiracies.

headline: CORNING CONSUMER IS PAYING $133 MILLION FOR EKCO
abstract: Corning Consumer Products Co, unit of the buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co, to buy Ekco Group Inc Nashua, NH, for $133.7 million (S)

headline: Profit at Microsoft Rose More Than 60% in Quarter
abstract: With its business surging on several fronts, the Microsoft Corporation reported yesterday that its quarterly profits increased more than 60 percent in the quarter ended June 30, exceeding analyst expectations.    But Microsoft, the world's leading maker of computer software, also warned that the growth of its business was likely to slow in the next year. The company said it expects the recent torrid demand for personal computers to ease and for spending on software to slow as companies focus instead on dealing with the Year 2000 problem confronting their computer networks.

headline: Negotiations Continue for Ulster Accord
abstract: British Prime Min Tony Blair, Irish Prime Min Bertie Ahern and Northern Ireland's political leaders talk past midnight deadline in effort to break impasse over Sinn Fein's refusal to promise any disarmament by its Irish Republican Army allies; deal being worked on envisions Sinn Fein's acceptance of IRA obligation to disarm by May 2000 in exchange for letting party take up its seats in new cabinet now; photos (M)

headline: Sony's Builds a Mall. But Don't Call It That.
abstract: Article describes features of Metreon, Sony Corp's new retail and entertainment complex in San Francisco; photos; diagrams (L)

headline: Finding Love or Friendship
abstract: Letter from Wayne Chin, prompted by Aug 26 article on finding love over Internet, details his failed efforts to find someone via E-mail

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro continues to rise against dollar; graphs; table (S)

headline: The Once And Future Network; Wiring the Home Has Made Big Strides, but Has Far to Go
abstract: Number of households with more than one personal computer is booming, and home networks are becoming a practical necessity for many people; trend for networking is expected to accelerate with deployment of new digital devices and as consumers begin downloading digital entertainment from the Net; listing of products for setting up home networks; drawing; photos (M)

headline: Eerie, Creepy Look at Cold War Culture
abstract: Conelrad, fledgling Web site, promises overview and creepy look at America's postwar atomic culture; Bill Geerhart, Conelrad's editor, says site will show how pop culture and cold war intersected; site contains films, records, television and literature, as well as official Government advice on what to do in case of atomic attack; photo (M)

headline: Bertelsmann Chief Turns Voting Control Over to a New Board
abstract: Reinhard Mohn, patriarch who has controlled Bertelsmann AG for nearly four decades, turns over his voting rights to new six-person board that includes two Bertelsmann executives and at least one member of his family; move insures Bertelsmann retains one of world's most curious corporate structures; most of company's stock was transferred by Mohn family to charitable foundation in 1993; but Mohn kept control of voting rights himself; charitable foundation is only entitled to stream of dividends; Mohn turns over his voting rights to new company that will in some ways resemble American board of directors; new design means that over time Mohn family will have very limited say over company (M)

headline: A Worried U.S. Says Little About Iran's Rising Turmoil
abstract: US, fearful of consequences of Iranian Government crackdown on pro-democracy student demonstrators, is concerned that muted American statements are being twisted to benefit of Islamic hard-liners; Clinton Administration had hoped that demonstrations would strengthen Pres Mohammad Khatami, but diehard Islamic radicals may now have upper hand as street battles rage in Teheran (S)

headline: Easier Than Crayons: Graphics Grows Up
abstract: Game Theory column describes displays at 26th annual Siggraph (Special Interest Group on Computer Graphics) conference in Los Angeles, which attracted 45,000 scientists, artists, engineers and designers; notes that computer game industry now represents current state of the art in computer graphics and animation; photos (M)

headline: CAREMATRIX TO CONSIDER BECOMING A PRIVATE COMPANY
abstract: Management of Carematrix Corp, operator of retirement communities, is considering taking company private (S)

headline: Suez Lyonnaise Buys Water Concern
abstract: Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux SA agrees to buy United Water Resources Inc, leading American water-management business, for $1 billion; Suez's deal strengthens its hand against Vivendi SA of France, Suez's main rival; deal comes at time of rapid change in water-management business in US, where towns and cities are now contracting out what were formerly municipal water services to private companies; Suez Lyonnaise has owned 33 percent of United Water and under terms of acquisition it will acquire rest for $1 billion; Suez will also assume $800 million in United Water debt (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: In France, Banking Rivals Could Be Ripe for Takeover  Now that French bank regulators have rejected a bid by Banque Nationale de Paris to keep its shares in Societe Generale and scuttled its effort to form a European giant, both banks could become takeover targets.    The big loser in the bank battle appeared to be the head of the French central bank, Jean-Claude Trichet, who had strenuously backed a three-way deal. The very French notion that the central authorities could dictate the shape of the banking system was badly wounded in the process as well. [Page C2.]

headline: Ecuador Says It Will Delay Brady Bond Interest Payment
abstract: Ecuador says it will delay payment on $94 million of Brady bond interest due on Aug 28; Pres Jamil Mahuad says nation will use 30-day grace period, negotiated under terms of Brady bond deal in 1994, after deadline to work out restructuring agreement with creditors; deference is first among countries that have issused Brady bonds; Pres Clinton sends letter of encouragement to Mahuad (M)

headline: Violence Among Israelis Sets Off National Wave of Soul-Searching
abstract: Recent brutal crimes and new studies detailing level of brutality in schools has spurred intense focus on violence among Israelis that has temporarily pushed aside historic focus on conflict with Arabs; many experts see new focus on internal violent behavior reflecting decline in Israel's willingness to accept aggression and rudeness as byproducts of life under siege; there are no data to confirm widely held view that violence in Israel is on rise or that rise is partly linked to arrival of many people from former Soviet Union; photo (M)

headline: Former Chief Of GE Capital Plans to Start Buyout Fund
abstract: Gary C Wendt, former chief of GE Capital Services, will start buyout and private-equity investment fund with other former company executives; will focus on Japan and Europe, which have attracted attention from big US investors because of large amount of nonperforming Japanese debt and quickening pace of reorganizations and takeover activity in Europe; photo (M)

headline: Suicide Note Blames President of Mexico
abstract: In a last attack on the political system he once served, a former Mexican justice official who apparently killed himself on Wednesday rather than face money-laundering charges in the United States blamed Mexican President Ernesto Zedillo for both his own death and the 1994 murder of his brother.    In a suicide note made public by his widow, Mario Ruiz Massieu charged that Mr. Zedillo had never forgiven his criticism of party officials after his brother, a party leader, was killed. He said the evidence against him was fabricated.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.25   8.25   8.50        Discount rate   4.75   4.75   5.00        Federal funds   5.13   5.24   5.46        3-month T-bills   4.60   4.66   4.72        6-month T-bills   4.87   4.92   4.69        10-yr. T-infl.   4.03   4.04   3.64        10-yr. T-note   5.89   5.95   4.84        30-yr. T-bond   6.04   6.09   5.23        Telephone bd.   7.80   7.87   7.08        Municipal bds.   5.81   5.82   5.13          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer

headline: New Trading After Hours Is a Success, Two Firms Say
abstract: On-line brokerage firms Discover Brokerage and Dreyfus Brokerage say stock trading after regular hours on New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq was success; just about 60,000 shares, or 142 orders, were executed, pittance when compared with nearly 1.8 billion shares that were traded during day on major exchanges; companies involved say they did not expect explosive start; it is first time small investors had chance to buy 200 of most active stocks on two exchanges so late in day through new electronic trading format; Michael O Sanderson, chief executive of Marketxt Inc, electronic trading system that created after-hours forum, says system is working as planned (M)

headline: Clinton Aides Seek Alternatives To an I.M.F. Sale of Some Gold
abstract: Clinton Administration, faced with mounting opposition in Congress, begins backing away from plans to have International Monetary Fund sell portion of its gold reserves to finance debt relief for some of world's poorest nations; Administration's plan calls for IMF to sell up to 10 million ounces of gold on open market; but gold prices have been falling, in part because of IMF plan and sale by Bank of England, and mining companies and gold-producing countries have lobbied to kill plan (M)

headline: Hong Kong Journal; Suzy Wong's Long Gone and Now, Sailors Begone!
abstract: Circle of Hong Kong merchants, restaurants and bars that cater to American sailors are being hurt by China's ban on visits by United States Navy ships to Hong Kong; China has barred 10 ships and 3 military planes since mid-May, but is showing signs of easing policy; photo (M)

headline: Dreamcast's New Games: Beauty That's Skin-Deep
abstract: J C Herz Game Theory column evaluates Sega Dreamcast; holds that although console is dazzling, available games are less impressive; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Gold jumps after Bank of England auctions 25 metric tons of bullion at prices that are unexpectedly above market rates; gold for December delivery rises 2.35 percent, or $6, to $261.80 an ounce; graph; chart (S)

headline: Without Ado, Israel Leaves Another 7% of West Bank
abstract: Israel completes its first set of obligations under new peace deal, transferring civilian control of chunk of West Bank to Palestinians ahead of schedule and with little fanfare; land cuts across West Bank, touching and in some cases connecting areas that belong to almost all existing Palestinian local governments; most Israelis, preparing for Jewish New Year, pay little attention to turnover of land that many fought so hard to hold on to; Yasir Arafat calls Prime Min Ehud Barak to wish him happy New Year; map (M)

headline: U.S. and Japan Agree to Joint Research on Missile Defense
abstract: United States and Japan agree to conduct joint research on missile defense system that in theory could destroy incoming ballistic missiles similar to one North Korea is threatening to test; Foreign Min Masahiko Komura and US Amb Thomas Foley sign agreement calling for both countries to combine technological know-how to improve basic abilities of so-called theater missile defense system (M)

headline: 3 Men Pay $70,000 On S.E.C. Charges
abstract: Former Westell Technologies sales executives Thomas R Allen and Christian Petersen and BellSouth Telecommunications engineer Alireza Hooshiari agree to pay nearly $70,000 to settle Securities and Exchange Commission charges of insider trading (M)

headline: Warnaco Plans An Acquisition
abstract: Warnaco Group Inc agrees to buy clothier ABS by Allen B Schwartz for undisclosed amount of cash (S)

headline: MEETING ON SEOULBANK
abstract: Financial Supervisory Commission, South Korea's financial watchdog agency, to decide whether to declare ailing Seoulbank insolvent and inject additional public funds (S)

headline: Caracas Journal; It's Sunday, and Venezuelans Have the Leader's Ear
abstract: Venezuela's most unusual radio show is Hello, President, featuring Pres Hugo Chavez taking calls every Sunday morning for two hours from any Venezuelan with a problem, a complaint or a suggestion; Chavez also makes point of discussing his official agenda for coming week, often announcing major policy initiatives on the show; program exemplifies Chavez's notions of what constitutes democracy; he has repeatedly attacked Venezuela's National Congress and state legislatures as unrepresentative bodies out of touch with citizenry; photo (M)

headline: Barnes & Noble to Phase Out Use of the Times List of Books
abstract: Barnes & Noble Inc is preparing to phase out its use of New York Times best seller list at its superstores, and to offer bargains based on chain's own sales rankings; has typically offered discounts on books on Times list of books; company executives say their own sales rankings do not always match Times best-seller lists; Barnesandnoble.com, Web company that chain spun off, plans for now to continue offering discounts based on New York Times best-seller lists; it is engaged in fierce competition with other top on-line booksellers to attract customers through 50 percent discounts on books from Times best-seller lists (M)

headline: Treasuries Fall for the First Time in 4 Days
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities fall for first time in four days; price of 30-year bond is down 13/32, to 101 12/32; yield is up to 6.03 percent from 6 percent; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Just Don't Expect a Coupon
abstract: Roberto Devorik, London fashion consultant used by Princess Diana as her personal shopping companion, joins Bestselections.com, New York-based Internet shopping company (S)

headline: INFLATION ANXIETY IN BRAZIL
abstract: Thirty-day inflation rate in Brazil's financial capital, Sao Paulo, jumped to 1.13 percent, or annualized rate of 14 percent; jump in inflation contributes to fall in value of currency, the real, to weakest level in nearly six months; increase raises concern that economic recovery could stall (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: ASIA    MYANMAR: BRITON GETS 17 YEARS -- A British activist was sentenced to 17 years in prison after trying to smuggle anti-Government literature into Myanmar, the country's military regime said. James Mawdsley, 26, was arrested after crossing into Myanmar at Tachilek, a trading town on the border with Thailand. It was his third arrest in two years for trying to rally anti-Government support. Anti-Government activists are calling for a mass uprising on Sept. 9, or 9/9/99, a date seen as auspicious in a country obsessed with numerology.   (AP)    SRI LANKA: 3 DIE IN BLAST -- An explosion tore through the headquarters of the People's Liberation Organization of Tamil Eelam in Vavuniya, killing three people, including Nagalingam Manikkadasan, the leader of the political party's militia. The group has three members in Parliament and has cooperated with the Government in fighting against the Tamil Tigers, a separatist guerrilla army.   Barry Bearak (NYT)

headline: See You in Two Weeks!
abstract: A co-worker goes on vacation, and you're asked to assume her duties, often in addition to your own. You have no idea how to do her work -- but, hey, you're a team player, right? It can be an opportunity to prove yourself, but it can also be a disaster. In a depopulated workplace, what have been your greatest adventures and misadventures? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: ALLIED WASTE IS SELLING SOME OPERATIONS TO REPUBLIC
abstract: Republic Services Inc will acquire certain solid-waste services assets from Allied Waste Industries for $230 million (S)

headline: SWISSCOM BOUGHT INTEREST IN DEBITEL
abstract: Swisscom, telecommunications company, is buying 58 percent share in German wireless company Debitel, in move that will nearly double Swisscom's customers, to 7 million (S)

headline: CABLE STAKE TO BE SOLD
abstract: Britain's Telewest Communications PLC agrees to buy 50 percent of Cable London PLC it does not already own for 428 million pounds ($685 million) in cash (S)

headline: Business Travel; Fliers may have missed it, but the nation's airlines have pledged to improve their customer service.
abstract: US airlines filed with Transportation Department last week their pledges to improve customer service; 'voluntary' pledges, which were adopted under Congressional threats to come up with improvements or else, are outgrowth of growing customer dissatisfaction with overall flight experience (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: Finding Love or Friendship
abstract: Letter from Patricia Lay-Dorsey says Aug 26 article on finding love on-line reminded her of her experience meeting friends on line

headline: London Fog Seeks Bankruptcy Protection
abstract: London Fog Industries seeks bankruptcy protection and says it will close about 110 of its 140 retail stores; closings will eliminate about 500 of approxmiately 1,500 jobs (S)

headline: Accusations of Bribery In the Kremlin Mount Up
abstract: Felipe Turover, who worked for Swiss Banca del Gottardo as debt collector in Russia, says he saw credit card bills and photocopies of credit cards bearing signatures of Pres Boris N Yeltsin and his daughters that were provided by Swiss construction company Mabetex Project Engineering, interview; says bank officials described to him Kremlin meeting at which Pavel Borodin and other senior Russian officials accepted money and gifts from Mabetex, which did $1.5 billion worth of work for Kremlin; scores Yeltsin for giving Russia over to corruption and decline; is key figure in Swiss probe; photo (M)

headline: Appeals Court Rules In Favor of Keating
abstract: Federal Appeals Court overturns lower court's 1994 ruling ordering former Lincoln Savings & Loan Association chairman Charles H Keating Jr to pay Resolution Trust Corp $4.3 billion; rules he cannot be held personally liable to Government without trial (M)

headline: Compressed Data; After Skimming the Manual, Settle Down With the Book
abstract: Shrinking size of computer user manuals noted; photo (S)

headline: TALKING MONEY WITH: DONALD SULTAN and FAYEZ SAROFIM; A Portrait Of the Artist As an Investor
abstract: Interview with artist Donald Sultan of New York City, who describes his haphazard investing habits of past and his current relationship with millionaire art collector and legendary investor Fayez Sarofim; Sarofim comments; photos; graph; drawing (M)

headline: Quake Victims Confront Chaos Of Relief Effort
abstract: New crisis besets Golcuk, Turkey, town of 80,000 that was destroyed by earthquake, as too many volunteer relief workers descend on town; in absence of coordinated plan or anything resembling crisis-management center, tens of thousands of volunteers from around Turkey arrive, outnumbering residents and promptly creating bedlam; highway into Golcuk is backed up 20 miles all day long, often blocking ambulances and rescue equipment; hundreds if not thousands of trucks bring bottled water and bread, far more than local residents can consume; time available to extract survivors from rubble is dwindling rapidly; photos; map (L)

headline: Warner Music Group Gets New Chief
abstract: Time Warner Inc names Roger Ames, former president of Polygram Music Group, as chairman and chief executive of Warner Music Group; Time Warner chairman-chief executive Gerald M Levin comments; Ames replaces Robert A Daly and Terry Semel, who announced last month that they would resign from both film studio and record company; photo (M)

headline: TECHNOLOGY: E-Commerce Report; As women start to use the Internet more for shopping, the prospects sharply improve for on-line retailers.
abstract: Percentage of World Wide Web shoppers who are women has jumped in last 12 months, to 38 percent from 29 percent, and industry executives expect that presence to rise quickly in next year; immediate impact will be felt in traditional female retail strongholds, which will benefit also from higher spending from more experienced female Internet shoppers; in recent survey, women who shopped on Internet in last year say they plan to spend 20 percent more on line in next year; graph (M)

headline: Controlling Students' E-Mail
abstract: Bob Lazaroff letter says he gives his home E-mail address to students but signs onto Internet with two different names (Sept 2 article)

headline: Jump in Labor Cost Prompts Fear of Rising Interest Rates
abstract: Labor Dept reports that employment cost index rose 1.1 percent from first to second quarter of year, its biggest gain in eight years; stock and bond prices fall sharply in wake of report; investors appear concerned that Federal Reserve Chmn Alan Greenspan might raise interest rates in near future as preventive measure against rising prices; analysts say financial markets may have overreacted to threat of inflation; Commerce Dept reports that gross domestic product expanded at modest 2.3 percent annual pace; graph (M)

headline: CBS, the 'Tiffany Network,' Is Sold in Record Deal
abstract: NEW YORK—  Viacom Inc., the media conglomerate that owns the MTV cable channel and the Paramount film studio, said Tuesday it was buying CBS Corp., which operates what was long considered the classiest U.S. television network.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.

headline: BELL ATLANTIC TO BUY REMAINING STAKE IN FRONTIER UNIT
abstract: Bell Atlantic Corp will buy 50 percent of Frontier Cellular, wireless phone venture in New York and Pennsylvania, that it does not already own from Frontier Corp; price is undisclosed (S)

headline: Kelvin Lancaster, 74, Dies; Revised Economic Theory
abstract: Kelvin J Lancaster, economic theorist, dies at age 74; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASIA    INDIA: POLLS PUT HINDUS AHEAD  An exit poll for the private Star TV said the Hindu nationalist-led coalition is heading for a sweeping victory in national elections that conclude Oct. 3. Another exit poll, broadcast by the state television network, put the coalition firmly in the lead, though not by such a large margin. A third, smaller exit poll, by a regional newspaper in the state of Maharashtra, showed the coalition narrowly ahead.    Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

headline: Media Talk; Magazine Lets Photographers Shoot Back
abstract: Photo District News, monthly that caters to New York photography market, issues ratings, based on survey of 100 photographers who regularly work for consumer magazines, of best and worst magazines to shoot for; photo (S)

headline: With Vote, Mexican Right Gives a Hand To Candidate
abstract: Mexico's National Action Party, pro-business opposition party, selects Vicente Fox Quesada as its presidential candidate in nationwide primary; outcome makes him candidate for governing Institutional Revolutionary Party to beat in 2000 election; polls show he is most popular challenger to governing party (S)

headline: Ear Training: A Digital Music Primer
abstract: Recent technologies for making, capturing and distributing music electronically described in light of Recording Industry Association of America's new standards designed to protect commercially recorded music from electronic pirating; drawing (M)

headline: Rebel War in Colombia Widening, Pulling In Neighbors
abstract: Kidnapping of foreign oil workers and tourists in Ecuador, apparently by Colombian rebels, stirs new fears that Colombia's longstanding internal conflict is spilling beyond its borders and becoming regional problem; Colombian guerrillas have used Ecuador as rear base and supply area in past, but not penetrated as deeply; both of Colombia's main rebel group deny responsibility; map (M)

headline: KOHLBERG KRAVIS BUYS 49% STAKE IN BIRCH TELECOM
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co agrees to pay as much as $110 million for 49 percent of Birch Telecom Inc (S)

headline: Swiss Reveal Secret World: Their Defense From Nazis
abstract: Switzerland, straining under cost of maintaining vast network of bunkers built during World War II as defense against German invasion, has decided to declassify secret complexes, and even start to sell some off; built chain of underground fortresses in response to June 1940 German entry into Paris; thousands of people worked night and day to tunnel into mountains and build hiding places for arms and men (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil rises above $24 a barrel on expectations that annual increase in heating demand will come with supplies unusually low; in New York, crude oil for October delivery rises 66 cents, to $24.21 a barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: HANVIT SALE TABLED
abstract: Hanvit Bank of South Korea shelves $1 billion sale of shares after government refuses to sell part of its stake at 25 percent discount demanded by investors (S)

headline: PUB DEAL
abstract: Punch Taverns Group Ltd agrees to acquire Allied Domecq's 3,500 British pubs for $4.3 billion; Punch Taverns says it will finance deal in cash, assumed debt and shares in Bass PLC, which has pledged to buy as many as 650 of pubs; graph (S)

headline: CNN Dismisses Executive at Financial News Unit
abstract: Top executives at Cable News Network dismiss David Bohrman as executive vice president of financial news network CNNfn and have him escorted out the door of CNNfn's headquarters in Manhattan, after power struggle over who will control CNNfn; Bohrman's replacement is Teya Ryan, executive producer of weekly prime-time magazine producer CNN & Fortune (M)

headline: AMERICA ONLINE'S CHAIRMAN TO BUY STAKE IN MAUI LAND
abstract: America Online's CÔ

headline: After 50 Years, China Youth Remain Mao's Pioneers
abstract: Young Pioneers, youth branch of Chinese Communist Party, enlists nearly every child; beginning in second grade, students learn about party's creation of strong China, in classes where Communism is offered and received as pure, idealistic force for good; most Chinese today are cynical about Communist ideology and many younger people are simply indifferent, suggesting that fervent messages propounded by Young Pioneers does not entirely stick; but many Chinese say all those lectures about party's all-embracing and benign role may have lasting effects, particularly patriotic and nationalistic elements; note that nearly every Chinese gets emotional about China's claim of sovereignty over Taiwan or Tibet; photo (M)

headline: 2 Israelis Die In an Attack By Guerrillas In Lebanon
abstract: Islamic Hezbollah guerrillas kill two Israeli soldiers and wound six others in clash in southern Lebanon; Israeli warplanes raid suspected Hezbollah positions in Lebanon, damaging cars in Shaqra; Israeli ships off southern Lebanese coast fire on dinghy near Tyre; Israeli security officials doubt clash is linked to killing of Hezbollah official Ali Hassan Deeb by car bomb outside Sidon that guerrillas attribute to Israel; Israeli Chief of Staff Shaul Mofaz, in unusual move, implies Israel was not involved in bombing; Israeli court convicts Steven Smyrek, German who converted to Islam, of conspiring with Hezbollah and taking photographs of public places to help group choose bombing targets; map (M)

headline: U.N. Plans Force in Congo After Cease-Fire
abstract: United Nations is preparing to send large peacekeeping force to help stabilize Congo once cease-fire is signed, despite reservations by Clinton Administration (S)

headline: The Valley Guys and Their Quirks
abstract: IN the second half of the 19th century, as in the second half of our own, American inventors and engineers were forging a definitive subculture and style.    Boston, for instance, was teeming with oddball tinkerers, some incubated at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, which nurtured spinoff enterprises. A local electrical workshop was a high-profile hangout useful for spying on rivals and stealing  their personnel. (Bell found Watson there.)

headline: Michelin Plans to Cut 7,500 Jobs Across Europe
abstract: Michelin, Europe's largest tire maker, says it will cut 7,500 jobs under program spearheaded by its new chairman, Edouard Michelin, to reduce costs and increase profit at century-old company; Michelin forecasts productivity gains of 20 percent under three-year plan, which includes plant closures and laying off one in 10 workers in Europe, where it employs 75,000; new management also aims to refocus on more profitable markets like truck and sports tires (M)

headline: Carolina Power Acquiring Florida Progress
abstract: Carolina Power & Light Company agreed yesterday to acquire Florida Progress Corp for $5.3 billion in cash and stock; merger will create Southeastern utility with 2.5 million customers (S)

headline: Deutsche and Dresdner Weigh Link That Could Lead to Larger Merger : 2 Big Banks In Germany May Create Retail Giant
