abstract: FRANKFURT—  Deutsche Bank AG and Dresdner Bank AG on Monday raised the possibility of a merged German superbank by confirming that they had been talking about combining their basic retail operations.

headline: U.N. Survey Finds Wide Destruction in Kosovo Villages
abstract: United Nations reports that two-thirds of the houses in villages across a wide swath of Kosovo are uninhabitable because of war damage, that most of schools are severely damaged or destroyed, that much of water is polluted and that a large part of agriculture is ruined; warns of serious humanitarian threat, with large pockets of people facing situations that could evolve into emergency; map (M)

headline: NICKEL MINE DISPUTE
abstract: Inco Ltd, Canada's largest nickel producer, locks out 1,060 workers at its mine in Thompson, Manitoba, after 86 percent of members of steelworkers local rejects its offer on new three-year contract; mining and smelting operations at Thompson, which account for 23 percent of Inco's total nickel production and about 4.5 percent of world supplies, will be completely shut down by Sept 19; price of nickel has reached two-year highs in expectation of shutdown, to more than $3.25 a pound (S)

headline: New Libyan Cooperation Leads to Renewed Ties With Britain
abstract: Britain resumes diplomatic ties with Libya after Libya agrees to aid in probe of fatal 1984 shooting of London police officer Yvonne Fletcher outside Libya's Embassy that caused break in ties; Foreign Sec Robin Cook says Libya will also pay compensation to officer's family and has accepted 'general responsibility' for death; Fletcher was killed and 11 demonstrators against Col Muammar el-Qaddafi wounded when shots were apparently fired from embassy (M)

headline: Saks Plans to Expand Its Presence on Line
abstract: Saks Inc says it will meld its catalogue and Internet businesses into new division to handle growth on line; Saks Fifth Avenue will set up on-line store in spring of 2000 (S)

headline: Clown Alleys Dot the Information Highway
abstract: Internet has its own clown alleys, traditional name for section off midway that houses clowns' dressing quarters; Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus maintains site, as does International Clown Hall of Fame; other sites described; photo (M)

headline: David Graham, 87, Is Dead; Antiwar Debater at Oxford
abstract: David Graham, who as Oxford undergraduate in 1933 played key role in student debating society's much-denounced and long-remembered vote against fighting for 'King and Country,' dies at age 87; photo (M)

headline: Media Talk; Now Opening for Business on Sundays
abstract: Wall Street Journal is producing new Sunday insert that will reach readers of 10 major metropolitan newspapers that circulate 4.3 million copies every Sunday; papers will share section's ad revenue with Journal, Dow Jones publication; articles will focus on personal finance and careers; photo (M)

headline: LOSS AT PAY-TV CONCERN
abstract: British Sky Broadcasting PLC, Europe's second-largest pay-television company, reports loss of $9 million for its fourth quarter as it tried to attract new customers; company, 40 percent owned by News Corp, says it gained 1.2 million subscribers for Sky Digital service (S)

headline: Why? New Eichmann Notes Try to Explain
abstract: German daily Die Welt publishes memoirs of Adolf Eichmann in which Eichmann sought to explain his central role in killing of six million European Jews by Nazis; Die Welt says it found Eichmann's handwritten reflections at Center for Research on Nazi Crimes in German town of Ludwigsburg; in them, Eichmann claims he was driven by visceral sense of duty rather than hatred to organize mass murder of Jews; says his life was predicated on being obedient, and suggests being obedient is in nature of the German; his remarks will prove sensitive in Germany, where question of responsibility for Holocaust remains contentious; Eichmann was captured by Israeli agents in 1960 and executed in Israel two years later; photo (M)

headline: Ex-Head of Talent Agency Emerges to Lead a Rival
abstract: James A Waitt is named president of William Morris Agency, three days after resigning as co-chairman of International Creative Management, a rival talent agency; Wiatt will replace Arnold Rifkin, who decided not to extend his current contract, which had a year left; photo (M)

headline: Clinton Widens Plan for Poor Debtor Nations
abstract: PresClinton, at meetings of World Bank and International Monetary Fund, announces major expansion in US effort to forgive debt of world's poorest nations, saying those countries would not have to repay billions of dollars borrowed from US aid agencies if they could show savings were being used for education and fighting proverty (M)

headline: Kodak to Shut Down Film Plant in China
abstract: Eastman Kodak Co will close its X-ray film plant in Wuxi, China, and dismiss 520 workers; says strict environmental laws are inflating plant-upgrade costs (S)

headline: VIACOM TO BUY CBS, FORMING 2D LARGEST MEDIA COMPANY
abstract: Viacom Inc will acquire CBS Corp for $37.3 billion in biggest media merger ever, creating world's second-largest media company after Time Warner Inc; Viacom chairman Sumner Redstone will run combined companies if merger is completed; deal adds major broadcast television network to Viacom's media portfolio, which includes highly profitable cable television networks, film studio and video-rental chain; CBS chief executive Mel Karmazin will become Redstone's second-in-command and heir apparent as president and chief operating officer; all Viacom and CBS units will report to him; acquisition signals another change in ownership of three once-independent major broadcast networks; Viacom could emerge as world's largest seller of advertising; chart; photo (M)

headline: Little Asias, Across Dixie
abstract: Joel Kotkin Grass-Roots Business column on dramatic growth in number of Asian entrepreneurs who are setting up businesses in southern cities, particularly Houston, Tex; city is experiencing economic resurgence since oil bust; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Centralized Price System Proposed for Stock Trading  Arthur Levitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, proposed a system for displaying electronically all orders to buy and sell United States stocks.

headline: RITE AID SHARES FALL AGAIN AFTER FLORIDA FILES LAWSUIT
abstract: Shares of Rite Aid Corp fall 14 percent after Florida's Attorney General files suit accusing company of overcharging 29,000 uninsured prescription drug customers; company says suit is groundless and that it will vigorously defend itself (S)

headline: MCI Worldcom In Deal to Build Internet Access
abstract: MCI Worldcom Inc makes big move into consumer market for high-speed Internet access, announcing partnership with Earthlink Network Inc to sell retail services in as many as 25 markets by end of year (S)

headline: G.M. Profit Beats Wall Street Expectations
abstract: General Motors Corp says it earned $1.73 billion in second quarter compared with $306 million it earned from operations during same period last year, when there was a costly strike; net income hit $1.92 billion compared with $389 million during period a year earlier; revenue rose to $45.07 billion from $37.27 billion (M)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; SUIT SEEKS INHERITANCE
abstract: World Business Briefing: Suit Se

headline: The Price of Low Inflation
abstract: Stanley Herz disputes Sylvia Nasar's August 22 article on inflation holds public has come to expect and accept poor service (S)

headline: Americans Lead the World in Hours Worked
abstract: International Labor Organization releases report showing Americans put in longest hours among workers in industrialized countries, averaging 1,966 hours at work in 1997, most recent year studied; that is increase of nearly 4 percent over average recorded by United States workers in 1980; American workers' productivity continues to outstrip European and Asian counterparts, but gap in some cases is narrowing; in comparing productivity gains in most recent term studied, 1980 to 1996, United States is behind its rivals; United States gained 22 percent while Thailand recorded 141 percent productivity gains, Japan had 43 percent gain, and France, Germany and England had 30 percent gains (M)

headline: Compressed Data; E-Gambling Software Gave Players an Edge
abstract: Reliable Software Technologies finds flaws in some Internet gambling software; photo (M)

headline: A Hunt for a Better Mortgage
abstract: Advice for home buyers on shopping for mortgages with lower interest rates and fees in wake of recent rate rise; discusses pros and cons of adjustable-rate mortgages; graph; photo (M)

headline: ROVER HURTS BMW EARNINGS
abstract: BMW reports profits for first half fell 27 percent, to 191 million euros ($203 million), down from 261.3 million euros in 1998 period (S)

headline: Condolences And an Offer Of Support To 'Province'
abstract: Pres Jiang Zemin of China offers condolences and aid to Taiwan's earthquake victims in statement issued by Foreign Ministry (M)

headline: ENRON TO EXCHANGE STAKE IN UNIT FOR PROPERTIES
abstract: Enron Corp says it will exchange 76 percent of its ownership in Enron Oil and Gas Co, stake valued at $1.2 billion, for properties that Enron Oil and Gas owns in India and China (S)

headline: BRAZILIAN RATES UNCHANGED
abstract: Brazil's central bank leaves its benchmark rate unchanged at 19.5 percent, ending series of 10 consecutive cuts in interest rates; cites concern that rising inflation could dent purchasing power (S)

headline: BUYOUT FIRM IN DEAL TO ACQUIRE HCIA AND TAKE IT PRIVATE
abstract: HCIA Inc, provider of information systems to hospitals and health care companies, agrees to be acquired and taken private by SV&A Communications Partners III LP in deal valued at $135 million (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Robert Solomon, who had been president for direct and interactive marketing at Ammirati Puris Lintas, opens Solomon Strategic, advertising consulting company (S)

headline: Criminal Charges Ruled Out In Morgan Stanley Inquiry
abstract: Manhattan District Attorney's office says Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Wall Street firm that has been under legal scrutiny since it was revealed that it had made a payment to a person involved in arrest of former employee Christian L Curry, will not face criminal charges in case; at issue was Morgan Stanley's payment of $10,000 to Charles J Luethke, who helped set up police sting operations against Curry in August 1998, several months after firm dismissed Curry; Curry, who is black, was arrested and charged with conspiring to plant fake racist E-mail messages on Morgan Stanley's computers to bolster contemplated discrimination lawsuit; those charges have since been dropped; firm still faces civil lawsuit filed by Curry that contends Morgan Stanley discriminated against Curry on account of race and perceived sexual orientation; Morgan Stanley praises ruling by District Attorney's office; Curry's lawyer Benedict P Morelli says action it will have no effect on civil suit; photo (M)

headline: Rally Against Milosevic Fails To Bind Opposition Parties
abstract: Size and passion of latest rally against Pres Slobodan Milosevic was impressive, but opposition politicians disagree on how best to harness that energy effectively; all do agree that they need time to work out best way to oust Milosevic, who shows no signs of volunteering to resign; Vuk Draskovic, leader of largest opposition party, wants early elections scheduled, with international observers; Zoran Djindjic and his group want mroe street protests to force Milosevic's resignation; photo (M)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICAN STEEL LAYOFFS
abstract: Altos Hornos de Mexico, largest steel manufacturer in Mexico, plans to lay off 25 percent of its white-collar staff and freeze salaries of workers who stay; besides layoff of 2,000 workers, move executives say will save $33.2 million yearly, company plans to raise at least $30 million from sales of assets unrelated to production (S)

headline: IRISH PHONE COMPANY PRICED
abstract: Irish Government announces that price of its shares in Telecom Eirann, nation's telephone company, will be equivalent of $3.99 (US); Government has sold shares representing its 50.1 percent of company and raised estimated $4.3 billion (S)

headline: SLUMPING SALES CAUSE OAKWOOD HOMES TO CLOSE PLANTS
abstract: Oakwood Homes Corp says it reduced its work force by 695 workers this summer and closed some plants (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ALLTEL CORP.,  Little Rock, Ark., which sells phone service in the Southeast and Midwest, said it would cut about 350 jobs in its rural long-distance business.    NEW VALLEY CORP.,  Miami, said its chairman, Bennett LeBow, was prepared to triple his stake in Gibson Greetings Inc., Cincinnati, to as much as 20 percent of the shares if the board removed a ''poison pill'' installed to deter unwanted suitors.

headline: Serbian Town Bombed by NATO Fears Effects of Toxic Chemicals
abstract: Serbs living in Pancevo fear effects of toxic chemicals released from petrochemical and fertilizer factories that were bombed during NATO air campaign over Kosovo; photo; map; residents report blistering rashes from touching soil and stomach ailments from eating river fish and vegetables or drinking tap water; children, many of whom were sent to Slovakia by Red Cross to escape noxious gases, still suffer headaches and dizziness, and doctors report twice as many miscarriages as last year; authorities admit testing equipment is outdated; UN sets up investigation under Finnish environmental official Pakka Haavisto; he says biggest danger now is that ground water and Danube River are directly polluted; air strikes against industrial complex in April unleashed tons of chemicals as NATO tried to cut off Milosevic Government's resources; Pancevo has 130,000 residents, many of Hungarian and Croatian descent, and has been center of opposition to Slobodan Milosevic (M)

headline: Long Sentences for 2 Chinese Dissidents
abstract: Beijing court sentences two prominent dissidents, Zha Jianguo and Gao Hongming, to eight-year prison terms for plotting to subvert Communist Party monopoly on political power (S)

headline: REGIONS FINANCIAL AGREES TO BUY MINDEN BANCSHARES
abstract: Regions Financial Corp to buy privately held Minden Bancshares Inc for about $86.5 million in stock (S)

headline: An Old-Fashioned Brawl Among Options Exchanges
abstract: Chicago Board Options Exchange and American Stock Exchange opt for old-fashioned market brawl by listing options for Dell Computer Corp, which for years have been traded exclusively on Philadelphia Stock Exchange; two win huge market share on first day of trading; nation's leading options exchanges are facing new challenges from electronic trading systems and regulatory inquiries into anticompetitive practices; Philadelphia Stock Exchange strikes back by listing options in Johnson & Johnson, IBM, Coca-Cola and Apple Computer--stock options that traded primarily or exclusively on Chicago and American exchanges (M)

headline: Not Nearly Shelved at 94
abstract: Nieman-Marcus chairman emeritus Stanley Marcus has compiled book, American Greats, contributed to by many top American writers, which will be released in November (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Sugar rises almost 9 percent after warehouse fire at Brazilian port destroys 15,000 metric tons of sugar waiting for export; in New York, sugar for October delivery rises 0.54 cent, to 6.7 cents a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Buy the Book: On-Line Stores Vie for Students
abstract: Appraisal of on-line textbook shop, Bigwords. com (S)

headline: JAPAN'S JOBLESSNESS STILL AT HIGH
abstract: Japan's unemployment rate remained at record high of 4.9 percent in July for second consecutive month on seasonally adjusted basis, with joblessness for women rising two-tenths of a point, to 4.6 percent; Labor Ministry says there were 46 job offers for every 100 job seekers, same as in previous month, equaling lowest ratio since 1963 (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ecuador Allowed to Default As a Warning for Markets  The Clinton administration's decision to let Ecuador default on its debts is being interpreted as a message from Lawrence H. Summers, the Treasury Secretary, that a little fear would be good for the markets.    That message, China's possible entry into the World Trade Organization and more aid for Russia are among the topics for the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. [Page C4.]

headline: Calpers Plans to Invest More Aggressively
abstract: California Public Employees' Retirement System says it will invest as much as $11 billion in hedge funds and other aggressive investments that have not been widely used by public pension funds; Calpers, nation's largest public pension system, says it is doing so to increase returns; Calpers board voted on Aug 16 to raise ceiling for hedge funds and other 'hybrid' investments to 25 percent of pension fund's $45 billion actively managed portfolio (M)

headline: U.N. Poverty Agency Vying With Aid Offices for Cash
abstract: Mark Malloch Brown, new chief of United Nations Development Program, is on marketing campaign to get more money for his agency following announcements by Denmark and Germany that they are slashing their annual contributions (M)

headline: NATO Commander Says Milosevic Is Moving Forces Into Pro-Western Montenegrin Republic
abstract: Gen Wesley K Clark, NATO's military commander, reports that Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic, still firmly in control of his army, is sending reinforcements into pro-Western Yugoslav republic of Montenegro; government of Montenegro Pres Milo Djukanovic is considered more democratic than that of Milosevic (M)

headline: Boeing Wins Approval for Small Airliner
abstract: Boeing Co says it has won approval for its smallest airliner, 106-seat 717, after year of flight tests; plane is scheduled for its first deliveries this month, to Airtran Holdings Inc, after its clearance by aviation authorities in both United States and Europe (S)

headline: Logging Off
abstract: Elinor Marshall letter on July 4 article on America Online's move to persuade customers to stay on line longer offers reasons why she switched to another Internet service provider (S)

headline: Some Security Flaws Reported in Software
abstract: Microsoft and Compaq acknowledged software security flaws that could enable intruders to gain access to the computers of millions of customers and to damage their data via E-mail or through commands sent from a malicious Web site. Certain Hewlett-Packard computers are also thought to be vulnerable.     Business Day, page C1.

headline: 3Com Plans To Spin Off Its Palm Unit
abstract: 3Com Corp, exploiting surging demand for calculator-size computers, will spin off its Palm Computing subsidiary, maker of popular Palm Pilot, as separate company early next year; under 3Com chairman Eric A Benhamou's plan, company will sell up to 20 percent of Palm to the public in initial stock offering some time around January; up to six months after offering, remaining shares in Palm will be given to existing 3Com shareholders (M)

headline: PROTECTIONISM WARNING
abstract: World Trade Organization's review of US trade policy gives country high marks for opening its markets but warns that any return to protectionism could jeopardize current economic prosperity; recent American actions against Brazil over steel and against New Zealand and Australia over lamb imports are cited as worrisome protectionist moves (S)

headline: 'Unlawful Interference' Cited in 1997 Accident : Report on SilkAir Crash Alludes to Pilot Suicide
abstract: SINGAPORE—  Indonesian investigators have concluded that "unlawful interference" may have caused the mysterious crash of a Singapore jet in December 1997 that killed all 104 people on board, the Singapore government said Wednesday.

headline: Co-Leader of Talent Agency Resigns After Disagreement
abstract: Jim Wiatt unexpectedly resigns as International Creative Management co-chairman in dispute with partner, Jeffrey Berg (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Microsoft to Join Fiber Optic Venture in Asia
abstract: Microsoft Corp, Global Crossing Ltd and Softbank Corp reported will form $1.3 billion joint venture, Asia Global Crossing, to build new Asian fiber optic communications web; Global Crossing will contribute its 57.75 percent stake in undersea fiber optic cable set to begin operating between Japan and United States by Jan; Softbank and Microsoft will each contribute $175 million and buy joint total of $200 million worth of communications capacity over next three years; will each have 3.5 percent initial stake, to Global Crossing's 93 percent (M)

headline: Brats on the Internet
abstract: Gail Gunther Concannon letter notes Internet provides assortment of sites where often uprooted children of military parents can register and search for past friends

headline: Media Talk; In Kennedy Death, Profit and Risks
abstract: Death of celebrity like John F Kennedy Jr fills magazine racks and bookshelves almost instantly; really big sales regarding Kennedy have been in magazines, not books, although two new books on Kennedy clan are scheduled to arrive in stores this week; photo (S)

headline: An Army's Recruits, Reaching Out to the Computerless
abstract: Article on cadre of Handtech.com sales representatives who pay $145 each to become so-called technology consultants and sell computers, mostly part-time, to friends, neighbors and tiny businesses; photo (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: AFRICA    RWANDA: BISHOP TRIED FOR GENOCIDE -- A Roman Catholic bishop went on trial, charged with genocide and other crimes against humanity in connection with the 1994 massacres in Rwanda, in which an estimated half million Tutsi and moderate Hutu died. Bishop Augustin Misago, 56, did not enter a plea and the trial was quickly suspended to allow the court to consider complaints by the defense counsel.   (Reuters)    SIERRA LEONE: LARGER U.N. PRESENCE -- The United Nations Security Council has tripled the number of military observers in Sierra Leone, to 210, and urged that the country move quickly to begin putting a July 7 peace accord into effect. The accord has been criticized because it grants amnesty to rebel fighters responsible for the deaths and mutilation of thousands of people. Peter Burleigh, the United States representative on the Council, said Washington is committed to prosecuting war criminals, and views the accord as ''the best guarantee for an end to the immense suffering.''   Barbara Crossette (NYT)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CHS ELECTRONICS INC.,  Miami, a distributor of microcomputer products, said it was selling a business unit that markets products in four European countries to an undisclosed party for about $50 million.    INFOSPACE.COM INC.,  Redmond, Wash., an Internet content provider, agreed to acquire Inex Corp., Toronto, for $37.6 million in stock.

headline: Child Labor: The Wrong, not the Inevitable, Ingredient
abstract: David Elsila letter on Daniel Akst's August 1 article on child labor supports contention by Honduran human rights activist Jorge Sierra that children who do nothing but work grow into adults without imaginations (S)

headline: GO2NET IS BUYING PROCESSOR OF ON-LINE TRANSACTIONS
abstract: Go2Net Inc, Internet directory and Web site operator, acquires Authorize.net Corp, payment processor for on-line transactions, for $90.5 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Remembering Oneida's Past
abstract: Oneida Community Mansion House executive director Bruce M Moseley letter corrects June 20 article on flatware maker Oneida Ltd, which evolved from Oneida Community; notes Mansion House is owned and operated by nonprofit museum formed in 1987, and is National Historic Landmark (S)

headline: Make a Quick Purchase. Wait for the Delivery Man.
abstract: Cost of home delivery and hassle of waiting for it pose barriers to growth of Internet commerce, forcing Internet retailers and companies that deliver their goods to strive to make shopping experience more seamless; analysts see delivery industry as big winner in E-commerce; table of tips on delivery; photo (M)

headline: Montenegrins, Angry at Serbs, Talk of a Split
abstract: The Government of Montenegro, once careful not to provoke Big Brother Serbia in Yugoslavia, appears to be moving swiftly toward independence, and seems ready to fight for it if necessary.    If negotiations with Serbia to get a bigger share of power and resources fail, this small republic plans a referendum in the autumn on independence. Montenegro, with 600,000 people, and Serbia, with 10 million, are the last republics left in the Yugoslav federation, whose Serbian leaders have been deserted by Slovenia, Croatia, Macedonia and Bosnia.

headline: Mubarak Attacker Killed
abstract: A man was shot dead by security guards after he grazed the hand of Egypt's President, Hosni Mubarak, with a sharp object. Page A10.

headline: ANGER OVER OIL COMPLAINT
abstract: Mexico's Energy Ministry disputes complaint by independent United States oil producers that Mexico, Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and Iraq sell crude oil at below production cost (S)

headline: GOODRICH SAYS IT WILL EARN LESS THAN EXPECTED FOR YEAR
abstract: B F Goodrich Co says it will earn less than expected this year; cites factors (S)

headline: A $43 Billion Hostile Bid In French Oil
abstract: Total Fina SA seeks to acquire Elf Acquitaine SA, French oil refiner and chemicals conglomerate, in hostile bid worth nearly $43 billion; Elf scores offer and lines up investment banks to plot defense; analysts expect extended battle that could lead to counteroffer from Elf or to rival bids from other oil companies; Elf shares surge 21.5 percent; graphs of oil company rankings; photo (M)

headline: TECHNOLOGY: E-Commerce Report; Many Internet companies have focused on attracting customers. The bigger challenge is fulfilling orders.
abstract: Internet retailers face mounting challenge with order fulfillment: the picking, packing and shipping of products; are scrambling to find third parties to handle distribution for them, but integrating distributors' own tracking and ordering systems with the retailers' is proving to require painstaking efforts; photo (M)

headline: Software for Palm VII Widens E-Mail Access
abstract: Palm VII, latest generation of 3Com's popular Palm electronic organizers, is getting help from ThinAirApps.com, start-up company giving away software that lets Palm VII users retrieve E-mail from a variety of providers (S)

headline: Buy the Book: On-Line Stores Vie for Students

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS

JPS INDUSTRIES, Greenville, S.C., a synthetic fabric maker, sold its Borden factory in Kingsport, Tenn., to Chiquola Fabrics L.L.C., a private manufacturing company, completing its exit from the cotton commercial fabric business. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

headline: Approval for Kansas City Southern's Spinoff
abstract: Kansas City Southern Industries receives Internal Revenue Service approval to proceed with spinoff of its financial services companies into entity called Stilwell Financial Inc

headline: Seagram Loss Is Smaller Than Expected
abstract: Seagram Co's fiscal fourth quarter loss widened to $129 million from $12 million a year earlier; loss is smaller than analysts had estimated; revenue rose 68 percent, to $3.5 billion from $2.1 billion (S)

headline: Stable Prices and Firm Dollar Push Treasury Prices Higher
abstract: US Treasury bond prices rise; benchmark 30-year bond posts biggest gain of week, climbing 22/32, to 101 7/32; yield falls 6.04 percent from 6.09 percent; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: New Fund for Initial Offerings
abstract: Hambrecht & Quist of San Francisco plans to open fund to invest in initial public offerings (S)

headline: DANA, MAKER OF AXLES, EXPANDING ITS BUSINESS
abstract: Dana Corp purchases closely held Innovative Manufacturing Inc; terms are not disclosed (S)

headline: BROADCASTING PURCHASE
abstract: Corus Entertainment Inc to buy the broadcasting assets of the Power Corp of Canada for $107.5 million (Canadian), or $72.6 million (US), adding its first television stations and putting it in Quebec market; Corus will get 17 radio stations and four television stations, all in Ontario and Quebec; purchase will increase to 31 number of radio stations that Corus owns (S)

headline: Past Military Rule's Abuse Is Haunting Brazil Today
abstract: Nearly decade and half of democracy has erased abuses of military rule from memory of most Brazilians, but two cases dating from unpleasant 21-year period have suddenly been thrust into national spotlight, creating embarrassment for Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso's Government (M)

headline: Beneath a Boom Quarter
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column assesses latest strong quarterly performance by Bear Stearns Cos, which continues to benefit from powerful stock market; graph (M)

abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: CADBURY PROFITS INCREASE
abstract: Cadbury Schweppes reports first half earnings rose 4.4 percent; chief executive John M Sunderland says company still plans to sell most soft-drink operations to Coca-Cola Co, despite drawn-out regulatory review of deal (S)

headline: Computer Executive to Run Microsoft Internet Unit
abstract: Microsoft Corp reportedly names Richard E Belluzzo, who resigned on Aug 23 as chairman and chief executive of Silicon Graphics Inc, to head its Internet operations called Consumer and Commerce Group, signaling that its future lies more in electronic commerce than in becoming media company; Belluzzo replaces Pete Higgins, who stepped down in November to take permanent leave of absence (M)

headline: JAPAN's OUTPUT SOARS
abstract: Japanese industrial output rose 4.6 percent in August, biggest monthly increase in 42 years; manufacturers expect to slow production in September and October amid concern stronger yen will crimp export sales; rise in industrial production is latest string of indicators to show recovery from last year's recession is taking hold (S)

headline: $700 MILLION DEAL IN HEALTH CARE PROPERTIES
abstract: Health Care Property Investors Inc to buy American Health Properties Inc for about $700 million in stock and assumption of $300 million in debt (S)

headline: National Semiconductor to Sell Cyrix Unit
abstract: National Semiconductor Corp agrees to sell its Cyrix unit to Taiwan's Via Technologies Inc; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Measuring The Force Of the Euro
abstract: Some of assumptions about how European stock markets would behave once single currency arrived are looking shaky, six months into Euro era; nations' borders still count along with industry sectors in investment decisions, and national stock markets have been casting up widely different returns; charts shows year-to-date changes in stock markets for countries participating in Euro; drawing (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: THE AMERICAS    VENEZUELA: POLITICAL SHOWDOWN  With Congress gutted by decrees that transferred its functions to a new Constitutional Assembly, opposition legislators threatened to convene an ''extraordinary session'' in defiance of the measures, but also began a ''dialogue'' with leaders of the  panel in an effort to recover some of Congress's powers. For its part, the assembly has begun deliberations on a new decree allowing them to ''evaluate'' government employees and possibly fire those deemed guilty of corruption or other misdeeds.    Larry Rohter (NYT)    COLOMBIA: REBELS REPELLED  In the heaviest fighting since mid-July, the army says it has repelled an attack by left-wing rebels on a provincial town, killing at least 47 guerrillas of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia. The attack was made in solidarity with an indefinite nationwide strike called by more than a million unionized workers and members of peasant associations.    Larry Rohter (NYT)    MEXICO: UNIVERSITY ULTIMATUM  The president of the National Autonomous University of Mexico, Francisco Barnes de Castro, issued an ultimatum to striking students, saying their shutdown of the campus ''must not continue for another day'' and warning he could use ''the force of the law'' to end it. He spoke to some 10,000 students and faculty at the largest demonstration so far against the 134-day-old strike.    Julia Preston (NYT)    CANADA: CHINESE MIGRANTS TO BE QUESTIONED  Officials plan today to start questioning 190 Chinese migrants detained off Vancouver Island. Two other ships from China were earlier intercepted as they sought to unload 254 undocumented migrants. Reflecting a hardening of attitudes, a national poll showed that 49 percent of respondents wanted the immigrants to be deported, while 49 percent said they should be allowed to apply as refugees.    James Brooke (NYT)    EUROPE    NORTHERN IRELAND: TORY CHIEF'S PROTEST  Abandoning the traditional bipartisan approach to British policy-making in Ulster, the Conservative Party leader William Hague, left, attacked Prime Minister Tony Blair's refusal to halt the continuing release of paramilitary prisoners there as ''an outrage.'' The early release procedure is part of the faltering peace settlement that will be the subject of a rescue effort in Belfast next week by former Senator George J. Mitchell, chairman of the talks that produced the April 1998 accord.    Warren Hoge (NYT)    BRITAIN: CANING BAN EXTENDED  Caning has been banned in Britain's private schools, 13 years after corporal punishment was outlawed in state schools. The move faces a legal challenge from a group of 40 private schools that say violence against teachers has increased in state schools.    Warren Hoge (NYT)    GERMANY: BARAK'S SYMBOLIC VISIT  Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel will be the first foreign leader to visit Germany's new capital in Berlin since the Government moved there last month. Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, speaking on the 60th anniversary of the start of World War II, made clear the visit had important symbolic value given ''Berlin's heavy historic responsibility.''    Roger Cohen (NYT)    TURKEY: AMNESTY BILL VETOED  President Suleyman Demirel vetoed a bill passed by Parliament that would have given amnesty to thousands of prisoners, including some of the country best-known gangsters and assassins. Many political and civic leaders had protested the law. Parliament is in recess until Oct. 1, and will then have a chance to override Mr. Demirel's veto by a simple majority.    Stephen Kinzer (NYT)    MIDDLE EAST    IRAQ: U.S. STRIKES IN NORTH  Iraqi forces fired at American and British planes striking at civilian targets in the north, a spokesman in Baghdad said. No mention was made of casualties or damage. The United States military said its planes had bombed a military site in northern Iraq and said all planes returned to the Incirlik airbase in Turkey.    (Agence France-Presse)    AFRICA    SIERRA LEONE: REBEL LEADERS HELD  Two commanders of the rebel movement that recently signed a peace accord with the Government remained in captivity after a group of former soldiers kidnapped them in Freetown. The soldiers are among those who also held a group of United Nations officials in July for several days, saying they had been excluded from the agreement. They had been allied since 1997 with the Revolutionary United Front, whose leader, Foday Sankoh, has yet to return to Sierra Leone almost two months after the signing of an increasingly fragile peace deal.    Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)    ASIA    INDONESIA: OFFICIAL VOTE RESULTS  More than two months after parliamentary elections, official results were finally released, confirming that the party of the presidential front-runner, Megawati Sukarnoputri, left, came in first. Ms. Megawati's Indonesian Democratic Party for Struggle won 153 seats, making her the favorite to be chosen president in November by an electoral college. The Golkar Party of President B. J. Habibie finished second with 120 seats in the 500-member Parliament.    (AP)    INDIA: ELECTION ALERT  After discovering several caches of explosives and ammunition in New Delhi, the police are beginning a major effort to guard polling places as the first round of parliamentary elections take place this Sunday in the capital and other locations. Most recently, a large supply of bomb-making materials was seized from a member of an Islamic militant group active in hit-and-run raids in Kashmir, the police said.    Barry Bearak (NYT)    VIETNAM: SECOND THOUGHTS  The Vietnamese Army ''made mistakes'' when it took over South Vietnam in 1975, the army newspaper said, indicating that a debate continues in Hanoi over the decision by northern Communists to destroy the freewheeling economy of the south, sending thousands of South Vietnamese into re-education camps. The general who signed the article, according to a Reuters report from Hanoi, said soldiers had failed to heed Ho Chi Minh's warnings against arrogance in victory.    Barbara Crossette (NYT)    CHINA: BRIGHT TOURISM FUTURE  China is expected to become a major force in international tourism in coming decades, the World Tourism Organization said in Hong Kong. The Madrid-based group predicts that rising standards of living will allow about 100 million Chinese to take international trips by 2020, putting them in fourth place in numbers of travelers after Germany, Japan and the United States. By the same time, China will outrank France as the world's top destination, the organization said.    Barbara Crossette (NYT)    KYRGYZSTAN: 3 HOSTAGES FREED  Armed militants released three Kyrgyz soldiers seized as hostages, but continued to hold a group of Japanese geologists, officials said.    (AP)

headline: Let's Make a Deal
abstract: Query to readers on unusual settings where people have found clients, investors, employees and employers (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    NORTHERN IRELAND: BLAIR CLARIFICATION -- Seeking to shore up wavering Protestant support for his blueprint for setting up the new Northern Ireland government this month, Prime Minister Tony Blair told the House of Commons that Sinn Fein would have to give up its cabinet positions if its I.R.A. allies did not disarm on schedule. Mr. Blair issued the clarification in a speech arguing that the plan, negotiated in Belfast last week, was the best opportunity for peace this generation of Britons would ever have.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: ITT INDUSTRIES IS BUYING A BUSINESS FROM STANFORD
abstract: ITT Industries Inc agrees to acquire space and military communications operations of Stanford Telecommunications Inc for $191 million; ITT says transaction is subject to completion of $280 million merger between Stanford and Newbridge Network Corp; that deal is expected to close in November; Intel Corp says it has agreed to buy Stanford's Component Products division for undisclosed amount of cash (S)

abstract: Boeing Co

headline: Serbian Protesters Install Their Own Government
abstract: Nearly 10,000 people demonstrate nightly in Novi Sad, Serbia, in opposition to Pres Slobodan Milosevic, and Nenad Canak forcuses protests on installing a new 'transitional' parliament and government for province of Vojvodina; photo (M)

headline: DEBT TENSIONS IN BRAZIL
abstract: Brazilian governors call for better access to tax revenue and for federal funds to cover state pension deficits (S)

headline: NISSAN TRANSACTIONS
abstract: Japan's Nissan Motor Co will sell stakes in two affiliated auto parts makers; affiliates will buy stakes in each other, bringing them closer together to compete more effectively against larger rivals; sales will distance them from Nissan, which is cutting costs and selling assets to reduce debt; Nissan will sell 11 percent, or about half its stake, of Tachi-S Co, seat maker, to Fuji Kiko Co, maker of safety belts and steering parts; it will sell most of its 23.8 percent stake in Fuji Kiko and Tachi-S (S)

headline: MARKS TO SELL KINGS MARKETS
abstract: British retailer Marks & Spencer PLC announces major overhaul of its US operations, saying it will sell Kings supermarkets in New Jersey while promoting Brooks Brothers men's wear stores (S)

headline: Korean Conglomerates Remain Entrenched
abstract: South Korean Government has spent much of last two years trying to shrink size and power of South Korea's big business conglomerates, which are widely blamed for reckless expansion and heavy debts that helped cause country's financial crisis; many of owners of these conglomerates, known as chaebols, have become more powerful, making it increasingly difficult for Government to force them to make changes; Korea Stock Exchange's analysis shows that average stake of one subsidiary held by another subsidiary within same conglomerate increased from 19.9 percent in January 1998 to 28.7 percent at end of August; average internal shareholding rose to 34.6 percent at end of August, compared with 27.2 percent before economic crisis that battered South Korea in late 1997; Ssangyong Group tops list in terms of stockholdings by owners or top executives; founding family group holds 6.52 percent of group's total shares, followed by Daewoo with 5.2 percent and SK with 3.88 percent (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ford Sales Increased 8.1% In Industry's Best August  Ford Motor said that its sales in August rose 8.1 percent, even higher than expected, making last month the best August ever for auto sales and the best month in the 1990's after adjusting for seasonal variations in demand.

headline: European Court Tells British To Let Gay Soldiers Serve
abstract: European Court of Human Rights declares that Britain's longstanding ban on homosexuals in military is violation of basic human right to privacy (M)

headline: Campaigns use flash, dash and Claymation to promote the TV networks' football coverage.
abstract: Studio programs that precede National Football League games on Sundays are promoting themselves in ads that focus on entertainment, expertise and interaction among announcers; in some spots, Fox has transformed its announcers into animated Claymation characters (M)

abstract: Global Industries to buy ETPM SA from Groupe GTM, Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux SA affiliate, for $265 million and assumption of $2 million of debt; will lease GTM's interest in two vessels and buy that interest in Jan 2002 for $25 million (S)

headline: Share Prices Move a Bit Lower, With Dow Losing 22.16
abstract: Stock prices staged a modest retreat for the first time in four sessions yesterday, despite a wave of glowing earnings reports from some of the nation's biggest corporations.    Traders said that a pullback was to be expected, because stocks have been so strong lately. On Friday, all three major market averages closed at record highs.

headline: Calculating Irrationality
abstract: Dr Edwar

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: 2 TORIES EYE MAYOR'S JOB  The opposition Conservatives moved closer to choosing a candidate in next May's election for a Mayor of London. Lord Jeffrey Archer, a millionaire writer and party stalwart, and a former Transport Minister, Steven Norris, emerged as front-runners in a vote among party members. The final choice will be made in a broader, postal ballot. The Labor Party has not yet named a candidate.    Alan Cowell (NYT)

headline: Canada Seizes Chinese Boat Smuggling In 100 Immigrants
abstract: Canada seizes ship carrying over 100 undocumented Chinese immigrants off Vancouver Island in what may be largest interception of immigrant smuggling on Canada's West Coast; arrests 11 crew members suspected of roles in smuggling ring; photo (M)

headline: CNN Shifts To Moss/Dragoti
abstract: CNN, cable television news network, moves its advertising account to Moss/Dragoti after less than four months at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos (S)

headline: Vodka Ad Is Stopped After Racism Protest
abstract: Skyy Vodka will discontinue ad after protest by members of Asian-American Web site Asianavenue.com, part of Community Connect Inc; site says ad is racially offensive; it shows nearly naked white woman being served glass of vodka by Asian woman robed in traditional Japanese attire; Arul Sundaram, spokesman for Web site, says its members felt that Skyy stereotyped Asian women as 'china dolls' and submissive to other races (S)

headline: Internet Connects Inventors to Information (and One Another)
abstract: Inventors are flocking to Internet, where they can find on-line support groups and message boards, patent and trademark databases, and information on suspicious promotion and development companies; several Web sites noted; photos of inventors Gary Kellmann and Rodney Long (M)

headline: Sony Schedules Rollout of Playstation 2
abstract: Sony Corp says it will begin selling its Playstation 2 home video game console in Japan on March 4, much later than most analysts had expected; machine will be priced at $368 (US) (S)

headline: QUESTOR IS BUYING A STAKE IN AEGIS COMMUNICATIONS
abstract: Aegis Communications Group Inc says Questor Partners Fund II LP will pay $46.75 million for equivalent of about 30 percent stake in company (S)

headline: American And British Law Firms Set to Merge
abstract: Lawyers at Rogers & Wells in New York and Clifford Chance in London announce merger of their firms, first combination between major British and American law firms; firms' partners further announce their intention to merge with Germany's third-largest law firm, Punder, Volhard, Weber & Axster, move that would create largest law firm in world in terms of both lawyers and revenue; partners at all three law firms plan to vote on German merger in September; combined firm would have 2,700 lawyers and 30 offices worldwide; three firms will earn more than $1 billion in fees this year (M)

headline: Fogarty Klein Buys Taylor Speier Group
abstract: Fogarty Klein & Partners, part of Lois/USA, acquires Taylor Speier Group (S)

headline: Prolific Chinese Painter Is Anonymous No More
abstract: Chinese officials for first time are allowing Wang Qizhi to admit that he painted portrait of Mao Zedong that looms over Beijing's Tiananmen Square; photo (M)

headline: Shares Up for 3d Consecutive Session, and Dow Gains 70.29
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 70.29 points, to 11,117.08; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 13.39 points, to 1,344.16; Nasdaq composite index climbs 25.94, to 2,671.22; graph; charts (M)

headline: U.S. Likely to Regain a U.N. Finance Seat
abstract: Senior American official says US is likely to regain seat on important United Nations budget committee, clearing one hurdle Clinton Administration faces in getting Congress to pay back dues to organization (M)

headline: Qwest and U S West Agree on Breakup Fee
abstract: Qwest Communications International Inc will pay US West Inc $850 million if it terminates $45.2 billion merger agreement; US West agrees to pay Qwest $850 million if it breaks agreement; Global Crossing Ltd, which has also sought to buy US West, agrees to reduced breakup payment from US West; to terminate merger agreement, US West will pay Global Crossing $420 million (S)

headline: Met Life Is Said to Be Near Deal for St. Paul Auto and Home Unit
abstract: Metropolitan Life, one of country's largest life insurance companies, is expected to announce acquisition of unit of St Paul Companies for more than $500 million in cash; deal is first of several that Met Life executives have previously said they intended to make in bid to catapult their company into top ranks of auto and home insurance business (M)

headline: The King and the 'Cabby' Inspect Jordan Incognito
abstract: King Abdullah II of Jordan disguises himself as taxi passenger and television journalist for forays into streets of Amman to get a first-hand look at common problems affecting Jordanians, who often complain that no one is attending to country's ailments; tests local law enforcement during cab ride and inspects operations in country's free trade zone during visit as journalist; visits echo common touch shown by late father, King Hussein, and great-grandfather, King Abdullah I, who often wore disguises, especially during clandestine meetings with Israelis; Abdullah also shows activist leadership and an attention to domestic matters that contrasts sharply with late father's all-absorbing preoccupation with foreign policy in final year of his reign; photo (M)

headline: Treasuries Fall as Investors Reassess What Fed Might Do
abstract: US bond prices fall for first time in a week; price of 30-year bond falls 23/32, to 103 6/32; yield rises to 5.90 percent, from 5.85 percent; graph on tax-exempt yields; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Ford's Labor Relations Are on Edge as G.M.'s Relax
abstract: Ford Motor Co is facing labor troubles in US and Canada even as labor relations at General Motors Corp are finally starting to improve after 19 strikes over last five years; increasingly contentious issues facing Ford are making it less likely that it will be chosen by United Automobile Workers union this year as first auto maker to negotiate pattern-setting, three-year national contract for industry; it appears possible, although still not certain, that UAW will negotiate first this year with DaimlerChrysler, leaving for later in autumn the difficult issues at Ford and complicated but less contentious issues at GM; union contracts with three major auto makers expire Sept 14 (M)

headline: Primedia Set To Name NBC Executive As Its Chief
abstract: Primedia Inc, which owns more than 200 publishing properties, names Thomas Rogers, president of NBC cable, as its chief executive; Rogers expanded NBC network into cable and Internet markets, and Henry R Kravis, founding partner of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, which controls just under 80 percent of Primedia's stock, says Primedia needs to become a full-service media company, involved in publishing, television, Internet and new technologies; other leaders in magazine industry have tried to figure out the way to translate a magazine's assets onto the Internet, none with much success; photo (M)

headline: Arnold Communications is leading what may be the biggest campaign against smoking.
abstract: Team of advertising agencies is selected to create and produce what is intended as largest single national advertising, marketing and public relations campaign to 'unsell' cigarette smoking; team was chosen after three-month review by American Legacy Foundation; initial annual budget will be $150 million to $255 million; Arnold Commnications is leading campaign (M)

headline: Gates Putting Some Money In Silver Miner
abstract: Microsoft Corp chairman William H Gates acquires 10.3 percent of Pan American Silver Corp, tiny silver mining company based in Vancouver; roughly $15 million investment, made by Cascade Investment LLC, one of Gates's personal investing companies, is made public in Securities and Exchange Commission filing; investment is seen as significant vote of confidence in metals markets; silver rises to $5.77 an ounce, up 7.6 percent (M)

headline: 20 Hindus Slain in Kashmir, Apparently by Muslim Insurgents
abstract: Twenty Hindus are killed in three incidents in remote areas of Jammu and Kashmir, India, in what officials fear to be stepped-up hit-and-run tactics by Muslim insurgents; 15 die in Lihota and rest in Punch District, where Government forces reportedly retaliate against militants, killing five; map; photo (M)

headline: New 'President' of Belarus Flees the Crackdown on Dissidents
abstract: Crackdowns on those who oppose President Aleksandr Lukashenko of Belarus have led the chief opposition figure to flee to Lithuania after his supporters voted him acting president and proclaimed the Lukashenko Government at an end.    The opposition leader, Semyon Sharetsky, a former Speaker of Parliament, apparently feared for his safety during a new Government crackdown on critics, who charge that Mr. Lukashenko has illegally extended his rule, which originally was to have ended earlier this week.

headline: Drug Makers Report Higher Profits in Quarter
abstract: Schering-Plough Corp's profits rose 20 percent in second quarter; Eli Lilly & Co's profits rose 17 percent; Bristol-Myers Squibb Co's profits rose 14 percent; net income for Schering-Plough rose to $547 million compared with $455 million in quarter a year ago; sales rose 15 percent, to $2.45 billion, from $2.12 billion; net income for Lilly rose to $576.4 million compared with $491.3 million; sales rose 8.7 percent, to $2.34 billion from $2.16 billion; Bristol-Myers says net income rose to $952 million compared with $835 million in quarter a year ago; sales rose 11 percent, to $4.92 billion, from $4.43 billion (M)

headline: A New Agency In San Francisco
abstract: Brothers Kelly and Tim Nice start their own agency, Nice Advertising, in San Francisco (S)

headline: The Cement Ceiling?
abstract: Survey of group of 109 blacks, Hispanic and Native Americans, all execs and professionals with master's degrees in business, finds that 79 percent say that MBA's from minority groups lag somewhat or far behind whites in being hired for corporate positions (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of August 29 article about financial relationship between artist Donald Sultan and collector Fayez Sarofim, which misspelled name of New York's Blum Helman Gallery and referred incorrectly to its history; it remains open as Joseph Helman Gallery (S)

headline: Brazilians Eagerly Seek a Big Bank's Entry-Level Jobs
abstract: At least one million people are competing for about 10,000 jobs at Government-run Banco do Brasil; even some longtime former employees, who lost their jobs in earlier cutbacks, are vying for entry-level positions; bank has work force of 72,000, making it one of nation's largest employers; positions are coveted because they come with benefits that are uncommon in other jobs; bank also pays salaries on time and in full, at rates more than five times Brazil's minimum wage of 140 reals a month--now $72.46; flood of applications illustrates bleakness of job situation in Brazil, even as country slowly emerges from recession; Government reports unemployment declined to 8.12 percent in July from 8.4 percent in June; graph; photo (M)

headline: Blair Spokesman Defends Alliance Briefings : A Key Adviser to NATO Assails Kosovo Coverage
abstract: LONDON—  A key figure in the media campaign waged by NATO governments during the conflict in Kosovo criticized Western journalists on Friday for devoting as much coverage to alliance blunders and Serb civilian casualties as to the atrocities committed by Serb forces against ethnic Albanians.

headline: REPRESENTATIVE RETURNING HOME
abstract: Shi Guangsheng, China's top negotiator in charge of securing his country's entry into World Trade Organization, holds single day of talks with his American counterparts in Washington, then says he is returning to Beijing for his nation's 50th anniversary celebrations; brief trip leaves Clinton Administration mystified (S)

headline: Venezuelan Leader Moves a Step Closer to Broad New Powers
abstract: Venezuela's newly empowered Constitutional Assembly approves decree that gives group far-reaching authority to abolish Government institutions and dismiss officials, and strengthens authority of Pres Hugo Chavez; Chavez took office in February vowing to carry out peaceful social revolution; his critics maintain his real aim is to impose left-wing military dictatorship; supporters of Chavez, including his wife, brother and half dozen members of his Cabinet, occupy 120 of 131 seats in assembly (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen continues to surge against dollar on expectations that investors will pour more money into Japanese stocks; in New York, dollar settles at 104.28 yen, down from 105.79; graph; chart (S)

headline: Amazon.com Gets Into Two New Businesses
abstract: Amazon.com plans to introduce two new divisions, one for consumer electronics and another for toys (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Gas prices fall on news that Hurricane Floyd is unlikely to hit Gulf of Mexico; October contract, up 9.2 percent on Sept 9, falls 5 cents, or 1.8 percent, to $2.801 for million BTU's; graph; chart (S)

headline: A Maverick Has Plans for Chicago
abstract: Profile of and interview with maverick software entrepreneur Andrew J Filipowski, who recent sold Platinum Technology International to Computer Associates; Filipowski says his next challenge is to turn Chicago into 'center for cyberspace;' photo (M)

headline: TAG AVIATION IS SET TO PURCHASE WAYFARER
abstract: TAG Aviation USA Inc plans to purchase Wayfarer Aviation Inc; terms are not disclosed but estimate is less than $20 million (S)

headline: Datek Chooses Bozell And 24/7 Expands
abstract: Datek Online Holdings Corp names Bozell Worldwide, part of True North Communications, as its first agency of record; 24/7 Media, which provides Internet advertising and direct-marketing networks, opens sales office in Washington and makes acquisition in Canada (Advertising column) (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    NORTHERN IRELAND: PROTESTANT FREED  Prison authorities in Belfast freed Johnny (Mad Dog) Adair, one of Northern Ireland's most notorious Protestant guerrilla commanders. He was the latest of almost 300 Protestant and Catholic prisoners released under a 1998 accord. Mr. Adair, 34, had served five years of a 16-year term for ''directing terrorism.'' His release coincided with new attempts to advance the peace effort.    Alan Cowell (NYT)

headline: For Linux Users
abstract: Letter from Brian Vogel comments on July 8 article on Internet protocol addresses

headline: Can It Be?Venerable Eton Takes a Tumble From Its Lofty Tower
abstract: WINDSOR, England—  When Alan Clark, the calculatingly outrageous Conservative politician who died just over two weeks ago, was asked about his days at Eton, he replied that they were remarkably useful, providing him with "an early introduction to human cruelty, treachery, and physical hardship."

headline: The Growing Roster of the Unretired
abstract: Fred Brock Seniority column on people who return to work after retirement; notes more baby boomers plan to keep working, at least part-time, after retirement, trend less popular among current retirees; drawing (M)

headline: Coca-Cola Bottler Reports Surprisingly Big Slide in Sales
abstract: Coca-Cola Co's major bottler in Central and Eastern Europe, Coca-Cola Beverages, reports unexpectedly steep drop in first-half volume sales and its stock falls sharply; Coca-Cola Beverages attributes 5 percent decline in volume, measured in cases sold, to severe economic problems in Russia, Kosovo conflict, company's recent bottled-water recalls in Poland and bad publicity from Coca-Cola beverage recalls in Belgium and France, which were handled by Coca-Cola Enterprises; first-half results are announced as merger talks continue between Coca-Cola Beverages and Hellenic Bottling, Athens-based independent Coke bottler; Ron Pugsley, general director of Coca-Cola Beverages Poland, says company will reopen affected Polish plant on July 14; photo (M)

headline: Merrill Posts 23% Increase In Earnings
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co posts robust second quarter earnings; reports earnings of $673 million, up 23 percent from $549 million in year-earlier period; net revenue rose 12 percent, to record $5.4 billion; commissions rose 8.8 percent, to $1.59 billion, and trading revenue jumped 7.6 percent, to $1.06 billion (M)

headline: Realnetworks, Realjukebox and Finally, It Seems, Real Money
abstract: Realnetworks, Seattle company that makes software for sending audio and video over Internet, will announce series of alliances with companies that will sell products or provide information to users of Realjukebox, software product that allows people to copy, store and play music from compact disks on their personal computers; Checkout.com, new Internet entertainment Web site co-founded by Michael Ovitz, will become exclusive on-line vendor of compact disks and provider of entertainment information for users of Realjukebox; 800.com will be exclusive seller of electronic products, while MP3.com will provide music that users of Realjukebox can download free; financial terms undisclosed (M)

headline: I.B.M. TO OFFER SERVER FOR INTERNET SERVICE PROVIDERS
abstract: International Business Machines Corp to offer server computer for Internet service providers, challenging Sun Microsystems in market (S)

headline: Westerners See a Toothless Japanese Giant
abstract: Bankers and analysts see little threat to American or European banks as result of proposed merger of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, Fuji Bank and Industrial Bank of Japan, with combined assets of $1.3 trillion; contend combination would not have global reach, profitability, technology or productivity necessary to make it threat; chart (M) y

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of July 18 article on accounting techniques that can mask company performance; irregularities at Cendant Corp were explosed i April 1998, not April 1997 ()S

headline: France Shops for Another Pretty Face
abstract: France's mayors vote on a model for a new Marianne, the national symbol, choosing from five beautiful finalists, including two supermodels; critics ask why a woman of intellect and accomplishments rather than her looks could not be Marianne; the new Marianne will join earlier versions from which each mayor selects the statue that will grace his or her city hall; photos (M)

headline: Hong Kong and Disney to Keep Discussing a Theme Park
abstract: Hong Kong announces that it will extend talks with Walt Disney Co on building theme park in Hong Kong until end of October; officials say they made significant progress in talks, but were not in position to sign agreement by June 30, date government had hopeed to have definitive deal; stumbling block appears to be how much Disney would pay for land on Lantau island; newspaper reports say Disney demanded 430-acre site free of charge--in addition to low-cost loans, electricity and water; Mike Rowse, Hong Kong's Commissioner of Tourism and chief negotiator with Disney, comments; photo (M)

headline: 2 Small-Aircraft Makers Told To Reduce Export Subsidies
abstract: World Trade Organization, in ruling that shakes market for small passenger jets, orders small-aircraft makers Embraer SA of Brazil and Bombardier Inc of Canada to scale back export subsidy programs; Embraer, which is more heavily dependent on subsidies, cautiously welcomes ruling, which does not require Brazil to scrap subsidy program completely; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MK GOLD CO., Salt Lake City, acquired the Las Cruces copper deposit in Spain for $42 million from Rio Tinto P.L.C., London, the world's second-biggest mining company.    JOHNSON CONTROLS INC.,  Milwaukee, a maker of automobile interiors, bought two German fabric and parts plants for an undisclosed amount from the closely held Benecke-Kaliko A.G., Hanover, Germany.

headline: You've Got Mail: Hello Muddah (and CC: Faddah)
abstract: Directors of many summer camps are leery about allowing computer technology to interfere with children's camping experience; parents, eager for word from their children, would like them to have access to E-mail; several companies, including E-Camp, are trying to give campers E-mail ability without burdening camps; they are installing computers at camps if parents agree to pay $5-per-month fee; photo (M)

headline: Do You Have Enough RAM? It Depends on Which Kind
abstract: Random access memory (RAM) speeds operation of computer; description of various types of RAM and advice on best type to use and how to upgrade; photo (M)

headline: SEAGATE TECHNOLOGY TO REORGANIZE SOFTWARE UNIT
abstract: Seagate Technology Inc will revamp its software unit; will buy 6.5 percent of its Seagate Software unit it does not own for eight million shares, or about $280 million, and take charge against earnings of $216 million; company will gain full control of 61 million shares of Veritas Softare Corp held by unit, valued at about $4 billion (S)

headline: French Aide Named to Lead Rebuilding Effort
abstract: Secretary General Kofi Annan chooses Dr Bernard Kouchner, French Health Minister, as his chief representative to run UN's vast civilian operations to be set up in Kosovo; Annan describes challenge as awesome; Kouchner's main deputy will be James Covey, former American diplomat; Kouchner will have sweeping authority and daunting task: rebuilding on broad front, restoring order and rule of law, providing housing and basic services, and re-establishing civil institutions like courts, police and remainder of local governments; Kouchner has been innovative and independent-minded in many crises, but he has little administrative or UN experience (M)

headline: Seoul Wants Longer-Range Rockets to Meet the North's Threat : U.S. to Upgrade South Korea Missiles
abstract: TOKYO—  The United States promised Thursday to help South Koreans counter growing military pressure from North Korea by trying to meet their demands for enhancing the number and range of their missiles.

headline: Reuters Says It Won't Face Federal Charges
abstract: Federal prosecutors will not charge Reuters Holdings PLC with improperly obtaining information from competitor, Bloomberg LP; grand jury has been investigating relationship between Reuters subsidiary, Reuters Analytics, and Cyberspace Research Associates Inc, company set up by former Bloomberg employee; prosecutors were looking into whether Cyberspace assisted Reuters Analytics in obtaining information about Bloomberg's operating code (S)

headline: As Jakarta Troops Leave, Peacekeepers Face Gunfire
abstract: International peacekeepers in East Timor have their first tense encounters with armed men in Dili, as last elements of Indonesian Army begin their final pullout from East Timor, smashing and burning their barracks and headquarters behind them; peacekeepers, in one small incident after another, encounter gunshots, some of them coming from truckloads of Indonesian soldiers, some apparently fired by irregular fighters; photo; maps (M)

headline: Big Turnout for Minority Journalists
abstract: More than 5,000 minority journalists attend second national convention of Unity: Journalists of Color Inc, to debate what news organizations must do to put world in focus; assumption is that major news organizations will have continuing trouble keeping their audiences; convention includes job fair at which scores of news organizations interview minority candidates; number of Hispanic, Native American, Asian and black newspaper journalists has risen to only 11.55 percent from 10.49 percent five years ago; Census Bureau estimates that 28 percent of country's population belongs to one of those four minority groups; photo (M)

headline: TYCO INTERNATIONAL TO SPLIT ITS STOCK
abstract: Tyco International Ltd will split its stock two shares for one (S)

headline: Idealism at Home
abstract: Nicole Mandarano letter on July 18 article on how Peace Corps volunteers hone business skills; notes same skills are learned at Vista and Americorps (S)

headline: AT&T Faces Its Spinoff As a Rival
abstract: AT&T Corp and Lucent Technologies vie for business in field of communications consulting, competing against each other for first time since Lucent was spun off from AT&T in 1996; Lucent intends to use International Network Services, which it acquired in August, to bolster its Netcare consulting operations; AT&T has built its AT&T Solutions consulting and outsourcing operation into a multibillion-dollar business and has long relied on International Network to supply engineers and networking experts for clients, who may now become targets for Lucent Netcare (M)

headline: Chechen Group Trying to Ransom U.S. Aid Worker's Remains
abstract: Chechen group, in new development surrounding disappearance of US aid worker Fred Cluny in war-torn Chechnya in 1995 during relief mission, claims to have his body and is demanding large ransom for its return; Russian authorities tell US group has turned over critical piece of evidence, namely, photograph that appears to show metal pin inserted in Cluny's leg after accident years ago; family rules out paying ransom; says doing so could endanger abduction of aid workers and might even compensate his killers; son says father adamantly opposed such action; Cluny went to Chechnya in 1995 on relief mission sponsored by billionaire investor George Soros; maps (M)

headline: On Hawaii, A Telescope Widens Orbit Of Japanese
abstract: Japan inaugurat7

headline: TLC BEATRICE NEARS FINAL LIQUIDATION WITH DISTRIBUTION
abstract: TLC Beatrice International Holdings Inc will distribute $30 a share, total of about $275 million, to stockholders as it nears final liquidation (S)

headline: NATO Commander in Kosovo Says Peacekeeping Force Has Reached Its Limit
abstract: Interview with Lieut Gen Sir Mike Jackson, head of NATO forces in Kosovo, Serbia, who is ending tour of duty; says that peacekeeping force has done about all it can to restore order and that civilian authorities must take over; says he is convinced he was right to act as he did in disobeying order by Gen Wesley Clark, NATO's Supreme commander, to seize Pristina Airport ahead of arrival of Russian force on June 11; photo (M)

headline: Postal Service Settles With Pitney Bowes
abstract: Pitney Bowes Inc gets $51.75 million from United States Postal Service to settle its suit over revenue from its electronic postage-meter-resetting system (S)

headline: U.S. Sand Supplier Is Sold
abstract: Hanson PLC says one of its units has purchased Tidewater Sand and Gravel Inc for $44 million (S)

headline: 2 WARY NEIGHBORS UNITE TO CONFRONT NORTH KOREA ARMS
abstract: North Korea's preparations to test new long-range missile have led to dramatic change of course in military planning and diplomacy for Japan and South Korea; Japan is considering stretching constitutional limits on its military, while South Korea is beginning to overcome suspicions of Japan and consider ways to cooperate in face of common threat; Japan has agreed to take part in missile-defense system that US is developing; map (M)

headline: Betting the Farm On the Virtual Store
abstract: Owners of small stores across the country are closing up shop and selling their wares via on-line auctions, lured by lower costs and higher profits; while none of auction sites knows how many peope have turned Internet auctions into full-time busineses, Ebay estimates that it has about 10,000 'power sellers' who sell merchandise for $2,000 to $25,000 or more each month; several merchandisers comment; sales strategies noted; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Corn futures prices fall as Midwest rain eases concern about crop damage; corn for Dec deliver falls 8 cents, to $2.165 a bushel; graphs; table (S)

headline: John Hancock Plans Stock Sale
abstract: Board of John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Co approves plans to convert company to publicly traded company; initial stock sale is expected by end of March 2000 (S)

headline: To Appease U.S., Kazakh Acts on MIG Sales
abstract: Kazakhstan Pres Nursultan A Nazarbayev, with strategic ties to US at risk over sale of MIG jet fighters to North Korea, orders series of arrests, reforms government's arms export system and dismisses his closest adviser,, Nurtai Abukayev (M)

headline: Smaller Than a Regular Mouse, But Big Enough for Travelers
abstract: Targus introduces new USB Mobile Mini Mouse for laptops; photo (S)

headline: Karadut Journal; On a Peak in Turkey, Closing In on a Fabled Tomb
abstract: Search for tomb of King Antiochus, under way for over century, may be nearing climax on Turkey's Mount Nemrut; giant statues and artifacts already found at Nemrut monument provide rich picture of Commagene kingdom, which existed from 162 BC to AD 72; map; photos (M)

headline: CSX IN TALKS TO SELL SHIPPING BUSINESS TO MAERSK
abstract: The stock of the CSX Corporation rose yesterday after it was reported that the company was in talks to sell its international container-shipping business to Maersk Inc. A transaction could be announced as early as this week and involve about $800 million in combined cash and assumption of debt, The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday, citing people familiar with the talks. CSX's stock rose $2.25 a share, to $51.1875. Both CSX, based in Richmond, and Maersk, which is Danish-owned but based in Madison, N.J., declined to comment. Maersk, a subsidiary of A. P. Moller Group of Copenhagen, is the largest container-shipping company in the world.

headline: INVESTING WITH: Robert E. Kern; Fremont U.S. Micro-Cap Fund
abstract: Investing With column focuses on investing strategies of Fremont US Micro-Cap Fund portfolio manager Robert E Kern; photo; chart; graph (M)

headline: INDIA CRITICIZES DUTIES
abstract: India denies US accusation that its companies were dumping cut-to-length steel plates on US market; Steel Ministry says Indian steel companies were exporting to US only at internationally competitive prices; US decision to impose preliminary antidumping duties of up to 59 percent on exports of steel plate to US will mainly affect India's largest steel maker, state-run Steel Authority of India Ltd (S)

headline: CHINA CLOSES COMPANY
abstract: China's financial regulators order closing of Pudong Lianhe Trust and Investment Corp, one of Shanghai's largest trust and investment companies, citing crushing debt load; Agricultural Bank of China, principal shareholder, will take over $1.2 billion debt (S)

headline: EGLOBE TO BUY TRANS GLOBAL FOR ABOUT $80 MILLION
abstract: Eglobe Inc acquires Trans Global Communications Inc for about $80 million in stock (S)

headline: CANADIAN PACIFIC CUTS
abstract: Canadian Pacific Railway Co will reduce its work force by 10 percent, or about 1,900 jobs, in next 18 months; reports that second-quarter earnings rose 16 percent but that reorganization will result in $199.3 million accounting charge (S)

headline: A Push to Intervene in East Timor Is Gathering Backers at the U.N.
abstract: Key nations at UN reportedly move toward sending force to East Timor to halt violence by rampaging militias, following vote favoring independence, if Indonesian military refuses to do so; five-member UN Security Council team leaves for Jakarta after meeting with Sec Gen Kofi Annan; Annan says he and Indonesia's Pres B J Habibie have agreed on need for further urgent measures to restore order; diplomats say military intervention must first be accepted by Indonesians; UN and US officials say Clinton Administration has not yet discussed what role, if any, US will play in such operation; Indonesia declares martial law in East Timor; national armed forces chief Gen Wiranto is placed in charge of restoring order; diplomats remain skeptical about prospects; note army command has not stopped violence in days since territory voted overwhelmingly to secede from Indonesia (M)

headline: Inventor Fills Girls' Desire for Their Own Gadgets
abstract: Profile of Dr Janese Swanson, founder of Girl Tech toys, an affordable line of electronic gadgets for girls; she comments on her most popular product, Password Journal, voice-activated diary; Girl Tech gadgets are remarkable not just because they sell, but also because they contradict sex stereotypes that in the toy market almost anything electronic is labeled as boys' product; her photo with some of her inventions (L)

headline: Bush Carries Some Baggage In Developing China Stance
abstract: Republican Presidential front-runner, Gov George W Bush, whose father was accused by candidate Bill Clinton of 'coddling' dictators in Beijing, is struggling to decide how hard a line to take toward China; issue of China is sticky one for Republican candidate, who is caught between hawkish conservatives on one side of his party and pro-business interests on the other; shadow of his father, who during his presidency claimed China as a special area of expertise, compounds problem (M)

headline: Broadcom to Buy Hothaus For $280 Million in Stock
abstract: Broadcom Corp to buy Hothaus Technologies Inc for $280 million in stock (M)

headline: Lenders Regard Mexican Economy With Suspicion
abstract: Foreign lenders are cautious about Mexican economy following failure of Bufete Industrial SA and Grupo Dina to meet debt payments and possibility that other heavily indebted companies may follow suit; analysts note country's economy has become divided between elite companies with easy access to foreign credit and scores of lesser businesses that pay high prices to attract capital or are shut out (M)

headline: TRADE DEFICIT RISE PROVOKES CONCERN OF RISK TO DOLLAR
abstract: Commerce Dept reports that US trade deficit in July hit $25.2 billion, higher than June imbalance of $24.6 billion, confounding expectations that deficit would start to shrink as economic growth picked up around world; imports from China, Western Europe and Japan hit new highs, but exports advanced only slightly; leap in US trade deficit fuels fears that continuing surge in imports is threatening health of dollar; stocks and bonds react by falling sharply in financial markets as US currency dips yet again versus Japanese yen; graph (M)

headline: Ford Motor hopes young consumers will be hooked by a campaign featuring live commercials.
abstract: Annabelle Gurwitch, co-host of TBS series Dinner and a Movie, will be star of live commercials for Ford Motor Co's new Focus car line; Gurwitch will be featured on more than 60 live commercials on four TV networks, which will begin Sept 9; ad campaign, developed by J Walter Thompson, is aimed at young consumers; photo (Advertising column) (M)

headline: BID FOR DISTILLERY
abstract: World7

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.25   8.25   8.50        Discount rate   4.75   4.75   5.00        Federal funds   5.31   5.21   5.42        3-month T-bills   4.66   4.67   4.47        6-month T-bills   4.81   4.85   4.39        10-yr. T-infl.   4.07   4.07   3.62        10-yr. T-note   5.79   5.91   4.62        30-yr.
