headline: Awaiting Images of Cosmic Phenomena
abstract: NASA will unveil first images taken by Chandra X-Ray Observatory; Chandra will transmit images of distant cosmic phenomena such as exploding stars, black holes and colliding galaxies; photo (S)

headline: U.S. Postal Service Approves Capital Plan
abstract: Postal Service governors approve $4 billion fiscal 2000 capital plan; M Richard Porras, Postal Service chief financial officer, says service is on track to earn $200 million in 1999 (S)

headline: Chase to Raise Some Automated Teller Fees
abstract: Chase to Raise

headline: Compressed Data; Oracle's Chairman Backs On-Line Venture
abstract: Lawrence Ellison, founder of Oracle Corp, has invested few million dollars in start-up company Netledger; Netledger hopes to convert market for accounting software used by small businesses into Web service, for which Netledger would charge monthly base fee; Netledger Web site is powered by Oracle's data base software; Netledger's president, Evan Goldberg, is former Oracle vice president; photo (S)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.P.S. Loses Tax Ruling That Could Cost It Millions  A judge has ruled that United Parcel Service took inflated deductions in 1984 and must pay taxes, penalties and interest that the company said might total nearly $300 million. Its ultimate tax liability could be much larger because the ruling covers only the first year of a practice that has continued ever since.

headline: State Dept. Expert Upbeat About Russian Fund Case
abstract: Deputy State Sec Strobe Talbott, Pres Clinton's top Russia expert, testifies before Senate Foreign Relations Committee on corruption in Russia; gives unusually upbeat assessment of widening investigation into allegations of Russian laundering of billions of dollars through American banks and whether top Administration officials turned blind eye to corruption at highest levels of Russian Government; photo (M)

headline: Oracle Posts Earnings Growth of 21% for Latest Quarter
abstract: Oracle Corp says earnings for first-quarter ended Aug 31 were $236.7 million, 21 percent from $195 million in year-earlier period; revenue rose 13 percent, to $1.98 billion (M)

headline: CONTIFINANCIAL CUTS WORK FORCE AFTER BIG LOSS
abstract: Contifinancial Corp will cut about a third of its work force; also posts huge first-quarter loss and says it is continuing to negotiate with lenders about pending expiration of its bank credit lines (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    THE NETHERLANDS: LEGALIZING EUTHANASIA  A bill legalizing euthanasia and assisted suicide and applying to children over age 12 has been presented to Dutch legislators. The legislation is intended to bring the law in line with medical practices that have existed for some time in the Netherlands, but had previously been confined to terminally ill adults. Passage seems assured since the coalition majority of the Socialist Prime Minister, Wim Kok, holds 97 of 150 seats in Parliament.    (Agence France-Presse)

headline: Beijing Continues Its Campaign Against Sect
abstract: Chinese Government continues its campaign of invective against Falun Gong, newly banned spiritual movement (S)

headline: Nike, Long Wary of E-Marketers, Links With Web Retailer
abstract: Nike Inc enters agreement with Fogdog Sports that will allow Fogdog to sell full Nike line of athletic shoes on its Web site in exchange for warrants to acquire 12 percent of Fogdog's shares; Fogdog, three-year-old company with less than $10 million in annual sales, files for public stock offering; hopes its recoup cost of deal from not only from consumers and but also from investors, who may see deal as indicator of potential of Fogdog's stock; photo (M)

headline: Media Talk; News Media's Eye Turns More to Children
abstract: Study conducted by Prof Dale Kunkel for child advocacy group finds coverage of children has become more of priority at major national newspapers and television news networks; also finds that when children appear in news reports, it is less often as victims or perpetrators of crimes than was case five years ago, and more often in articles related to health, safety and cultural issues; Kunkel found that in 1998, there was 37 percent increase in number of newspaper articles about children and no change in amount of television time devoted to children by major television networks (M)

headline: $1 BILLION DEAL IN SEOUL
abstract: Kokusai Securities Co of Japan signs memorandum of understanding for $1 billion investment in Korea Investment Trust Co, one of largest money managers in South Korea; Nomura Securities of Japan and its affiliates hold 41 percent stake in Kokusai (S)

headline: INVESTING WITH -- Donald W. Hodges; The Hodges Fund
abstract: Investing With column focuses on Donald W Hodges and son, Craig, who manage Hodges Fund; they comment on their investment styles and preferences; photo; graph (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Barak's Headache: New Role for Peres
abstract: Meetings have taken place at the highest levels, including several with Prime Minister Ehud Barak. Memorandums have been drafted and rejected. And despite assurances that a deal is imminent, tensions remain high six weeks after the formation of the new Israeli Government.    The issue is not peace with the Arabs. It is what to do with Shimon Peres.

headline: Technology Helps Shares Make First Advance of Week
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 6.65 points, or 0.06 percent, to 11,002.78; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 2.19, or 0.2 percent, to 1,379.29; Nasdaq composite index climbs 29.59, or 1.1 percent, to 2,761.77; price of benchmark 30-year bond slips 8/32, to 90 31/32; yield rises to 5.90 percent from 5.88 percent; graph on Dow Jones industrial average; charts on stocks with large price percentage gains and losses and US key interest rates (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: International Team Breaks Internet Security Codes  An international team of researchers has demonstrated that it is possible to break the security codes used to protect financial transactions over the Internet.

headline: CALPINE, A POWER PRODUCER, TO ADD COGENERATION
abstract: Calpine Corp, independent power producer, agrees to acquire 80 percent stake in Cogeneration Corp of America for about $145 million (S)

headline: Hong Kong Journal; A Free-Spoken Editor Won't Be Back
abstract: Jonathan Fenby fails to have his contract renewed as editor of South China Morning Post, Hong Kong's leading English-language newspaper; newspaper's sharp criticism of Hong Kong Government may be reason for his ouster; paper is owned by Robert Kuok of Malaysia; photo (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

headline: Pakistan-Backed Force Leaves Indian Kashmir
abstract: Indian officials say withdrawal of Pakistani-backed forces from Indian-controlled area of Kashmir is on schedule to be finished by July 16 deadline; accuse Pakistan of sponsoring guerrilla attack on paramilitary camp near Srinigar on July 13; map (M)

headline: The China Cloud: Is a Bomb Being Waved at Taiwan?
abstract: News analysis of timing of China's disclosure that it has technology to make neutron bomb; sees disclosure aimed at intimidating Taiwan, coming just days after Taiwan says it is dropping its adherence to its longstanding principle that it and Chinese mainland are separately governed parts of same country (M)

headline: Fewer Computer Users Give Microsoft a Positive Rating
abstract: Microsoft continues to get high approval rating from public, but numbers appear to be slipping; latest New York Times/CBS News poll finds 60 percent of people who use computer at work or at home say they have favorable opinion of Microsoft, down from 67 percent year ago and 73 percent two years ago in Gallup poll; Microsoft says that its own market research has found no erosion in its public image and that its favorable ratings have long held steady at 75 percent; Times/CBS poll did find people less convinced than year ago that Government is doing right thing with its major antitrust suit against Microsoft; still, marketing experts say Microsoft should watch for any hint of declining support; charts; graph (M)

headline: Debate on Cause of Moscow Blast Heats Up
abstract: At least 32 people die in deafening explosion that levels much of a nine-story apartment building in Moscow; Mayor Yuri Luzhkov says there 'high degree of confidence' that terrorists staged blast; police clamp new security measures on city (M)

headline: LOUISIANA-PACIFIC TO BUY EVANS FOREST PRODUCTS
abstract: Louisiana-Pacific Corp acquires Evans Forest Products Ltd, Canadian maker of engineered wood and lumber, for $90 million (S)

headline: VODAFONE AIRTOUCH AND BELL ATLANTIC TO SPLIT VENTURE
abstract: Bell Atlantic Corp and Vodafone Airtouch PLC agree to split Primeco Personal Communications LP, their cellular-phone joint venture, dividing up markets (S)

headline: Earthquakes Help Warm Greek-Turkish Relations
abstract: Relations between Greece and Turkey improve with spectacular suddeness in in wake of earthquakes in both countries in last few weeks; each has sent rescue teams to help the other, and gestures have been greeted by waves of ecstatic publicity and popular emotion; although serious political differences remain, both sides are displaying willingness to resolve them that has not been shown for generations; map; photo (M)

headline: Thompson and Dell Settle Dispute
abstract: J Walter Thompson and Dell Computer Corp settle dispute generated by two lawsuits; agency and company say Thompson will pay unspecified sum for work agency had completed on campaign carrying theme 'Be direct' as part of its brief stewardship of Dell account, which has billings estimated at $100 million; Thompson was hired by Dell in June 1998 and dismissed only three months later; it was replaced by BBDO Worldwide; Thompson filed suit against Dell, seeking $6.33 million in damages; Dell countersued, seeking unspecified damages; both suits have been discontinued with settlement (S)

headline: Indonesia Military Sorts Out Its Role
abstract: Indonesia's influential military, its morale and public image battered by country's recent turmoil, is attempting to become more professional and less overtly political, but a small, unified military voting bloc may be in position to determine who will become Indonesia's next president; photo (M)

headline: Goods Ready to Rent, Stocks Ready to Grow
abstract: Article on drop in value of stocks of equipment rental companies, whose bellwether, United Rentals of Greenwich, Conn, has declined by 44.5 percent since July 1998; photo (M)

headline: Creditors Grant Daewoo New Delay and a Brief Loan
abstract: Daewoo's South Korean creditors give nearly insolvent conglomerate another reprieve, deferring repayments on debts owed by 12 of its affiliated businesses for three months and providing $700 million in new short-term loans (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.

headline: Crescent in Accord on Hospital Operator
abstract: Crescent Real Estate Equities Co, head by billionaire Richard Rainwater, says it has reached agreement whereby affiliate, Crescent Operating Inc, will take control of struggling psychiatric hospital operator Charter Behaviorial Health Systems LLC; Crescent Real Estate says Magellan Health Services Inc will transfer 80 percent of its common-stock stake in Charter, which has 80 sites across country, and all of its preferred stake to Crescent affiliate; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Microsoft Acts on Digital Music By Getting Support From Cirrus
abstract: Microsoft Corp is set to announce that newest line of Internet audio chips from Cirrus Logic will support Microsoft's Windows Media audio format; portable digital music players and other devices built with Cirrus chip would be able to play music encoded with Windows Media technology; right to use Microsoft technology is included in price of the chip (M)

headline: In a Time Warp With Pac-Man and Pong
abstract: Classic Games Expo held in Las Vegas, Nev, lets gamers pore over video game consoles of yore; there is still a following for such classics as Intellivision's Backgammon and Baseball, released in 1980, and for Pong from Atari, which first showed up in video arcades in 1972; photos (M)

headline: Flaw Allows Hackers Into E-Mail Accounts
abstract: Microsoft scrambled to close a security breach that left tens of millions of E-mail accounts on Hotmail accessible through Web sites created to exploit the vulnerability. It was not clear how much information might have been compromised.    Business Day, page C1.

headline: New Face, New Sheen at Gallo
abstract: Gina Gallo, third-generation member of famous California wine family and head of E & J Gallo Winery, is aiming to raise Gallo-Sonoma's profile among upscale brands; company has embarked on $4 million print and advertising campaign; Gallo comments; photo (M)

headline: F. M. Thrower, 89, of TV's Yule Log Fame
abstract: Fred M Thrower, former television executive who contributed televised Yule log to New Yorkers' Christmas Eve celebrations, dies at age 89 (S)

headline: Signs of strain between agencies and their customers persist for a second year.
abstract: Survey by Nancy L Salz Consulting shows relations between agencies and advertisers are showing signs of strain for second consecutive year; results of survey, which asked executives at agencies and client companies to assess nature of their dealings with each other, indicate that efforts to narrow gap between them have fallen short, as they did last year; Nancy L Salz comments (Advertising column) (M)

headline: PMC-SIERRA TO PAY $400 MILLION FOR ABRIZIO
abstract: PMC-Sierra Inc, maker of chips that accelerate telecommunications transactions, agrees to buy Abrizio Inc for $400 million in stock (S)

headline: Chevron and Phillips Talks Prompt a Rash of Rumors
abstract: Chevron Corp and Phillips Petroleum Corp have discussed forming joint venture in petrochemical business; merger is not imminent; Sunday Times of London reports Chevron is in talks to buy Phillips in deal that would be worth about $16.5 billion, or $65 a share; companies refuse comment (M)

headline: SAMSUNG CHAIRMAN MAY FACE INQUIRY
abstract: National Tax Service says Lee Kun Hee, chairman of Samsung Group, may face tax probe on charges of illegally handing over wealth to his son; move is latest by South Korean authorities to turn up heat on country's major business conglomerates; Lee photo (S)

headline: NATO Holds 3 Albanians in Killing of 14 Serbs
abstract: NATO police hold three Kosovar Albanians as suspects in murders of 14 Serbian farmers on July 23 in village of Gracko, and NATO sends weapons, ammunition and clothing to Britain for forensic evidence (S)

headline: Spinoff Is Christened With Care by Hewlett
abstract: Hewlett-Packard names its corporate spinoff Agilent Technologies after four months of research into names, and with help of corporate-naming company it hired; photo of Agilent's logo (S)

headline: The Timor Enigma
abstract: News analysis of political turmoil in East Timor; crisis comes against backdrop of broader crisis of leadership in Indonesia, in which central Govt is weak and fragmented as politicians fight over presidential succession and once-powerful military has become hestiant, angry and divided; while it is clear that irregular militias backed by military are carrying out campaign of terror, less clear is what campaign is meant to achieve and what degree of control Govt in Jakarta has over people waging it; photo (M)

headline: Prices on Treasuries Rebound As Fears of Rate Increase Ease
abstract: US Treasury bond prices rebound somewhat from previous day's losses; 30-year benchmark Treasury bond is up 8/32, to price of 100 11/32; yield falls to 6.10 percent from 6.12 percent; graph on Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp participation certificates; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: A Suburb Sees the Future In Its Old Downtown
abstract: Joel Kotkin Grass-Roots Business column describes renovation of downtown Downers Grove, Ill; renovation, like increasing number of other suburbs and small towns, is centered on rehabilitating and refurbishing old stores and historic buildings; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Soybean futures prices fall on July 27 as Midwest rains diminish concerns that hot, dry weather had damaged crop; November delivery fell 26.75 cents to $4.3525 per bushel; graph

headline: Bell Atlantic Dealing On Its Wireless Unit
abstract: Bell Atlantic, the nation's largest local phone company, appears close to an agreement to combine its wireless telephone operations with the United States wireless assets of Vodafone Airtouch P.L.C., the world's largest wireless company. The deal would create an independent joint venture valued at $70 billion to $80 billion that would rank with the largest cellular networks.  Article, page 34.

headline: CROWN GROUP TO EXPAND USED-CAR BUSINESS
abstract: Crown Group Inc plans to expand into Florida by taking over Smart Choice Automotive Group Inc and merging it with Paaco Automotive Group Inc in transaction valued at $52.4 million (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: SPY KNOWN FOR 30 YEARS -- The Government said that for more than 30 years it had evidence of the espionage activities of Melita Norwood, the 87-year-old woman who admitted giving nuclear weapons research documents to the Soviet Union. Home Secretary Jack Straw said M.I.5 decided not to interview her out of fear of jeopardizing other investigations. It decided seven years ago never to prosecute her, he added. Two other people identified as agents in a book based on K.G.B. files were former Labor M.P.'s, Tom Driberg and Raymond Fletcher, both now dead.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: PSINET AGREES TO BUY DATA SERVICE PROVIDER
abstract: Psinet Inc acquires Transaction Network Services Inc for $720 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Technological Pioneering, Past and Present
abstract: Paul Andrews book, How the Web Was Won: Microsoft From Windows to the Web, reviewed by Michael Hafner; photo (S)

headline: Trace International Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: Wall Street investor Marshall S Cogan puts his closely held holding company, Trace International Holdings Inc, into bankruptcy protection (S)

headline: Buy the Book: On-Line Stores Vie for Students
abstract: Appraisal of on-line textbook store, Efollett.com (S)

headline: That time again: A guy from Brooklyn plays 20 questions about Madison Avenue and its clients.
abstract: Stuart Elliott Advertising column humorously asks twenty questions about advertising, marketing and media drives (M)

headline: REVISED DEAL FOR NEWCOURT
abstract: CIT Group Inc, New Jersey, says it had signed new agreement to acquire Newcourt Credit Group Inc, Toronto, through an exchange of shares valued at $1.8 billion, 34 percent lower than the value set in March (S)

headline: Multimedia Transmissions Are Driving Internet Toward Gridlock
abstract: Experts warn streaming media, widely hailed as future of home entertainment, threatens to hog Internet, causing other data traffic to pile up; problem arises because computer sending streaming data will reduce flow only slightly in response to Internet congestion; Cisco Systems Inc chief scientist Van Jacobson notes streaming media providers have no incentive to comply with traffic rules (M)

headline: New Independent Mexican Election Council Veers Off High Road
abstract: Mexico's new independent election council, which presided over 1997 balloting that was most democratic ever, falters, as sober deliberations give way to shrill quarreling among political parties; infighting began last year when several members tried to get council to investigated Pres Ernesto Zedillo's 1994 campaign finances (M)

headline: MILITIAS IN TIMOR MENACE REFUGEES AT U.N. COMPOUND
abstract: Workers and refugees taking shelter at besieged United Nations compound in East Timor are menaced by militias there after most of staff is evacuated; Gen Wiranto, armed forces chief, has resisted international pressure for Indonesia to accept deployment of UN peacekeeping force; he now says UN force may be allowed in future; turbulence in East Timor has begun to shake political position of Pres B J Habibie; reports from Dili, East Timor's capital, describe scene of continuing tension and fear; photo; map (M)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: HOMEGROCER.COM, Seattle, named Mary Alice Taylor chairman and chief executive. She had been executive vice president of global operations and technology for Citigroup Inc., New York.

headline: AOL Options For Browsers
abstract: Q&A column answers question on installing Web browser (S)

headline: Three Indicted In Bank Case; Funds Diverted, U.S. Charges
abstract: Three former executives of the Bankers Trust Corporation were indicted yesterday on Federal criminal charges that they diverted $15.5 million of unclaimed customer money into the bank's own accounts from 1993 to 1996 to lift their department's financial results.    Bruce J. Kingdon, a former Bankers Trust managing director who headed the bank's Client Processing Services division and two subordinates were each charged in United States District Court in Manhattan with one count of conspiracy, 12 counts of misapplication of bank funds and 12 counts of falsifying books and records.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Commercial Internet Deals For College Sites Criticized  More than 500 colleges and universities have made deals with commercial companies to run campus Web sites and electronic mail services. As a result, students who want to check course outlines or send E-mail will become an audience for advertisers.    The move has set off a debate over the intrusion of advertising into the educational part of the Internet. [Page A1.]    Tax Liability Gives U.P.S. a Loss  United Parcel Service revised its second-quarter earnings to reflect a $1.4 billion charge to cover its potential liability from last week's court decision that it had inflated its income tax deductions. As a result, U.P.S. had a net loss of $854 million in the quarter instead of net income of $588 million reported last month. [C2.]    Time Warner Names Music Chief  Time Warner named Roger Ames, the former president of the Polygram Music Group, as chairman and chief executive of the Warner Music Group, which has had management shake-ups and declining market share. [C2.]    David Bohrman, the executive vice president of the financial news network CNNfn, a unit of Time Warner, was dismissed. [C9.]    A $2.5 Billion Deal for Nielsen  VNU, the Dutch publisher, plans to acquire Nielsen Media Research, the largest television audience measuring company in the United States, for $2.5 billion. [C8.]    Venator Group Chief to Step Down  Roger N. Farah said he would step down immediately as chief executive of Venator Group, the former Woolworth. Its president, Dale W. Hilpert, will succeed him. [C5.]    A Shift in France's Bank Battle  The focus of the five-month takeover battle involving three of France's biggest banks shifted to the Government after shareholder votes left none of the three a clear winner. [C4.]    Stocks Rise in Light Trading  Stock prices edged up in sluggish trading. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 73.14 points, to 11,046.79. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 3.09 points, to 1,330.77, and the Nasdaq composite index gained 7.47 points, to 2,645.28. [C9.]    Toys 'R' Us Profit Falls 25%  Toys ''R'' Us said its second-quarter profit had fallen 25 percent, to $12 million, or 5 cents a share, because of costs to develop its Internet division. Shares of Toys ''R'' Us rose 62.5 cents, to $15.8125. The company said sales at its United States stores that have been open at least a year rose 4 percent from the quarter a year earlier. [C20.]    A Breakup Plan for Daewoo Group  In an unusual breakup plan, creditors of South Korea's Daewoo Group will sell six of the heavily indebted company's 25 subsidiaries. [C4.]    Ouster at Waste Management  Waste Management said that it had ousted its No. 2 executive, Rodney R. Proto, and that it would sell some assets. [C20.]

headline: Treasury Schedules Bill Auctions For Financing During the Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three-  and six-month bills and a 52-week bill being auctioned on Tuesday.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 4.61 percent and the rate on the six-month issue was at 4.84 percent. The rate for the 52-week bill was 4.89 percent.

headline: VIVENDI PROFIT RISES 29%
abstract: Vivendi SA says first-half profit rose greater-than-expected 29 percent; company earned 783 million euros ($825 million) (S)

headline: School Long Seen as Despots' Training Center Faces a Cutoff
abstract: House votes to cut off recruitment funds for Army's School of the Americas, long criticized for graduating Latin American military officers who became tyrants and murderers; passes amendment to foreign aid bill that withdraws money for recruiting and transporting foreign officers; those costs run from $1.5 million to $2 million a year; other operations of school, at Fort Benning, Ga, are financed by Pentagon (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Advertising account changes noted (S)

headline: Oil and Stock Prices Up in Europe; Asia Is Higher
abstract: Crude oil prices rise nearly 3 percent, to 19-month high, on continued signs that Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is cutting output; brent crude for Aug delivery rises 52 cents, to $18.18 a barrel; oil-company shares rise; shares in London surge, with Financial Times Stock Exchange index rising 1.54 percent, to 6,592, third-highest closing level; Frankfurt's DAX index rises 1.93 percent, to record 5,625.62; Asian markets are also higher, with big gains in Japan and Hong Kong (M)

headline: New Player From Sony Will Give a Nod to MP3
abstract: As Sony celebrates the 20th anniversary of its Walkman cassette-tape player, company is introducing revolutionary update, device that has no moving parts; called Memory Stick Walkman, device does not use cassette tapes or compact disks or even mini-disks to play recorded music; instead, device stores and plays music on Sony's own data storage medium called Memory Stick, which stores up to 80 minutes of digital-quality music; device photo (M)

headline: Michael Sveda, the Inventor Of Cyclamates, Dies at 87
abstract: Dr Michael Sveda, chemist who invented cyclamates, dies at age of 87; photo (M)

headline: Fighters Customizable for Combat
abstract: Fighter Maker, computer game published by Agetec for Playstation, is combat game featuring range of martial arts; photos (M)

headline: Gaza Dilemma: Boycott or Paycheck
abstract: There are estimated 11,000 Palestinians who work in Jewish settlements in West Bank and Gaza Strip, building houses for Israelis, building the very communities that Palestinian leaders have called a cancer strangling prospects for independent Palestinian state; in recent weeks, Palestinian Authority has mounted campaign to stop laborers from working at settlements, trying to root out phenomenon that has become entrenched over more than 30 years, strengthened by Israeli border restrictions that prevent many workers from reaching jobs in Israel; Palestinian workers who build homes say they have little choice, that they have to earn a living; photo; map (M)

headline: MOTOROLA AGREES TO BUY METROWERKS FOR $95 MILLION
abstract: Motorola Inc agrees to buy Metrowerks Inc for $95 million (S)

headline: Iridium Proposes Bondholders Swap Debt for an Equity Stake
abstract: Iridium PLC, which filed for protection under Chapter 11 of Bankruptcy Code, says it has proposed that group of bondholders swap $1.45 billion of debt for 33 percent stake; company says bondholders have not yet agreed to do so; Iridium's proposal wins approval of its biggest investor, Motorola Inc, which would also have converted its Iridium debt into 12 percent equity stake (M)

headline: E-Commerce Report; On-line merchants find that a well-designed Web site can have a big impact on the bottom line.
abstract: Web-site design is looming as ever-more crucial factor in E-commerce as sites seek profitability by expanding product offerings; International Business Machines Corp's redesign of its own site to make it easier for customers to use noted; photo (M)

headline: Seoul Delays Announcement of a Plan to Revamp Daewoo
abstract: South Korean Government puts off announcement of much-awaited revamping plan for troubled Daewoo Group that had been expected Aug 11; Financial Supervisory Commission says Daewoo and its creditor banks will sign plan to overhaul conglomerate's financial structure on Aug 16 and that no announcement will be made before then; delay apparently reminds investors of delays in other pending deals and sends them scurrying to sell South Korean stocks (M)

headline: Equity Offerings Scheduled for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: GLOBAL ONE CHIEF RESIGNS
abstract: Global One chief executive Gary Forsee says he will resign; Michel Huet, executive vice president, will head interim executive committee while owners decide what to do (S)

headline: Barry Shipp, 62, the Developer Of the Jovan Musk Fragrance
abstract: Barry Shipp, perfume salesman who discovered an aromatic oil being sold in a drug paraphernalia shop and developed it into a multimillion-dollar business called Jovan Musk, dies at age 62 (M)

headline: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY; Economic Catch-Up
abstract: Bureau of Labor Statistics reports that 69.1 percent of female high school graduates received bachelor's degrees between 1982 and present, compared with 62.4 percent of male graduates (S)

headline: U.S. Finds No One to Back Among Milosevic's Foes
abstract: Clinton Administration is finding it difficult to capitalize on opportunity presented by opposition protests bubbling up across Serbia, despite clear desire to see Pres Slobodan Milosevic ousted; question of new leadership in Serbia is as troubling as its is important, not only because Milosevic has been indicted on war crimes charges, but also because without participation of Serbia, it will be hard to build stable Balkans; wait-and-see attitude prevails in Washington, even though Administration has made it clear that it considers Milosevic international outlaw who should be brought to justice (M)

headline: August Huber, 87, Ex-Investment Banker
abstract: August Huber, investment banker and stock market analyst in 1960's and 1970's, dies at age 87 (M)

headline: Microsoft Names New Leaders For Troubled Net Business
abstract: Microsoft Corp, in effort to revive its beleaguered Internet business, names new leadership for its Consumer and Commerce Group, its on-line group; as expected, company names Richard Belluzzo as head of group; also promotes Brad Chase and Jon DeVaan to post of senior vice president (M)

headline: CHILE LIFTS CONTROLS
abstract: Chile's central bank lifts controls on peso for first time in 15 years; decision, viewed as more technicality than substantial policy shift, is accompanied by weakening of peso to record low of 522.30 to the dollar before slight rebound (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen rises against US dollar on expectations that Japan will get little help from other industrial nations in arresting currency's recent surge; dollar falls to 103.95 yen from 104.17 in New York (S)

headline: Many Latin Stocks Leave Home, Trading on Wall Street
abstract: Many Latin American stock brokers are moving their trading from region to New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq because declining volume and high transaction costs have sapped much of activity on local stock markets; since Brazil's Government imposed tax on financial transactions in June, volume on Sao Paulo Stock Exchange, Latin America's largest market, has dropped by a third; with many banks and brokerage firms opting to trade in international centers like New York and London, Sao Paulo market has become victim of trend that has spread through Latin America in 1990's; graph (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 184.26 points to 10,973.65; Nasdaq composite index gains 88.32, to 2,637.81; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 29.52, to 1,327.68; graph (M)

headline: Halifax Journal; Canada Celebrates Immigrants, but Which Ones?
abstract: Canada celebrates its 132d birthday, when Queen Victoria declared a nation of four individual Canadian colonies, with opening of Pier 21 National Historic Site; Pier 21 is Canada's Ellis Island, last surviving immigration shed in Canada; it is here that more than million immigrants, refugees and World War II war brides and displaced people first set foot in North America; many of these people settled in Canada and so changed country that today the history of 20 percent of all 30 million Canadians can be traced to this spot; photo of 160 war brides arriving by ship in Halifax for opening of Pier 21 National Historic Site (M)

headline: South Africa Confronts Brutalities Of One Man
abstract: Grisly details of more than 100 instances of torture and killings by Eugene de Kock, South Africa's most notorious apartheid-era henchman, are contained in amnesty application pending before Truth and Reconciliation Commission; many South Africans believe de Kock has still not told entire truth and may be holding back details in effort to make himself look more like soldier than monster, even though confession runs for more than 4,000 pages and is by far largest ever received by commission; de Kock, who headed counterterrorism unit from 1985 to 1993, is serving two life terms plus 212 years for range of charges; has written book on his life, lashing out at generals who he says abandoned him after he finished their dirty work (M)

headline: AMRESCO CAPITAL TRUST AGREES TO BUY IMPAC COMMERCIAL
abstract: Amresco Capital Trust to buy Impac Commercial Holdings Inc, Dallas, for about $55.5 million in stock (S)

headline: CLINTON TO PRESS SYRIAN TO REOPEN TALKS WITH ISRAEL
abstract: President Clinton pledged today that he would get in touch with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria to emphasize that a ''golden opportunity'' lay before him to complete a peace deal with Israel. Mr. Clinton spoke as he and Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel ended a series of meetings.    From their joint announcement at a news conference of plans to increase military assistance to Israel, to a plan to include Israeli astronauts on a NASA shuttle journey next year, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Barak appeared eager to show that the nations' relationship had been reinvigorated. [Excerpts, page A8.]

headline: A Reign Of Terror
abstract: Michelle Cottle Working column offers advice on how to workers in nonprofit organization can deal with director who is controlling and has poor management skills (M)

headline: TYCO INTERNATIONAL SHEDS SOME NONVALVE BUSINESSES
abstract: Tyco International Ltd sells some nonvalve portions of its flow-control business for undisclosed price to company formed by DLJ Merchant Banking Partners II LP, merchant banking fund of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc; businesses sold include Mueller Co and Grinnell Supply Sales and Manufacturing units (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: World Wrestling Federation Plans an Initial Offering  World Wrestling Federation Entertainment, the company that promotes and stages the most popular wrestling events, including Wrestlemania, plans to raise up to $175 million by selling a minority stake in the company in an initial public offering.    The company, which produces television shows like ''W.W.F. Smackdown,'' has cashed in on the public's taste for increasingly outrageous competitions. Wrestling dominates the rankings of cable television shows, and those high ratings have produced stellar financial results. Market Place. [Page A1.]

headline: Ford Motor Shifts Work to WPP Unit
abstract: Ford Motor Co consolidates Ford brand's South American account with J Walter Thompson, awarding duties in Brazil to J Walter Thompson Publicidade Ltda; account had been handled by Young & Rubicam Brazil (S)

headline: TV Proves Most Potent Campaign Tool in Mexico
abstract: Television campaign commercials are rattling Mexico's political system in advance of first-ever presidential primaries; have given Roberto Madrazo Pintado, former governor of backwater state, edge in race for governing party's nomination; ruling party is letting opposition parties buy air time for first time as part of broader move toward competitive politics and loosening of political system; shift cuts power of newspapers and Government-influenced television news shows and of traditional power brokers like labor and peasant bosses; photos (M)

headline: In Child Custody, Germany Is Tough on the French
abstract: France and Germany are in dispute over preference given by German courts to German parent in almost all contested child custody cases involving other nationals; photo (M)

headline: E.D.S. PLANS TO REPURCHASE UP TO 27 MILLION SHARES
abstract: Electronic Data Systems Corp to buy back up to 27 million shares, or 5.5 percent of its shares outstanding, and earmark them for stock options that employees will not exercise for at least five more years (S)

headline: IRELAND EMPLOYMENT BOOMS
abstract: Ireland's unemployment rate is 5.8 percent; number of unemployed is 95,100, first time in 20 years figure is below 100,000 (S)

headline: Which Way the Fed? Sorting Out the Signals on Interest Rates
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer Portfolio's, Etc column on implications for stock market of Federal Reserve's switch from bias toward higher interest rates to neutral stance; notes shift is likely temporary and questions why Fed spoke up about it, knowing it would spur investor enthusiasm (M)

headline: Four Agencies Make Acquisitions
abstract: Earle Palmer Brown Cos acquires Ketchum Advertising from Omnicom Group; will rename it Egan/St James; Healthworld Corp acquires Falk Communications for $15.5 million in stock and cash plus future considerations; Euro RSCG Worldwide acquires major stake in Field Force; Foote, Cone & Belding Worldwide acquires McElroy Communications and renames it McElroy FCB (M)

headline: Workers' Free Wine Ends, But South Africans Still Pay
abstract: Alcohol abuse among South Africa's farm laborers and vineyard workers continues to be a problem; under system started centuries ago, workers were given free wine to addict them to alcohol, keeping them working for virtually nothing; system has been illegal for decades and is now publicly repudidated by wine industry, which is very conscious of its image and of past mistakes; some surveys suggest that 20 percent of farms in Western Cape Province still use system; but experts say that end of old system is ushering in new set of hardships, and new research shows an alarming rate of fetal alcohol syndrome in workers' children; photos; maps (L)

headline: LIBRARY/MUSIC ENCYCLOPEDIA; A Century of Pickin' and Riffs on CD-ROM
abstract: Bruce Feiler appraises Country.com's Century of Country CD-ROM, with 26 albums of country music listed in anthology; photos (M)

headline: East Timorese Vote /Militias Interfere With a Cash Crop : Coffee Industry Embroiled in a Tug of War
abstract: ESTADO, East Timor—  Beneath the shade of the forest, the steep hillsides are quilted with the dark green leaves of the coffee trees. Mist curls through the canopies, and a fine rain soaks the undergrowth.

headline: The Mouse and Methuselah
abstract: Disney's Michael Eisner apologizes to Viacom's Sumner Redstone, 76, for making disparaging remark about his age in August 18 article; photo (S)

headline: Treasury to Sell Bills and Notes This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's auction of three-  and six-month bills and a 10-year inflation-index note tomorrow.     By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.53 percent, and that on a six-month bill was 4.77 percent. The current issue 10-year inflation-index note was trading at a price to yield 3.97 percent.

headline: LEAP WIRELESS IS IN 2 DEALS FOR EQUIPMENT AND SERVICES
abstract: Leap Wireless International shares rise as much as 38 percent after company says it will buy $660 million in wireless equipment and services from Lucent Technologies Inc and Ericsson AB; Leap Wireless says it will pay phone equipment makers $330 million each for gear to expand its Cricket Communications wireless service, which provides local phone service at flat rates in Tennessee (S)

headline: Gray Eminence Compels Respect and Even Fear
abstract: Profile of Vladimir V Putin, 46, chief of Russia's domestic intelligence service and newly nominated Prime Minister; he is now Boris N Yeltsin's choice to succeed him as President (M)
