headline: Labor Goes to Capitalism's Citadel, and the Sky Doesn't Fall
abstract: AFL-CIO president John J Sweeney, head of movement that has often been nemesis of business--the labor movement, rings opening bell at New York Stock Exchange; idea of inviting Sweeney came from exchange's chairman Richard A Grasso (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of advertising account changes (S)

headline: Scoop on an Owner's Deal Raises Issue of Favoritism
abstract: Article in first issue of Daily Deal, American Lawyer Media Inc's new journal for mergers and acquisitions, broke news that Voicestream Wireless Corp was 'in the midst of negotiating a new acquisition'; it added that 'analysts agree that Aerial Communications is likeliest candidate'; what piece did not say was that American Lawyer Media is owned by Bruce Wasserstein's investment banking firm, Wasserstein Perella & Co, and that investment banker for group of Aerial's independent directors is same Wasserstein Perella & Co; article raises issue of what happens when corporate boss is in position to leak information about about coming deal to its news subsidiary; Wasserstein and Daily Deal editor in chief Robert Teitelman deny that happened in this instance (M)

headline: A New Agency Opens in Oregon
abstract: Direct marketing executive Tim O'Leary opens Respond2 Inc in Portland, Ore; advertising agency will focus on television and Internet (S)

headline: Sega Is Giving New Product Special Push
abstract: Sega Enterprises will offer its new Dreamcast video game console for rental at 1,000 Hollywood Video stores before it goes on sale in September; hopes unusual pump-priming marketing experiment, in which new machines will be available for rent before they go on sale, will whet potential buyers' appetite for machines; has been losing money and is in midst of overhaul that includes eliminating 1,000 jobs, about quarter of its work force; Dreamcast system has had weak sales in Japan, where it has been available for last year; photo (M)

headline: Worse Odds Than Roulette: Buying Trump Casino Stock
abstract: Article on rapid decline of stock of Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts, which has fallen about 85 percent from its peak amid worries that Donald Trump runs company as if there were no public shareholders; says share price, now at $4.44, is not climbing even though casinos' financial results are improving; graph (M)

headline: Sounding Off on eOne
abstract: Letter from William J Cooper calls for decrease in Internet access charges

headline: In E-Mail, Many Ways to Say Goodbye
abstract: Proper way to say good-bye in electronic mail is still under construction; informal survey finds variety of ways people are signing off; photos (M)

headline: Its Sales Up 15%, Wal-Mart Posts Profit of $1.25 Billion
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores Inc says its second-quarter sales rose 15 percent as its profit rose 21 percent; net income increased to $1.25 billion from $1.03 billion a year ago (M)

headline: Graft Cases Remind South Koreans of Bad Old Days
abstract: Corruption has long been something of a national pastime in South Korea. With few laws and little Government effort to prosecute offenders, many Koreans have come to regard bribes, payoffs and kickbacks as part of political life.    But that was all supposed to change with the election of Kim Dae Jung as President in December 1997. Mr. Kim, a former political dissident, campaigned on a platform of stamping out corruption and reforming South Korea's faltering economy.

headline: I'll Take a Double Latte And a Personal Loan
abstract: South Umpqua Bank chief executive Raymond P Davis comments on laid-back attitude he hopes to instill in customers at bank's 15 branches; amenities include coffee, sofas and chairs, background music, magazines, big-screen TV and computer terminals for trading stocks over Internet (S)

headline: Disney Promotes Executive
abstract: Walt Disney Co names Sanford Litvack as vice chairman, title he will share with Roy Disney (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CMS ENERGY CORP., Dearborn, Mich., owner and operator of energy operations worldwide, agreed to buy a 77 percent stake in Grupo Companhia Paulista de Energia Electrica, Sao Paolo, a group of power companies in southern Brazil, for $85 million in cash.    INTERNATIONAL MULTIFOODS CORP, Wayzata, Minn., the No. 1 American distributor of food for vending machines, agreed to buy the closely held Better Brands Inc., Windsor, Conn., for about $26 million.

headline: OCEAN GROUP OF BRITAIN MAKES OFFER FOR MARK VII
abstract: Ocean Group PLC, one of Britain's largest freight transport companies, makes $227 million bid to acquire Mark VII Inc (S)

headline: H & R BLOCK ACQUIRES A FRANCHISE THAT OWNS 90 OFFICES
abstract: H&R Block Inc, nation's largest tax preparer, buys one of its largest franchises, adding 90 offices in North and South Carolina to number of sites it owns; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Debasing the Medium
abstract: Letter from Robert Yesselman expresses dismay about new computer game that turns golf balls into grenades

headline: FIFTH THIRD BANCORP OF OHIO ACQUIRES A BANK IN INDIANA
abstract: Fifth Third Bancorp of Ohio agrees to buy Peoples Bank Corp of Indianapolis for $228 million in stock (S)

headline: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; One Envelope, One Vote
abstract: Edward C Stephens My Money, My Life column explains why he finds it easier to complete proxy statements sent by mail than vote via Internet (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: *US dollar edges up against Japanese yen and euro; dollar rises to 104.17 yen from 103.95 in New York; graph; chart (S)

headline: $150 MILLION JET ORDER
abstract: Venezuelan Air Force will acquire eight fighter jets from Brazil's Embraer SA in contract worth $150 million (S)

headline: Panel Urges Stepped-Up Attention to Ties With North Korea
abstract: Presidential advisory panel led by former Defense SecWilliam J Perry has urged Pres Clinton to significantly step up diplomatic and trade ties with North Korea in bid to end North Korean efforts to develop nuclear arms; officials say Clinton has tentatively accepted findings; panel also recommended United States maintain its troop strength in South Korea and remain vigilant to new provocations (M)

headline: Talk and Point: Interactive Map Is Learning to Show the Way
abstract: Pennsylvania State University computer science and engineering department researcher are working on computerized map that can respond to tourists' spoken questions and to their hand gestures; prototype consists of two computers that communicate, respectively, with cordless microphone and video camera to respond to person standing in front of map; photo (M)

headline: Create Your Own 3-D Computer Body Image
abstract: New technology allows people to create realistic three-dimensional computer images of themselves in digital photo booth; representations, called avatars, can be used as more lifelike digital personas in Internet chat rooms or in networked computer games; photo (S)

headline: She Knows Species Like Family Members
abstract: Biographical profile of Lu Zhi, environmentalist with World Wide Fund for Nature and leading light in China's nascent conservation movement who may know more than anyone about giant pandas; photo (M)

headline: Toys 'R' Us Loses Another Top Executive
abstract: Toys 'R' US Inc, in continuation of turmoil at company in disarray, says chief executive Robert C Nakasone has resigned effective immediately; Nakasone will be temporarily replaced by his predecessor, Michael Goldstein, who is chairman and stepped down as chief executive in February 1998; Goldstein comments; photo (M)

headline: China Seizes Taiwan Ship, Accusing Crew
abstract: Chinese authorities seize Taiwan freighter near Taiwan military post on Matsu, accusing crew of trying to smuggle goods into China; Taiwan officials deny allegations; incident provokes concern that China may have acted improperly, using ship as pretext to aggravate already strained situation; maps; photo (M)

headline: Windows Registry Tip: Look, but Don't Touch
abstract: Q. -- I have heard a lot about the Microsoft Windows registry. What is a registry and what is it used for?    A. -- The registry is a vast and detailed database of information that Windows uses to keep track of your system's settings and configuration information. Each time you add a hardware device like a modem or scanner, install new programs or adjust your system's settings, new data are added to the registry file. This file is so important to your computer's health that Windows will not run properly (if at all) if the registry is damaged or corrupted.

headline: Deadly Yachting Regatta Spurs A Race to Be First in Bookstores
abstract: The crowded race to publish books about the disastrous Sydney-Hobart yacht competition of 1998 has all the critical elements of calamity adventure -- except, of course, multiple deaths.    There are the four fiercely competitive authors: an underfinanced Montana fly-fisherman with a scrappy David-vs.-Goliath attitude; a seasoned Australian journalist and former weatherman with ocean racing experience; a secretive reporter for The Wall Street Journal on leave to write a book, and a rugged Southern Californian with a zest for kayaking and climbing on the international endurance-sport circuit.

headline: KOREAN STOCKS RALLY
abstract: Korea's benchmark Kospi stock index stages biggest rally this month, surging 39.19 points, or 4.5 percent, to 917.58, after Moody's Investors Service says it might raise nation's credit rating, surprising investors who were focused on breakup of debt-laden conglomerate Daewoo (S)

headline: Seoul and Tokyo, United by Common Interests, Are Drawing Closer as Anger Fades
abstract: Governments of South Korea and Japan are drawing dramatically closer, bringing new spirit of reconciliation to one of Asia's most bitter relationships; countries are being driven together by variety of factors, including common threat from North Korea, shared economic interests, and approach of jointly organized World Cup soccer tournament; first major step toward rapprochement occurred last fall with Pres Kim Dae Jung's visit to Japan, and most recently with joint naval drill held last month at halfway point between the two countries in Sea of Japan; Emperor Akihito is scheduled to make historic visit to South Korea next year; map (M)

headline: Neuberger Fund Firm Again Considers Selling Shares to the Public
abstract: Neuberger Berman LLC, private investment partnership which decided in October 1998 against going public, reportedly is considering giving initial public offering second try (M)

headline: FDX PLANS TO BUY BACK UP TO 15 MILLION SHARES
abstract: FDX Corp will repurchase up to 15 million of its shares, or about 5 percent of those outstanding (S)

headline: Nasdaq Slides As Technology And Internet Selloff Continues
abstract: Sharp rise in long-term rates batters Internet and technology stocks again, pushing Nasdaq composite index down for seventh time in eight sessions; Nasdaq index falls 28.99 points, or 1.1 percent, to 2,518.98; Nasdaq is off 12 percent from its peak on July 16; Street.com's Internet index falls 18.36 points, or 2.7 percent, to 480.03; Dow Jones industrial average drops 6.33 points, to 10,707.70; graph; chart (M)

headline: Yeltsin Derides His Military For Dagestan 'Carelessness'
abstract: Pres Boris Yeltsin derides Russian military's handling of Islamic rebellion in Dagestan as inexcusably careless, joining chorus of critics who say nation's commanders appear to have learned nothing from humiliating defeat by rebels in Chechnya three years ago (M)

headline: Rwandans and Ugandans Meet on Congo
abstract: Rwandan leaders travel to Uganda for talks to ease tensions after troops from both nations, formerly firm allies, fight for third day in Congolese city of Kisangani; outcome of discussions remains unclear; Ugandan spokesman is optimistic problems can be worked out, citing close friendships between governments in past, but seems to suggest that Uganda is willing to end cooperation with Rwanda in Congo if some agreement is not reached; both have soldiers stationed in Congo as part of mutual support for rebels fighting to overthrow Pres Laurent Kabila; map (M)

headline: Taking Internet Music To the Living Room
abstract: Netdrives develops compact disk player for home stereo systems that can play traditional CD's and disks recorded in MP3 file compression format that is popular among Internet music aficionados; this is first consumer MP3 player that does not need to be connected to personal computer; photo (M)

headline: SALES FORCE TO BE REALIGNED AGAIN THIS YEAR
abstract: Xerox Corp will realign its sales force for second time in a year; plans to divide force into six groups from four recreated in revamping in January; no job cuts are planned (S)

headline: Brazil, in a Rift With Argentina, Suspends Commercial Talks
abstract: Brazil halts all commercial negotiations with Argentina following clashes in series of trade disputes; move follows Argentina's decision to review imports for evidence of unfair trading practices and possibly to impose restrictions in some areas; Brazil calls for meeting with Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay, members of Mercosur regional trade zone, to discuss bloc's future (M)

headline: Takeover Bid Is Canceled
abstract: Enna Corp withdraws $182.6 million bid for Racing Champions Corp (S)

headline: Business Best Sellers
abstract: HARDCOVER  This Month: Last Month    1: 2: THE LEXUS AND THE OLIVE TREE by Thomas L. Friedman (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.50). A columnist and former correspondent for The Times explains the electronic global economy.  2+: 4: BUSINESS @ THE SPEED OF THOUGHT by Bill Gates with Collins Hemingway (Warner, $30). The chairman of Microsoft discusses how new technology is changing the ways business is done.  3+: 7: WHO MOVED MY CHEESE? by Spencer Johnson (Putnam, $19.95). Techniques for dealing with change in the workplace.  4+: 3: THE COURAGE TO BE RICH by Suze Orman (Riverhead, $24.95). How to create a life of material and spiritual abundance.  5+: 11: FIRST, BREAK ALL THE RULES: What The World's Greatest Managers Do Differently by Marcus Buckingham and Curt Coffman (Simon & Schuster, $25). Based on 80,000 interviews.  6*+: 1: LIFE STRATEGIES by Phillip C. McGraw (Hyperion, $21.95). How to define and achieve goals in life and work.  7: 6: HOME TOWN by Tracy Kidder (Random House, $25.95). A study of socioeconomic changes in Northampton, Mass.  8+: 5: THE NINE STEPS TO FINANCIAL FREEDOM by Suze Orman (Crown, $23). Ways to manage your money now and in the future.  9*+: --: LIVING THE SEVEN HABITS by Stephen R. Covey (Simon & Schuster, $26). Inspirational tales from people who have turned their lives and businesses around.  10: 9: SEUSS-ISMS FOR SUCCESS by Dr. Seuss (Random House, $6.99). Corporate wisdom culled from the writings of Dr. Seuss.    PAPERBACK    1+: 1: THE MILLIONAIRE NEXT DOOR by Thomas J. Stanley and William D. Danko (Pocket, $14). A look at wealthy Americans.  2: --: ORGANIZING FROM THE INSIDE OUT by Julie Morgenstern (Owl, $14). How to prioritize your workload and transform office space from a disaster zone to a disciplined environment.  3: --: PHILISTINES AT THE HEDGEROW by Steven Gaines (Back Bay, $14.95). How business tycoons and Hollywood hotshots helped shape the social fabric and property values of the Hamptons, the elite oceanfront enclave.  4: 2: EMOTIONAL INTELLIGENCE by Daniel Goleman (Bantam, $13.95). Factors other than I.Q. that contribute to success.  5*+: 3: A CIVIL ACTION by Jonathan Harr (Vintage, $13). A lawsuit brought by Massachusetts homeowners against industrial polluters.    Rankings are based on June figures of almost 4,000 bookstores and of wholesalers serving 50,000 hardcover retailers and 60,000 paperback retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets). The numbers are statistically weighted to represent sales in all such outlets nationwide. *Indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. +Some bookstores report receiving bulk orders on these titles.

headline: After a redesign and editorial changes, Rodale Press promotes a new New Woman magazine.
abstract: Rodale Press is hoping redesign, backed by multimillion-dollar advertising and circulation campaign, will revitalize New Woman magazine; Rodale will introduce redesigned version with September issue; is spending $750,000 on direct mail campaign, created in-house, that will begin next month; it is spending $3 million more on three-month national newsstand sales drive; also has hired Ziccardi & Partners Inc to create $1 million trade advertising campaign (Advertising column) (M)

headline: PHILIPS INVESTS IN KOREA
abstract: Royal Philips Electronics, in what may be biggest foreign investment in South Korea, invests $1.6 billion in joint venture with LG Group's liquid-crystal-display unit (S)

headline: Quiet Bank Swept Up In a Furor
abstract: Bank of New York, with assets of about $67 billion, is 17th largest bank in US and one of oldest; it is conservative, well-regarded institution, not company typically found at center of financial scandals (M)

headline: Plot Report in Israel and Arrests in Jordan Renew Fear of Hamas
abstract: Political and security threat posed by militant Islamic movement Hamas gets renewed attention when Israeli officials charge that two bombs that exploded prematurely in Sept had been intended for passenger bus; Jordan arrests Hamas leaders Khaled Meshal, Ibrahim Ghoshen and Musa Abu Marzook at Amman airport (M)

headline: Provantage Stock Offering
abstract: Provantage Health Services Inc closes 18 percent above its offering price on its first day of trading; company sells 5.6 million shares, or 31 percent stake, at $18 each; stock closes at $21.1875, giving it market value of $384.6 million (S)

headline: You've Got Romance! Seeking Love on Line
abstract: Growing numbers of single people are using Internet to search for love; more than 2,500 Web sites for adults are now devoted to matchmaking; it has been boon for busy professionals; services use software to sort and match preferences of sort commonly expressed in newpaper personal ads, except size of dating pool is far greater than any newspaper could offer; photos of several married couples who met on Internet; photos (M)

headline: SEARLE VENTURE IN MOSCOW
abstract: Searle Pharmaceutical unit of Monsanto opens $30 million manufacturing center in suburban Moscow, part of joint venture with Biopreparat, a Russian concern; plant will initially make low-cost generic drugs rather than more expensive brand-name medicines developed by Searle (S)

headline: Disney Said to Be Selling Fairchild Publications
abstract: Walt Disney Co has decided to sell Fairchild Publications, magazine division that includes W, Women's Wear Daily, Los Angeles and Jane magazines as well as many trade publications; Conde Nast Publications and Hearst Magazines are reportedly bidding for unit; Conde Nast chairman S I Newhouse Jr has offered $650 million; Disney has wrestled with issue of whether to sell Fairchild since 1995, when Disney acquired Capital Cities/ABC, then longtime parent company of Fairchild Publications; Disney has been under pressure recently from Wall Street to sell nonstrategic assets and revive its core business; Los Angeles Times reports Disney is said to be considering sale of its Anaheim Angels baseball team and its Anaheim Mighty Ducks hockey team (M)

headline: Pullout From Panama and Venezuelan Reluctance Leave Gap in U.S. Air War on Drugs
abstract: Withdrawal of United States from Howard Air Base in Panama, combined with refusal of Venezuela's new Governement to let its airspace be used for US surveillance and pursuit flights, has created huge gap in regional drug interdiction that trafficking cartels are exploiting; map (M)

headline: Wall Street's Latest Media Whiz; As Tabloid Owner, CBS Adviser Has Practical Experience
abstract: Evercore Partners, boutique investment firm that served as principal adviser to CBS Corp in its $37.3 billion merger with Viacom Inc, has become important adviser and player in mergers and acquisitions involving media companies in last few years; Evercore's founder, Roger C Altman, is former Deputy Treasury Secretary in Clinton Administration; he has been involved in half-dozen transactions for CBS, and also for NBC, Court TV, Tele-Communications, Time Warner and American Media; photos; chart; Altman resume (M)

headline: Boeing Banks on Low Costs
abstract: Article explores possibility that Boeing's X-32 Joint Strike Fighter project may gain edge over Lockheed version; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Forecast for Brazil's coffee regions shows increased likelihood of rain next week, which could bolster production; in New York, coffee for December delivery settles down 1.8 cents, to 92.3 cents a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Japanese Chemical Maker to Plead Guilty
abstract: Nippon Gohsei, Japanese chemical maker, agrees to plead guilty and pay $21 million US criminal fine for taking part in 17-year conspiracy to fix prices for food preservatives; fine is third of its kind to come out of US Justice Department probe of $200 million worldwide market for sorbates (S)

headline: NOMURA TRADING SUSPENSION
abstract: Japan bans Nomura Securities Co from trading stock on its own account and from participating in Government bond auctions for one week, beginning Aug 6, for role in 1995 manipulation of stock prices (S)

headline: Shock and Sorrow in the Aftermath of Timor's Violence
abstract: Countless people in towns around East Timor are victims of rampage by violent men who burned thousands of homes and kidnapped tens of thousands of people in mass deportation of one-fourth of population; international peacekeeping forces have arrived, and in Dili, mood has shifted from one of terror to one of anxiety and pain of personal traumas; refugees walk back to their old neighborhoods to see whether their homes are still standing and whether it is safe to return to live in them; photo (M)

headline: Team Finds NATO Bombing Left Few Environment Woes
abstract: United Nations environmental team finds no evidence of major ecological woes in Yugoslavia stemming from NATO bombing; Pekka Haavisto, team head, urges West to provide immediate aid to help clean up 'hot spots' of war-related pollution, news conference; cites damage in heavily bombed industrial towns like Pancevo, Kragujevac and Bor (M)

headline: Dell Options Trading To Shift to Chicago
abstract: Chicago Board Options Exchange says it will list options on Dell Computer Corp, most active option on US markets, starting on Aug 23; Dell's options now trade exclusively on Philadelphia Stock Exchange, where some 8.7 million Dell contracts traded through end of July (S)

headline: JIM McDERMOTT, Co-founder, Stamps.com
abstract: Jim McDermott, Stamps.com co-founder, cites his favorite places to shop on Internet; photo; drawing (S)

headline: Colombia Is Reeling, Hurt by Rebels and Economy
abstract: Colombian Government announces postponement of start of formal peace negotiations with Marxist guerrilla group when sides disagree on role of international observers; a rapidly deteriorating political and economic situation has weakened Pres Andres Pastrana's hand, undermining prospects for peace and emboldening the rebels; thanks to huge profits from drug trade and kidnappings, country's two main guerrilla groups, as well as right-wing paramilitary death squads that combat them, are better armed than ever, and control nearly half territory of country larger than Texas; photo (M)

headline: CORT BUSINESS SERVICES ACCEPTS HIGHER OFFER
abstract: Cort Business Services Corp, after already agreeing to buyout offer from management-led group, accepts higher bid of $376 million from the group after big shareholder criticizes price (S)

headline: U.S. Colonel's Wife Named In Bogota Drug Smuggling
abstract: Laurie Anne Hiett, whose husband, Col James C Hiett, heads United States military operations in Colombia, is charged with shipping 15.8 pounds of pure cocaine to New York City from American Embassy in Bogota; probe by NY police, US Customs agents and Army found no evidence of involvement by Col Hiett, who stepped down voluntarily last week; Ms Hiett says she mailed packages for husband's driver and did not know contents; driver, Jorge Alfonso Ayala is also charged and is being sought in Colombia; Timla Arcila is charged with receiving packages (M)

headline: HUTCHISON PLANS SALES
abstract: Hutchison Whampoa Ltd, flagship of Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing, plans to sell off more units to increase value to shareholders, including stakes in Partner Communications Co and Husky Oil Ltd; photo (S)

headline: Tickle Funny Bones, and Sell More Burger King Whoppers?
abstract: Burger King is adopting new advertising strategy with humorous spots that poke fun at lengths to which hamburger chain will go to satisfy customers; drive is part of comprehensive strategy to enhance brand image that includes new corporate logo and product packaging, restaurant renovations and even some tweaking to cooking system; table of Burger King's advertising agencies and campaigns over years; photos (M)

headline: Qwest's Game Of Aggressive Phone Tag
abstract: Article on Qwest's aggressive, hostile takeover bid for U S West Inc and Frontier Corp in direct competition with Global Crossing; action by principals involved, which has concluded with announcement that U S West and Qwest will merge, detailed; photos; charts; chronology (L)

headline: North Carolina Radio Sale
abstract: Cumulus Media Inc acquires six North Carolina radio stations--two in Wilmington and four in Fayetteville--from Cape Fear Companies for $47 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: MOTOROLA HIRING 2,000 WORKERS FOR CELL PHONE DIVISION
abstract: Motorola Inc to hire some 2,000 people in its digital cellular phone division to meet increasing demand for its products; will add jobs in next six months at Harvard, Ill, plant (S)

headline: NEWS WATCH
abstract: Brabus, German auto company, is marketing Megacar, fully wired automobile that comes with wireless connection, Intel Pentium III chip, Windows NT and 17-inch monitor for teleconferencing (S)

headline: Holbrooke's Long Wait Appears to Be Over
abstract: Way is cleared for Richard C Holbrooke to win Senate confirmation as US delegate to United Nations as Sen Charles E Grassley releases final 'hold' preventing vote; photo (M)

headline: Searching For Less, Not More
abstract: Peter H Lewis (State of the Art) column evaluates next generation of faster Web search engines, including Gurunet (www.gurunet.com), which he calls remarkable but still unfinished instant information utility, and Google (www.google.com), which he describes as very fast and which uses clever intuitive techniques to rank search results by relevancy (M)

headline: ST. JUDE'S STOCK FALLS AFTER ACQUISITION REPORT
abstract: Shares of St Jude Medical Inc fall as much as 20 percent after it says it will acquire Vascular Science Inc for about $100 million (S)

headline: Star-Struck Girls and Mexican School for Scandal
abstract: Mexico is rocked by sex scandal involving pop star Gloria Trevi and manager, Sergio Andrade; they are accused by Miguel and Teresa Yapor of luring away their 12-year-old daughter, Karina, and sexually abusing her during the past few years in their care as aspiring starlet; several other young women have emerged with similar accusations; photos (M)

headline: Treasury Prices Fall on Stronger-Than-Expected Retail Sales
abstract: Price of 30-year US Government bond falls 31/32, to 100 3/32, as yield climbs to 6.12 percent from 6.05 percent; graph on yields of selected Treasury securities; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: AT&T and British Telecom to Buy Canada Mobile Phone Stake
abstract: AT&T and British Telecommunications PLC announce they will invest almost $1 billion in mobile phone company, Rogers Cantel, controlled by Rogers Communications of Toronto, creating framework for cable and phone communications network to compete with domestic giant Bell Canada; Rogers Communications owns Canada's largest cable television and mobile phone companies (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Little-Known Stocks Gain On Usually Reliable Ones  For most of the 1990's, individual investors have gotten rich in the stock market by sticking to a couple of relatively simple strategies: buying big-name companies whose products they know or use and piling into stocks that have already been big winners.    But these strategies appear to be losing steam. Some of the stocks that have been the hottest -- companies as diverse as America Online, Pfizer, Yahoo, Gillette and Dell Computer -- are down considerably from their highs of earlier this year. Many of these stocks have been outrun by companies few investors have ever heard of. Market Place. [Page A1.]

headline: Unselling the Cigarette
abstract: Advertising agencies that previously vied for tobacco accounts discover new lucrative field--what could be called the unselling of smoking; stepped-up efforts to fight smoking include state-sponsored campaigns to dissuade youngsters from taking up habit, coming national anti-smoking initiative to be funded by recent settlement between 46 state attorneys general and tobacco industry, ads for drugs meant to help smokers stop, and even handful of anti-smoking campaigns aimed at young people by tobacco marketers like Philip Morris Cos; photos; graph (M)

headline: PROCTER & GAMBLE IS BUYING MAKER OF WATER FILTERS
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co agrees to acquire Recovery Engineering Inc, maker of PUR drinking-water filter systems, for about $213 million (S)

headline: Freelancers Win Appeal in Copyright Suit
abstract: US Appeals Court rules that three major publishers, including The New York Times Co, cannot include work of freelance contributors in electronic data bases without their permission; unanimous ruling overturns lower court finding that agreed with arguments of New York Times, Newsday and Time Inc Magazine Co and their co-plaintiffs, University Microfilms International and Mead Data Central Corp, former owner of Lexis-Nexis data bases; publishers argued that electronic data bases like Nexis are analogous to anthologies or other 'collective works' that can be revised without permission of individual copyright holders; appeals panel says 'the privilege afforded authors of collective works' under existing law 'does not permit the publishers to license individually copyright works for inclusion in electronic data bases'; ruling comes as on-line publishing is exploding and many publications expand and rely on freelance contributors to supplement work of their regular staff; it could force companies to offer retroactive electronic-rights payments for opinion pieces, full-length magazine articles, photographs and graphics; it could force publishers to pull from their data bases any freelance work covered by ruling; recent work is less likely to be subject to ruling, since number of media companies, including The New York Times, have for several years required freelancers to sign contracts that allow electronic reproduction of work without additional compensation; E Leonard Rubin, head of intellectual property section of Chicago law firm Gordon & Glickson, says impact of decision could be 'devastating'; George Freeman, assistant general counsel for The New York Times Co, says in case of New York Times, 'our complete record is historical archive; if one takes this decision at its word it would seem to require, absent an agreement with freelancers, that we delete articles that were part of that historical record'; adds 'opinion's effect appears to be tampering with the historic record'; Jonathan Tasini, president of National Writers' Union and lead plaintiff, praises decision that overturns ruling by Federal District Judge Sonia Sotomayor; Chief Judge Ralph K Winter writes ruling (M)

headline: Advice on Annuities
abstract: Thomas J McInerney letter on June 13 article on some teachers' dissatisfaction with their tax-deferred retirement plans

headline: SOFTBANK SAYS IT WILL INVEST $91 MILLION IN MORNINGSTAR
abstract: Softbank Corp will invest $91 million in Morningstar Inc in return for 20 percent stake in company; companies, which formed joint venture in Japan last year, say money will be used to accelerate growth of Morningstar's Internet business (S)

headline: In the Gaming Industry, the House Can Have Bad Luck, Too
abstract: Article explores recent worse-than-expected financial quarter at Mirage Resorts Inc as result of drop in hold percentage on table games money casinos retain as percentage of amount of chips bought; Mirage's winnings can be more volatile since it caters to high rollers; photo; graphs (M)

headline: Considered a strong regional market, Atlanta is getting a new agency to develop its potential.
abstract: Bayless & Partners and Atlanta office of Merkley Newman Harty are merging to form Bayless/Cronin; Tim Bayless will be chief executive and relinquish his duties as creative director to Jerry Cronin, who will also be managing partner; Jerry Brown will be director for strategic development and new business; agency will be autonomous Merkley Newman unit (M)

headline: Women's Groups Oppose Vatican on Family Planning
abstract: 126 women's orgns from around world, frustrated by Vatican's efforts to thwart plan to limit world population growth, present open letter to Roman Catholic Church at conference at United Nations; women's groups, led by 57 Latin American orgns, express their disagreements in series of questions, asking how church that holds life as 'a fundamental value' could watch thousands of women die because they lack access to family planning and abortion (S)

headline: Nike Is Sued Over Tiger Woods Golf Ads
abstract: Acushnet Co sues Nike Inc over its use of Tiger Woods in TV advertisements for Nike's golf clothing and shoes; suit contends ads are deceptive, implying that Woods endorses Nike golf balls and equipment in violation of his contracts with Acushnet, which makes Titleist and Cobra golf balls and equipment; Nike Golf spokesman Mike Kelly says ads are not deceptive; suit also says Nike induced Woods to appear in commercials without his or his agent's approval; Woods's agent Mark Steinberg says Woods and IMG, his management company, have requested that ads be withdrawn (S)

headline: AVNET MAKES ITS SECOND ACQUISITION DEAL IN TWO WEEKS
abstract: Avnet Inc to buy SEI Macro Group, Britain, for about $60.5 million (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.25   8.25   8.50        Discount rate   4.75   4.75   5.00        Federal funds   5.31   5.32   6.14        3-month T-bills   4.68   4.71   4.24        6-month T-bills   4.75   4.77   4.31        10-yr. T-infl.   4.07   4.07   3.56        10-yr. T-note   5.95   5.90   4.41        30-yr. T-bond   6.12   6.08   4.97        Telephone bd.   7.91   7.86   6.88        Municipal bds.   5.91   5.87   5.04          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer

headline: The Great-Grandmother Comes In From the Cold
abstract: Melita Norwood, 87-year-old British woman, admits that for decades she furnished Soviet Union with research documents from Britain's top secret nuclear weapons development program and says she has no regrets about her actions; disclosure of her spying is contained in The Mitrokhin Archive, a book by Christopher Andrew being serialized in Times of London, and newspapers predict that further excerpts from book will unmask up to a dozen more Britons who worked for Soviet intelligence; photo (M)

headline: SHARES OF DRKOOP.COM SURGE OVER AMERICA ONLINE DEAL
abstract: DrKoop.com Inc, Internet site founded by former US Surgeon General C Everett Koop, says it will become largest health information provider for America Online Inc, sending DrKoop.com shares up 56 percent; company will pay America Online $89 million over four years and will give America Online warrants to purchase shares of DrKoop.com (S)

headline: A Resignation Is Expected From Chrysler's President
abstract: Thomas T Stallkamp, president of Chrysler Corp, will resign just 10 months after merger that formed DaimlerChrysler AG; Stallkamp is expected to be replaced by James P Holden, who is now head of sales and marketing for North American brands; move is part of larger shakeup of DaimlerChrysler's management board, which will be reduced to 13 people from 17 and comes at time when company's stock has been slumping badly; departure of Stallkamp also signals serious tensions between Daimler's American and German executives and perhaps over basic strategic issues as well; several other executives, some from Daimler, will lose their positions on management board as well; Kurt Lauk, head of Daimler's truck division, is expected to step down along with Heiner Tropitzsch, Daimler's personnel chief; Theodore Cunningham, Chrysler executive who is in charge of Latin American sales, will also lose his seat (M)

headline: Milosevic Meets His Backers As Opponents Seek to Unite
abstract: Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, attends rare strategy meeting of his Socialist Party, apparently in response to growing opposition movement against him; Serbian Orthodox church brings key opposition leaders together and backs their plans for democratic change (M)

headline: Steelmaker to Raise Prices
abstract: Ispat Inland Inc will increase steel-bar prices by $15 a ton as industry tries to take advantage of decline in imports of low-cost steel; price increase applies to shipments on Jan 1 (S)

headline: ANOTHER RATE CUT IN BRAZIL
abstract: Brazilian central bank cuts main lending rate to 19.5 percent, from 21 percent, in effort to stimulate economic growth; cut is 10th since March (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of July 18 article on accounting techniques that can obscure company's financial performance and gave incomplete calculation for determining operating cash flow (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil rises after Pres Hugo Chavez of Venezuela rules out production increases; in New York, crude oil for October delivery rises 27 cents, or 1.1 percent, to $24.13 a barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Rosenbluth Buys Big Stake In Business Travel Web Site
abstract: Rosenbluth International buys majority stake in Biztravel.com, leading site for making business travel arrangements over the Internet; price is not disclosed; other investors, including Continental Airlines, Marriott International, Sun Microsystems and Excite-@Home, also buy stakes in company, which promises to move Rosenbuth, travel management firm, into forefront of on-line travel (M)

headline: RUSSIA THREATENS TO WIDEN CONFLICT IN THE CAUCASUS
abstract: New Russian Prime Min Valdimir V Putin threatens to launch air strikes against Islamic militants in breakaway republic of Chechnya, risking a widening of seven-day-old conflict in neighboring region of Dagestan; tough line suggests that Moscow is ready to set aside shaky hopes for improvement in relations with Chechnya for a military victory against group of Chechnya-based Islamic insurgents in Dagestan; map; photo (M)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; People
abstract: Keith Sherman is named senior vice president and account director at Publicis & Hal Riney; John Rollins and Anne Welch are named co-presidents at Vibe/Spin Ventures, part of Miller Publishing Group (S)

headline: Tangled War In Congo Now Snares Namibians
abstract: Recent brief battle in small town in Namibia seen as example of domino effect of war in Congo; Namibia sent troops to Congo to help Pres Laurent Kabila, who has allowed Unita rebel movement in Angola to keep bases in Congo; Unita's suspected motive is to punish Namibia for its role in Congo war; map (M)

headline: Britain Nominates Its Defense Secretary to Be Head of NATO
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair nominates Defense Sec George Robertson, Scottish labor union veteran whose vigorous denunciations of Yugoslav military actions in Kosovo were almost as intense as NATO's bombing campaign, to be Britain's candidate for NATO Sec Gen; Robertson, 53, immediately becomes front-runner to succeed Javier Solana, who is soon to leave NATO job in Brussels to become European Union's coordinator for foreign and defense policy; Robertson photo (M)

headline: Auto Industry's Contract Talks Continue
abstract: Negotiators for United Automobile Workers and DaimlerChrysler AG continue their round-the-clock labor talks after indefinitely extending their contract; chart (S)

headline: Big Home Movers in Talks
abstract: NFC PLC is in talks to sell its Allied Pickford moving-services business to North American Van Lines (S)

headline: So Many Mannequins, So Little Time; Saks Tries to Balance Tradition and Risk
abstract: Saks Fifth Avenue, hurt by general softening in luxury market this summer, is trying to introduce cutting-edge clothing without sacrificing its established couture and career lines; high-end designer apparel accounts for 15 percent of stores' revenue but only about 6 or 7 percent of its profits; Saks Holdings Inc is owner of Saks Fifth Avenue; R Brad Martin, chief executive of Proffitt's, which bought Saks Holdings last year and adopted corporate name, had lofty expectations for Saks Fifth Avenue, but Saks has had trouble meeting Wall Street's expectations; graph; photo (M)

headline: SHOE SHARES ACQUIRED
abstract: Italian shÈ

headline: When a Rosy Picture Should Raise a Red Flag
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Investing column describes items in annual reports that financial analyst Robert A Olstein says should raise red flags among investors; drawings (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Copper falls amid expectations that Highland Valley Copper will reach deal with its union and reopen Canada's largest mine; in New York, copper for September delivery falls 2.5 cents, to 74.55 cents a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Learning the Local Ropes
abstract: International development agencies consultant B Meredith Burke letter on September 5 article lauds Indonesia's new World Bank director Mark Baird for living with rural family in order to gain first-hand experience (S)

headline: Japan Lets the Yen Rise, but for How Long?
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer Portfolios, etc. column on changes over past week in Japan's currency and stock markets; Japanese officials, rather than intervene again in foreign exchange market, have stepped to sidelines; reasons why intervention has not restrained yen from rising explored; graph (M)

headline: JUST DON'T DO IT, NIKE IS TOLD
abstract: Spain's Supreme Court rules that Nike International, unit of Nike Inc, cannot sell Nike apparel in Spain because Spanish company, Cidesport, has rights to Nike clothing trademark, registered in 1932, long before American company was founded; ruling does not affect Nike footwear (S)

headline: CHECKPOINT TO BUY METO OF GERMANY FOR $265 MILLION
abstract: Checkpoint Systems Inc plans to acquire European rival Meto AG of Germany for $265 million; it will also assume debt of $35 million (S)

headline: Baron Case Trustee Continues Pressure on Bear Stearns
abstract: James W Giddens, trustee for liquidation of A R Baron, brokerage firm that defrauded investors of $75 million before it failed in 1996, is in negotiations with Bear Stearns Securities Corp to resolve claims relating to Baron's failure; resolution may require Bear Stearns to pay more than $38.5 million it agreed to in settlement with Securities and Exchange Commission last week; if Giddens' talks with clearing unit of Bear Stearns are not successful, Giddens is prepared to sue brokerage firm to reach its objective of paying Baron customers and ceditors all of their allowable claims (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Gold falls 4 percent as banks and speculators make more of metal available so that they can take advantage of higher prices; gold for December delivery falls to $302 an ounce, from $308.10 previous day; graph; chart (S)

headline: Ronald N. Yurcak, 57, Junk Bond Trader and a Milken Associate
abstract: Ronald N Yurcak, pioneering junk bond trader, dies at age 57 (M)

headline: An Ebay Report Card
abstract: Marc Zawel letter on Sept 9 article notes his lucrative business on Ebay's on-line auction site distracted him from his high school studies

headline: COLOMBIA ALTERS OIL POLICY
abstract: Ecopetrol, Colombian state oil company, eases terms for oil exploration contracts in bid to spur stalled output and attract foreign producers; will cut its stake in output and development costs of any new field from 50 to 30 percent (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Creation of Banking Giant Signals Revamping in Japan  Japan signaled the start of a far-reaching consolidation of its bloated and debt-ridden banking system with official word that three of the country's biggest banks would unite to form the world's largest financial institution, with $1.3 trillion in assets.

headline: Munis Gaining Luster As Yield Gap Narrows
abstract: Article on factors at play that are making high-quality municipal bonds look more attractive relative to Treasury bonds; graph (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil rises almost 2 percent on expectations that producers will stick to their plan to limit output until end of March; in New York, crude oil for October delivery rises 38 cents a barrel, to 24.51; graph; chart (S)

headline: European Union's Commission Is Revamped After a Scandal; a 'New Era' Is Promised
abstract: Romano Prodi, president of European Union's Executive Commission, announces appointment of 19 commissioners and promises new era of change after the forced resignation of the entire previous commission amid accusations of corruption; among the new commissioners is Chris Patten of Britain, who will direct European Union's relations with foreign countries (M)

headline: NISSAN BUYS MAZDA STAKE
abstract: Nissan Motor Co to buy Mazda Motor Corp's 34.7 percent stake in Jatco, their automatic transmission joint venture (S)

headline: Flexing at Goldman, Sachs
abstract: Goldman Sachs opens custom-designed private health club for employees at its offices in lower Manhattan (S)

headline: FDX GLOBAL UNIT TO ACQUIRE GEOLOGISTICS AIR
abstract: FDX Corp's FDX Global Logistics Inc unit to acquire Geologistics Corp's Geologistics Air Services for about $116 million (S)

headline: Newspapers Seek Cyberpartners To Fight On-Line Ads
abstract: Newspapers, which see on-line classified advertising as major threat to their profits, have been scrambling to compete in fast-growing world of on-line classifieds; geometric expansion of on-line competitors has coincided with disturbing dip in newspapers' help-wanted ads in some markets that has more than offset gains in other classified ads; graphs of newspaper classified advertising revenues; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Fugitive's 8-Week German Hotel Stay Ends in Arrest
abstract: Martin R Frankel lives for eight weeks at luxurious Prem Hotel in Hamburg, Germany, before being arrested to face charges in US of embezzling more than $200 million from insurance companies; came to Germany after playing cat-and-mouse game with FBI that took him through Italy and perhaps other countries; is captured with help of tips from friends and disgruntled former associates and a winding trail of bank account and credit card charges; photos (M)

headline: Job Site Is to Work On Line and Off
abstract: Brass Ring, on-line job board, will offer training tools, on-line career fairs, job listings, and information and hiring software for companies to use to sort and manage resumes that come their way; Brass Ring stands out from other job-board sites because it combines resources of Kaplan Education Centers, The Pavement, Web site that offers career information, and Hire Systems, company that develops hiring-management software (M)

headline: H & R Block to Buy Olde For $850 Million in Cash
abstract: H&R Block Inc acquires Olde Financial Corp, parent of nation's fourth-largest discount brokerage firm, for $850 million in cash; Block is intensifying its push to become broad-based provider of financial services to Middle America; Olde's brokerage unit, Olde Discount Corp, is emerging from scandal that last year resulted in $7 million settlement of allegations that its management practices in early 1990's encouraged its brokers to defraud investors (M)

headline: New Source for Initial Offerings
abstract: Friedman Billings Ramsey Group of Arlington, Va, plans to make shares of initial offerings it manages available to Fidelity Investments' clients (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Fishermen Feel Xenophobia in 'Pure Ivoirian' Pride
abstract: Malian fishermen have been driven from Ayame, Ivory Coast after decades of living there and replaced by Ivoirian fishermen; map; photo (M)

headline: Former Head of Dell Publishing to Move to Dutton Books
abstract: Penguin Putnam Inc names Carole Baron, former Dell Publishing president and publisher, president of its Dutton Books (M)

headline: FEDERAL-MOGUL PLANS TO SELL 3 OF ITS UNITS
abstract: Federal-Mogul Corp plans to sell its lighting, wiper blade and fuel units (S)

headline: Economist Laureate, Quill in Hand
abstract: Profile of economist John Kenneth Galbraith, 90, who has just published new book, Name-Dropping; he comments on his background and past role in American politics; photo (M)

headline: Tingka Journal; Uncivil Rights: Are Tibetans 'Citizens' of China?
abstract: Article on plight of ethnic Tibetans in Sichuan Province, China, who say Govt is deliberately overwhelming their culture; they accuse China of engaging in policy of brutal intolerance, religious oppression and widespread racism; map; photo (M)

headline: Weakness in Technology Hurts Shares
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 47.80 points, to 10,863.16; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 9.18 points, to 1,347.76; Nasdaq composite index falls 73.21 points, to 2,619.19; graph; tables (M)

headline: Russian Denies Plan for War or Surrender in Chechnya
abstract: Prime Min Vladimir Putin says Russia has no plans to wage another war in secession-minded Chechnya region to suppress Islamic militants who are mounting attacks from bases there; says Government will not cede anything to Chechen militants, who have twice invaded neighboring republic of Dagestan and are widely blamed for terrorist bombings that have killed hundreds in Moscow and southern region of Rostov; photo (M)

headline: Cutting Through the On-Line Clutter
abstract: Summaries of information on Internet news sites are gaining in popularity as number of Web sites grows; such digests sift on-line content of established media organizations as well as alternative outlets; most popular digests play important promotional role for World Wide Web sites they send readers to; photo (M)

headline: A Showdown On Messaging May Unite Web Users
abstract: Analysis of public spat between Microsoft Corp and America Online Inc over open access to instant-message systems that have become increasingly popular on Internet; says it is no accident that Microsoft is taking lead in talking about open standards in instant messaging, service in which America Online has 80 million users; says Microsoft, like America Online, makes it hard for competitors to gain access to markets it holds dear; photo (M)

headline: Uneasy Moscow Swept by Rumors About What Yeltsin Will Do
abstract: In Russia there is new conflict smoldering in Caucasus, international inquiries are casting new suspicions over financial institutions and Pres Boris N Yeltsin's office, and bombs are exploding in night, killing families in their sleep; situation is going from bad to worse, and consensus is emerging across society and across political spectrum that Pres Boris Yeltsin's time has run out; rumors that Yeltsin may retire early early continue to circulate (M)

headline: Bank of Scotland Makes $34 Billion Hostile Offer for Natwest
abstract: Bank of Scotland PLC mounts $34 billion hostile bid for National Westminster Bank, biggest takeover attempt in British banking history; Natwest chairman Sir David Rowland promises to block deal; chart; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Latin American Markets Respond Calmly to Default  Stocks rose and currencies steadied across much of Latin America, the first day of trading after weekend news that Ecuador would default on some foreign debt and Colombia abandoned its system for defending the exchange value of its currency.    Analysts attributed the generally calm regional response to relief that both nations had ended weeks of speculation and uncertainty about how they intended to address their economic problems. Even with the Colombian central bank no longer intervening to prop up the value of the peso, the currency there slipped barely 1 percent. [Page C6.]

headline: Let's Make a Deal
abstract: Readers are asked to respond to query about unusual places where people have sought or found clients, investors, employees and employers (S)

headline: Treasuries Fall as Remarks by Fed Official Stoke Rate Fears
abstract: Treasury securities fall sharply after Federal Reserve Board governor Edward W Kelley Jr says Fed remains 'intently vigilant' about economy; 30-year bond falls 21/32 to price of 100, with yield rising to 6.13 percent, from 6.08 percent; graph; key rates chart (M)

headline: Tips to Arrests, French Pursue a Mass Killing in Kosovo
abstract: French police serving as peacekeepers in Kosovo notify families of 26 men missing from town of Mitrovica for five months that they were killed by Serbs and dumped in mass grave, and that four suspects have been arrested; map; photo (M)

headline: Coming Soon to a Web Site Near You: A Simpler Sales Tax
abstract: Debate over taxation of E-commerce is likely to lead to simplification of sales taxes; no map exists that matches every address to each taxing jurisdiction and E-commerce companies that operate in one state and ship to others have no incentive to create such map because they are not currently required to collect sales tax (M)

headline: Mademoiselle's Editor Is Leaving at End of Year
abstract: Elizabeth Crow resigns as editor in chief of Mademoiselle magazine, effective at end of year; Conde Nast Publications expects to name new editor next week (M)

headline: HEALTHSTAR TO TAKE 49% STAKE IN PHYSICIANSITE.COM
abstract: Healthstar Corp, health care management company with 121,000 physicians, agrees to buy 49 percent stake in Physiciansite.com for $42 million in stock and cash to add on-line services; Physiciansite.com is Internet site that will allow doctors to process insurance claims, order supplies and prescriptions, and schedule appointments on line (S)

headline: WHITE CAP INDUSTRIES SET TO BE TAKEN PRIVATE
abstract: Buyout led by management group and Leonard Green & Partners LP affiliate will purchase White Cap Industries and take it private (S)

headline: Making a Mac Do Windows
abstract: Q. I have a new iMac and need to install Virtual PC so I can use a Windows accounting program. What do I need to run Virtual PC?    A. For Macintosh users who need to run Windows-only programs, software like Virtual PC from Connectix (www.connectix .com) and Soft Windows from Insignia Solutions (www.insignia.com) can transform the Mac into a temporary PC. These programs emulate Windows and run best on a Mac with a fast processor, plenty of RAM  and a good chunk of hard drive space. Although these software solutions won't run Windows programs as fast as a real PC or a Mac with a special hardware card installed, the programs do let Mac users visit the ''other side'' from the comfort of their own machines.

headline: Debt Ties Hands of U.S. at U.N., Albright Says
abstract: Sec of State Madeleine K Albright says Congressional unwillingness to pay what US owes to United Nations has hamstrung Clinton Administration's ability to influence organization (M)

headline: Memorial for David Ogilvy
abstract: Memorial program for David Ogilvy, founder of Ogilvy & Mather advertising agency, will be held at Avery Fisher Hall in Lincoln Center in Manhattan (S)

headline: Korean Famine Toll: More Than 2 Million
abstract: North Korea appears to be emerging from prolonged severe famine with help of international food aid, but four terrible years of hunger from 1995 through 1998 may have cost country two million to three million lives; experts say many of dead are old people and children, or urban dwellers of any age with no way to forage off land; during that time, North Korea got nearly 3.5 million metric tons of food donations from abroad, mostly from China, Japan, South Korea and United States; it still needs more (M)

headline: Piraeus Bank Bids $5.2 Billion To Acquire Ergo, a Greek Rival
abstract: Piraeus Bank agrees to buy Ergo Bank for $5.2 billion; deal would thwart hostile bid by EFG Bank European Financial Group (S)

headline: OIL CHANGE IN INDONESIA
abstract: Indonesia, seeking to end 32 years of corruption under regime of former Pres Suharto, will strip state-owned oil and gas company Pertimina of its monopoly on granting contracts in petroleum reserves; photo (S)

headline: N.A.S.D. Fines Prudential $20 Million
abstract: Prudential Insurance Co of America is fined $20 million by National Association of Securities Dealers, highest fine ever imposed by association; Barry R Goldsmith, head of enforcement for NASD, says investigators found that Prudential committed 'serious violations of securities law and our rules' in sale of variable life insurance policies, which are combination of life insurance and investments similar to mutual funds; Prudential spokesman Robert DeFillippo says he knows of no further pending investigations of company as it revamps with expectations of making its first public offering of stock, probably in about 10 months (M)

headline: Xerox Dusts Off Its Used Copiers
abstract: Xerox Corp, world's biggest seller of new copiers, will enter $1 billion-plus market for used copiers; Xerox hopes to build brand loyalty among small businesses, prime customers for used machines, so that they will turn to Xerox when they are ready to buy expensive new copier (S)

headline: A Bank Start-Up Dies Aborning
abstract: Organizers of Village Bank in Lawrenceville, NJ, cancel initial offering after raising less than half of $4.25 million needed to open (S)

headline: Report by U.N. Agency Asks Trade Opening to 3d World
abstract: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development says industrial nations must relax trade barriers and open their markets to developing world, lest these third world countries be forced to rely on unpredictable foreign capital for economic growth; study of some 40 developing countries shows increased trade deficits and declining economic growth; urges that concerns of poorer nations be centerpiece of forthcoming global trade negotiations, contending that market access, not foreign capital, is key to growth; its concerns are seconded by World Bank, which backed far-reaching trade round to start at World Trade Organization's ministerial meeting in Seattle in November (M)

headline: LVMH'S SALES JUMP
abstract: LVMH-Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SA says sales climbed 18 percent in last three months; for first six months of 1999, sales increased 15.5 percent over year before, to $3.7 billion; photo (S)

headline: 5 Hyundai Group Executives Indicted
abstract: Lee Ik Chi, chairman of Hyundai Securities, is charged with rigging stock prices of chip-making affiliate of Hyundai Group; four executives from Hyundai Merchant Marine, Hyundai Heavy Industries, Hyundai Securities and Hyundai Electronics are also indicted on charges of rigging share prices of their own companies; arrest of Lee is one of most visible efforts by Government to rein in nation's most powerful business groups (S)

headline: WAL-MART FACES TAX AUDIT
abstract: US retail giant Wal-Mart Stores Inc is facing tax audit by South Korean Government for refusing to accept credit cards at its Korean outlets; Office of National Tax Administration says it will include Wal-Mart on its tax audit list because retailer has received large number of complaints from consumers about its refusal to accept credit cards; consumer organizations contend Wal-Mart is discriminating against Korean consumers (S)

headline: True North Forms Global Marketing Unit
abstract: True North Communications is forming global marketing services operation, Marketing Drive Worldwide; head of two units joining Marketing Drive Worldwide are named its co-chief executives; Wes Bray is president of Promotion Services Group; Mark Timbrell is chairman of Marketing Drive (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    AUSTRIA: IRAQI DEPARTS  The second in command to the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, left Austria one day after a Viennese official filed a criminal complaint against him for human rights abuses in Iraq. Izzat Ibrahim, deputy chairman of Iraq's ruling Revolutionary Command Council, arrived in Austria on Aug. 6 for undisclosed medical treatment. Foreign Ministry officials would not say whether the charges had prompted him to cut short his visit.   (AP)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: COMPUWARE CORP.,  Farmington Hills, Mich., a developer of testing, management and development software, won a 10-year, $1 billion contract to take over information systems for the Detroit Medical Center, the academic health center of Wayne State University.

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for DAVID SAKS; After Viagra, Pfizer Finds Another Winning Strategy
abstract: Gruntal & Co pharmaceutical analyst David Saks answers questions on Pfizer's winning strategy in marketing Monsanto's new arthritis drug Celebrex; photo (M)

headline: Lord Whitelaw, 81, Key Aide And Fixer for Mrs. Thatcher
abstract: William Whitelaw, key aide to his fellow Conservative Margaret Thatcher while she was Britain's Prime Minister, dies at age 81; photo (M)

headline: A Ragged Rip in Schroder's Party Is Becoming All Too Public
abstract: Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's efforts to move Germany's Social Democratic Party to right is meeting mounting resistance from workers, who feel party has abandoned them; outcome of current struggle is likely to determine not only character of Social Democratic Party, with its roots in struggle of factory workers for social justice, but also future course of Schroder's coalition Government with environmentalist Greens (M)

headline: AT&T's Planned Mediaone Deal Poses Test for U.S. Cable Policy
abstract: AT&T Corp's planned $58 billion acquisition of Mediaone Group poses test for US cable policy; AT&T executives say acquisition is needed to establish cable network so vast and powerful that it will provide high-speed Internet service, cable TV and telephone service that can compete with regional Bell companies; three consumer groups--Consumers Union, Consumer Federation of America and Media Access Project--say cost of opening local markets is not worth price and urge Government to kill deal because it would permit AT&T to dominate both cable television industry and market for high-speed Internet service; in papers filed with Federal Communications Commission and Justice Department, groups assert that proposed acquisition would violate raft of antitrust and telecommunications rules intended to limit concentration of ownership in cable and other industries (M)

headline: Lycos and RCN Form a Strategic Alliance
abstract: RCN Corp and Lycos Inc form business alliance that will marry Web content developed by Lycos and RCN's high-speed telecommunications network (S)

headline: Lights to Ease Boomers Down the Road
abstract: Lighting industry has tried different strategies to give drivers better light for night driving, redesigning both innards of headlights and their reflectors and glass and plastic lenses; auto industry is facing largest group of aging drivers--baby boomers--giving it economic incentive to make things brighter; photos; diagram (M)

headline: The Flux in Pop Music Has a Distinctly Download Beat to It
abstract: Sue Cummings article on music industry changes spurred by popularity of MP3; artists of every stripe are using Internet to distribute audio in hopes of establishing following, reviving career or promoting new work; photo (M)

headline: Firm Showings By Two Issuers Aid Treasuries
abstract: Bond prices rise; price of benchmark 30-year bond rises 23/32, to 89 27/32; yield falls to 5.99 percent from 6.04 percent; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Belgrade Presents Schedule For Reservists' Back Pay
abstract: Yugoslav Defense Min Pavle Bulatovic, in unusual open Cabinet meeting aimed at assuaging popular grievances, says army reservists mobilized for Kosovo conflict will be paid equivalent of $100 million in overdue wages in installments over next six months; sets back pay as top priority; protests continue; map (M)

headline: Ice-cream makers suffer through a hot summer of flat sales.
abstract: Advertising column discusses advertising campaigns by ice cream manufacturers seeking to boost sales, which have remained flat for some time; photo (M)

headline: Russians Name a Chechen as the Chief Suspect in 5 Bombings
abstract: Russiaï

headline: ALCOA BUYS HAYES LEMMERZ STAKE IN AUTO PARTS MAKER
abstract: Alcoa Inc buys remaining 50 percent stake it does not own in A-CMI from Hayes Lemmerz International Inc; renames company Alcoa Automotive Castings (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Wrestling Games Trounce All Comers on Video
abstract: Sales of wrestling-related video games from January through May increased by 23 percent, to $60 million, from comparable period last year; increase outpaced growth of video game sales generally, which grew 14 percent, to $1.9 billion in same period; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Orange juice prices fall on speculation that most citrus groves in Florida will escape severe damage from Hurricane Floyd; in New York, frozen concentrated orange juice falls 0.45 cent, to 96.55 cents a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: For the Love Of Their Sons' Game
abstract: James Schembari Midstream column on shuffling of schedules of parents and coaches to attend practice sessions, games and tournaments of Little League team in Toms River, NJ, which won World Series in 1998 and came in second this year; photo (M)

headline: In Latest Move to Diversify, Medtronic Will Buy Xomed
abstract: Medtronic Inc agrees to acquire Xomed Surgical Products Inc for $800 million in stock (M)

headline: Stone Asset Fraud Case Widens
abstract: US Attorney in Manhattan unseals indictments against four more people in connection with accusations of stock fraud manipulation at Stone Asset Inc, unregistered broker-dealer where, authorities say, about 200 investors were defrauded of about $1.5 million; of 13 people indicted earlier, 8 have been convicted; new charges are against Germann Vesterman, Samir Maalouf, Frank Mangano and John Cantania, who are accused of participating in scheme involving unregistered stock of Vital Signs and Connectechnologies (S)

headline: Hard Line at Harvard
abstract: Institute for Study of Civic president Edwa

headline: San Francisco Firm Bought by Marc USA
abstract: Marc USA acquires Zuckerman Fernandes & Partners, which will be renamed Zuckerman Fernandes/Marc USA and run under current management (S)

headline: President's Top Security Adviser Questioned by Senate Committee
abstract: President Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R Berger, in unusual closed-door appearance before Senate committee, answers questions about how Clinton Administration has handled charges of nuclear espionage by China; reportedly repeats previous accounts (M)

headline: Boards Study Bell Atlantic-Vodafone Deal
abstract: Boards of Bell Atlantic Corp and Vodafone Airtouch PLC are expected to meet to approve combining of companies' US wireless businesses; board of GTE, which agreed to be bought by Bell Atlantic for $52 billion in deal set to close next year, is also meeting to discuss transaction (S)

headline: Scandal and Bloodshed Roil Russia
abstract: Weekly stock market roundup; benchmark Russian Trading System goes into tailspin as result of possible money laundering scandal involving Bank of New York, series of mysterious bombings and speculation over possible resignation of Pres Boris Yeltsin; graphs (M)

headline: In Unusual Announcement, China Tells of a Missile Test
abstract: China reports successful test of new long-range missile; military experts say weapon is probably Dong Feng-31 missile, which can carry 1,500-pound nuclear warhead, has range of 5,000 miles and can reach US; say missile relies on mobile launching to evade attack; missile has been under development for several years; launching is announced at same time Chinese authorities publicly excoriate US decision to proceed with sale of sophisticated military equipment to Taiwan, at time when relations between China and Taiwan are extremely delicate (M)

headline: Single Candidate Is Expected as Next President : No Contest for Singapore
abstract: SINGAPORE—  The official committee that screens presidential candidates in Singapore said Tuesday it had approved only one of three applicants — S.R. Nathan, a former Singapore military intelligence chief and ambassador to the United States.

headline: Credit Offerings That Are Planned During the Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.51 percent and on a six-month bill, 4.84 percent.

headline: New Chinese Missiles Seen as Threat to U.S.
abstract: United States National Intelligence Estimate survey predicts that within 15 years, China will be aiming missiles at United States that will be fitted with small nuclear warheads developed with help of espionage; findings detailed (M)

headline: Computer Shock
abstract: Letter from Willis A Smith says Dr Edwin Rothman, who had such trouble setting up computer, should have bought a Mac

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Cost of Drink Recall Rises For Coca-Cola's Bottler  Coca-Cola's bottler, Coca-Cola Enterprises, said that it would take a $103 million charge against second-quarter earnings to cover expenses associated with the recall of soft drinks in Europe last month, about 70 percent more than previously acknowledged. The charge erases second-quarter earnings for the bottler.    Coca-Cola Enterprises said two weeks ago that the recall involved 14 million cases of soft drinks and would cost the company $60 million. But that number ballooned after 17 million cases of products were returned. [Page C7.]

headline: In China, Physicist Learns, He Tripped Between Useful Exchange and Security Breach
abstract: George A Keyworth recalls being peppered with detailed, pointed questions by Chinese weapons experts during conference in 1980, when Keyworth was senior scientist from Los Alamos National Laboratory; Keyworth went home believing he had avoided traps, but was concerned enough to report incident to Los Alamos and intelligence officials; House committee has not resurrected episode and charged that inadvertent disclosures bordered on negligent security breach (M)

headline: VEHICLE SALES DROP
abstract: Brazil's vehicle sales declined in June as high domestic interest rates sapped consumer financing; sales fell 1.5 percent, to 92,960 units from May (S)

headline: INTEGRATED BUYS SOFTWARE DEVELOPMENT SYSTEMS
abstract: Integrated Systems Inc., a developer of security software, said late on Thursday that it had bought the closely held Software Development Systems for $40 million in stock and cash. Integrated Systems said it would merge Software Development Systems, a Chicago-based maker of software-debugging products, with its Diab Data subsidiary. The combined company will operate independently as Diab-Software Development Systems and have more than $20 million in annual revenue.

headline: Antacid Maker Picks Bates USA
abstract: TAP Pharmaceuticals names Bates USA as first agency to handle general market advertising for Prevacid, prescription medication for ulcers and heartburn (S)

headline: Hachette Proceeding With Kennedy Tribute
abstract: Hachette Filipacchi Media plans special October issue of George magazine as tribute to John F Kennedy Jr, magazine's late president and editor in chief (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Strong Corporate Earnings Push Stock Gauges Higher  Stocks ended a week of record-setting sessions as Wall Street cheered good corporate earnings. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index gained 25.11 points, or nine-tenths of a percent, to 2,864.48, its third consecutive record finish.

headline: S.E.C. Civil Suit Says Faxes About 12 Stocks Were False
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission officials file federal suit against Globus Group Inc of Miami and its principal, Anthony DiMarco, for allegedly promoting shares of dozen micro-cap companies through bogus faxes sent to investors (M)

headline: Hilton to Buy Promus Chain, Creating One of Biggest Hotel Groups
abstract: Hilton Hotels Corp to buy Promus Hotel Corp for $3.1 billion in cash and stock, creating one of world's largest hotel companies; photo (M)

headline: Enron to Buy Natural Gas From Petronas
abstract: Enron Corp will buy as much as 2.6 million tons of liquefied natural gas a year from Malaysia's state oil company, Petroliam Nasional Berhad, commonly known as Petronas, and sell fuel to India; 20-year agreement is worth about $9.6 billion (S)

headline: BRITISH CELL PHONE DEAL
abstract: British Telecommunications PLC will buy 40 percent of BT Cellnet Ltd that it does not already own from Securicor PLC for $5.12 billion (S)

headline: Peter A. Bordes, 71, Broadcast Executive
abstract: Peter A Bordes, co-founder, chairman and chief executive of Greater Media Inc, dies at age 71 (S)

headline: Anheuser-Busch to Recall Beer in Europe
abstract: Anheuser-Busch Companies says it is recalling 5.7 million bottles of its Budweiser and Bud brands beer from 12 European nations after consumers complained that glass slivers broke off rim of some bottles when twist-off caps were removed; says recall covers less than 1 percent of its beer sold annually in Europe; also says two glass plants are working to resolve problem by revising their production equipment; photo of Budweiser cases at warehouse near Lisbon that are part of recall (M)

headline: Equity Offerings Are Set for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:
