headline: Qwest Is Nimble in Dance of the Hostile Bid
abstract: Analysis of improved outlook for Qwest Communications International's hostile bids for Frontier Corp and U S West, companies that have agreed to merge with rival Global Crossing; Frontier and U S West, fearing investor suits or offending either suitor, have avoided picking sides; both Qwest and Global Crossing are trying to catapult selves into ranks of communications elite (M)

headline: ACCORD WITH NATO LETS MOSCOW ADD TROOPS IN KOSOVO
abstract: NATO and Russian military commanders resolve differences over Russia's role in peacekeeping operations in Kosovo, Serbia, clearing way for arrival of about more 3,600 more Russian troops after weeks of wrangling; NATO spokesman says all issues were clarified within context of June 18 Helsinki agreement on integration of Russian troops; says there are currently no military obstacles for deployment of Russians, who have agreed reluctantly to serve under nominal control of allied commanders of each sector where they will operate--but will reserve right to refuse to carry out orders; Russian commanders failed to obtain permission to send troops into Italian sector, which would have altered boundaries previously negotiated in painstaking detail; Clinton Administration official says part of difficulty stemmed from fact that following Helsinki agreement each side, for unknown reasons, had different maps showing different areas of operations for Russia's troops; map (M)

headline: Cisco Systems to Invest $1 Billion In the Accounting Giant KPMG
abstract: Cisco Systems Inc, dominant maker of networking equipment for Internet, says that it is making $1 billion investment in accounting and consulting firm KPMG LLP (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil prices drop after Germany says it will sell about 32 million barrels from its reserves over next year; in New York, crude oil for October delivery falls 37 cents, or 1.7 percent, to $21.47 a barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Sugar prices rise on signs of steady demand; sugar for Oct delivery rises 0.28 cent, to 6.04 cents a pound; graphs; table (S)

headline: Toppling Icons
abstract: Letter from Charles Luttrell on Aug 5 article on getting America Online's icon off the screen

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.00   8.00   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   5.06   4.82   5.46        3-month T-bills   4.59   4.53   4.95        6-month T-bills   4.59   4.77   5.04        10-yr. T-infl.   3.98   3.97   3.75        10-yr. T-note   5.86   5.82   5.41        30-yr. T-bond   6.03   6.00   5.60        Telephone bd.   7.76   7.74   7.06        Municipal bds.   5.55   5.54   5.21          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Humming Off Key For Two Decades
abstract: Sony Walkman celebrates its 20th anniversary; in 1979, when it was introduced, it heralded age of personal electronics; it is close to staple now; more than 186 million have been sold; model that cost $200 20 years ago can now be found for $20, and available everywhere; basic shape of first model has evolved into many models and styles of Walkmans; Walkman's solitary, enveloping quality became its defining feature; its 'personal sound' was forerunner of personal computers and personal digital assistants; photos (M)

headline: Despite the G.I.'s, Kosovo Town Is Purged of Serbs
abstract: All 350 Serbs in Zitinje, Kosovo, leave village under armed US escort; ethnic Albanians intimidated Serbs despite presence of US troops, just as Serbs had intimidated them; map; photo (M)

headline: New Devices Given Road Test By Business Students at Duke
abstract: Students at Duke University's Fuqua School of Business are taking part in ususual project started by school this semester in which they will test 'next-generation devices' that Nevin Fouts, associate dean for information technology, belives may replace laptop computers for use in classrooms, libraries and study lounges; nine companies are participating in project, sending their latest gadgets to school for testing; pros and cons of testing for both Duke and companies discussed; photo (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Latest Offer in Overseas Calls: Free but Not Commercial-Free
abstract: Cortex Telecom is offering free international phone service to callers willing to listen to 15-second advertisement at beginning of each call and another ad interrupting conversation every three minutes; currently offers service in five cities; seeks $15 million from venture capitalists and plans to expand network to dozens of cities around world; photo (M)

headline: Can Defendants Cry 'E-Sanctuary' and Escape the Courts?
abstract: Explosive growth of Internet commerce raises legal questions about jurisdiction of local laws over medium that knows no geographic boundaries and thrives on anonymity; trickle of rulings in United States and abroad has begun to define commercial rules for Web by applying analogies from older principles, but medium has created problems that defy easy answers; economic realities put strain on development of cyberspace law; drawing (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: IT'S LORD ROBERTSON NOW  Defense Secretary George Robertson, 53, who is leaving the Government to become General Secretary of NATO, has been made a peer with the title of Lord Robertson of Port Ellen, the village on the Hebridean Island of Islay where he was born. His elevation to the House of Lords moves up the date of the by-election for his seat in Parliament to Sept. 23, helping the governing Labor Party by limiting the time the Scottish Nationalists can mount an organized challenge.    Warren Hoge (NYT)    RUSSIA: DAILY DUE BACK ON STANDS  Kommersant, one of Moscow's most respected daily newspapers, will resume publication today after it was shut down for a day by city authorities for what were said to be violations of fire safety codes. Editors of the paper, which was recently bought by Boris A. Berezovsky, a financier and media magnate with close ties to the Kremlin, denounced the shutdown as a ''silly'' attempt by Mayor Yuri M. Luzhkov of Moscow to put pressure on the news media. Celestine Bohlen (NYT)    RUSSIA: DAGESTAN CAMPAIGN  Military officials said they were on the verge of reclaiming control of territory seized two weeks ago by Islamic militants who crossed into Dagestan Province from the secessionist republic of Chechnya. A spokesman for the militants said they had withdrawn in order to regroup as they shift tactics in their fight for Dagestan's independence. According to military reports, Russian troops were still engaged in scattered fighting in the mountainous region between Dagestan and Chechnya.    Celestine Bohlen (NYT)    RUSSIA: NEW OPPOSITION ALLIANCE  Sergei V. Stepashin, one of Russia's former Prime Ministers, announced that he would join forces with Grigory Yavlinsky's liberal opposition party Yabloko in parliamentary elections in December. Mr. Stepashin, whose three months in office gave him a national reputation and modest popularity, backed out of a coalition last weekend with parties made up of former allies of President Boris N.Yeltsin.    Celestine Bohlen (NYT)    ASIA    KYRGYZSTAN: SECURITY SUMMIT TALKS  President Boris B. Yeltsin of Russia arrived in Bishkek, the capital of Kyrgyzstan, to take part in a meeting today on security and cooperation in the region with the leaders of China, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Kazakhstan. The officials were arriving as Kyrgyzstan forces traded fire with gunmen who crossed from Tajikistan, seized hostages and occupied three villages.    (Reuters, AP)    THAILAND: WARRANT FOR BUDDHIST LEADER  About 10,000 followers of the leader of a Buddhist sect, Phra Dhammachayo, 55, gathered at their Dhammakaya temple compound outside Bangkok to prevent his arrest on charges of fraud, embezzlement and corruption. The arrest warrant capped a police investigation into allegations that the monk and his top aides illegally amassed a fortune estimated at $110 million. The sect has branches in 10 countries, including the United States.    (AP)    MIDDLE EAST    ISRAEL: PALESTINIANS QUIT TALKS  Palestinian negotiators discussing a prisoner release with Israel suspended the meetings, saying no progress had been made. Hisham Abdel Razek, the Palestinian Minister for Prisoners, called the meetings ''a waste of time.'' The failure is likely to put a damper on talks in Washington on Thursday between Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and two top Palestinian negotiators, Saeb Erekat and Mahmoud Abbas.    (AP)    THE AMERICAS    VENEZUELA: HIGH COURT CHIEF QUITS  Accusing her colleagues of capitulating to political pressure by ruling that a new constitutional assembly has authority to take control of the judicial system, the chief justice of the Supreme Court, Cecilia Sosa, has resigned. ''The court simply committed suicide to avoid being assassinated,'' she said in a nationally televised news conference. ''But the result is the same: it is dead.'' She also criticized Congress and political parties for not resisting what she called attempts by President Hugo Chavez to concentrate power in his own hands through the assembly.    Larry Rohter (NYT)    ARGENTINA: GAY SOLDIERS  Gen. Martin Balza, who retires as the commander of the army in December, suggested that the military code should be amended so that military personnel found to be homosexuals would no longer face prison sentences of up to six years. But he added that he did not want to allow declared homosexuals to enter the military. Any change in the military code must be approved by the high command and the Defense Ministry.    Clifford Krauss (NYT)    MEXICO: OPPOSITION TALKS FALTER  Negotiations to form a coalition of opposition parties for the July 2000 general elections turned difficult. Eight parties opposed to the Institutional Revolutionary Party of President Ernesto Zedillo have written a joint electoral platform, but have failed to agree on how to select a single presidential candidate. The center-left Party of the Democratic Revolution suggested that the months of talks should end, in success or failure, by Aug. 31. But the pro-business National Action Party said it would ignore that deadline.    Sam Dillon (NYT)    AFRICA    SOUTH AFRICA: STRIKERS' PROTEST MARCH  An estimated 35,000 public workers marched through Pretoria during a one-day walkout, demanding higher wages in the biggest union protest in the post-apartheid era. The Government's main wage negotiator, Public Service and Administration Minister Geraldine Fraser-Moleketi, responded to the protest by agreeing to return to the bargaining table ''within days.'' The strike came just two months after the inauguration of President Thabo Mbeki.    (AP)

headline: Champion of Free Kosovo Now Urges Moderation
abstract: Adem Demaci, long and fervent advocate of Kosovo independence, urges fellow Kosovo Albanians to use sudden gift of freedom to build civilized society, interview; holds reconciliation between Serbs and Albanians is possible and necessary over time and will lead to real state in modern Europe of shared sovereignty; photo (M)

headline: Alaska Plans Public Meetings on Oil Deal
abstract: Alaska's Gov Tony Knowles says BP Amoco PLC's proposed purchase of Atlantic Richfield Co will be discussed at public meetings that could be held across Alaska next month; Knowles and other state officials have said they may try to block merger unless companies make concessions, such as hiring more Alaskans (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Delta Is in Talks With 3 Agencies
abstract: Delta Air Lines said yesterday that it was in discussions over advertising work that is now being handled by Saatchi & Saatchi in New York, part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C.    John Kennedy, a spokesman for Delta in Atlanta, confirmed reports this week in Advertising Age and Adweek that the airline was speaking with two other agencies -- which he identified as the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago and TBWA/Chiat/ Day in New York, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group. -- along with Saatchi & Saatchi about a fall brand campaign. The airline spends about $45 million annually on advertising. Burnett handled the worldwide United Airlines account until 1996.

headline: CONCENTRIC NETWORK TO BUY BRITISH INTERNET PROVIDER
abstract: Concentric Network Corp agrees to acquire Internet Technology Group PLC for 146 million pounds ($235 million) to enter European Internet-access market (S)

headline: Federal Court Sets High Standard for Fraud Suits
abstract: Federal appeals court, in victory for high-technology companies and others facing securities fraud suits, rules, 2-1, that such suits must be dismissed at outset unless they contain detailed evidence of deliberate fraud; ruling, for nine-state territory that includes California's Silicon Valley, conflicts with interpretations by Securities and Exchange Commission and most other Federal appeals courts; comes in suit against Silicon Graphics (M)

headline: French Utility to Raise Stakes in Two Pay-TV Companies
abstract: Vivendi SA, French utilities giant, agrees to pay about $2.7 billion in cash and stock to increase its holdings in pay-TV stations Canal Plus SA of France and B Sky B of Britain; surprise move heightens speculation that Vivendi is out to push two companies into merger; such an idea would likely to face opposition from Rupert Murdoch, chairman of News Corp, which owns 40 percent of B Sky B; Vivendi raises its stake in B Sky B to 24.5 percent from 17 percent while increasing its holding in Canal Plus to 49 percent from 34 percent; Vivendi purchases indirect stakes in B Sky B held by Pearson PLC and Granada Group PLC; if two pay-TV companies merged, Vivendi would hold 30 percent of combined entity, leaving Murdoch with 25 percent; Vivendi acquires Cie Financiere Richemont AG's 15 percent stake in Canal Plus for $1.4 billion in stock (M)

headline: TECHNOLOGY: Capturing the Reality of Motion; Computing Power Puts Video Games in Television's League
abstract: Video game producers are using motion capture technology to more realistically duplicate moves of human actors; Electronic Arts Inc, which uses motion capture for over dozen sports titles and many of its other games, is seen as leader in field; such technologies are helping games expand beyond their male teen-age stronghold into increasingly mainstream form of entertainment that rivals movies in revenues; photos (M)

headline: Avis Selects McCann-Erickson
abstract: Avis Rent a Car names McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising to handle its account, which had been at Bates USA (S)

headline: Moscow Blast, 3d in 2 Weeks, Kills at Least 95
abstract: Third major explosion in two weeks and second in four days demolishes apartment building in Moscow, killing at least 95 people while they slept; Russian officials blame Islamic militants, who they say have taken their war in Caucasus to nation's capital; Pres Boris Yeltsin says terrorists has declared war on Russian people; orders tightened security at airports, nuclear power plants and other possible targets; vows to check each of Moscow's 33,000 apartment buildings; Mayor Yuri M Luzhkov says all visitors to city must submit to questioning and obtain new residency permits; says two suspects have been detained; Shamil Basayev, Chechen warlord leading offensive against Russian troops in Dagestan, denies involvement in blasts; scene of blast described; map; photos (M)

headline: Profits Rise at Citigroup and Other Banks in 2d Quarter
abstract: Citigroup, the nation's largest financial services company, said yesterday that its second-quarter profit surged 21 percent as robust consumer spending and the resilient stock market bolstered earnings at several leading banks.    Nearly every area of activity at the Citigroup conglomerate, from underwriting insurance policies at Travelers to advising companies on mergers at Salomon Smith Barney, posted sharply improved results. Cost reductions, especially in the group's consumer division, helped the bottom line.

headline: CARREFOUR BUYS STORES
abstract: Carrefour S.A. of France bought 33 supermarkets in central Brazil, proceeding with an expansion plan that has made it the country's largest retailer. The acquisition gives Carrefour 81 supermarkets in Brazil as well as 67 of the giant discount stores known as hypermarkets. Carrefour bought the stores for an undisclosed amount from Mineirao, a company with a strong presence in Belo Horizonte, Brazil's third-largest city. The food-retailing industry in Brazil is consolidating as family-run chains have been squeezed by high interest rates. Larger companies with cash for expansion have gone on takeover sprees.   Simon Romero

headline: Compressed Data; E-Commerce Twist: Full-Service Shipping
abstract: Commercekey, Internet start-up, will offer to deliver customers' merchandise around world; Commercekey is joint venture between Vardinoyannis Group of Cos and Leventis Group, Greek industrial giants with access to fleet of cargo ships and network of climate-controlled warehouses throughout world; photo (M)

headline: Global Crossing Sharply Narrows Loss
abstract: Global Crossing Ltd reports second-quarter operating profit of $4 million; reports net loss narrowed to $4.2 million, from year-earlier $193 million (S)

headline: Don't Coddle Farmers. Buy Them Out.
abstract: Daniel Akst On the Contrary column, noting problems that farmers face as result of drought, holds Federal Government's continual agricultural bailouts are irrational; holds Government, instead of paying drought aid or crop support, should buy out farmers altogether; drawing (M)

headline: EASTERN, GAS UTILITY, MAY OFFER ITSELF FOR SALE
abstract: Eastern Enterprises says it might put all or part of itself up for sale to stay competitive in region's deregulating energy markets; hires Salomon Smith Barney to assist in process (S)

headline: NATO and Moscow Still Differ Over Where Russian Forces Will Be Stationed
abstract: NATO officials say Russia and NATO are still arguing about exactly where Russian peacekeepers should go in Kosovo and whose orders they should follow; say Russian negotiators, led by Vice Adm Valentin Kuznetsov, are insisting that their troops take orders only from Russian officers; say Russians want to station troops in Italian as well as French, American and German sectors; map (M)

headline: Tardy Kosovo Rebels Force Extension of Arms Deadline
abstract: Failure by Kosovo Liberation Army to turn in sufficient number of its heavy weapons, including mortars and antitank and antiaircraft guns, forces NATO commanders to extend deadline for compliance with a disarmament agreement; NATO officials say it is apparent that rebel commanders have hidden large stockpiles, and that peacekeepers fear growing divisions among rebels could lead to factional fighting; map (M)

headline: Global Food Fights: The Worst Are Yet to Come
abstract: David E Sanger Economic View column on disputes, for different reasons, between American and European farmers and World Trade Organization; next big round of global trade negotiations will center on politically sensitive farm subsidies and import restrictions on agricultural goods (M)

headline: Toll Now 19 in Swiss Canyon In an Adventure Gone Awry
abstract: Death toll rises to 19 in Swiss canyoning accident, as rescue workers search rapids for two missing tourists caught in flash flood in mountain stream near Interlaken, Switzerland; disaster has led to soul searching about adventure sports and in particular fad of canyoning; it is fueling questions about thin line between calculated risk and recklessness in most affluent sectors of society; Swiss authorities suspend all canyoning expeditions; map; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Why Big Firms Are Courting Day Traders
abstract: Some of nation's leading investment and securities firms have held talks in recent months with number of day-trading firms despite growing regulatory concern about world of day trading; Fidelity Investments, Lehman Brothers and Instinet, division of Reuters Group, have discussed adopting software platforms of day-trading firms, forming alliances with them or making outright acquisitions; electronic trading boom is forcing big firms to look for cheaper and more efficient trading formats; day-trading firms have critical experience developing and using advanced trading and trade-routing software, systems that could someday give all investors instant access to financial markets; Wall Street firms have little or no interest in computer-jammed offices where day traders converge to make rapid-fire trades; they want software and in some cases transaction volume generated by these smaller firms; Broadway Trading, Tradescape.com and Cybercorp, all privately held companies, have each been approached in recent months by companies interested in buying stake or acquiring firms; three firms decline to comment (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Jakarta Military Is Taking Central Role in Crisis
abstract: *Indonesia's army again emerges as central player in national crisis; with East Timor under martial law and with Pres B J Habibie's ability to control events there doubtful, fate of ravaged province rests more than ever with military and its supreme commander, Gen Wiranto; Wiranto insists that fresh troops can halt killing and looting in East Timor without outside help; but military experts say Wiranto is struggling to curb rogue field commanders, who fiercely opposed East Timor's recent independence vote and are taking their revenge by joining with local militias to reduce province to ashes; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GTE CORP. , the local phone company being acquired by Bell Atlantic, said it would buy back as many as 26 million shares to offset shares issued under employee benefit and dividend reinvestment programs.    CALPINE CORP.,  which owns stakes in power plants in 12 states, said it would buy the right to build a $350 million plant in Northern California from Enron Corp. for an undisclosed price.

headline: BIGGER JAPANESE SURPLUS
abstract: Japan's merchandise trade surplus widened in July, as decline in imports outstripped fall in exports; rising yen also pushed down cost of imports and crimped export earnings; surplus widened to 1.233 trillion yen ($10.7 billion), seasonally adjusted, from 1.055 trillion in June; imports fell 6.8 percent and exports declined eight-tenths of 1 percent; surplus shrank 4.6 percent, to 1.25 trillion yen, from year ago; graph (S)

headline: A Report That North Korea Has Plans to Test-Launch a Missile
abstract: North Korea confirms that it is prepared to test a missile, according to Yasushi Akashi, former United Nations Under Secretary General following a private trip to North Korea (S)

headline: CITY NATIONAL TO BUY PACIFIC BANK FOR $153 MILLION
abstract: City National Corp acquires Pacific Bank for $153 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Growing a Giant in the Vineyard
abstract: Profile of and interview with Canadaigua Brands Inc president and chief executive Richard Sands, who comments on recent acquisitions that have made it one of biggest wine and spirits companies in US; photo (M)

headline: At 'Little America' in Bonn, Lights Are Going Out
abstract: United States is closing its mission in Bonn after half a century there, and moving most operations to Germany's new capital, Berlin; Bonn had become one of most elaborate American diplomatic communities anywhere; one area of Bonn is referred to as Little America; situation will be far less cozy in Berlin than in Little America; photo; map (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar falls against Japanese yen on doubts that international finance officials meeting in Berlin will move to weaken Japanese currency; in New York, dollar settles at 110.73 yen, down from 111.56; graph; chart (S)

headline: STAFFMARK WEIGHING NEW DIRECTIONS
abstract: Staffmark Inc hires Credit Suisse First Boston to examine strategic alternatives; also says slower growth in its information-technology staffing business will adversely affect earnings for second half of 1999 (S)

headline: A Searchable C-Span For Politics Hounds
abstract: Web developers are angry at prospect of having to pay Unisys $5,000 for license to use image-file format that has become building block of Web, so-called GIF's; Unisys says license will be required only for Web sites that have valuation in the billions (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: STOCKS -- Jobless Rate in August Again Dipped to a 29-Year Low; Markets Rally, Reflecting Hope on Interest Rates
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average surges 235.24 points, or 2.17 percent, to 11,078.45; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbs 38.13 points, or 2.89 percent, to 1,357.24; Nasdaq composite index gains 108.87 points, or 3.98 percent, to 2,843.11; it is largest one-day point gain for Nasdaq ever; price of 30-year Treasury bond trades up 1 17/32, to 101 17/32; yield drops to 6.01 percent from 6.13 percent; graph on fluctuations in Dow Jones industrial average; charts on stocks with large price percentage gains and losses and US key interest rates; photo (M)

headline: Full Speed Ahead in Fog of Russian Economy, Bank of New York Hit a Shoal
abstract: Allegations of money laundering swirling around Bank of New York and FBI inquiry have thrown spotlight on hazards and rewards of banking in Russia; Bank of New York chmn Thomas A Renyi photo (M)

headline: Autonation to Shed Car Rental Businesses
abstract: H Wayne Huizenga says Autonation Inc will spin off or sell its struggling car rental businesses, which include National Car Rental and Alamo Rent-a-Car; denies plan is retreat, interview; says company hopes to contract to service and sell cars to car rental groups; says he acts to increase Autonation's share price; Autonation names Michael E Maroone president; seeks new chief executive to replace co-chief executives: Huizenga, who will remain chairman and Steven R Berrard, who is leaving management but will remain director; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Red hot pace of Internet stock trading cools off, pulling high flying on-line brokers back to earth.
abstract: Market Place column on easing of pace of Internet stock trading and decline in volume at high flying on-line stock brokers (M)

headline: Microsoft Says Worker Wrote Smear of Rival
abstract: Microsoft Corp acknowledges that one of its programmers apparently masqueraded as independent computer consultant earlier this week in effort to discredit America Online's tactics in companies' quarrel over instant messaging; Microsoft is unable to identify employee who forged E-mail message accusing America Online of irresponsible behavior; whoever did deed sent message to one computer security expert who is most likely to trace it back to Microsoft; bitter dispute has developed between Microsoft and America Online over instant on-line messaging; dispute began last month when Microsoft introduced clone of AOL Instant Messenger program, which permits computer users to chat over Internet with other computer users; America Online says Microsoft is making illegal use of proprietary directory information that is essential to connect instant messenger users via Internet; Microsoft disinformation incident came to light on Aug 11 when Richard Smith, president of Phar Lap Software and leading computer security expert, received E-mail message from someone identifying himself as Phil Bucking of Bucking Consulting; author suggested that he was developing his own instant messaging program and was studying America Online's tactics in blocking Microsoft users (M)

headline: Media Talk; Microsoft at Length in The New Yorker
abstract: New Yorker magazine's latest issue contains 23,000-word article by Ken Auletta on antitrust suit against Microsoft Corp, longest article by far published under new editor, David Remnick; Autletta portrays Microsoft chairman William H Gates more as angry adolescent than billionaire defendant; photo (M)
