headline: G.E.'s Quarterly Earnings Top Expectations
abstract: General Electric Co reports second-quarter earnings rose 15 percent, slightly beating analysts' expectations; posts earnings of $2.82 billion compared with $2.45 billion in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose 9.3 percent, to $27.4 billion from $25.1 billion (M)

headline: SYNOVUS FINANCIAL IS ACQUIRING HORIZON BANCSHARES
abstract: Synovus Financial Corp agrees to acquire Horizon Bancshares Inc for $19.4 million in stock (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen rises as optimism that Japan is recovering from slump raises demand for Japanese stocks and the yen to pay for them; in New York, dollar settles at 120.59 yen, down from 121.32; graph; chart (S)

headline: CHASE TO BUY MELLON BANK'S HOME MORTGAGE UNIT
abstract: Chase Manhattan Corp to buy Mellon Bank Corp's residential mortgage busines (S)

headline: HOOPER HOLMES TO BUY RIVAL COMPANY IN HEALTH TESTING
abstract: Hooper Holmes Inc acquires Paramedical Services of America, unit of Pediatric Services of America Inc, for as much as $95 million (S)

headline: Wireless TV Finally Gets Validation
abstract: Fortunes of small wireless cable companies, which provide television and high-speed data services using fixed, ground-based wireless links, have been tossed about by changing plans of telecommunications industry giants; industry participants at Wireless Communications Association International convention, New Orleans, see upswing; photo (M)

headline: G.M.-DAEWOO TALKS ADVANCE
abstract: General Motors Corp takes its first step toward alliance with car-making affiliate of debt-ridden Daewoo Group of South Korea; 20-member GM fact-finding mission begins assessing Daewoo Motor (S)

headline: On Newsstands In Britain, Beer and Babes Are in Decline
abstract: British laddie magazines, which use sex and hedonistic male behavior as marketing tools, are experiencing decline in circulation after five years of double-digit percentile growth; decline is occurring while appetite for men's life-style magazines in US seems far from sated; decline in circulation of some leading British publications discussed; phoros (M)

headline: An Anti-Milosevic Leader Tries for a Comeback
abstract: Zoran Djindjic, Yugoslav opposition figure, vows to push to oust Pres Slobodan Milosevic; photo (S)

headline: More Trouble With Rebates
abstract: Letter from Walter Gray on Sept 16 article on comsumers' problems getting their rebates after buying computers

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Dollar is little changed against yen, settling at 111.52 yen; euro rises to $1.0668; graphs (S)

headline: Rival Assemblies in Venezuela Reach a Shaky Accord
abstract: Agreement brokered by Roman Catholic Church averts, at least for now, dangerous political showdown bewteen Venezuelan Congress and rival Constitutional Assembly, which earlier stripped legislature of authority to enact laws; Congressional leaders give up plans for special session in defiance of decree, and assembly agrees to 'dialogue' with legislators (S)

headline: Gore, Playing Underdog, Wants Bradley to Debate
abstract: WASHINGTON—  Vice President Al Gore, in a tacit but surprising admission that his campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination was stumbling, on Wednesday challenged his fast-rising rival, former Senator Bill Bradley, to a series of debates.

headline: Morse Code Hams Let Their Fingers Do the Talking
abstract: Some amateur radio buffs belong to groups, or nets, that communicate only through Morse code; some of these nets have very restrictive admissions requirements; members share passion for Morse code and commitment to keeping it alive; Federal Communications Commission is proposing to reduce number of classes to obtain ham radio license, step that could reduce Morse code requirements in lower-level licenses; many Morse enthusiasts are disturbed, saying Morse remains fail-safe mode of communication in emergencies and should be required; photo (M)

headline: A Unified Europe Ends Most Duty-Free Shopping
abstract: Duty-free shopping ends within 15-nation European Union; European Union's decision to end such shopping was made eight years ago on basis that such sales skew Europe's vaunted single market; International Duty-Free Confederation, trade group made up mainly of airports and ferry companies, fought unsuccessfully to preserve system, arguing that more than 140,000 jobs in $6.5 billion annual business would be at risk; photos (M)

headline: Daewoo Is Given a New Set of Loans
abstract: Creditors of Daewoo Group release 2.6 trillion won of new loans, matching amount of old loans they called in; banks and insurers agree to provide further 1.4 trillion; South Korea's central bank says it is ready to support financial markets in attempt to avert nation's biggest bankruptcy; Daewoo plans talks with foreign banks on rescheduling $3 billion of debt maturing this year; worries about Daewoo continue to unnerve stock market, with main stock index falling another 3.5 percent (M)

headline: Keyboards for Tough Customers
abstract: Ryan Sheldon has designed wireless keyboard for bonobos, small apes, so they could use it to communicate with Sue Savage-Rumbaugh, scientist who has been trying to prove that animals are capable of developing language; Sheldon's wireless keyboard sends radio signals to computer that then 'speaks' the bonobos' words by playing recorded voice files in English; photo (M)

headline: CHIPSET UNIT SOLD
abstract: Via Technologies Inc of Taipei to acquire about half of National Semiconductor Corp's Cyrix microprocessor design unit for undisclosed price (S)

headline: So Easy, Even a Landlubber Can Do It
abstract: Global positioning devices, laptops and navigational software have made it easier for less experienced boaters to pilot sailboats and powerboats with more confidence; but experienced sailors and sailing organizations agree on dangers of overreliance on technology; note that one stray electron or one dead battery could put these devices out of commission; say boaters must still know how to navigate and read charts on their own; photos (M)

headline: EXCITE@HOME AND COX UNIT ARE INVESTING IN TICKETS.COM
abstract: Excite at Home Corp and Cox Interactive Media, unit of Cox Enterprises Inc, say they will invest $85 million in Tickets.com Inc (S)

headline: Paradyne Stock Triples
abstract: Paradyne Networks Inc stock more than triples its offering price in first day of trading (S)

headline: Qwest's Deal For U S West Appears Set
abstract: US West Inc board meets to approve what is being called merger of equals with Qwest Communications International Inc, long-distance communications carrier, in deal valued at more than $30 billion; as result of deal, resolution of Qwest's battle against Global Crossing Ltd, to acquire US West and Frontier Corp, will probably begin to take shape (M)

headline: Merger in Britain Creates Largest Publisher
abstract: Trinity PLC, Britain's largest regional newspaper company, announces decision to acquire Mirror Group PLC for equivalent of about $2 billion; deal will create largest newspaper publishing company in Britain (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: G.M. to Lift Texas Output
abstract: General Motors Corp will build its next-generation, full-size sports utility vehicles at its truck assembly plant in Arlington, Tex; will increase its investment in plant by $70 million, to about $500 million, raising its capacity by 50 percent (S)

headline: A Small Flotilla Sets Sail For Mission in East Timor
abstract: a small flotilla sets sail for mission in east

headline: In Remote Dagestan, Moscow Wages a High-Stakes War
abstract: Russian forces decisively again drive thousands of Islamic extremist troops out of Dagestan and back to bases in neighboring Chechnya; launch air and artillery strikes on guerrilla bases in Chechnya; Chechen rebel leaders reportedly threaten to extend random bombings in Russia to other targets until Russian troops leave Dagestan; Russia views Dagestan as strategic asset whose loss would accelerate disintergration of its Capsian Sea provinces; Dagestanis look to Russia for protection; extremist warlords who effectively run Chechnya view Dagestan as prize worth fighting for and can force Russia to pay extremely high price to keep province; map (M)

headline: Locking the Door
abstract: Mike Sandman letter offers tip to users of high-speed Internet connections for protecting security (July 8 article)

headline: Media Talk; Parody of Talk Magazine Upsets Disney
abstract: Michael Colton, staff writer at Brill's Content magazine, has posted Web site parodying Talk magazine, forthcoming Hearst Magazines and Miramax venture edited by Tina Brown; Miramax, Walt Disney Co unit, complained to Earthlink, site's Internet service provider, which shut down site; Earthlink restored site after Brown intervened; photo (M)

headline: Survivors Lead a Chorus of Demands to Punish the Builders
abstract: Earthquake survivors in Turkey turn their anger not at nature, but at builders of high-rise death traps; in Yalova, seaside resort near Istanbul, relatives and neighbors of victims burn car and stone house of local contractor, 7 of whose 16 buildings collapsed when earthquake hit; builder, who once boasted in an interview that he was able to provide affordable housing by using cheap materials, ducks his attackers and slips away; Interior Min Saddetin Tantan joins chorus, promising to bring harsh punishment against builders of shoddy housing and their friends in local city halls (M)

headline: Chopping Down a Limb Before Investors Fall Off
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column on move by Charles Schwab to limit number of stocks it allows its customers to buy on margin; graph (M)

headline: A Bully Pulpit to Restore Lost African Icons
abstract: a bully pulpi

headline: Otto A. Silha, 80, a Publisher Of a Minnesota Newspaper
abstract: Otto A Silha, onetime copy editor and newspaper marketer who became president and publisher of The Minneapolis Star and Tribune in 1970's and after retiring in 1984 underwrote a program in media ethics at University of Minnesota, dies at age 80; photo (M)

headline: Virtual Ink Narrows Review to 6 Agencies
abstract: Virtual Ink Corp narrows its review to six advertising agencies for account of business technologies software company; estimated billings are $5 million to $8 million (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro falls to record level against dollar after unexpected drop in German industrial production pushes currency lower; in New York, euro settles at $1.0148, down from $1.0176; graph; chart (S)

headline: Morgan Stanley and U.S. Panel Given Deadline on Case Dispute
abstract: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and Equal Employment Opportunity Commission are given two weeks to resolve dispute over whether company must produce all information the Federal agency has subpoenaed in gender-discrimination case; suit stems from complaint by bond saleswoman Alison K Schieffelin, who says she was denied promotion to managing director because she is woman (S)

headline: McKesson Sets Costly Charges In Restatement
abstract: McKesson HBOC Inc will cut $327.4 million from its revenue for last three fiscal years to correct accounting irregularities at HBO and Co, software maker it acquired in January; will cut $191.5 million from operating income for last three fiscal years and will not meet analysts' earnings expectations for first quarter, ended June 30; McKesson earned $84.9 million after special items in fiscal year ended March 31, 1999, down from original report of $237.1 million (M)

headline: The Casino Effect in Asian Stock Markets
abstract: Asian markets are soaring despite widely held view among financial experts that collusion, corruption and financial bungling that contributed to Asia's economic troubles have merely been diluted, not eradicated; some analysts say soaring Asian equity markets are not vote of economic confidence, but rather symptom of continuing financial gridlock that has turned these markets into corporate casinos for skeptical Asian savers and skittish Asian banks; big gains in Asian stock indexes are helping to obscure just how much value corporate Asian has lost; graph (M)

headline: Microsoft Issues a First Repair For Office 97 Security Flaw
abstract: Microsoft Corp releases partial corrective for security flaw that appears when its Office 97 group of programs is installed with most versions of its Internet browser; says it tests better solution (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: State Securities Regulators Urge Day-Trading Changes  Many day-trading firms use deceptive marketing practices to lure customers into a stock trading strategy that will probably cause them to lose money, and then they help to keep them trading by arranging what could be illegal loans, according to the North American Securities Administrators Association, a group of state regulators.    In a report, the regulators urged the firms to do a better job of screening potential customers and to disclose more fully the risks. The group also asked national regulators to step up their enforcement of trading rules and to ban some of the day-trading industry's most common lending practices. [Page A1.]

headline: CRYSTAL GAS SHARES CLIMB AS SALE IS STUDIED
abstract: Shares in Crystal Gas Storage Inc rise 15 percent after company says it hired Goldman Sachs Group Inc as financial advisor to help it find ways to raise its share price and that is considering selling itself (S)

headline: As U.S. Relations With U.N. Languish at a Low Point, Is Clinton or Congress to Blame?
abstract: Diplomats, senior United Nations officials and foreign policy analysts say relations between US and UN are at one of their lowest points in years, with many blaming Clinton Administration and Congress for growing tensions; criticize Congress for refusing to pay UN $1.6 billion in back dues; say it is hostile to many UN initiatives that command wide support within international community, and blame Pres Clinton for letting relationship deteriorate (M)

headline: F.B.I. Finishes Examining Sites
abstract: Federal Bureau of Investigations agents in Kosovo complete examination of two burial sites, Djakovica; find many of victims died of gunshot wounds to head; findings support accusations in international war crimes tribunal's indictment of Pres Slobodan Milosevic; FBI team prepares to return to United States (M)

headline: Prosecutor Tells Lockerbie Relatives He'll Keep Trial Nonpolitical
abstract: Approximately 200 relatives of people killed in bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over, Lockerbie, Scotland, nearly 11 years ago are assured by Scottish officials that two Libyan suspects will be prosecuted vigorously and without regard to political considerations; assurances by Lord Hardie, Scotland's senior law officer, comes at meeting arranged by US Justice Dept to brief relatives on case; trial of suspects Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi and Lamen Khalifa Fhimah will begin in February 2000 and will take place in Netherlands under Scottish law (M)

headline: John R. Philip, 72, Environmental Scientist
abstract: Dr John Robert Philip, one of Australia's foremost environmental scientists, was struck by car and killed in Amsterdam June 26, at age 72 (S)

headline: Computer Shock
abstract: Letter from Norman Kiell, commenting on July 1 article on Dr Edwin Rothman's ordealin setting up computer, claims computer is not just for young, but for rising aging population; photo

headline: I Link, Therefore I Am: a Web Intellectual's Diary
abstract: Heather Anne Halpert, software designer, maintains diary of ephemera on Web; her stream-of-consciousness narrative is one of her site's most compelling aspects; she says she tries for balance between personal tidbits and purely intellectual ruminations; she does not track number of visitors to her site, but says she gets constant flow of E-mail from people around the world who want to tell her about their own daily encounters; photo (M)

headline: Vote for Me, Declares Argentine, I'm Boring
abstract: Mayor Fernando de la Rua of Buenos Aires, running for president of Argentina, takes every opportunity to contrast himself with Pres Carlos Saul Menem and to tie his principal opponent, Buenos Aires Gov Eduardo Duhalde, to departing President and his glitzy style of politics; de la Rua's campaign offers few detailed proposals, but blandness appears to be winning message at time of mounting Government scandals, street crime and unemployment; de la Rua has gaping lead in polls with just month to go before Oct 24 vote (M)

headline: A Well-Known Face Is Taking to the Streets
abstract: George Stephanopoulos, former White House aide, will add to his role at ABC-TV by doing political commentaries on streets of New York; photo (M)

headline: Bringing Good Things to Fiat?
abstract: Profile of Paolo Fresco, 66, Italian who retired from General Electric after nearly four decades, having reached post as vice chairman under John F Welch Jr; Fresco hopes to bring some lessons learned from Welch to his post as chairman as Fiat SpA, which he took 14 months ago; photos; graphs; charts (M)

headline: Gauging the Reach Of Lower Commissions
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission review of stock-trading practices at number of mutual fund companies finds that commissions have not dropped as much as individual stock-trading commissions since advent of online brokerage firms and electronic trading networks (S)

headline: AIRLINE CHAIRMAN RESIGNS
abstract: Chiang Hung-i submits his resignation as chairman of China Airlines, four days after one of carrier's planes crashes in Hong Kong, killing two people and injuring 211 others; move comes after Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Feng-cheng calls for airline's senior management to resign; photo (S)

headline: Numico Seeks Food Concern
abstract: Royal Numico NV offers to buy General Nutrition Cos for $1.77 billion and assumption of $760 million in debt (M)

headline: U S West to Talk With Qwest
abstract: Board of US West agrees to allow management and its advisers to enter into preliminary merger talks with Qwest Communications International Inc; move is important development for Qwest, which is trying to buy not only US West but Frontier Corp; those two companies have already agreed to be acquired by Global Crossing Ltd (M)

headline: Telling Them What They'll Pay to Hear
abstract: Daniel Akst On the Contrary column questions why so many companies are turning to outside management consultants to tell them how to run their businesses; drawing (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Cutting Through Fog of Growth for Net Retailers
abstract: Internet retailiers boast of fast growth in revenues and customers; but if total revenues for each quarter are divided by total customers, companies appear to be losing ground; small group of renegade skeptics are taking E-tailers' numbers--total revenues for quarter and total customer base--and dividing one by the other; results go straight down; figures for Amazon.com, CDNow and Ebay discussed; graph (Market Place column) (M)

headline: INVACARE BIDS FOR DANISH MEDICAL EQUIPMENT MAKER
abstract: Invacare Corp makes 945 billion Danish kroner ($131 million) bid for Scandinavian Mobility International (S)

headline: FUGITIVE SELLS STAKE
abstract: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc gains control of CEI Citicorp Holdings SA, acquiring 39 million shares, or about 8 percent, from fugitive executive Raul Moneta's companies for $125 million to increase its stake to 41 percent (S)

headline: FRENCH-GERMAN STRENGTH
abstract: Widely watched monthly survey of business confidence in Germany by IFO Institute for Economic Research rose nearly two percentage points in August, more than many economists had expected; in France, Government reports exports surged 4.5 percent in July, fueled in part by rising sale of Airbus planes (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar rises aginst euro as US financial markets exhibit confidence in Federal Reserve's steps to control inflation; in New York, euro settles at $1.0425, down from $1.0529; graph; chart (S)

headline: In East Timor, Decisive Vote For a Break From Indonesia
abstract: United Nations reports that people of East Timor have rejected with a vote of 78.5 percent Indonesian Government's offer of a new autonomous status, opting instead to become an independent nation; Pres B J Habibie says he accepts the results of referendum and calls on his forces in East Timor to uphold law, security, safety and public order; violence that has swept through territory since the vote threatens to plunge the new state into civil war; photo; map (M)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; BUFETE DEADLINE LOOMS
abstract: Bufete Industrial SA has only six days left before payment of $100 million bond issue is due; it has given no hint about how it will refinance debt (S)

headline: A combined Viacom-CBS would cast an awfully large shadow across a wide range of ad media.
abstract: Advertising executives comment on planned Viacom Inc-CBS Corp merger, which would unite many powerful media brands under single ownership; some warn it will reduce advertisers' clout; expect further media mergers spurred by relaxation of rules meant to limit concentration of ownership of TV stations in local markets (M)

headline: ISRAEL COURT BANS MOST USE OF FORCE IN INTERROGATIONS
abstract: Israeli Supreme Court, in watershed ruling, unexpectedly outlaws routine use of physically coercive interrogation methods by security services which critics have long denounced as torture; not only rules interrogation methods are illegal, but immediately orders Govt to stop using them; ruling is praised by Israeli civil rights officials, but Prime Min Ehud Barak says it could be problematic; Barak says way must be found to allow for interrogation that could thwart bomb attacks and save lives; Govt has long aruged that forceful interrogations are legal and desirable tools for extracting information to prevent attacks; say techniques, such as violent shaking of upper torso, do not constitute torture, but are emergency methods used on suspects who may have knowledge of 'ticking bomb' (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: British Telecom Ordered To Open Network to Rivals  Already under pressure from rival telephone and cable operators, British Telecommunications, which controls about 85 percent of the ''local loop'' copper network used by home subscribers and small businesses, was ordered by regulators to upgrade its network and open it to competitors by July 2001.    The directive reflects the rapidly intensifying competition in Europe to offer high-speed Internet access and other broadband services. But it also highlights the difficult situation facing the former state monopoly: competition is likely to accelerate the growth of the high-speed market, but it could also reduce British Telecommunications' slice of it. [Page C5.]

headline: AMATIL STAKE TO BE SOLD
abstract: Philippines-based San Miguel Corp plans to sell its stake in Coca-Cola Amatil Ltd (S)

headline: Renewed Fears About Rate Increases Send Shares Lower
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 44.32 points, to 11,034.13; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 6.79 points, to 1,350.45; Nasdaq composite index drops 5.85 points, to 2,837.26; graph; tables (M)

headline: PUBLISHER'S EARNINGS DROP
abstract: Reed Elsevier PLC, British-Dutch publishing giant, reports first-half pretax earnings fell 10 percent, to $601 million; says it foresees no likelihood of earnings increases in the second half (S)

headline: Bangkok May Ban King's Biography
abstract: BANGKOK—  Sales of the first biography written by a foreigner about King Bhumibol Adulyadej of Thailand with extensive cooperation of the monarch himself are being "strongly discouraged" by Thai authorities who say the book will likely soon be banned.

headline: Carnival Orders New Ship
abstract: Carnival Cruise Lines orders liner, to be called Carnival Pride, from Kvaerner MasaYards of Helsinki, Finland; sister ship, Carnival Spirit, is under construction there (S)

headline: Mercedes Dealers Award Account
abstract: Mercedes-Benz Retailers of Southern California names Merkley Newman Harty to handle its advertising account, which had been handled by Yellow Card; billings estimated at $10 million (S)

headline: Britain Says Ta-Ta To Old Phone Numbers
abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin Business World column on major makeover of British telephone numbering system as demand for cell phones, Internet lines, fax machines and other modern conveniences continues to escalate; many small business owners complain about expenses involved in changing over to new system, which takes effect on April 22, 2000; photos; chart (M)

headline: Miniature Pinball With Buzz, And a Bunch of Apes on the Run
abstract: Pokemon Pinball and Ape Escape are two innovative new games for Nintendo Game Boy and Sony Playstation systems respectively; photo (S)

headline: MCI Points Finger at Lucent For Recent Network Woes
abstract: MCI Worldcom Inc's chief executive Bernard J Ebbers, in first public comment on 10-day breakdown of data network, says company plans to offer each of as many as 3,000 customers who were affected by problems up to 20 days of free service; Ebbers tries to shift responsibility for problem to Lucent Technologies, and Lucent--which wells MCI Worldcom hundreds of millions of dollar worth of products every year--accepts it; some of MCI Worldcom's customers have been scathing in their attacks on company; some analysts point out that network debacle raised unflattering questions about MCI Worldcom's policies for handling such situations, especially in light of AT&T's speed in dealing with similar problem last year (M)

headline: Proliferation of Passwords
abstract: Letter from Gordon Brott comments on Aug 5 article on abundance of passwords on Internet

headline: Disney to Join Operations Of Studio and ABC Units
abstract: Walt Disney Co becomes first large Hollywood production studio to put its operations under same umbrella as television network when it announces that it will consolidate its television entertainment divisions into one unit; unit, to be named ABC Entertainment Television Group, will absorb functions previously performed by Walt Disney Television Studio, which had been production arm independent of ABC network, which Disney also owns; move is expected to increase efficiency and cut costs; main goal is to establish vertically integrated entity that will guarantee that more programs owned by Disney are placed on ABC's prime-time schedule; networks are pressing to own as much programming as possible to generate new revenue sources to offset declining audiences and rising program costs; new unit will be headed by co-chairmen Lloyd Braun and Stuart Bloomberg; executives stress ABC Entertainment president Jamie Tarses will also have increased role, as she also participates more directly in development of shows for network (M)

headline: Business School Puts Courses In Hands of an On-Line Market
abstract: Students at University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Business may register for elective courses on Wharton's course auction Web site (S)

headline: Financial Executive at Iridium Resigns
abstract: Iridium LLC, which filed for bankruptcy protection last month, says Leo Mondale has resigned as chief financial officer; names David Gibson as interim chief financial officer (S)

headline: BOTTOM IN BRITISH RATES
abstract: Further cuts in British interest rates, now at 22-year low, seem unlikely after release of minutes of Bank of England policy-making committee meeting on July 8; panel voted without dissent to keep banchmark rate unchanged at 5 percent; graph (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.00   8.00   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.94   5.09   5.50        3-month T-bills   4.56   4.53   4.92        6-month T-bills   4.56   4.52   4.98        10-yr. T-infl.   4.02   4.02   3.76        10-yr. T-note   5.80   5.84   5.48        30-yr. T-bond   6.01   6.03   5.74        Telephone bd.   7.75   7.78   7.16        Municipal bds.   5.53   5.53   5.26          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer

headline: A Rival Bid for National Westminster Is Expected Shortly
abstract: Royal Bank of Scotland Group is expected to make an offer of about $41 billion for National Westminster Bank, for which Bank of Scotland has offered more than $34 billion; Abbey National reportedly also weighs a bid for Natwest (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Are the cash levels of emerging-market mutual funds telling a cautionary tale?
abstract: Market Place column on low level of cash in emerging-market mutual funds; says mutual funds that invest in emerging markets now have lowest levels of cash on hand in three years that records for these funds have been kept; Investment Company Institute says at end of June--most recent reading--funds had cash equal to 3.9 percent of their assets, or less than $700 million; holds redemptions suggest that fund managers have little money left to invest in stocks and to fuel rally in emerging markets, and that they may even have felt pressure in recent weeks to sell stocks to meet investor redemptions; graph (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Wild Ascent Of a Small-Cap Stock, Perhaps By Mistake
abstract: Market Place column on wild ascent of stock of ABR Information Services, which more than tripled on June 30, soaring as high as $100 a share on what appears to have been colossal mistake; says in next three weeks, few hundred shares of ABR that are still in circulation will be worth no more than $25.50 each in cash because of company's acquisition by Ceridian Corp; theories on how stock, part of Russell 2000 index, tripled discussed (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Soybeans rise 2 percent after report shows that torrid weather in July did more damage than had been expected; in Chicago, soybeans for November delivery jumped 9.25 cents, to $4.7275 a bushel; graph; chart (S)

headline: U.S. Cancels Military Aides' Visit to Taiwan
abstract: Pres Clinton says he will cancel planned visit to Taiwan by Pentagon officials to avoid heightening tensions between Taiwan and China, news conference; will instead send diplomatic envoys to Taiwan and China to spur peaceful resolution of dispute over Taiwan's status (M)

headline: Indian Report Blames Individual In Killing of Missionary and Sons
abstract: India releases summary of judicial probe that found Jan killing of Australian missionary Graham Staines and his two young sons by frenzied mob in Manoharpur was spurred by individual and not by any Hindu right-wing group associated with governing party; Judge D P Wadhwa found Dara Singh, Hindu chauvinist fanatic, egged on youths in village of Manoharpur, saying Christian missionaries were destroying Hinduism; Singh reportedly is hiding in forests under villagers' protection (M)

headline: Postal Service Stops Ad With Cigarette
abstract: United States Postal Service pulls ad showing woman holding cigarette after American Lung Association and other public health groups protest (S)

headline: People
abstract: Michael Gross, regional financial director at J Walter Thompson North America, is named to new position of chief operating officer at J Walter Thompson, New York; Stephen Kuehn succeeds Gross; Michael Sheehan is named to new position of executive vice president and executive creative director at DDB Chicago; John Doig is named creative director at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos Inc; Jim McCabe, vice president for advertising sales, is named publisher at Worth magazine, succeeding Missy Godfrey; Jason Lundy, strategic director at Esquire magazine, is named to new position of director of marketing and strategic planning (S)

headline: Assad Stands Firm on Conditions for Restarting Talks
abstract: State Sec Madeleine K Albright meets in Syria with Pres Hafez al-Assad; Clinton Administration aide says meeting will not lead to immediate resumption of Israeli-Syrian peace talks, but lays groundwork for new talks; says Assad sticks to demand that Israel recognize 1967 border before talks resume; Albright visits Beirut, Lebanon, in effort to show that time is right to widen peace effort to include Syria and Lebanon and that Lebanese Government makes strides in normalizing daily life; meets with Prime Min Selim Hoss and calls for resumption of Israeli-Lebanese talks; photo (M)

headline: More Trouble With Rebates
abstract: Letter from Manuel Mendez says consumers do not get back sales tax when they are issued rebate by manufacturer

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Big Advertisers Turning To Their Own Magazines  While advertisers like Sony, Philip Morris, Mercedes-Benz and Starbucks used to press magazines to mention their products in the editorial pages, they have now adopted a more sophisticated approach, creating magazines in which they control the mix of feature articles and product placement.    Custom published magazines are either sold on newsstands, given out at stores or sent to a list of customers. The magazine publisher is almost always guaranteed a profit because, to the corporate sponsor, the magazine is a marketing tool intended for one purpose alone -- to reach the consumer -- and losses are counted as marketing expenses. [Page C6.]

headline: 2 Leaders Seal Their Bond at a German Crime Scene
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak, visiting Germany, tours site of Nazi concentration camp in Sachsenhausen with Chancellor Gerhard Schroder; they pledge to stand together against intolerance; map; photo (M)

headline: Basic E-Mail Service, Cheap and Lightweight
abstract: Vtech Industries will introduce two lightweight and simple-to-use devices that allow user access to E-mail through telephone connection, without need of computer; photo (S)

headline: Banque Nationale Merger Bid Seems Only Partly Successful
abstract: Banque Nationale de Paris chairman Michel Pebereau says he is certain of gaining control over Paribas; stops short of claiming Banque Nationale will gain clear control over Societe Generale (M)

headline: Of Technology And Turnover
abstract: Michelle Cottle Working column answers question on steps that managers and business owners can take to attract and retain computer technicians (M)

headline: People
abstract: Della Femina/Jeary & Partners names Don Morrison executive director for media services, new post (S)

headline: Cisco Systems' 50% Sales Gain Helps It Top Earnings Estimates
abstract: Cisco Systems Inc reports nearly 50 percent gain in its fourth-quarter sales and earnings, beating Wall Street estimates; reports pro forma earnings, excluding acquisition-related charges, of $727 million, up 38 percent from $525 million a year earlier; sales rose 48 percent, to $3.55 billion, compared with $2.40 billion a year earlier; for the year, Cisco had earnings of $2.10 billion compared with $1.35 billion for fiscal 1998 (M)

headline: The Digital Brain Drain; So Many Computers, So Little Interest in Hard Science
abstract: Computer science as specialty is growing in popularity among American students entering college and those in graduate school, while interest in most traditional sciences and engineering is on the wane; experts worry that vocational schools will soon churn out too many computer repair people and too few refrigerator technicians; they worry even more that universities will produce scads of people who can use computers as research and calculating tools but far too few who can use scientific method to solve problems; they are concerned that prospect of quick wealth will lure bright students who might have become research scientists--or science teachers and professors--into joining Internet ventures instead; graphs; photo (M)

headline: An Advertising Power, but Just What Does Doubleclick Do?
abstract: Randall Rothenberg profile of Doubleclick, rapidly growing company devoted to making advertising work on Internet; firm, whose clients include ad agencies, media companies and marketers, sells ad space for 490 Internet publishers worldwide; uses system that delivers ads from central location to different Web sites, altering what ads user sees to conform to user's location and demographic characteristics; photo (M)

headline: Moneyline's New Look; Yes, Willow Bay Is an Ex-Model, but One With an M.B.A.
abstract: CNN's recent choice of Willow Bay to co-anchor Moneyline News Hour, its most lucrative show, reflects her career shift from entertainment to business news; former model has MBA degree; graph of show's ratings; photos (M)

headline: Clinton Favors Broad Rights In Palestinians' Resettlement
abstract: Pres Clinton says that Palestinian refugees should be able to settle 'wherever they want to live,' startling Israeli officials with what appears to be significant shift in American policy on one of Middle East's most contentious issues; but White House and State Dept officials say that Clinton did not intend any change in policy (M)

headline: It's Test Time for N.T.T.'s Global Ambitions
abstract: Interview with Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Co head Junichiro Miyazu on new law that reshapes NTT and lets it compete directly overseas for first time; he hopes to transform Japanese giant into global player, setting up operations around world and taking stakes in companies that provide services related to Internet and telecommunications; business plan seems oblivious to market principles; critics charge restructuring, which confirms NTT's monopoly on local calls, will hobble Japanese competition in global telecommunications; photo (M)

headline: Rushmore to Buy Two Day-Trading Firms
abstract: Rushmore Financial Group Inc will buy day-trading firms Millennium Daqcom/Dallas LP and Daqcom International LLC (S)

headline: Ford Executive Will Retire at End of Year
abstract: Ross Roberts, Ford Motor Co executive who has tried to streamline company's dealer network, will retire at end of year; no successor named (S)

headline: NEWS WATCH
abstract: New Grove Dictionary of Opera on line features full-text searches of more than 11,000 articles and detailed essays on more than 1,800 operas and external links to performers and opera houses (S)

headline: Mahaheng Amatsho Journal; Seer's Life: Win a Few, Lose a Few, Take an Aspirin
abstract: Interview with Mmatsepo, healer and spiritual counselor accorded much reverence in Lesotho, where she is seer to kings; she mixes traditionalism with modernism; map; photo (M)

headline: Strains With North Korea Ease, but Clouds Hover
abstract: US and North Korean officials will meet for talks in Berlin on September 7 that US says are aimed at emphasizing to North Korea advantages of toning down its threatening behavior, in particular of shelving plan to test long-range missile; talks come as North Korean Govt has made sudden conciliatory moves after weeks of tensions over plans for missile test (M)

headline: SONY IS SHUTTING NORTH AMERICAN WIRELESS PHONE UNIT
abstract: Sony Corp is shutting its North American wireless phone business and dismissing about 200 employees (S)

headline: Swiss Step Up Their Scrutiny On Transfers Of Big Money
abstract: Swiss police authorities report sharp increase in number of reports of suspected money laundering under new law mandating stricter accountability by banks (S)

headline: BRITISH UNEMPLOYMENT FALLS
abstract: British Government says unemployment fell to 19-year low of 4.2 percent in August, from 4.3 percent in July; also says wage growth increased to 4.6 percent between May and July from 4.4 percent in previous three months; graph (S)

headline: Stocks Slump As Investors Take Profits
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average loses 125.70 points, or 1.13 percent, to close at 10,991.38; Nasdaq composite index is down 13.49 points, or five-tenths of 1 percent, to 2,657.73; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 11.32 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,332.84; graph; chart (M)

headline: Wunderman Cato Trims Its Staff
abstract: Wunderman Cato Johnson dismisses about 50 employees at its New York headquarters; attributes dismissals to strategic restructuring that includes elimination of 100 employees overseas and closing of one overseas office (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen rises and dollar closes at 116.55 yen, down from 116.70; graphs; chart (S)

headline: A Step Toward a Versatile High-Definition VCR
abstract: At least three different formats and technologies for recording high-definition television broadcasts are competing in research laboratories and product development studios around world; most companies are waiting to see which high-definition VCR technology will dominate market as digital television becomes mainstream product in years ahead; format war seems inevitable; Panasonic Corp is first to offer entry-level product; photo (M)

headline: Soweto Journal; Where Apartheid Ruled, Tourists Are Swarming
abstract: Tourists are flocking to Soweto, black township that helped set off final battles against apartheid in South Africa; photo; map (M)

headline: ASSOCIATES FIRST CAPITAL BUYS CREDIT CARD PORTFOLIO
abstract: Associates First Capital Corp agrees to purchase $120 million private-label credit card portfolio from Citgo Petroleum Corp for undisclosed amount; will acquire credit card loans of Citgo and issue, process and service oil company's 1.3 million accounts (S)

headline: Defense Dept. Urges Industry To Cooperate With Europe
abstract: Defense Department, concerned that European NATO forces lagged United States forces in technology during Kosovo conflict, is shifting policy to encourage trans-Atlantic mergers and joint ventures in military industry; is beginning direct talks with European allies and major contractors in Europe; Under Sec Jacques Gansler says Kosovo has shown that US must be more willing to share technology with allies and they must be more willing to guard secrets (M)

headline: In the Internet Gold Rush, Fund Customers Find a Research Treasure
abstract: Article assesses advantages gained by Internet-accessible mutual fund companies and their online customers over past two years; many no-load fund groups, hoping to retain customers, have opened their own online brokerage firms; self-directed investors now have wealth of research available at their fingertips; drawing; graph (M)

headline: A Web Site That Shows How Your New Gadget Works
abstract: E-Sim posts Web site to enable consumer electronics manufacturers to generate simulations of their new and popular products; its Live Manuals site is designed to permit new and prospective product owners to sample features and learn how to use them; photo (S)

headline: Stresses of Milosevic's Rule Blamed for Decline in Births
abstract: Serbian women in unprecedented numbers are deciding not to have children, primiarly because of anxiety about the war in Kosovo, fear of civil war in Serbia and unwillingness to raise children in a nation whose standard of living has declined every year for the past decade; abortion rate appears to be rising sharply and increasing numbers of young women are telling doctors they do not want to give birth; photo; map (M)

headline: Mortar Attacks in Kosovo Kill 2 Serbs and Increase Tensions
abstract: Two Serbs are killed and four hurt in mortar attack on Serbian village of Donja Budriga, Kosovo; mortar attack on Petrovic reportedly wounds two Serbs; United Nations police, who slowly arrive to take over civilian policing and law enforcement from NATO forces, are seen as key to containing crime wave sweeping Kosovo and forcing many ethnic Serbs and minorities to flee (M)

headline: Times Company Replaces Publisher at Boston Globe
abstract: New York Times Co announces that senior vice president Richard H Gilman has moved to Boston to succeed Benjamin B Taylor as publisher of The Boston Globe, member of family that ran paper for 126 years; Gilman headed Times's circulation department in New York; Taylor will remain chairman of Globe Newspaper Company board; shift comes several months after Sunday circulation and high-margin help-wanted advertising revenue began experiencing declines; Times Co chairman Arthur Sulzberger Jr praises Taylor and says Gilman will be outstanding publisher during time of rapid change in news industry; Taylor does not specifically address questions about change; photo (M)

headline: A New German Assertiveness On Its Foreign Policy Stance
abstract: Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, marking break with caution of German foreign policy since World War II, has laid out new vision of his country's international role, describing Germany as 'great power in Europe' that will not hestitate to pursue its national interests; new definition of German foreign policy appears to signal formal end of Germany's self-imposed reserve even as it underscores country's irreversible attachment to NATO and European Union; Schroder photo (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    NORTHERN IRELAND: FOCUSING ON PEACE  Former Senator George J. Mitchell will conduct a ''tightly focused'' review of the halted Northern Ireland peace settlement, Prime Minister Tony Blair said. Mr. Mitchell will meet with party leaders in Belfast this week, then break for August and resume talks in September. The parties failed to meet a deadline last week for starting up the new assembly that divides power between Catholics and Protestants because of an impasse over guerrilla disarmament.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: Summer Gas Prices Rise in U.S., Continuing Trend
abstract: Analysts and Energy Department survey report that gasoline prices this summer are continuing upward trend begun earlier in year when oil-producing nations cut supplies; graphs (M)

headline: ON MY... BOOKMARKS: JOHN J. BRENNAN
abstract: Vanguard Group chief executive John J Brennan describes his computer Web site bookmarks; photo; list (S)

headline: Star Power?
abstract: S Abraham Ravid letter on June 13 article on changing economics of movie making

headline: SURGE COMPONENTS DROPS PLAN TO BUY ORBIT NETWORKS
abstract: Surge Components Inc cancels plans to buy Orbit Networks Inc, saying Orbit could not meet terms of earlier agreement; transaction was valued at $66 million when it was announced in December (S)

headline: CNN Executive Stays on Top After a Year Of Upheavals
abstract: CNN/USA president Richard N Kaplan has survived year of both on-air and personal challenges, including Tailwind false reporting incident and departure of Moneyline anchor Lou Dobbs; Kaplan and CNN chairman Tom Johnson are planning revamp of Newsstand; photos; critics inside CNN say Kaplan still has not come up with overall plan to raise CNN's ratings during slower news periods (M)

headline: Aetna Shares Fall on Doubts Over Health Unit
abstract: Doubts that Aetna Inc got its billion dollar's worth when it bought Prudential health care business last year send Aetna shares tumbling more than 12 percent in last two days; plunge follows complaints by Wall Street analysts that Aetna failed at meeting with investors on Sept 27 to explain how deal would deliver immediate increases in profits that Aetna had projected (M)

headline: Ford is starting a big campaign to establish a common image for its sport utility vehicles.
abstract: Ford Motor Co plans one of largest advertising campaigns ever in auto industry to establish common brand image for its ever-growing family of sport utility vehicles; will start advertising vehicles as group, as well as individually, with separate new slogan (M)

headline: A Degree, And a Stake To Grow On
abstract: Article on Bruce Schneider who, year after presenting business plan to group of venture capitalists, is about to receive $250,000 investment from Columbia University Business School to open Schneider Vineyards in Cutchogue, NY; photo (M)

headline: Alexander Farkas, 69, Ex-Head of New York Discount Retailer
abstract: Alexander S Farkas, former Alexander's department store chain president, dies at age 69; photo (M)

headline: BRITISH RATE ANXIETIES
abstract: Bank of England policy makers decide to leave British interest rates unchanged at 22-year low of 5 percent; British stocks drop on fears that British rates are likely to rise later this year (S)

headline: Grey Acquires Data-Base Company
abstract: Grey Direct, marketing arm of Grey Advertising, acquires Marketdata Solutions, which offers data-base marketing services; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: Mines and NATO Bombs Still Killing in Kosovo
abstract: Aid agencies in Kosovo report casualties from mines and unexploded bombs are soaring to alarming levels; say volatile British- and American-made cluster bombs have been found in almost every part of province and have caused some terrible accidents; mines were planted by Yugoslav Army and Albanian guerrillas during yearlong war before NATO bombing; as death toll rises, recriminations are growing over NATO's use of cluster bombs; those clearing mines find far greater presence of mines than they had expected; in Kosovo, there is widespread ignorance about danger of cluster bombs; World Health Orgn reports 130 to 170 people were injured or killed in bomb and mine accidents between June 13 and July 12; photo (M)

headline: Treasuries Set for Auction During Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and a 52-week bill being auctioned on Tuesday.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 4.60 percent and the rate on the six-month issue at 4.87 percent. The rate for the 52-week bill was 4.95 percent.

headline: Where the Help Desk Goes for Good Advice
abstract: Locker Gnome, Web site offering technical advice and information to Microsoft Windows users, evaluated (S)

headline: China Tests a Missile And Berates the U.S.
abstract: China said it successfully test-launched a new type of long-range missile, and then it excoriated the United States for selling military equipment to Taiwan in the middle of a major diplomatic crisis.    Military experts said it was probably the Dong Feng-31 missile, which can carry a single 1,500-pound nuclear warhead in a range of about 5,000 miles, capable of reaching the United States, and which relies on mobility to evade attack.

headline: A Potentially Costly Lawsuit
abstract: Fight over legal fees could result in losses to Navellier Aggressive Small Cap Equity fund as well as reinstated fund manager Louis Navellier; Federal jury in San Francisco has ruled in favor of directors claiming that Navellier wasted funds and breached fiduciary duty; two directors are expected to seek reinbursement of legal fees that could total several million dollars; photo (S)

headline: Vanguard Founder Declines An Offer to Stay as Director
abstract: Vanguard Group's board of directors votes to allow founder John C Bogle to remain a director past mandatory retirement age of 70; Bogle says he will step down at end of year to run new center, financed by Vanguard, to analyze financial markets; board's move linked to backlash from investors who felt Bogle was being treated shabbily (M)

headline: Is Wall St. Too Narrow For a New Winnebago?
abstract: Article on renewed investor interest in Winnebago Industries, maker of motor homes; ownership is expected to grow to 1.6 million in 2000 and 1.7 million by 2005; photo (M)

headline: Recrimination and Rescue in Turkey; Toll Hits 4,000 -- Shoddy Housing Vulnerable
abstract: Over 1,000 relief workers from 19 countries join search for victims of earthquake in Turkey as survivors raise outcry over shoddy construction practices and lax government regulations; officials say at least 4,053 people have died and over 16,000 were seriously injured; rescue teams are unable to reach some areas because roads are impassable and communications disrupted; Public Works and Housing Min Koray Aydin tells Parliament that earthquake affected area where 45 percent of Turkish population lives; map; photos (M)

headline: Gene Federico, 81, Graphic Designer, Dies
abstract: Gene Federico, graphic designer and advertising executive, dies at age 81; his photo; photo of one of his most memorable designs (M)

headline: Albright Addresses New Warning To Indonesia
abstract: Secretary of State Madeleine K Albright meets with Jose Alexandre Gusmao, man expected to lead an independent East Timor, and warns Indonesia that it risks losing American aid and investment unless it protects refugees in areas it controls; Albright's warning is strongest yet by Washington, which has been reluctant to threaten sanctions against world's fourth most populous country; it is also first time Washington has made clear that it would hold Jakarta accountable for behavior beyond border of East Timor; Albright voices concern for 100,000 to 200,000 refugees forced into West Timor during siege of violence by militias backed by Indonesian military; they are reportedly being threatened and attacked by militia members who fled there as peacekeepers arrived in East Timor (M)

headline: New Form Allows for 401(K) Cost Checks
abstract: Small-business owners can compare costs of 401(k) plans offered by mutual fund, insurance and banking firms using new form developed by three industries in cooperation with Labor Department; 10-page form, which is available on Internet, grew out of Labor Department hearings into hidden and excessive fees charged to 401(k) plans and similar retirement savings programs; Labor Sec Alexis M Herman praises move (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent account changes noted (S)

headline: Toward Better Communication Across the Language Barrier
abstract: Scientists create speech-synthesizer technology that translates spoken words from one language into another, even when speaker and listener are on opposite sides of earth; photo (M)

headline: Thailand Acts Anew to Sell One of Its Troubled Banks
abstract: Thailand Acts Anew to

headline: UGI Is Planning to Repurchase Some Shares
abstract: The UGI Corp to buy back up to 4.5 million shares, 14.2 percent of its shares outstanding, in so-called Dutch auction; drops plan to sell its utility businesses (S)

headline: New Ways to Play MP3 Music, Without Plugs or Speakers
abstract: Ultraportable, chip-based music players, called MP3 players, download music from computer and store it on RAM chip, which plays it back through headphones; growing number of consumer electronics companies are coming out with their own models; players from Sensory Science, I-Jam Multimedia, Rioport and Creative Labs described; photos (M)

headline: More Stock Sales At Waste Hauler
abstract: Executives of Waste Management Inc sold $19.5 million in company shares in June in second round of stock sales by insiders in two months before company issued July 6 profit warning (S)

headline: Shares Fall on Revived Fear Of an Interest Rate Increase
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 176.04 points, or 1.6 percent, to 10,914.13; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 24.25 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,324.02; Nasdaq composite index drops 46.21 points, or 1.7 percent, to 2,712.69; graph; chart (M)

headline: Settlement In Legal Battle
abstract: Legal battle between Michael E Kassan who had been North American president and chief operating officer at Western Initiative Media Worldwide, and Western parent, Interpublic Group of Companies, has been settled; terms undisclosed; Kassan filed lawsuit and arbitration action against Interpublic, asking for $63.5 million for breach of contract and defamation of character (S)

headline: America Online Unit to Reduce Subscription Costs in Britain
abstract: America Online, hoping to stem its market slide in Great Britain, says it will lower monthly cost of subscribing to its service in Britain; AOL's new charges will make it more competitive with Freeserve PLC, British market leader, which requires only cost of local phone call to connect to Internet; move surprises some analysts because AOL UK introduced Netscape Online, subscription-free service similar to Freeserve, with considerable fanfare only a month ago; Freeserve says it will offer 10 free hours of off-peak hours if users place certain total of calls with its partner, Energis PLC (M)

headline: A Century of Pickin' and Riffs on CD-ROM
abstract: Ben Ratliff appraises new CD-ROM, Dick Hyman's Century of Jazz Piano; photos (M)

headline: WESTERN WIRELESS PURCHASES THREE NEW LICENSES
abstract: Western Wireless Corp agrees to pay $195 million for wireless telephone licenses in Texas, Arkansas and Utah; is buying licenses from KO Communications Inc, Netwireless LLC and American Rural Cellular Inc (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The Dwindling Market in U.S. Treasury Bonds
abstract: Market Place column on changing financial landscape in which Treasury securities, mainstay of professional hedging strategies, influence on consumer and corporate borrowing costs and safe haven for investors, will become increasingly scarce; sees shift, spurred by Federal debt cuts, as profoundly important; shrinking supply of bonds will likely cause prices to rise, cutting yields; may spur investors to seek riskier investments (M)

headline: Business Travel; Alaska Airlines plans to offer a system that allows passengers to check in on the Internet.
abstract: Alaska Airlines is using Internet in attempt to revolutionize checking in at airports, process that is often arduous; carrier is testing new on-line check-in system, first developed by a US airline; it expects to offer system in early October to travelers who have bought electronic tickets on its Web site and are flying on its domestic routes; Swissotel Washington, in Watergate complex, has undergone $13 million renovation; hotel is owned Blackstone Real Estate Advisors, part of Blackstone Group; Reliance Building in Chicago has been converted into 122-room hotel named the Burnham, after Daniel Burnham, building's original architect; hotel is owned by Canal Street Hotel LLC and is managed by Kimpton Hotel and Restaurant Group; Hilton Hotels has opened new 600-room, $100 million hotel at Logan International Airport in Boston; Returnme.com, new on-line service, helps travelers find items lost in transit; American Express predicts respite next year from recent major increases in business travel costs; projects these expenses will rise only 2 to 3 percent over all (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: Stakes in 2 Dairies Sold
abstract: Nash Finch Co sells its majority stake in Gillette Dairy of

headline: Russia Troops Are in New Battle With Separatists in the Caucasus
abstract: Russian forces are engaged in battle with Islamic separatists in Caucasus region, where Wahhabite militants have occupied several villages along border with breakaway republic of Chechnya; Prime Min Sergei V Stepashin arrives in Dagestan, joining top military and Interior Ministry commanders; Wahhabis want to copy rule of Islamic law, called sharia, already in place in Chechnya, and local officials view their campaign as an attempt to overthrow lawful authority; Wahhabi militants reportedly have back of Chechen field commanders, some of whom are members of Shura, a council of radical Muslim leaders established in Chechnya, or Ichkeria, as the self-proclaimed independent republic calls itself (M)

headline: F.A.A. Says Boeing Failed to Disclose Problem
abstract: Federal Aviation Administration says that Boeing Co had known for more than a year about safety valve defect in fuel valves of its 757 jets, but failed to tell regulators; agency proposes penalty of $392,000; FAA routinely proposes penalties against airlines but has seldom cited Boeing (S)

headline: Rebels Can't Conquer the Hearts of the Congolese
abstract: Rebels seeking to overthrow Pres Laurent Kabila of Congo have been unpopular with populace, even as they conquered nearly half of country; rebels are linked too closely with Rwanda, which provides them with troops and arms but is despised by many ordinary Congolese; Pres Kabila is unpopular, but his stature in capital of Kinshasa, in west of country, soars when compared with rebels who rule east; Congolese anger is aimed at fact that two rebellions in Congo, in 1996 and 1998, began in part after Rwandan soldiers crossed into Congo to chase Hutu miltants; photo; map (M)

headline: A Better Road For Whistle-Blowers
abstract: Carleton University Prof Stephen Maguire letter disputes Jeffrey L Seglin's September 19 article on corporate whistle-blowers (M)

headline: DAEWOO IN TALKS TO SELL UNIT
abstract: South Korean brokerage firm Daewoo Securities says it is negotiating sale of 80 percent stake in its unlisted affiliate Daewoo Capital Management Co, to Scudder Kemper Investments of US (S)

headline: KOREAN BEVERAGE MAKER SOLD
abstract: Hong Kong-based investment firm Clarion Capital has agreed to buy one of South Korea's best-known makers of soft drinks for $255 million; main creditor bank, Cho Hung Bank, says Clarion Capital and Haitai Beverage Co will sign deal, ending 21-month-long bid by bankrupt Haitai Group to sell its beverage unit (S)

headline: Beanie Move Giving Rise To Skepticism
abstract: Ty Inc's announcement that it will 'retire' all Beanie Babies at end of year is giving rise to skepticism; many consumers are furious at being manipulated by Ty Inc for what is probably publicity stunt to ratchet through-the-roof prices for the toys even higher; spokeswoman for McDonald's Corp says it will continue to offer Teenie Beanies again next year as part of its Happy Meals promotion; Ty Inc last month filed trademark registration requests for several new Beanie-related names with Patent Trademark Office of Commerce Department; one is for Bean E Bears, and toy industry experts say that it is likely that all hype about Ty's intentions might come down to slight name change for new versions of what are essentially same toys; photo (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

headline: Orange County's Lawyers Ask Huge Bonus
abstract: Hennigan, Mercer & Bennett, law firm that battled Merrill Lynch & Co and other securities firms on behalf of Orange County, Calif, is preparing to go to court against county itself, demanding nearly $50 million in extra payments for its work in wake of county's bankruptcy in late 1994; firm is seeking bonus of $48.7 million on top of $26.3 million it has earned in hourly fees; law partner J Michael Hennigan says firm deserves bonus because it recovered $865 million for county and its municipalities from suits against nearly 20 securities companies, as well as some law and accounting firms (S)

headline: LADY LUCK GAMING TO ADD LAS VEGAS CASINO AND HOTEL
abstract: Lady Luck Gaming Corp plans to buy Lady Luck Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, Nev, and right to use trademark from Andrew H Tompkins, chairman of Lady Luck Gaming, for $45.5 million (S)

headline: Big Increase in Retail Sales Pushes Treasury Yields Up
abstract: Yields of Treasury securities move sharply higher; price of 30-year bond drops 13/32, to 86 12/32, while yield rises to 6.27 percent from 6.21 percent; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: He Just Keeps On Drilling
abstract: John R Stanley, whose third oil-related company, Trans Texas Gas Corp, filed for bankruptcy protection, his third in 20 years, lines up creditors for reorganization but loses control of natural gas refinery in Norco, La; photo (S)

headline: Chip Set Is Introduced That Might Cut Cell Phone Costs
abstract: Analog Devices Inc plans to introduce new chip product that it says will reduce cost of radio part of cellular phones, while increasing battery life; chip set, tiny assembly of components, allows for 1,000 hours of standby time for cell telephones and allow users to leave phone switched on for month and half between charges (M)

headline: As Media Suits Flourish, Malaysia Judges a Journalist
abstract: KUALA LUMPUR—  Malaysia's Court of Appeal will decide soon whether to uphold a three-month prison term for a Canadian journalist for contempt of court.

headline: BCE UNIT IN $160 MILLION DEAL FOR 2 CANADIAN COMPANIES
abstract: BCE Emergis Inc acquires SNS/Assure Corp and Assure Health Inc for $235 million (Canadian), or $160 million (US) (S)

headline: Covering More Partners
abstract: Human Rights Campaign figures reportedly show that 2,856 employers now offer health insurance to their employees' same-sex domestic partners (S)

headline: Analog's Success Stories
abstract: Article on staying power of analog chips, which even high-powere digital equipment relies on for drive power; result is that analog market is booming as digital market moves forward; photo; graphs (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: AFRICA    NIGERIA: SPEAKER QUITS IN SCANDAL -- The Speaker of Nigeria's House of Representatives, the fourth highest ranking member of the country's new Government, resigned amid reports that he had lied about his age and educational background. The Speaker, Salisu Buhari, at first denied a magazine article that said he was only 29 years old, not 30, as required by law, and had refused to step down.   Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)    CONGO: 14,000 FLEE FIGHTING -- An estimated 14,000 Congolese fleeing continued fighting in northern Congo have arrived in the Central African Republic in recent weeks, according to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. The flight has continued despite a cease-fire agreement that was signed by the countries involved in the war, but not by the two main rebel movements.   Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

headline: Working at Humor
abstract: Letter from Kenn Fong says July 15 article on E-mail jokes neglected to mention worst aspect of phenomenon, spam

headline: For Swiss, Some Soul Searching After Losing a Bid for Olympics
abstract: Decision to award 2006 Winter Olympics to Turin, Italy, infuriates the Swiss, who were counting on Sion to get the honors; Swiss link loss of Games to the fact that it was a Swiss member of International Olympic Committee who blew the whistle on widespread corrupt practices within Olympic movement (M)`

headline: How Bigger Didn't Turn Out to Be Better in Insurance Scheme
abstract: Probers say Martin R Frankel, who allegedly milked assets of Southern insurance companies he controlled for nearly seven years, went on global expansion quest early last year in hopes of masking thefts; say he drew scores of new people into his dealings; note expansion kindled regulators' suspicions; cite his recent ties to stock fraud veteran Thomas F Quinn and detective Antonio Greco; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Regulators in Once-Obscure Corners of Wall St.
abstract: Market Place column on recent actions by state and national securities regulators that warned brokerage firm executives that they have to take more responsibility for protecting individual investors; holds brokerage firms that may have looked other way as investors were hurt either by fraudulent practices or by risky trading strategies are being put on notice that such practices will no longer be tolerated; specific cases cited (M)

headline: Sidelined for Days, Turkey's Army Joins Rescue
abstract: Turkish army finally joins in earthquake rescue and cleanup effort after days on sidelines and bitter complaints from victims; photo; map; death roll rises past 12,000; soldiers begin picking up rotting garbage in several devastated towns and deputy prime minister is assigned to lead effort to put out blaze that has consumed Turkey's largest oil refinery (M)

headline: Some Expatriate Benefits May Survive Dead Tax Bill
abstract: WASHINGTON—  The Republican tax package that President Bill Clinton is expected to veto this week never had much of a future.

headline: Julius R. Lunsford, 84, Trademark Law Expert
abstract: Julius R Lunsford Jr, trademark lawyer, dies at age 84; photo (M)

headline: European Commission Clears Exxon-Mobil Merger
abstract: European Commission gives approval to Exxon Corp's planned takeover of Mobil Corp, which would create world's largest publicly held oil company, on condition that they shed assets in Europe to preserve competition; commission says companies, which still need approval of US Federal Trade Commission, have agreed to requirements; key among conditions is that Mobil divest itself of its 30 percent interest in joint venture with BP Amoco to refine and market gasoline and other products in Europe (M)

headline: Women's group is set to present its Good, Bad and Ugly Awards.
abstract: Advertising Women of New York to present its Good, Bad and Ugly Awards, meant to encourage improvement of how women are portrayed in advertising; some winning agencies noted; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude and gasoline futures soar on basis of refinery problems in Calif and cutbacks by producers; crude for August delivery gains 46 a barrel, to $20.62, in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: The Hats of Summer
abstract: A co-worker goes on vacation, and you're asked to assume her duties, often in addition to your own. You have no idea how to do her work - but, hey, you're a team player, right? It can be an opportunity to prove yourself, or a very short, very unwelcome course in skills you never thought you would need. Or it can be a total disaster. In a depopulated workplace, what have been your greatest adventures and misadventures? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: Ex-Premier Andreotti Acquitted of Mafia Murder Conspiracy
abstract: Giulio Andreotti, seven-time Italian Prime Minister, is acquitted of conspiring with Mafia in 1979 murder of Carmine Pecorelli, a muckracking journalist, and also of killing him; so are four other co-defendants, some of whom have been convicted of mob-related crimes in other cases; verdict revives soul-searching about country's judicial system and prosecutors' reliance on testimony of turncoat informants (M)

headline: For Serb Draftee in Kosovo, A Close-Up of Deadly Purges
abstract: Interview with Serbian draftee who describes his role as Yugoslav Army unit commander in Kosovo; he says troops held ground while police and paramilitaries carried out ethnic cleansing; describes watching friends crack up, die or turn into avid looters and killers; map; photo (M)

headline: Travel Agents Express Anger On Internet-Only Plane Fares
abstract: Travel agents react with anger and disappointment to latest airline offers of additional discounts on tickets booked over carriers' World Wide Web sites; hold Internet-only fares are effort to put them out of business; industry defend cost-cutting move (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Heady Aroma of Recovery; An Ancient Trade Propels Indonesia's Economy Ahead
abstract: Agriculture, in particular the spice trade, is pointing toward stability and hope for the future of Indonesia; has proved the bulwark of nation's economy, sheltering rural communities from recession; while agriculture alone will not be enough to pull Indonesia out of recession, it accounts for 40 percent of Indonesia's jobs, and sector's health has been crucial in containing the spread of poverty; history of Indonesia's spice trade; photos; chart (M)

headline: Hundreds Die When 2 Trains Crash Head On in North India
abstract: Two crowded trains collide head on near Gaisal, India, killing at least 210 people, many of them soldiers; initial investigation points to signal failure as cause; recent analysis of 37,000-mile rail network, on which accidents are epidemic, attributes 70 percent of mishaps to human error and 11 percent to failing equipment; photo; map (M)

headline: Internet Showing its Value In Remote Alaskan Villages
abstract: Internet is reaching even most remote coastal villages of Alaska, state with population that is unusually sophisticated when it comes to Net; Alaska has relatively young residents, and 73 percent of them have computers, compared with 40 percent of households in lower 48 states; in remote regions of Alaska, Internet provides help for doctors and schooling for children; photos (M)
