headline: Rubin Is Planning to Return to Wall Street
abstract: Former Tre

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar falls against yen after stronger-than-expected Japanese report on machine orders bolsters optimism about economic recovery; in New York, dollar settles at 114.81 yen, down from 115.20; graph; chart (S)

headline: You've Got Mail. You're Being Watched.
abstract: Jeffrey L Seglin The Right Thing column on company monitoring of its employees' e-mail; such monitoring is rarely continuous and is used far more often to investigate employee complaints about inappropriate messages than to check up on employees; drawing (M)

headline: Disney to Buy Biggest Stake In On-Line Toy Retailer
abstract: Walt Disney Co is expected to acquire majority stake in Toysmart.com; Disney officials indicate company will have 60 percent stake in Toysmart, but will not say how much it paid, citing regulatory restrictions in advance of planned sale of shares in Go Network; Toysmart.com's educational products will be promoted through Disney's Family.com site (M)

headline: Corporations Battling to Bar Use of E-Mail For Unions
abstract: Companies are fighting to keep their E-mail systems off limits to unions, which have found E-mail to be unusually effective organizing tool; some union officials are embolden by Pratt & Whitney's accord to allow some limited use of its system by union organizers and by Government's decision to side with employees Pratt & Whitney suspended for using system; others remain wary; photos (M)

headline: How Korean Pride Rallied To Save a Software Maker
abstract: Article details role of South Koreans in helping Hangul and Computer Co return to profitability and rebuff takeover effort by Microsoft; photo; graph (M)

headline: GOLD BANC IN STOCK DEAL FOR AMERICAN BANCSHARES
abstract: Gold Banc Corp to buy American Bancshares Inc for $91.4 million in stock (S)

headline: Daewoo Sells Switching-Equipment Division
abstract: Daewoo Group sells its Daewoo Telecom Co for $345 million (US) to Laves Investment Inc (S)

headline: PRISON TERM IN COPPER SCANDAL
abstract: Juan Pablo Davila, former chief trader at Chilean miner Codelco, is sentenced to eight years in prison for fraud in trading scandal that cost company, which is world's largest copper producer, $218 million; is also fined more than $200 million for charges that include falsifying documents and breach of fiduciary duties to Codelco; charges are tied to millions of dollars in kickbacks from brokers who handled Davila's bets on copper market as he racked up losses in 1993 and 1994 (S)

headline: Investment in Webhire
abstract: Webhire Inc says Softbank Capital Partners LP, Internet investment arm of Japan's Softbank Corp, has agreed to invest $20 million in it and buy 1.67 million Wehire shares from Amazon.com; investments--total of about $31 million--will give Softbank a 40 percent interest in Webhire (S)

headline: LUCENT TO BUY SPECTRAN FOR $64 MILLION
abstract: Lucent Technologies Inc agrees to buy Spectran Corp, maker of fiber optics products, for $64 million; will also assume $35 million in debt (S)

headline: Victoria Journal; In Canada's 'Lotusland,' Unhappy Is Premier's Lot
abstract: Dan Miller is sworn in as new Premier of British Columbia; Glen Clark, his predecessor, resigned on Aug 21; he is province's third Premier in row to quit under cloud of scandal; it has been 20 years since voters elected Premier who served out his term; Miller vows to step down as soon as his party, New Democrats, chooses successor; map; photos (M)

headline: Treasury Auction Limited to Bills
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.76 percent and that on the six-month bill was 4.92 percent.

headline: Avant Wins Ruling in Cadence Copyright Suit
abstract: Federal court rules in favor of Avant Corp, Sunnyvale, Calif, regarding certain claims in trade secrets suit brought against the company by Cadence Design Systems Inc, San Jose; Cadence sued Avant in 1995, accusing it of stealing Cadence's software code and other improprieties in connection with its computer-design software; decision on issue detailed; remainder of suit is scheduled for trial on Oct 12 (M)

headline: Seven Are Cited In Honors List
abstract: American Advertising Federation will induct seven people into its Hall of Achievement, which honors executives 40 and younger; executives are Gilbert Davila, Christy Haubegger, Philippe Krakowsky, William McKendry, Kevin O'Connor, Matthew Ross and Ian Rowden (S)

headline: Computerized Machine Steps In To Shuffle Cards by the Ton
abstract: Duplimate, computerized card-shuffling machine developed by Per Jannersten, proves invaluable at bridge tournaments (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Coffee falls as forecasts for mild weather in Brazil, world's biggest grower, eases concern that frost will reduce output next year; in New York, coffee for September delivery falls 4.6 cents, to 92.7 cents a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Media Talk; More Older People Telling Press to Ease Up
abstract: Pew Research Center poll finds that distaste for press scrutiny into politicians' backgrounds has grown among people 50 and older and among those 30 to 49 by at least 10 percentage points since 1987; under-30 group is also growing more disenchanted with such reporting, but not as rapidly; some 53 percent of all adults consider press scrutiny valuable, compared with 59 percent in 1987 (S)

headline: Dow Falls, Led by Banks, on Fears About Latin Markets
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 25.96 points, to 11,175.02; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 5.54 points, to 1,393.56, and Nasdaq composite index declines 12.21 points, to 2,778.23; price of 30-year Treasury bond falls 1/32, to 90 29/32; yield is unchanged at 5.90 percent; graph on fluctuations in Dow Jones industrial average; charts on stocks with large price percentage gains and losses and US key interest rates (M)

headline: Spain's Telefonica and IDT Seen in Deal
abstract: Telefonica SA of Spain agrees to form wide-ranging joint venture with IDT Corp to market telephone and Internet service to Spanish speakers in US and Latin America; Telefonica is facing challenges on Web from Starmedia Network Inc and Quepasa.com Inc, both of which are developing Spanish-language Web services; IDT intends to invest about $10 million in venture initially; IDT also agrees to acquire 10 percent of project begun by Telefonica to lay underwater fiber optic communications cable around Latin America; cable, which will include connections from Chile to US, is meant to be completed in few years at cost of about $1.5 billion; also agrees to buy at least $100 million worth of communications services from overall undersea cable venture over five years; while Telefonica's deal with IDT could expand its presence in US, it is bound to raise questions about Telefonica's relationship with MCI Worldcom Inc, which has had strategic partnership; it is unclear how Telefonica intends to reconcile that partnership with forming venture with IDT partly to win customers in US (M)

headline: A Subtle Shift to a Bolder Plumage : Color Is Back as Men Rediscover Their 'Inner Peacock'
abstract: WASHINGTON—  On an unremarkable day in a Washington office, a rather remarkable scene took place. Three gentlemen without any connection to the garment industry had a conversation about their shirts. All of them were dressed in rich, sapphire blue shirts. They were wearing elegant geometric-print silk ties. And they were chuckling about the coincidence of their all wearing these shirts on the same day. Each was trying to guess where the other had purchased his shirt. And they were noting how they liked the look of this deep color in contrast to the standard white business shirt.

headline: Justice Department Approves Merger of Allied Waste and Browning-Ferris
abstract: Justice Department gives its approval to one of largest mergers in trash hauling business on condition that combining companies, Allied Waste Industries and Browning-Ferris Industries, sell operations in 18 metropolitan areas in 13 states; merger will create trash hauling giant with revenue of about $6.4 billion (M)

headline: Japanese Regulators Consider Penalties for Credit Suisse
abstract: Japanese regulators meet to consider possible sanctions against Credit Suisse Group for obstructing six-month investigation into its financial activities in Japan; Credit Suisse could lose at least one of its licenses to do business in Japan; regulators are outraged by efforts of Michael Winning, executive in charge of handling legal matters at Credit Suisse in Tokyo, and other executives based there to hide firm's activities by shredding some documents and shipping others out of country; authorities began scrutinizing Credit Suisse's actions when Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan and Nippon Credit Bank were nationalized by Government last year; both banks were Credit Suisse clients, and their employees helped investigators understand how bank had hidden their losses using Credit Suisse products and services (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Should Clinton embrace the China trade deal? Some say yes.
abstract: Economic Scene column on bold trade deal that China offered United States in April and Pres Clinton rejected in what many deem serious foreign policy blunder; notes that Daniel H Rosen and colleagues at Institute for International Economics have analyzed arguments for rejecting offer and found them to be weak, misleading or misguided; notes Clinton can reverse course when he meets Pres Jiang Zemin this week in Australia; drawing (M)

headline: ESKIMO PIE SHAREHOLDERS APPROVE LIQUIDATION
abstract: Eskimo Pie Corp will sell its licenses and plants under liquidation plan from its largest shareholder and suitor, Yogen Fruz World-Wide Inc (S)

headline: A Founder of a Year 2000 Service Quits to Try a Different Approach
abstract: Paloma O'Riley resigns as research director of Cassandra Project, an Internet-based clearinghouse for effort to organize neighborhoods and communities for potential Year 2000 computer threats, saying people are losing interest in such efforts; her new focus will be pressing public officials to prepare more aggressively for possible disasters; photos (M)

headline: DAEWOO APPEALS TO CREDITORS
abstract: South Korea's Daewoo Group asks foreign creditors to promise to roll over loans maturing in 1999 and not call in loans, totaling about $6 billion, before their due dates (S)

headline: Net Stocks Rebound; Nasdaq Rises
abstract: Internet stocks rebound, lifting the Nasdaq composite index for the first time in six sessions; Dow Jones industrial average gains 119.05, to close at 10,793.82; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 8.38 to 1,313.71; Nasdaq gains 25.83 to 2,565.81; graph; chart on performance of some specific stocks (M)

headline: Jet Order for Bombardier
abstract: Bombardier Inc sells 20 of its 50-passenger Canadair regional jet aircraft to Atlantic Coast Airlines for $430 million (S)

headline: NISSAN-RENAULT TIES
abstract: Japanese auto maker Nissan Motor weighs teaming up with French counterpart Renault SA to buy steel and other components to cut costs; shares of both companies soar; graph of Renault stock price (S)

headline: INDONESIAN BANK RESTRUCTURING
abstract: Bank Niaga shareholders approve 8.85 trillion rupiah ($1.3 billion) rights issue that is likely to give Indonesian Government 99 percent stake in insolvent bank (S)

headline: Where Rebates Come True
abstract: Letter by Nelson Marans, responding to Sept 16 article on trouble with computer rebates, says buyers of computers and electronic equipment are encountering same problems that consumers have been exposed to since mailed-in rebates came into fashion; says his past experience with rebates makes him prefer that any refund be done up front at time of purchase .

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Big Gain in Labor Costs Raises Fear of Higher Rates  The Labor Department reported that the so-called employment cost index rose 1.1 percent from the first to the second quarter of the year, its biggest increase in eight years. The unexpected gain overshadowed a separate Government report that showed the robust American economy took a breather in the spring.

headline: Mexico City Journal; The Billboard War: Were Lingerie Ads Selling Sex?
abstract: Mexican television exec Anna Fusoni Ponthier's campaign against Vicky Form lingerie company's billboards has grown into Mexico's latest battle over sexuality and women's rights; she says that company's advertisements are sexist and degrading; photo (M)

headline: Milken-Supported Libel Suit Against a Writer Is Dismissed
abstract: New York State Supreme Court Justice Barry A Cozier dismisses $35 million libel lawsuit against author James B Stewart that had been pursued for seven years and had been subsidized in part by Lowell Milken, brother of fallen junk bond investment banker Michael R Milken; lawsuit centered on one paragraph in Stewart's book Den of Thieves, which explored Wall Street's insider trading scandals of 1980's and roles of Milken brothers; plaintiff, Michael F Armstrong, criminal defense lawyer who represented Lowell Milken, filed suit in 1992 against Stewart, his research assistant and his publisher, Simon & Schuster; Armstrong argued that book wrongly accused him of preparing false affidavit for witness to sign to exonerate Lowell Milken on charges of violating security laws; Milken was not party to lawsuit, but in unique arrangement he and his wife set up general partnership to lend Armstrong and his law firm up to $1.6 million for legal expenses, with understanding that loan would not have to be repaid if lawsuit failed (M)

headline: Russia Ousts U.S. Officer As Ties Sour Over Kosovo
abstract: Russia orders Lieut Col Peter Hoffman, assistant Army attache at US Embassy in Moscow, to leave the country in a fresh sign of tensions that have grown between US and Russia since war in Kosovo (M)

headline: Ambassador Nominations Seen as 'Demolition Derby'
abstract: Long-drawn-out approval of Richard C Holbrooke as chief American delegate to UN focuses fresh attention on process of picking ambassadors that is increasingly mired in bureaucratic delays and political infighting; Administration and Congressional officials as well as outside experts say delays of a year or more that often attend filling of important diplomatic posts are threatening to drive away some of nation's most talented diplomats; process has come to pit career diplomats against political donors for posts abroad, and it is one that holds nominees hostage to Senate in exchange for demands on White House that often have nothing to do with qualifications of envoys themselves (M)

headline: NUCOR TO SPEND CASH ON ACQUISITIONS OR SHARE BUYBACKS
abstract: Nucor Corp plans to use cash of about $600 million to make acquisitions or repurchase of stock to increase shareholder value (S)

headline: 2,900 JOBS IN JEOPARDY
abstract: Placer Dome Inc and Western Areas Ltd plan to dismiss up to 2,900 workers, 40 percent of work force, at their joint venture near Johannesburg because of lower gold prices (S)

headline: U.S. Freezes Assets Of Afghan Airline
abstract: US freezes assets of Ariana Afghan Airlines, calling it link in chain of support for Osama bin Laden, suspected terrorist leader living in Afghanistan (S)

headline: Spurning PC's, Sun Challenges Rival Microsoft
abstract: Sun Microsystems Inc is planning ambitious campaign to move everyday applications like word processing and spreadsheets away from personal computer desktop and onto World Wide Web--strategy that amounts to direct assault on Microsoft's biggest business; Sun to announce acquisition of Star Division GmbH, German producer of office productivity software, which moved its headquarters to California last year; its Star Office is bundle of programs in same application categories as Microsoft Corp's Office suite (M)

headline: Lawyer Says He Told of Fraud Case in '92
abstract: Lawyer Terry Davis told Securities and Exchange Commission regulators in 1992, who were working on fraud case against seemingly insignificant money manager, Martin R Frankel, that Frankel was lying to them; rather than being destitute, as Frankel was maintaining in his settlement talks with regulators, he secretly controlled millions of dollars, moved money into Swiss bank account and was using series of aliases as he made expensive purchases through dummy companies; SEC apparently did little to follow through on '92 fraud case, settling its case against Frankel and barring him from securities industry; Frankel is now at center of one of largest insurance fraud investigations in history; SEC spokesman refuses comment on what information was available about Frankel in early 1990's (M)

headline: The Future of Dreamcast
abstract: Robin Hardison letter on Sept 9 article notes new Dreamcast game console has multiplayer capabilities, but no network or modem-to-modem games are available for it yet

headline: Fund Expenses: They're Going Down, Down, Down; Conventional Wisdom Is Belied By the Numbers
abstract: Mutual fund average expense ratios are falling, trend that flies in face of conventional wisdom that expenses have been flat, or rising; trend reflects investor shift to index and other low-cost funds and emergence of more low-cost competitors; some analysts see fund companies under continuing pressure to cut fees; graphs of average expense ratios, expense ratios of largest fund managers and impact of lower fees; photo (Mutual Funds Report) (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas futures soar to eight-month high; graphs; in New York, gas for August delivery rises 13.3 cents, to $2.528 a million BTU's; chart (S)

headline: OAK FORECASTS PROFIT SHORTFALL, AND ITS STOCK DECLINES
abstract: Oak Industries says it expects third-quarter net income to fall short of analysts' estimates, setting off 32 percent decline in its stock price; shares fall $13.25, to $27.75 (S)

headline: Alan Clark, a British Scold, Is Dead at 71
abstract: Alan Clark, outrageously acerbic Conservative Member of Parliament, dies at age 91; photo (M)

headline: The Stock Auction, Take 3
abstract: Andover.net of Action Mass, which provides online tools, news and other services for Linux programmers and Web site designers, plans initial public stock option via W R Hambrecht & Co's Open IPO system (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    FRANCE: NEW BLOW TO CHIRAC -- The supreme court rejected an attempt by former Prime Minister Alain Juppe, left, to escape an investigation into corruption charges that have cast a shadow over Jacques Chirac's presidency. The court agreed that Mr. Juppe must be investigated on suspicion of being an accomplice in the misuse of funds when he served as a deputy to Mr. Chirac when Mr. Chirac was Mayor of Paris. The ruling came two days after the current Mayor, the fellow Gaullist Jean Tiberi, was ordered to be investigated for influence-peddling.   (Reuters)

headline: Rules Hurting Sales, Satellite Makers Say
abstract: Only months after tighter restrictions on satellite exports took effect, concern is growing within the aerospace industry and in Congress that the new rules are entangling manufacturers in red tape, delaying launches and hurting American satellite makers in foreign markets.

headline: GE CAPITAL JOINS CABLE GROUP
abstract: Deutsche Bank AG says GE Capital Services will join its consortium bidding for several regional German cable television networks; new partner, unit of General Electric Co, signs memorandum of understanding with DB Investor, bank's investment banking unit; consortium will bid for networks put up for sale by Deutsche Telekom AG (S)

headline: UNITED RENTALS, ON BUYING SPREE, ACQUIRES 17 COMPANIES
abstract: United Rentals Inc, pre-eminent US equipment-rental company, buys 17 companies with combined annual revenues of $150 million as its moves to dominate traffic-safety market (S)

headline: How to Play the Treasury Bond Buyback
abstract: Article describes new ways for investors to buy outstanding US Treasury bonds, which are in short supply; drawing; graph (M)

headline: Australia Faces Economic Fallout From Timor
abstract: SINGAPORE—  As troops from the Australian-led intervention force started landing in East Timor on Monday, executives and analysts warned of potentially heavy economic and commercial fallout in Australia.

headline: Conde's Latest Acquisition Has Fashion Industry Fidgeting
abstract: Fashion, advertising and magazine publishing industries are abuzz over Conde Nast plan to acquire Fairchild Publications, move that will give it control of most of American fashion press; photos (M)

headline: Was It the Met? No, 'Juice' Set MTV's Record
abstract: Annual MTV Video Music Awards show attracted 8.1 million viewers, making it most-watched entertainment program in history of cable television; audience was 37 percent bigger than it was last year; Judy McGrath, rpesident of MTV, says having Chris Rock as host and broadcasting from Metropolitan Opera House added to show's attraction this year (M)

headline: Soon to Bow Out, Argentine Brushes Off the Boos
abstract: The wild mutton-chop sideburns are gone. The televised cheek-to-cheek tangos with marquee entertainers  are a thing of the past. And when President Carlos Saul Menem does take the occasional spin in a hot sports car these days, his bodyguards no longer need to make death-defying weaves through traffic to chase after him.    At age 69 and in his final five months in office, Mr. Menem still makes good copy -- but now the press attention is focused on the presidential psyche. Argentine magazines, quoting anonymous sources, report that Mr. Menem is depressed, lonely and bitter because many of his closest allies, including his hand-picked Vice President, have abandoned him.

headline: Crowds Denounce Milosevic In Opposition Stronghold
abstract: About 10,000 people fill main square in Novi Sad, Yugoslavia's second-largest city, to demonstrate against Slobodan Milosevic; they cheer when local opposition politicians threaten to throw Milosevic out if he does not quickly resign as president; this is first large public gathering in Novi Sad since NATO bombs knocked out three bridges that were its economic arteries; angry crowd and politicians say little about bombings, blaming all their troubles on Milosevic; repair of vital bridges has become new theme separating Belgrade and opposition and western Governments that are offering help; Belgrade wants to control construction work and money for it; map (M)

headline: Japan Gives American-Led Group Right to Acquire Big Bank
abstract: Japanese Government, in landmark decision that gives foreigners go-ahead signal to take control of Japanese bank, grants group led by Ripplewood Holdings LLC, private investment firm in New York, right to acquire Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, former financial giant hobbled by bad loans (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro climbs after report shows German construction orders rose in May, suggesting European growth is reviving; in New York, euro settles at $1.0530, up from $1.0413; graph; chart (S)

headline: Guessing Who Is on Line
abstract: Turing Game is on-line multiplayer game whose goal is to separate posers from real thing; in the game, three or four people answer questions from each other, with some pretending to be what they are not; game's creator, Joshua Berman, says game seeks to examine identity and culture in on-line communities (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Sprint's Lesson in Foreign Entanglements
abstract: Sprint Corp's Global One venture with France Telecom and Deutsche Telekom of Germany is on rocks, riven by competing priorities, absence of coordination and unsurprising tension between German and French executives; telecommunications industry executives believed troubled partnership would be resolved or dissolved by now; reason proposed deal has run so long appears to be that Global One's fate has depended in large part on whether Sprint is acquired outright by Deutsche Telekom, which already owns 10 percent stake; Sprint conducted extensive discussions with Deutsche Telekom during summer about such acquisition, but those talks appear to have hit roadblock; executives close to companies say MCI Worldcom Inc has seriously considered bid for Sprint; Sprint may have backed away from Deutsche Telekom to assess MCI Worldcom's interest (Market Place column) (M)

headline: A Corporate Chess Game; Copper Industry Rivals in Nasty, Convoluted Negotiations
abstract: Acquistion of Asarco Inc and Cyprus Amax Minerals Co by Phelps Dodge has turned into 1980's-style corporate brawl among three companies and Grupo Mexico to emerge as dominant copper producer in industry; industry's bleak prospects proved to be catalyst that prompted Asarco's chief executive Francis McAllister to talk to Cyprus Amax chief Milton Ward in first place last May; copper prices have risen 33 percent since then, and Asarco and Cyprus Amax, instead of being left alone to merge with each other out of desperation, have, in effect, become much more valuable prizes on auction block; Asarco and Cyprus Amax have sought bid from Group Mexico, which has offered $1.03 billion in cash for Asarco, barely edging out Phelps Dodge's $1.01 billion stock and cash offer; graph; photos (M)

headline: The Ripple Effect of Rising U.S. Rates
abstract: Weekly stock market roundup focuses on possible global ramifications of rising US interest rates; graphs; charts (M)

headline: HARVARD INDUSTRIES AGREES TO SELL SEALANT SUBSIDIARY
abstract: Harvard Industries sells its sealant business, Kingston-Warren, to Hutchinson SA of France for $115 million (S)

headline: BENIGN INFLATION IN CANADA
abstract: Inflation rose at annualized rate of 2.1 percent in Canada in August, highest in two and a half years; core inflation rate rose unexpectedly low annualized rate of 1.6 percent, down from 1.7 perent in July (S)

headline: Remembering Their War, Germans Embrace the First Victims
abstract: Germany marks 60th anniversary of its invasion of Poland and start of World War II by declaring Poland should have place in European Union as soon as possible; Pres Johannes Rau visits Gdansk; most major German newspapers ignore anniversary; Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder's position, acknowledgment and awareness of past allied to determination to look beyond it, reflects that of large majority of Germans (M)

headline: Freetown Journal; Survivors Sadly Say, Yes, Reward the Tormentors
abstract: Residents of Freetown, Sierre Leone, who suffered unspeakable atrocities from anti-Govt rebels during eight years of brutal civil war, are angered by amnesty granted rebels under peace agreement signed in July, but say time has come to forgive and forget; rebels spread terror by cutting off civilians' hands and feet instead of killing them outright; human rights officials say atrocities were worst in recent years outside genocide in Rwanda; residents and foreigners alike say those who oppose amnesty overlook prime importance of stopping war and hard political reality that country remains mariginally significant at best to international community; maps; photo (M)

headline: Three Are Picked By Morningstar.com
abstract: Morningstar Inc awards its first assignments to handle advertising account of its recently revamped Morningstar.com World Wide Web site to Chicago offices of Rubin Postaer & Associates, Quantum Leap Communications and Western Initiative Media; total billings estimated at $20 million (S)

headline: U.S. Teams Seek Lessons in Turkey
abstract: Researchers from United States are going to Turkey to study geology of North Anatolian Fault, where Turkey's earthquake occurred, to see if there are any lessons relevant to San Andreas fault in California (M)

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for BILL WALKER; Responding To a Call Of Disaster
abstract: Bill Walker, vice president of Motorola Corp, answers five questions on possible adverse impact three of company's Taiwanese suppliers from recent Taiwan earthquake; photo (M)

headline: Technology Shares Lift Nasdaq, but Dow Falls 74 Points
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes at 10,524.07, loss of 74.40 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 2.93 points, or slightly more than two-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,310.51; Nasdaq composite index climbs 37.06 points, or 1.31 percent, to 2,858.16; graph; chart (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.00   8.00   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   5.13   5.12   5.63        3-month T-bills   4.61   4.58   4.94        6-month T-bills   4.64   4.63   4.99        10-yr. T-infl.   4.03   4.03   3.77        10-yr. T-note   5.90   5.87   5.49        30-yr. T-bond   6.10   6.07   5.71        Telephone bd.   7.84   7.81   7.18        Municipal bds.   5.59   5.58   5.26          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer

headline: The Price of Low Inflation
abstract: Louis Cohen letter responds to Sylvia Nasar's August 22 article on inflation holds employers and economists view 'efficient wages' differently than American families (S)

headline: In Japan, Mired in Recession, Suicides Soar
abstract: Japanese are committing suicide in record numbers, and experts say economic recession and shame and stress caused by layoffs or fear of them is to blame; total of 32,863 people committed suicide in 1998, both largest number and highest rate recorded since police began keeping records in 1947; compared with Western countries, suicide carries less of stigma in Japan, where it is regarded as honorable form of protest; rate of suicide in US in 1997 was 11.4 per 100,000 people, compared with 19.3 per 100,000 in Japan; graphs; photos (M)

headline: ANOTHER BOMBING KILLS 18 IN RUSSIA
abstract: Huge explosion tears apart apartment complex in Volgodonsk, in southern Russia, killing at least 18 people and leaving more than 200 wounded; fifth bombing in less than three weeks spreads threat of terrorism to Russia's heartland, and underscores how vulnerable Russia remains to terrorist attacks, even with heightened security; latest blast bears hallmarks of earlier detonations: target was apartment house for ordinary citizens, bomb went off as they were sleeping, and no one claimed responsibility; Russian police and intelligence officials insist there is evidence that confirms involvement of Chechen militants; they have detained 27 suspects; Pres Boris N Yeltsin says security forces will try to seal off separatist Chechnya; photo (M)

headline: Britain Awaits Rogue Trader With Interest In the Spoils
abstract: Nicholas W Leeson, the Rogue Trader who brought down Barings merchant bank in 1995, is set to fly back to Britain after almost four years in a Singapore jail for fraud and forgery; his assets are reportedly frozen, his future is unclear and his freedom flawed by reports that he bragged in prison about having stashed away millions from the days when he traded fast and loose in Singapore; photo (M)

headline: Aftershock Hits Turkish Cities Struck by Quake in August
abstract: At least seven people die and hundreds are injured in severe tremor in region of Turkey where more than 15,000 people died in huge earthquake on August 17; tremor was felt in Istanbul, Ankara and Izmir; maps; photo (M)

headline: Working at Humor
abstract: Letter from Steven A Ludsin says July 15 article on E-mail jokes is reminder that humor requires some originality
